headline: Greenspan Sees Calming Of Markets
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan says investors and lenders appear to be calming down after fright thrown into them by global financial turmoil, suggesting that central bank is less concerned than a few weeks ago that credit squeeze could derail the economy, speech delivered from Washington by video conference to meeting of Securities Industry Association; economists say Fed is still more likely than not to trim interest rates again in November; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: CHILD PROSTITUTE AS VICTIM -- The Government issued guidelines aimed at treating child prostitutes as victims of abuse rather than as criminals and at marking their employers and clients for prosecution. The latest annual figures, for 1995-1996, show that 177 youths under 17 were convicted of prostitution and another 207 were formally cautioned.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: BATONS VS. TRUNCHEONS -- The British police are being warned that the growing substitution of longer and heavier American-style batons for the 11-inch wooden truncheons traditionally carried by officers has resulted in an increased number of brutality complaints. The report from the independent Police Complaints Authority says British police forces should instruct their members in restrained use of the new weapons to reduce the possibility of serious injury.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: GTECH HOLDINGS IN BID FOR TRANSACTION NETWORK
abstract: Gtech Holdings Corp is seeking to acquire Transaction Network Services Inc (S)

headline: Finding Her Stage In the Costume Racks
abstract: Profile of career of Suzy Benzinger, costume designer for Broadway musical Miss Saigon; photo (M)

abstract: Euro Disney SA reports net income for fiscal year ended Sept 30 rose 34 percent to 290 million francs ($51.62 million), from 217 million francs year earlier (S)

abstract: Nigerian widow Virginia Anikwata says she and her American born, 11-year-old daughter face sexual abuses if they have to return to her homeland; asks to stay in US under new law that makes international convention against torture part of American law (M)

headline: C.I.A. Ignored Report of Payments To Chinese for Satellite Contracts
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency unearths and passes on to Justice Department a March 1996 cable in which agents in China warned headquarters that Bansang W Lee, a Chinese-American who has worked for Hughes Space Communications and for Loral Space and Communications, had made payments to Chinese officials in hopes of getting lucrative contracts; it is not clear whether cable specifies on whose behalf Lee would have been making any payments to Chinese officials; cable languished in CIA files until Congressional committees began examining whether Clinton Administration had compromised national security in its zeal to promote high technology exports to China; Hughes and Loral deny any wrongdoing (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    SWITZERLAND: BANANA CHARGES FLY  The great banana battle heated up again as the United States and the European Union went to the World Trade Organization in Geneva and accused each other of violating international law. European countries want to retain import preferences for bananas from former colonies in Africa. The United States, defending American distributors like Chiquita Brands, wants equal treatment for bananas from Central American and the Caribbean.   Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)    YUGOSLAVIA: ARMY CHIEF DISCHARGED  President Slobo- dan Milosevic has discharged the army chief, Gen. Momcilo Perisic, left, after reported disputes between the two officials. Recently General Perisic subtly criticized Mr. Milosevic's policy in Kosovo, the Serbian province where ethnic Albanians are fighting for independence, saying the conflict was partly a result of ''certain politicians' wish to stay in power.''   (AP)    RUSSIA: ACCORD ON NOTES FOR DEBT  Foreign creditors who represent holders of Russia's restructured Soviet-era debt agreed to let Russia pay $216 million of a $940 million payment due on Dec. 2 in cash, with the remainder covered by notes that promise to pay the interest later .The original agreement had called for half the $724 million to be paid in new notes and half in cash.   (Bloomberg News)    RUSSIA: CUSTOMS DISMISSALS IN FUNDS INQUIRY  The heads of four customs departments in Moscow were dismissed after an investigation into the flight of capital from Russia, officials said. Billions of dollars have been taken out of Russia, often illegally, with Russian companies' having hidden $2.5 billion abroad just in September, the officials said.   (AP)    ALBANIA: IN FAVOR OF NEW CONSTITUTION  With more than half the ballots counted from a referendum on Sunday, Albanians have apparently voted overwhelmingly in favor of enacting the first post-Communist Constitution, an election commission official said.   (Reuters)    LITHUANIA: RESIGNATION SHAKES GOVERNMENT  The Government, shaken by the resignation of Transport Minister Algis Zhvaliauskas, said it might seek a court ruling on whether it needed a fresh mandate from Parliament. Of the 18 ministers originally appointed to the Cabinet in 1996, seven remain. Mr. Zhvaliauskas resigned after having been accused of using a state airplane to return from a hunting trip in Sweden.   (Reuters)    MIDDLE EAST    LIBYA: 3 JAILED IN LOCKERBIE BOMBING  Three top intelligence officials have been tried and jailed in connection with the bombing of a Pan American World Airways jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, The Guardian and Al-Hayat newspapers reported in London. Libyan dissidents saw the arrests as a ploy by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to block the officials' testimony, should two other Libyan suspects stand trial before Scottish judges in the Netherlands under a plan that the United Nations Security Council approved.   (AP)    AFRICA    CONGO: KABILA TO ALLOW POLITICAL PARTIES  Political parties will be allowed in two months, President Laurent Kabila said on a visit to Brussels. Mr. Kabila announced a two-year transition to democracy shortly after coming to power. But his Government has been criticized for abuses of human rights and an apparent lack of resolve to institute democracy.   (Agence France-Presse)    THE AMERICAS    MEXICO: SEARCH FOR 500 CORRUPT OFFICERS  Two days after the arrests of nearly 100 police officers in Mexico City and neighboring states on felony charges, authorities have identified at least 500 additional officers wanted for crimes like police brutality and homicide. The Interior Ministry said it would ask the 31 states' attorneys general to arrest the officers, many of whom have been fugitives for years.   Sam Dillon (NYT)    CHILE: INTEREST LOWERED TO 8.5%  In another attempt to jump-start a slowing economy the Central Bank lowered annual interest rates, from 10 to 8.5 percent. It was the fourth rate decrease in two months.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)    ARGENTINA: EX-RULER HELD IN KIDNAPPINGS  A former military ruler, Emilio Massera, has been arrested in connection with the kidnappings of two infants born to political dissidents imprisoned by the previous military dictatorship, BBC News reported. It cited an estimate that from 200 to 400 babies were taken from their detained mothers and given to military and police couples in the 1970's and 80's.    ASIA    JAPAN: JIANG STARTS 5-DAY VISIT  President Jiang Zemin of China, left, arrived for a five-day visit that is expected to touch on issues like relations with Taiwan and memories of World War II. Mr. Jiang, the first Chinese head of state to visit Japan, met Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi for an unofficial dinner. The leaders plan to issue a communique calling for warmer ties between China and Japan.   Nicholas D. Kristof (NYT)    CHINA: TRIAL OF COMPUTER SPECIALIST DELAYED  The trial of a computer software specialist accused of inciting subversion by providing e-mail addresses to a dissident publication, has been postponed. Authorities gave no reason for delaying the trial of the defendant, Lin Hai, had been scheduled to begin on Friday in Shanghai.   Erik Eckholm (NYT)    AFGHANISTAN: LAST IRANIANS FREED  The last of dozens of Iranian prisoners held by the Taliban militia has been freed, Iranian radio reported. The release may ease tensions, but the Taliban are still resisting Iran's demands that those responsible for killing Iranian diplomats in August be punished.   Douglas Jehl (NYT)     Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

headline: Language Lessons, Object Lessons
abstract: User's Guide on language courses offered online (M)

headline: Hershey to Sell Pasta Business And Focus on Sweeter Profit
abstract: The Hershey Foods Corporation is shopping for a buyer for its pasta business, saying it wants to stick to making chocolate and candy.    Although Hershey has the leading share of the United States dry pasta business, the company said its resources would be best used making and selling sweets, such as Hershey's Kisses and Reese's peanut butter cups.

headline: Congressman Fears Famine Is Decimating North Koreans
abstract: Interview with Democratic US Repr Tony P Hall, who visited remote parts of North Korea and says famine of last two years may be decimating population (M)

headline: In Its Case Against Microsoft, U.S. Now Cites Note From Apple
abstract: Justice Department introduces host of new evidence to strengthen its antitrust case against Microsoft Corp, including note written by Fred D Anderson Jr, Apple Computer's chief financial officer, describing what Government portrays as strong-arm tactics Microsoft successfully employed to force Apple to ship Microsoft's Internet Explorer with Macintosh computers; new evidence comes as lead Government lawyer, David Boies, gets to question his own witness, Netscape Communications president, James L Barksdale, who completes his fifth day of testimony (M)

headline: 4 Brazilian Officials Resign As Bid-Rigging Scandal Erupts
abstract: Four senior Brazilian Govt officials resign, scalded by accusations that two may have tried to influence bidding on giant telephone system; include Communications Min Luis Carlos Mendonca de Barros, brother Foreign Trade Sec Jose Roberto and Andra Lara Resende, president of Govt's National Bank of Economic and Social Development (S)

headline: Wedding Blues
abstract: Letter by Jeffrey F Friedman questions whether weekly Circuts section caters to an illiterate subset of Times readers by virtue of type of software (CD-ROM) it reviews

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Talks Between Oil Giants Reflect Global Realities  The talks between Exxon and Mobil on a possible combination show how global competition and advancing technology have made what were once seen as unthinkable deals practical and even necessary.    Even industry giants have been forced to seek ways to cut costs on huge, expensive international projects. In addition, oil companies have decided that they will not be rescued soon by a rebound in oil prices.   [Page A1.]    Health Insurance Costs to Rise  Many working Americans will have increases of 8 percent to 20 percent or more on health insurance premiums next year in the sharpest price increases since the early 1990's.   [A1.]    OPEC Won't Cut Production  Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, deeply divided over the best strategy for propping up sagging crude oil prices, took no action on making further production cuts, delaying any decision until March.   [C3.]    Default Expected on Soviet Debt  Russia has told Western bankers that it will renege on the terms of repaying $28 billion in Soviet-era debt to creditors, effectively paving the way for a default on interest payments next month, bankers in London said.   [C3.]    Markets Gain in Asia and Europe  Stock markets in Asia and Europe advanced, as Japanese investors awaited economic stimulus measures and the European markets percolated with rumors of a big oil merger. Tokyo's main index, the 225-issue Nikkei, gained 134.30 points, or 0.89 percent, closing at 15,207.77. The index rebounded from a drop of 91.17 points on Wednesday.   [C2.]    Honors for Leo Burnett  Leo Burnett, the adman behind the Marlboro Man, was selected one of the 20 most influential business leaders of the 20th century. Stuart Elliott: Advertising.   [C4.]

headline: North Korean Nuclear Arms Pact Reported Near Breakdown
abstract: North Korea refuses to allow inspection of huge underground construction site that could be used to hide a nuclear reactor, a stand that could cause collapse of four-year-old agreement meant to freeze North Korea's nuclear weapons program; American officials are also alarmed by intelligence evidence suggesting that North Korea is making preparations to test-fire a medium-range ballistic missile over Japan (M)

headline: 2 Big Assignments For Messner Vetere
abstract: Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York is awarded two assignments that together have combined billings estimated at $60 million to $80 million; accounts are Volvo Cars of North America and Universal Studios Recreation Group, part of Seagram Co (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BOMBARDIER INC., Montreal,  named Robert Brown president and chief executive.    GOODYEAR TIRE AND RUBBER CO., Akron, Ohio, named Stephanie Bergeron vice president and treasurer.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Chinese company close to default raises issues about how reliable a borrower China may be.
abstract: Market Place column on Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corp's failure to make scheduled interest payment of $8.75 million on $200 million last week; says some bankers worry that looming credit crunch could weaken China's immunity to financial turmoil that has already hit most of its Asian neighbors (M)

headline: In First Step to Democracy, Nigerians Vote
abstract: Local government elections in Nigeria appear to be going on peacefully; are seen as early test of new Government's seriousness about reform; photo (M)

headline: Ericsson to Eliminate 10,000 More Jobs
abstract: Ericsson AB, Swedish company that has been aggressively reorganizing its business to resist growing competition in its key cellular phone business, says its fourth-quarter profit will be 15 percent to 20 percent lower than expected and that it will cut 10,000 more jobs because of flagging demand for its phones and public switching systems (M)

headline: Discover Card Account Is Placed in Review
abstract: Discover Financial Services places in review its Discover Card advertising account; DDB Needham Chicago, which handled account, participates in review (S)

headline: A Truckload of 'Howevers' Burdens the Iraqis' Promise
abstract: Iraqi representative at United Nations Nizar Hamdoon, is pressed to promise that no sites, including Presidential properties belonging to Saddam Hussein and his security services will be barred to inspectors as in past; says that certain 'modalities' govern searches of such places, according to agreement signed with Sec Gen Kofi Annan in Feb (M)

headline: Saudi Was Target In Raid, U.S. Says
abstract: Clinton Administration officials now acknowledge that one of the clear but unstated objectives of last August's raid in Afghanistan was to kill Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile who has been charged by Federal prosecutors with leading a global war against American interests and who has been linked to the Aug. 7 bombing of two American embassies in East Africa.

headline: Haiti Paralysis Brings a Boom In Drug Trade
abstract: Colombian and Dominican drug traffickers have made Haiti fastest-growing transit point for cocaine on way to US, seizing singular opportunity in country weakened by paralyzed Government and inexperienced police force; Clinton Administration drug czar, Barry R McCaffrey, says situation has become emergency, with Haiti becoming principal focus of groups trafficking in drugs in Caribbean; Haitian police chief Pierre Denize concurs; says small police force, limited in resources and training, is unable to cope with problem; US officials estimate 15 percent of all cocaine consumed in US currently flows through Haiti--doubling in little more than year; all along country's southern coast, indications of landings by fast boats from Colombia have increased, as have reports of airdrops in coastal weaters, and seizures at airport in capital of Port-au-Prince are up; US Customs officials note corresponding increase in drugs found aboard Haitian freighters docking in Miami; maps (M)

headline: Toddlers' Tools Without the Ring of Truth
abstract: Hasbro Interactive unveils its Tonka Workshop, plastic play set that straps onto computer keyboard so children 3 and older can use 'tools' when prompted by CD-ROM character named Tonka Joe; by using the plastic tools atop the keyboard, the Workshop game depresses the keys underneath and creates an on-line project (M)

headline: Insurance Shortcuts, On Line
abstract: Article offers advice on tapping into Internet in search of life insurance coverage; photos (M)

headline: Late Surges Bring Wide Gains as Dow Climbs by 54.83
abstract: Late-session surges drive stocks to broad gains with Dow Jones industrial average up 54.83 to 9,041.11; Nasdaq market gains 18.92; graph; chart on some stocks with large price percentage gains and losses (M)

abstract: COPPER FALLS.  Copper futures posted 11 1/2-year lows on rising inventories, reinforcing concern that construction demand is slowing sharply. In New York, copper fell 1.40 cents, to 67.45 cents a pound.

headline: Ruling Japan Party Weighs A Cut in the 5% Sales Tax
abstract: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party is reluctantly discussing temporary reduction in nation's sales tax in effort to win support from opposition Liberal Party; Liberal Party would like to see tax temporarily reduced from 5 percent to 1 percent to stimulate consumer spending and lift Japan's stagnating economy (M)

headline: Around the U.S., Cynicism And a Showing of Support
abstract: Americans turn attention away from Pres Clinton's probable impeachment by House to his motives for launching air strikes against Iraq; find timing more than just coincidental; photo (M)

headline: Apple Executive Testifies of Threats and Bullying by Microsoft
abstract: Apple Computer Inc senior executive Avadis Tevanian Jr, in written testimony as Government witness in antitrust trial against Microsoft Corp, recalls a software developer warned him that if Apple did not stop selling its highly successful Quicktime multimedia software product, Microsoft would take any necessary action to drive Apple out of business; Tevanian accuses Microsoft of threatening and bullying Apple to drop support for Netscape Communications Corp's browser for navigating World Wide Web and instead to favor Microsoft's Internet Explorer browser (M)

headline: In Balkans Again, Promises, Promises
abstract: Through forceful if belated diplomacy, the Clinton Administration has won enormous concessions from the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic. But the agreement announced today on Kosovo, the embattled province in southern Serbia, seems fraught with the dangers that have long bedevilled the West in Bosnia.    For a Serbian leader to accept NATO jet fighters patrolling over the sacred ground of Kosovo is an unusual act of pragmatism over principle.

headline: Allied Signal Will Pursue AMP Despite Adverse Ruling by Judge
abstract: Allied Signal Inc will proceed with its offer of $44.50 a share to buy 9 percent of outstanding stock of AMP Inc, indicating confidence that Allied's $9.7 billion hostile takeover bid will be successful despite Federal District Judge James T Giles' ruling that part of its purchase plan is unlawful; AMP, in effort to show shareholders that it can add value to company, says it will buy back up to 30 million of its shares, or about 14 percent, for $55 a share (M)d

headline: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO CLOSE TWO FIBERBOARD PLANTS
abstract: International Paper Co will close fiberboard plants in South Carolina and North Carolina and dismiss 336 workers after company fails to find buyers for sites; layoffs come on top of 1,500 job cuts that were announced on Oct 13 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Two French Drug Makers In $10.4 Billion Merger  Two French drug makers, Sanofi and Synthelabo, agreed to merge for $10.4 billion, the second alliance between two European pharmaceutical companies announced this week.

headline: Biggest Shareholders Act To Protect BMW Stakes
abstract: Quandt family, largest shareholder in BMW, says it has moved most of its 45.6 percent stake into holding companies to protect against takeover attempts (S)

headline: Japan's Recession Deepens; Output Falls at a 2.6% Rate
abstract: Japanese economy shrank in third quarter at annual rate of 2.6 percent, signaling deeper recession woes; consumers and industry cut back on spending, and polls show public in gloomy mood, although Government has started to implement $140-billion stimulus program (S)

headline: Unicef Study Predicts 16% World Illiteracy Rate Will Increase
abstract: Unicef study finds that nearly one-sixth of 5.9 billion people in world cannot read or write and predicts that illiteracy rates will steadily grow into next century (M)

headline: Merger Tidings Carry S.& P. and Nasdaq to High Ground
abstract: Nasdaq composite index and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index reach new highs in anticipation of new wave of mergers and buying by investors; Nasdaq gains 31.23 to finish at 2,016.44; S&P 500 gains 5.46, to 1,192.33; graph; chart of some stocks with largest percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: Long-Term Capital Said to Earn A Small Profit for Its Rescuers
abstract: Long-Term Capital Management has earned small paper profit for banks and brokerage firms that saved it from bankruptcy in September; portfolio's value has risen no more than 1 percent since 14 banks and brokerage firms invested $3.6 billion six weeks ago (M)

headline: Soccer by Satellite
abstract: Letter from Jim Bentley says Direct TV allows him to see soccer games he would ordinarily miss (S)

headline: Treasury's Schedule This Week Offers Two Bills and a Note
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and a 10-year inflation index note on Wednesday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.08 percent and a six-month bill was 4.20 percent. The current 10-year inflation index note is selling at a price to yield 3.50 percent.

headline: The Man Who Built Time Warner Leaves a Legacy of Appreciation
abstract: Compensation expert Graef Crystal says late Time Warner Inc creator Steven J Ross' estate has earned far more money since he died than when he was alive (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: Apple Computer releases MSC OS 8.5, new operating system for Macintosh (S)

headline: NATO Is Likely to Extend Deadline for Kosovo Strikes
abstract: NATO and Clinton Administration officials say alliance will extend October 26 deadline for ordering air strikes against Yugoslav military and police forces in Kosovo Province; weigh more general open-ended threat to use force, instead of setting new deadline, if Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic violates pledge and orders resumption of crackdown on people of Kosovo, who are predominantly ethnic Albanians (M)

headline: LARGEST CANCER-MANAGEMENT COMPANIES TO MERGE
abstract: American Oncology Resources Inc to acquire Physician Reliance Network Inc for $655 million plus assumed debt of $60 million (S)

headline: Oil Pipelines From Caspian Lack Money From Backers
abstract: Prospects for quick construction of American-backed oil pipeline from Caspian Sea are set back further this week when senior oil executive says countries supporting it do not seem willing to help pay for it; John Leggate, who heads consortium of oil companies that is considering pipeline routes, asserts that 'not a single country' supporting pipeline has suggested it would participate in financing project; does not name any countries, but the three through which pipeline would pass are Azerbaijan, Georgia and Turkey; maps shows various proposed pipeline routes (M)

headline: A Webliography of Chuckles That Wears a Cap and Gown
abstract: Webliography for Humor (www.mtroyal.ab.ca/programs/academserv/lib/ Subguide/sghumour.htm), compiled by librarians at Mount Royal College in Calgary, Canada, provides more that 50 links to humorous Web sites; was compiled by Margy MacMillan, library's Internet coordinator; photos (M)

headline: Merger Deal Can Count On a Gantlet of Inquiries
abstract: Exxon Corp's proposed merger with Mobil faces tough antitrust scrutiny from Federal and state regulators and from officials in Europe and Japan; experts believe merger can be completed if companies shed some assets; Charles F Rule, former Justice Department antitrust division head, will lead legal team representing Exxon before Federal Trade Commission; Janet L McDavid, set to become American Bar Association antitrust section head, will lead Mobil team; table of world's biggest companies (M)

headline: Ex-Soviets Are Focus Of Inquiry By the Swiss
abstract: Switzerland is concerned that rich free-spending Russians who have appeared since fall of Communism are using country as haven where they can stow ill-gotten cash from former Soviet Union; authorities recently detained former Ukrainian prime minister, Pavlo Lazarenko, who entered on Panamanian passport, and indicted him for money-laundering; Geneva prosecutors also brought organized-crime charges against Sergei Mikhailov, reputed Moscow mob kingpin who had been living quietly in Switzerland; Mikhailov was acquitted for insufficient evidence, thwarting effort to send message to Russian gangsters; Russia and Ukraine have both tried to seek out illegal funds deposited in Switzerland (M)

headline: Monthly Sales Fall 33% For Samsung Motor
abstract: Samsung Motors Inc says sales were 33.5 percent lower in October than in September, biggest decline since Samsung entered auto business in April (S)

headline: All Nippon Airways May Join Star Alliance
abstract: All Nippon Airways Co is set to become next member of Star Alliance, world's biggest airline group, as alliance pushes to expand its reach in Asia (S)

headline: LEVITZ FURNITURE TO CLOSE 27 STORES AND CUT 1,000 JOBS
abstract: Levitz Furniture Co will close 27 of its 90 stores and cut 1,000 jobs, about 25 percent of work force; will shrink warehouse system down to 17, from 65 sites, continue efforts to freshen up dowdier stores and open at least 15 stores (S)

headline: Sending Carbon Copies
abstract: Letter from Michael Taglieri comments on Dec 10 article on E-mail etiquette (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Exxon-Mobil Talks Add To Oil Workers' Anxiety  They have been downsized, cut back and re-engineered. So when the 900 remaining blue-collar workers at Mobil's largest domestic refinery in Beaumont, Tex., heard that their company was in merger talks with Exxon, it was like an alarm warning them that an already suspect valve might be about to blow.    ''I think it's a terrible thing,'' said Dick Mabry, a refinery operator, as he emerged from the main gate after his 12-hour shift. ''It's a revival of the Standard Oil Company. It's going to put 20 or 30 thousand people out of work. I think the Justice Department should step in and stop it.'' [Page A1.]

headline: Accounts
abstract: Eaton Truck Components Operations, unit of Eaton Corp, to Ketchum Advertising, to handle its marketing communications, which had been handled by Europe RSCG Tatham; billings estimated at $3 million (S)

headline: Giant Has New Ideas for On-Line Guides
abstract: Microsoft Corp is expected to introduce makeover of Sidewalk, its on-line city guide, in ambitious effort to create on-line advertising vehicles for dozens of local products and services (S)

headline: GE CAPITAL AGREES TO ADD EAGLE STAR REINSURANCE
abstract: GE Capital Corp to acquire Eagle Star Reinsurance Co from Zurich Financial Services; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: European Union Delays Decisions on Ex-Communist Countries
abstract: Leaders of European Union meeting in Vienna put off until 1999 the decisions on changing budget and decision-making procedures to prepare for admission of formerly Communist nations; say commitment to expansion to the east remains undiminished (M)

headline: S.E.C. Guidelines to Yield Data on Year 2000 Risks
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission issues guidelines that will offer public information about how most Wall Street companies are doing in assessing Year 2000 computer problem and reducing their risks; agency had been alarmed at how vague and limited most disclosures had been; now, new data on Year 2000 problem will appear in quarterly earnings reports filed with SEC; Congress approves of new SEC guidelines, and has sent Pres Clinton bill allowing companies to exchange information on their Year 2000 readiness or put such information on World Wide Web without fear that information could be used against them in lawsuit if it turns out to be wrong (M)

headline: Shoney's Will Sell or Close 84 Restaurants
abstract: Shoney's Inc will sell 34 restaurants to Elias Brothers by early 1999 and close 50 locations by end of January to focus on its restaurants in Southeast; terms of sale to Elias Brothers, which operates Big Boy restaurants, are not disclosed (S)

headline: Royal Philips to Reduce Shares by 8%
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics NV will reduce number of its outstanding common shares by 8 percent (S)

headline: I.B.M. and Realnetworks in Joint Venture
abstract: IBM and Realnetworks Inc announce venture to integrate audio and video into E-mail and other Internet software as IBM tries to gain edge on Microsoft Corp; companies will combine IBM's Lotus Notes and Domino products, software that allows people in different locations to work together on projects and conduct meetings, with Realnetworks' Realsystem G2 audio and video technology (S)

headline: Bond Arbitrager To Quit Salomon
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney names Paul Matthews head of global bond arbitrage, replacing Costas Kaplanis, who is leaving (S)

headline: PHILIP SERVICES SELLING SOME PLANTS FOR $70 MILLION
abstract: Philip Services Corp to sell its aluminum plants to Wabash Alloys LLC, subsidiary of Connell Limited Partnership, for $70 million in cash to reduce its $1.1 billion in debt (S)

headline: Fashion's Crossover Moments : Playing to the Galleries:Wannabe Art
abstract: LONDON—  To the right, a plastic maternity dress with a porthole window at the front. That's a fashion item? No! It's art — Mimi Smith's feminist statement from the 1960s.

headline: Equity Offerings Are Set
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Economic Scene; A study cuts through the usual blather on Social Security.
abstract: Michael M Weinstein Economic Scene article on report by nonpartisan National Academy of Social Insurance expert panel on pros and cons of privatizing Social Security; report resolves most of financial issues and exposes political issues that cannot be settled by technical analysis; suggests Government system that can invest in stocks and bonds can achieve same financial goals as private system at lower administrative costs; shows argument for private accounts is political, to bar manipulative potential of Government control of huge stock holdings (M)

headline: Chevron Shares Soar on Speculation on a Sale
abstract: Shares of Chevron Corp rise after Internet site that tracks Dutch stocks speculates that Royal Dutch/Shell Group might attempt takeover of company (M)

headline: Bond Prices Surge as Investors Push Yields to 31-Year Low
abstract: Bond prices surge for biggest one-day gain in more than year as investors worldwide seek relative safety of Treasury securities for fifth consecutive day; yields on Treasury's 30-year bond plummet to 4.72 percent, from 4.84 percent, lowest for long-term Government debt since April 1967; prices rise 2 2/32 point, or more than $20 per $1,000 in face amount, biggest gain since Sept 16, 1997; graphs (M)

headline: At Russian Post Office, Check Isn't in the Mail
abstract: Russia's Railway Ministry refuses to move mail cars until Post Office makes good on some 210 million rubles in old bills; several airports hold up air mail over past-due debts; so much mail is backed up that post offices in Moscow and elsewhere simply refuse to accept out-of-town mail; delivery schedules fall weeks, perhaps months, behind, causing real pain in a country of ardent letter writers; photo (M)

headline: Camelot: The Realm On Line
abstract: King Arthur, in legend the greatest king of Britain's Dark Ages, is subject of many scholarly Web sites as well as almost every video and computer game featuring swords and sorcery; drawing (M)

headline: Facing Oblivion, Rust-Belt Giants Top Russian List Of Vexing Crises
abstract: Most vexing of Russia's problems lie in its Rust Belt, interlocking series of industrial giants now living off barter and choking on bloated work force; many of industries are pillars of communities that have no other reason for being; solving their problems without causing social upheaval will be key test for Russia's new Government, headed by Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov and staffed with old-style Soviet ministers who have pointedly set out to rescue Russian industry; many fault Pres Boris N Yeltsin's team of young free-market reformers for failing to anticipate economic disarray--and corruption--that followed their lifting of state controls; Magnitogorsk, once largest steel mill in former Soviet Union, is producing less than half raw steel it did decade ago, with same work force; bottom has fallen out of its domestic market as Russian factories that buy steel approach bankruptcy and struggle to sell what Russians either do not want or cannot afford; photos; map; charts (L)

headline: Sema Gets Olympic Jobs Once Held by I.B.M.
abstract: Sema Group PLC, Europe's second-largest computer services company, wins contract worth up to $300 million to run computer systems for four Winter and Summer Olympic Games from 2002 to 2008, replacing IBM (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of October 18 headline about Chrysler Corp president Thomas T Stallkamp's effort to learn to speak German, which misspelled Porsche (S)

headline: Iraqis Are Called Masters of Concealment
abstract: UN weapons inspectors and other arms experts say Iraqis are masters at hiding weaponry, and have extremely well-developed plans for moving them out of way of bombs; Iraqis reportedly have also fine-tuned ability to reconstitute programs quickly; Scott Ritter sys UN inspectors have seen emergency dispersal plan; photo of Iraqi airfield, showing planes that were removed from hangars before allied bombing (S)

headline: THE NEW EUROPE: Money That Binds; Primer on Euro: From Birth To Growth as Unifying Force
abstract: Special report: The New Europe. Money That Binds, a primer on the euro; after decades of dreams, diplomacy and delays, euro is suddenly real; on Dec 31, 11 European countries are to lock their exchange rates to euro, now worth about $1.17, and cede to new European Central Bank power to set interest rates and monetary policy; currency conversion represents most important step in Europe's long quest for political unity; in getting to this point, 11 euro nations for first time have adopted common economic policiy that has reined in public spending, reduced debt and tamed inflation; this achievement has seriously altered political debate; governments in Germany, Italy and France have fallen in large part because of spending cutbacks required to create euro; business strategy has been transformed, and more residents and visitors are thinking of Europe as a single place instead of jigsaw of nationalities; origins of idea of single currency discussed; euro guide shows what happens in Jan 1999, and by Jan 1, 2002 and by July 1, 2002; map shows European Union countries that are adopting euro, and those that are not; photos (L)

headline: Life in the Fast Lane (Thanks, Dad)
abstract: Sequent Computer Systems is helping to sponsor drag-racing team whose driver is Cristin Powell, 19, daughter of Sequent's chairman Karl C Powell Jr (S)

headline: Coming Soon to HDTV: New York's Sports Teams
abstract: MSG Network to deliver gamesof New York area's professional sports teams to cable television subscribers in high definition next year (M)

headline: U.N. and World Bank Unite To Wage War on Malaria
abstract: Three major United Nations agencies and World Bank are joining forces in coordinated campaign against malaria, leading killer of world's poorest people; project will be coordinated by World Health Organization in cooperation with UN Development Program, Unicef and World Bank; new drive is first project undertaken by WHO's new director general, Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland (M)

headline: Financial Giant Seeking A Big Footprint in Funds
abstract: GE Capital Services, financial arm of General Electric, is working hard to raise its profile in mutual funds; GE already offers eight stock and four bonds funds to public; it plans to start 12 others next year (M)

headline: SPECIALTY FOODS TO PAY $100 MILLION FOR TWO COMPANIES
abstract: Specialty Foods Corp to buy Archway Cookies Inc and San Diego Bread Co for more than $100 million (S)

headline: Time Warner Is Sued by U.S. In Employee Benefits Case
abstract: US Labor Department sues Time Warner Inc and officials of nine corporate pension and health plans, saying they wrongly denied health and retirement coverage to hundreds of employees; suit says workers were mistakenly classified as independent contractors or temporary workers rather than official employees entitled to benefits, adding that company violated Employee Retirement Income Security Act (M)

headline: AFFILIATED MANAGERS TO BUY RORER ASSET MANAGEMENT
abstract: Affiliated Managers Group Inc to buy 65 percent of Rorer Asset Management for about $65 million in cash; Rorer's principals will retain 35 percent of company (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Can Rhone-Poulenc and Hoechst be equal partners?
abstract: Market Place column examines ramifications of planned merger of French drug maker Rhone-Poulenc SA and Hoechst AG of Germany; photo (M)

headline: FORD SAYS IT WILL TEMPORARILY CLOSE 3 ASSEMBLY PLANTS
abstract: Ford Motor Co will temporarily close assembly plants in Kansas City, Mo, Cuautitlan, Mex, and Lorain, Ohio, to prevent inventories from building up (S)

headline: Commodity Deflation And Trade Angst
abstract: Labor Dept report of drop in wholesale prices in November is attributed to continuing slump in commodity prices; graph (S)

headline: Jobless Rate Rises In South Korea in Month
abstract: South Korea's unemployment rate rises to 7.3 percent, Nov, from 7.1 percent in Oct; graph (S)

headline: Why March? 'People Are Fed Up With This Business'
abstract: Demonstrators comment on their participation in mass protest, Moscow; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Mixed as Glitch Interrupts Big Board Action  Stock prices ended mixed in relatively subdued trading as a rally in European exchanges and better-than-expected earnings reports from a number of companies lifted shares early in the day before investors took profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.08 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 8,432.21.    Broader market averages did better, however, and small-cap stocks continued to rally. In the Treasury market, the price on the 30-year bond rose as the yield fell to 5.11 percent from 5.17 percent. [Page C10.]

headline: MBNA IS BUYING PNC BANK'S CREDIT CARD OPERATIONS
abstract: MBNA Corp will buy PNC Bank Corp's credit card operations for $443 million; deal includes PNC's American Automobile Association affinity-branded credit cards (S)

headline: Akzo Nobel Shares Jump On Report of Asset Sale
abstract: Shares of Akzo Nobel NV rise after newspaper report that company plans to sell recently acquired packaging unit to Schroder Ventures (S)

headline: Brazil Chief to Offer Spending-Cut Plan
abstract: Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso, trying to calm investors while placating Brazilian voters, says he will announce in two weeks a plan to cut spending to reverse growing budget deficit and shore up investor confidence (S)

headline: Malaysian Government To Buy Bank Stake
abstract: Malaysian Government's largest investment unit, Khazanah Nasional Bhd, agrees to pay 725.4 million ringgit ($191 million) for 30 percent of banking unit of RHB Capital Bhd, country's second-largest banking group and unit of Sakura Bank (S)

headline: Equity Offerings for Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY     Amer Sts. Wtr    Armstrong World    Atl Richfield    Bausch & Lomb    Carpenter Tech    Crane    Ft Dearborn Inc.    Kennametal    Ku Enrgy.    LandAmer Fincl Grp    Medusa    Peco Enrgy    Regency Rlty    Utd Dominion

headline: Investor Cancels Pact For Bouygues Stake
abstract: French executive Vincent Bollore cancels year-old pact to buy shares in Bouygues SA; Bollore's exit is seen as removing obstacle for other investors interested in buying into company (S)

headline: PACIFIC DUNLOP TO SELL BATTERY-MAKING UNIT TO QUEXCO
abstract: Pacific Dunlop Ltd will cut price for its GNB Technologies battery-making unit after US regulators delayed approving sale and market conditions subsequently worsened; business will now be sold to Quexco Inc for $500 million, $50 million less than originally agreed (S)

headline: Deutsche Bank Considers Merging Securities Unit
abstract: Deutsche Bank and Sakura Bank may merger their Japanese securities businesses (S)

headline: Greenspan Sees Calming Of Markets
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan says investors and lenders appear to be calming down after fright thrown into them by global financial turmoil, suggesting that central bank is less concerned than a few weeks ago that credit squeeze could derail the economy, speech delivered from Washington by video conference to meeting of Securities Industry Association; economists say Fed is still more likely than not to trim interest rates again in November; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: CHILD PROSTITUTE AS VICTIM -- The Government issued guidelines aimed at treating child prostitutes as victims of abuse rather than as criminals and at marking their employers and clients for prosecution. The latest annual figures, for 1995-1996, show that 177 youths under 17 were convicted of prostitution and another 207 were formally cautioned.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: BATONS VS. TRUNCHEONS -- The British police are being warned that the growing substitution of longer and heavier American-style batons for the 11-inch wooden truncheons traditionally carried by officers has resulted in an increased number of brutality complaints. The report from the independent Police Complaints Authority says British police forces should instruct their members in restrained use of the new weapons to reduce the possibility of serious injury.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: GTECH HOLDINGS IN BID FOR TRANSACTION NETWORK
abstract: Gtech Holdings Corp is seeking to acquire Transaction Network Services Inc (S)

headline: Finding Her Stage In the Costume Racks
abstract: Profile of career of Suzy Benzinger, costume designer for Broadway musical Miss Saigon; photo (M)

headline: STOCK OF VALLEY FORGE UP 45% ON NEWS OF PURCHASE DEAL
abstract: Stock of Valley Forge Corp rises 45 percent after recreation boating products firm agrees to be acquired by Key Components LLC (S)

headline: MONY UNIT TO BUY U.S. FINANCIAL LIFE FOR $48 MILLION
abstract: US Financial Life Insurance Co agrees to be acquired by the Mony Life Insurance Co, unit of Mony Group Inc, for $48 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.69   4.72   5.45        3-month T-bills   4.40   4.44   5.31        6-month T-bills   4.43   4.44   5.27        10-yr. T-infl.   3.81   3.79   3.64        10-yr. T-note   4.70   4.63   5.69        30-yr. T-bond   5.13   5.06   5.87        Telephone bd.   6.69   6.73   7.15        Municipal bds.   5.18   5.15   5.23          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Euro Disney Profit Up Despite Visitor Decline
abstract: Euro Disney SA reports net income for fiscal year ended Sept 30 rose 34 percent to 290 million francs ($51.62 million), from 217 million francs year earlier (S)

headline: Mother Cites New U.S. Law on Torture to Fight Return to Nigeria
abstract: Nigerian widow Virginia Anikwata says she and her American born, 11-year-old daughter face sexual abuses if they have to return to her homeland; asks to stay in US under new law that makes international convention against torture part of American law (M)

headline: Offering Tips For Skiers Of All Levels
abstract: Skinet Web site offers tips for skiers of all levels (S)

headline: Seoul to Double Aid To Its Ailing Banks
abstract: South Korean Government will double its assistance to financial institutions in bid to revive nation's most troubled industry; Ministry of Finance and Economy says it will spend 23.2 trillion won ($16.8 billion) through next June to buy bad debt from banks and financial companies (S)

headline: And Now, Back to Real Life
abstract: Matt Richtel reviews book My Tiny Life: Crime and Passion in a Virtual World, by Julian Dibbell; photo (S)

headline: Both Sides in Ulster Carve Out Crucial Accord on Cabinet
abstract: For first time since Ireland was partitioned in 1922, leaders of Northern Ireland's Protestant majority and Catholic minority agree to specific reforms that will give Catholics more power in British province; breakthrough after eight months of stalemate allows both sides to set up 10-member ruling Executive Cabinet that would include two representatives of Sinn Fein; negotiators sidestep issue of disarming Irish Republican Army and other guerrillas, problem that has blocked peace effort since general agreement was reached in April; photo (M)

headline: TR FINANCIAL ASKS HIGHER PRICE IN MERGER WITH ROSLYN
abstract: TR Financial Corp will end agreement to be bought by Roslyn Bancorp unless Roslyn agrees to pay about $25 million more than companies originally agreed (S)

headline: Warwick Baker Adds Gitano Line
abstract: Fruit of the Loom Inc expands its relationship with Warwick Baker O'Neill by naming agency to handle advertising for Gitano Jeanswear; account, with billings estimated at $5 million, has been handled by Mullen Advertising (S)

headline: Microsoft Refrain: Who Was Harmed?
abstract: Analysis of antitrust trial against Microsoft Corp focuses on Microsoft's defense, which boiled down to one question: Where's the harm? photo of Microsoft lead lawyer John Warden (M)

headline: World Bank Worried by Pressure for Quick-Fix Fiscal Action
abstract: World Bank, amid spread of global economic crisis, fears being transformed from slow-moving development agency into financial fire truck, programmed to squirt streams of cash at countries under speculative attack; finance ministers from world's seven largest economies, attending bank's and IMF's annual meeting in Washington, warn that without radical strengthening of international financial system crisis will spread far beyond Asia and Russia to affect entire developing world; IMF has lowered economic growth forecasts for developing world as whole, predicting that economies will expand by 2.3 percent in 1998 and 3.6 percent in 1999--compared with 5.8 percent in 1997 (M)

headline: IN MY... SUITCASE/ROBERT M. WORSLEY
abstract: Suitcase of Skymall Inc chief executive Robert M Worsley, frequent business traveler, always includes lightweight data projector; photos (S)8

headline: No More Policy Changes, Japan Bank Chief Says
abstract: Bank of Japan governor Masaru Hayami says no further changes in monetary policy will be made until Government judges effects of recent measures to pull nation out of recession; photo (S)

headline: Inside The Head Of the Fed; Alan Greenspan's Journey To the New World Economy
abstract: Profile of Federal Reserve Board chairman Alan Greenspan; focuses on what his views on market conditions, US economy and interest rates as US joins other countries in heading toward new world economy; photos; chart (L)

headline: U.S. Seeks Input on New Rules for the I.M.F.
abstract: Clinton Administration begins consultations with foreign Governments about changes that will be demanded of International Monetary Fund under deal with Congress to provide fund with $18 billion; compromise legislation being hammered out by White House and Republican Congressional leaders would provide full financing for fund, but would also demand greater openness in its decision-making and new restrictions on loans (M)

headline: Starcom Is Awarded 3 Diageo Accounts
abstract: United States subsidiaries of Diageo PLC--United Distillers and Vintners North America in Stamford, Conn, Schieffelin & Somerset in New York and the Pillsbury Co in Minneapolis--name Starcom Media Services unit of Leo Burnett Co to handle media responsibilities, with estimated billings valued at more than $150 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Two Depart at Fox and Universal After TV and Film Setbacks; Network Program Chief Had Scored Some Hits
abstract: Peter Roth, head of programming for Fox television network, announces his resignation, saying he plans to start a production company; Fox, News Corp subsidiary, is expected to appoint Doug Herzog, president of cable channel Comedy Central, as its new head of programming; shift may reflect conclusion of broadcast networks that they need to change their approach to programming; Scott Sassa, recently named president of NBC's entertainment division, along with Herzog, built their careers at entertainment operations of cable networks; Fox's move was not entirely unexpected because the network started the television season in September with several weeks of disappointing ratings and was quickly forced to cancel four comedies; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen declines for second day on expectations that Japan's economy is falling deeper into recession; in New York, dollar settles at 119.81 yen, up from 118.95 yen on Dec 4; graph; chart (S)

headline: Iran Discontent Rises as Oil-Based Economy Falls
abstract: Iran's economy weakens by the day, the victim of falling oil prices, and political discontent is growing as a result; oil price has dipped below $10 a barrel, a 25-year-low and well below the $17.50-a-barrel figure assumed as basis for current budget; Government has been forced to slash imports, dig deeper into reserves and postpone payments on foreign debt; Pres Mohammad Khatami wants to end gasoline subsidies that keep prices at 12 cents a gallon, but opponents in Parliament vow to block proposal; photo; graph (M)

headline: Clinton Appeals To North Korea For Closer Ties
abstract: Pres Clinton, speaking at joint appearance with South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung in Seoul, makes unusual direct appeal to North Korea to set aside any nuclear ambitions in favor of strengthening ties to South Korea and US; says construction site in North Korea that could be beginnings of nuclear weapons plant and test firing last Aug of missile over Japan are 'cause for deep concern'; Clinton also comments on Iraq's refusal to comply with request from weapons inspectors; he urges caution and says it is 'important that we not overreact'; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of natural gas increases as below-normal temperatures in Midwest and Northeast bolsters heating demand; gas for December delivery rises 15.8 cents, to $2.553 for each 1,000 cubic feet; graph; chart (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Deflation is frightening, but toothless, for 90's Americans.
abstract: Economic Scene column says there is little evidence to suggest deflation will hit US economy; holds deflation has not reached all-important labor markets; says if wages do not fall, prices will almost certainly not fall either; holds labor costs typically account for two-thirds of cost of producing goods and services; says in general, wages and prices move up and down together; holds productivity is rising by less than 2 percent a year, providing no room for prices to fall if wages continue to rise anywhere near their current 4 percent clip; drawing (M)

headline: GORE, IN MALAYSIA, SAYS ITS LEADERS SUPPRESS FREEDOM
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore rebukes Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad's Government for suppressing freedom and lauds growing protest movement, speech at Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, attended by Mahathir and other top Malaysian officials; holds democracies have done better in coping with economic crises, giving reforms needed legitimacy; attack eclipses his announcement that United States and Japan will join in providing $10 billion to help rebuild Asia's shattered banks and corporations; photos (M)

headline: Led by Intel, Stocks Rise as S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq Hit Records
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 157.47 points, or 1.74 percent, to 9,202.03; Nasdaq composite index rises 51.56 points, or 2.43 percent, to record 2,172.54; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 24.97 points, or 2.07 percent, to record 1,228.54; tables; graphs (M)

headline: Creator of the On-Line Swap Meet
abstract: Profile of Pierre Omidyar, founder of Ebay, on-line auction service where more than 70,000 new items go on sale daily; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Warns Banks Against Overgenerous Reserve Levels
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission regulators, usually concerned about banks not setting aside enough money to cover expected losses, say Suntrust Bank Inc did just reverse and has set aside too much money in its reserves; in essence, bank has said in its financial statements that it will not collect on some outstanding loans even though they would most likely be paid; Suntrust, after talks with regulators, agrees to decrease its loan reserves by $100 million--an adjustment that will force the bank to restate earnings for 1994, 1995 and 1996; regulators have been reviewing financial statements of Suntrust because of its proposed acquisition of Crestar Financial Corp; in past year, securities regulators have expressed concern about what they say is growing number of companies playing games with their numbers (M)

headline: Antitrust Suit Filed Against Visa and Mastercard
abstract: Justice Department files antitrust lawsuit against Visa USA and Mastercard International, contending that nation's two biggest credit card networks restrain competition and limit consumers' choices; suit challenges control of both credit card associations by same set of banks, as well as rules adopted by Visa and Mastercard that ban member banks from offering credit cards of competitors like American Express and Discover (M)

headline: Philippine Airlines' Debt Plan Rejected
abstract: European creditors reject rehabilitation plan proposed by debt-ridden Philippine Airlines, casting new doubt on whether carrier can survive (S)

headline: Sensor Sensation
abstract: Bret Cohen letter, commenting on Nov 12 article on smart plumbing, says New York City already mandates use of temperature pressure balancer to keep constant water temperature in the shower when the toilet is flushed somewhere else in the house

headline: KVAERNER TO SELL TRAFALGAR HOUSE, A U.S. HOME BUILDER
abstract: Kvaerner PLC agrees to sell its US home-building business, Trafalgar House Property Inc, to two buyers for $150 million; US construction company, which Kvaerner declines to identify, agrees to buy bulk of home-building business; 6,000-plot South Riding, Va, development is being bought by consortium led by Gregory Cox, South Riding's president (S)

headline: T. Rowe Price Bank Plan
abstract: T Rowe Price Associates Inc, mutual fund company, applies to open Federal savings bank so that it can offer certificates of deposit to its customers (S)

headline: Women on the Web
abstract: Maureen Sheridan letter comments on Oct 22 article on sites for women on Internet; denies that women function differently on line

headline: Compressed Data; From the Electronic Innards To the Everyday Cash Register
abstract: John T Chambers, chief executive of Cisco Systems, No. 1 manufacturer of data communications equipment, gives the impression in speech to electronic commerce news conference that company is seriously considering ways to move into retail consumer market; in wireless communications market, people can often choose their phone company first and their Internet service provider second; if similar evolution occurs in high-speed data device market, Cisco wants to be major player (S)

headline: The 'Lifestyle' Phenomenon:Pills to Enhance Well-Being
abstract: PARIS—  Disease, pain and life-threatening conditions have been the usual reasons people turn to prescription drugs. But aging baby boomers, interested in continuing to feel and look good as long as possible, have recently fueled a vigorous new phenomenon in the pharmaceutical industry going by the name of "quality of life" or "lifestyle" drugs.

headline: Rejecting Warning, Albright Sees Anwar's Wife
abstract: KUALA LUMPU—  Avoiding official talks with the Malaysian government, the U.S. secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, met Sunday with the wife of Anwar Ibrahim, the country's ousted deputy prime minister. The meeting was apparently a protest against the treatment of Mr. Anwar, who is in jail.

headline: Short Sales Decline 3% On Nasdaq For Month
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers says open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market fell 3 percent in most recent monthly period; drop marks first time in last 12 months that short-interest positions have declined for three consecutive periods; charts (M)/

headline: 2d Broker Charged in New York Inquiry
abstract: New York State prosecutors charge Michael Lamarti, second former broker at A S Goldmen, with violating New York State general business law by manipulating stock trades (S)

headline: LEVEL ONE IN STOCK DEAL FOR JATO TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Level One Communications Inc to buy Jato Technologies Inc for $80 million in stock (S)

headline: Peugeot to Hire 900 At British Auto Plant
abstract: Peugeot Citroen to hire 900 people at Ryton, Eng, plant to raise output of its 206 small car model by 26 percent (S)

headline: Political Costs Widen in Mexico Bank Bailout
abstract: Mexican Finance Min Guillermo Ortiz is at center of controversy that has brought country's young democracy to high-risk impasse and severely tested ability of its Congress to resolve issues through dickering and deal-making of party politics; major opposition group is demanding that Ortiz resign as head of Banco de Mexico, central bank, claiming Ortiz violated Constitution by failing to obtain congressional approval before he put together $61 billion emergency program to rescue sinking banks during economic crisis of 1995; Pres Ernesto Zedillo and his party have closed ranks around Ortiz; at stake is country's continued financial stability; fight over Ortiz is driven by plain old politics (M)

headline: Judge Deals Allied a Blow In AMP Bid
abstract: US District Court Judge James T Giles, Pennsylvania, deals blow to Allied Signal Inc's $9.7 billion hostile takeover bid for AMP Inc, ruling against Allied's effort to seek AMP shareholders' written consent for its purchase offer (M)

headline: Lord Soper, Whose Pulpit Was Hyde Park, Dies at 95
abstract: Rev Lord Soper, Methodist minister and Labor peer who was the most famous and longest-running soapbox orator at Speakers' Corner in Hyde Park, dies at age 95; photo (M)

headline: Agencies try to pick hits from the fall television schedule so advertisers can place their bets.
abstract: Dozens of advertising agency executives preview television networks' new fall offerings in spring to decide which shows their clients will support; increase in number of networks fiercely competing for audience share has complicated job of predicting which shows will be hits; Bill Cella (McCann-Erickson), other forecasters comment (M)

headline: Beijing to Expel Foreign Reporter, 2d in a Month
abstract: China expels Jurgen Kremb, reporter for German news magazine Der Spiegel, one day after eight officials burst into his office and accused him of possessing secret documents; Japanese reporter was charged with possessing state secrets and deported in Oct (M)

headline: 3 at Riney to Open Rubin Postaer Office
abstract: William Marks, William Mericle and Paul Janas, top executives from Chicago office of Publicis & Hal Riney, have left to open office in Chicago on Jan 4 for Rubin Postaer & Associates (S)

headline: AVADO BRANDS SELLS 36 RESTAURANTS FOR $48.3 MILLION
abstract: Avado Brands Inc sells 36 more restaurants to Apple Illinois Corp and Delta Bluff LLC for $48.3 million (S)

headline: Brazil's President Pledges Budget Cuts in Early Austerity Step
abstract: Brazil's Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso pledges to cut $7 billion in spending from deficit-ridden Federal budget in 1999; says in televised speech that Government is determined to attain fiscal balance in shortest possible time (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: SEAGRAM CO., New York, said Joseph W. Farrelly would become senior vice president and chief information officer.     SYBASE INC., Emeryville, Calif., said its chairman, Mitchell Kertzman, had resigned to become president and chief executive of Network Computer Inc., a software maker controlled by Oracle Corp. He succeeds David Roux, who becomes chairman. At Sybase, John Chen, president and chief executive, was named chairman.

headline: Familiar Rite, Familiar Politics in Cambodian Assembly
abstract: Cambodia's National Assembly opens after months of sometimes violent political wrangles amid show of amity; foreign analysts fear instability in coalition of past battlefield enemies led by Prime Min Hun Sen and Prince Norodom Ranariddh; Hun Sen is in sole charge, improving chances for stability, with Prince Ranariddh is relegated to Assembly Speaker; photo (M)/

headline: Netanyahu Challenged From Left And Right
abstract: Israel's Environment Minister, Rafael Eitan, becomes fourth right-wing candidate to throw his hat into ring to replace Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu; many important issues face country, but so far, only lightning rod for debate has been Netanyahu's character; Netanyahu sees race as between him and 'the left,' term he uses as slur; but now he faces opposition from his own side; even Ariel Sharon, hawkish Foreign Minister and Netanyahu's most powerful ally, would not categorically rule out run for Prime Minister; photo (M)

headline: The Town Crier for the Year 2000
abstract: Article on Peter de Jager of Toronto, Canada, former computer programmer credited with first warning world about year 2000 computer glitch in Computerworld article five years ago; photo (M)

headline: Well-Read on Web
abstract: Comment on Arts & Letters, Web site started by Denis Dutton for cerebral browsers; photo of screen suggesting sources of interesting news articles, books and essays (S)

headline: Tradition or Change?Japan Dithers
abstract: TOKYO—  Asia's financial crisis may have started in Thailand, but its solution, say many, must begin in Japan.

headline: New Delhi Journal; Sacred Cows Are Wily Too; Just Try Catching One
abstract: Some 40,000 cows, animal sacred to Hindus, roam streets of New Delhi, often blocking traffic and scavenging through garbage; are threatened by plastic garbage bags, which clog their digestive tracts; cow catchers, who take cows to refuge, often face resistance both from animals and onlookers; photo (M)

headline: She's Not Even Pushy, So Break Out the Brandy
abstract: Business Council, all-male chief executives' club, will open semiannual meeting in Williamsburg, Va, with new female member, Springs Industries chief executive Crandall Close Bowles; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Rising health premiums don't mean medical inflation is back.
abstract: Economic Scene column; finds the most worrisome economic tiding for new year is that health care premiums for employer-based coverage will rise by 10 percent or more in 1999; startling figure, based on preliminary data from private employers and program covering Federal employees, is out of line with scant rate increases over last four years; it raises question of whether managed care plans have returned to days of double-digit rate increases, abandoning their promise to smooth medical inflation; holds there are good reasons to believe that answer is no, and that next year's double-digit premium increases appear likely to be temporary; drawing (M)

headline: Home Ownership in U.S. Rises to a Record
abstract: Housing Sec Andrew M Cuomo says US home ownership rate soared to record of 66.8 percent in third quarter, driven by strong economy; says 7.4 million more families owned homes than did so when Pres Clinton took office in 1993; number of families owning their homes climbed to 69.1 million in third quarter (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY     None

headline: Japan's Plan: A Big Shrug
abstract: Analysis of Japan's new $195 billion economic stimulus plan, which spurs little investor reaction; critics call package misguided and short-sighted; Government's credibility remains as fragile as economy (M)

headline: Hughes to Buy A Satellite TV Competitor
abstract: Hughes Electronics Corp agrees to pay about $1.3 billion in cash and stock to buy United States Satellite Broadcasting Co, move aimed at fortifying Hughes' DirecTV unit as nation's leading provider of television programs transmitted directly to homes by satellite (M)

headline: America's Turn to Colonize; Credit Card Issuers Invade Britain, With U.S. Firepower
abstract: American credit card companies have invaded Great Britain with innovative marketing and by offering interest rates that are lower than the average rates of 22 and 23 percent charged by British issuers; John Eaton, managing director of Barclaycard, company that is still dominant issuer of cards in Britain, says industry has become 'battleground'; in past few years, Household International Inc of Illinois, MBNA, Delaware, People's Bank of Connecticut, American Express and Capital One Financial, Virginia, have captured 10.2 percent of cards issued in $136.7 billion market; chart on credit card issuers in Britain; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PROVIDIAN FINANCIAL CORP., -- San Francisco, a credit card company, agreed to buy 600,000 Bravo card customers and their $350 million in balances from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, for undisclosed terms.    PEGASUS COMMUNICATIONS CORP., -- Randor, Pa., a direct broadcast satellite, broadcast television and cable company, agreed to acquire five independent DirecTV providers for $27.8 million in cash and $4.3 million in notes and assumed debt.

headline: After Brief Trials, Outcome Uncertain for Dissidents in China
abstract: Separate trials in China of two prominent democracy advocates for inciting subversion of the state open and close quickly, with families of both defendants protesting their inability to hire defense lawyers; trial of Wang Youcai, 32-year-old founder of China Democracy Movement, now suppressed, is held in eastern city of Hangzhou; trial of Qin Yongmin, 45-year-old veteran dissident, is held in central city of Wuhan (S)

headline: Hearing Aids: Smaller and Smarter
abstract: Latest technology has made hearing aids much less obtrusive and much more helpful than earliest models; modern devices fit surreptitiously behind or into ear while augmenting sound coming in; digital hearing aids use power of computer chips, or microprocessors, to manipulate incoming sound to amplify specific frequencies that user is having trouble hearing; this feature, called equalization control, was rarely available with analog devices; drawings; charts (M)

headline: SOUTHERN TO BUY ORANGE AND ROCKLAND PLANTS
abstract: Southern Energy Inc unit of Southern Co will acquire all electric power plants of Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc in deal valued at $480 million (S)

headline: The New York Times Business Best Sellers
abstract: THIS MONTH / LAST MONTH

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As sales start at banks, hopes are high that the Japanese will, at last, learn to like mutual funds.
abstract: Japanese banks and insurance companies begin selling mutual funds as part of nation's closely watched effort to deregulate its financial markets; join brokerage firms in push to draw more of personal savings out of bank deposits and into riskier investments (M)

headline: FINANCE MINISTERS AGREE TO EXPLORE CLINTON I.M.F. PLAN
abstract: Finance ministers of world's largest industrial nations will explore Pres Clinton's proposal to alter IMF workings so it can intervene earlier to prop up economies in trouble; lukewarm agreement comes in vaguely-worded communique after meeting in Washington that appears to break little new ground on quelling world financial turmoil; US, Europe, Japan and emerging-market nations all have different strategies; Japan announces $30-billion Asian aid package; Treasury Sec Robert Rubin, in lukewarm reaction, suggests it is much more urgent for Japan to get its own banks in order and its huge economy restarted; Min Kiichi Miyazawa responds that Congress should approve $18 billion US has pledge to IMF (M)

headline: MGM SAYS IT WILL BUY POLYGRAM'S MOVIE LIBRARY
abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc will pay $250 million in cash to Seagram Co for most of Polygram NV's library of movies; struggling studio's Orion Pictures unit will pay $235 million of its own cash and $15 million from cash flow of Polygram Filmed Entertainment's movies; purchase will increase MGM's library by more than 1,300 films to about 5,200, including more than half of all Hollywood films produced since 1948 (S)

headline: Footwear Campaign To Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: Just For Feet Inc, athletic footwear retailer, Birmingham, Ala., names Rochester office of Saatchi & Saatchi as the first agency to handle advertising for national branding campaign, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Listed
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:  Columbia Bancorp, the Dalles, Ore., an initial public offering of 1 million shares. Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Decisions by U.S. and I.M.F. Worsened Asia's Problems, the World Bank Finds
abstract: World Bank report concludes that decision last year by International Monetary Fund and US Treasury to push Asian nations to send their interest rates soaring was crucial blunder that worsened world financial crisis; graph (M)

headline: Palestinians Denounce Arafat's Forces
abstract: Hundreds of Palestinian youths, denouncing Palestinian security chiefs as agents of CIA, marched through streets of Ramallah on West Bank, protesting killing of teen-ager by Palestinian police; killing occurred when military intelligence officers fired on demonstrators protesting weapons search at local headquarters of Al Fatah, movement founded by Yasir Arafat (M)

headline: Linking the Computer and the World, the Clever Modem
abstract: Workings of a computer modem and the advances that have led to today's fastest modems explained; drawing (M)

headline: Rejection of Arthritis Therapy Hurts Stock
abstract: Anika Therapeutics Inc's shares plunge after Food and Drug Administration rejects it Orthovisc treatment for osteoarthritis for the knee (S)

headline: D.R. HORTON, HOME BUILDERS, APPOINTS KEY OFFICERS
abstract: D R Horton Inc promotes Donald J Tomnitz to vice chairman and chief executive and Richard Beckwitt to president; also says its board has approved buyback of up to $100 million common shares and up to $100 million of senior debt securities (S)

headline: Indonesia Panel to Study Reports Of Army Slayings in East Timor
abstract: Indonesia's human rights commission will probe charges that soldiers executed up to 50 people in East Timor earlier in November in military operation against armed rebels; International Committee of Red Cross says team it sent to area found no confirmation of large-scale atrocities; as many as 2,000 East Timorese students continue to occupy local parliament building, Dili, to protest alleged killings (M)

headline: Wrangling Over I.M.F. Bill at Fever Pitch
abstract: Clinton Administration and Congressional Republicans are working frantically on bill to give International Monetary Fund added $18 billion as fund seeks to avert global financial meltdown; agree money is urgently needed; debate curbs sought by conservatives on future lending by IMF, which has been criticized by both Republicans and Democrats for mismanaging global financial crisis (M)

headline: Tempting the Inner Child
abstract: Mary Theresa Weil, executive-floor receptionist at T Rowe Price, mutual fund company, says many of most important leaders of corporate America cannot resist playing with ball of 26,000 rubber bands on her desk (S)

headline: Time Out, at 30, Plots for Further Expansion
abstract: Time Out magazine is celebrating its 30th anniversary; founder, Tony Elliott, considered putting magazine on Internet to mark anniversary, but shelved idea because of $1.6 million cost; discusses magazine's future; photos (M)

headline: Network Has Less Glitz, Fewer Glitches
abstract: Rachel Lehmann-Haupt evaluates Net Radio Network's Internet offering (www.netradio.com); photo (S)

headline: Crane Vows to Press For Coltec Takeover
abstract: Crane Company will press unsolicited bid for Coltec Industries, despite company's $1.3 billion deal with B F Goodrich (S)

headline: JETS SAID TO AVOID POISON GAS SITES
abstract: Pentagon officials say US and British forces are taking care to avoid hitting Iraqi factories suspected of producing chemical and biological weapons; say that damage at military, intelligence and communications targets has been extensive; say strikes avoided plants out of fear of unleashing plumes of poisons and killing civilians; say attack, which represents Pres Clinton's biggest military operation, appeared to surprise Iraqis, who had done little to disperse troops or weapons; Defense Sec William S Cohen and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chmn Henry H Shelton outline mission intended to weaken Saddam Hussein's Government and military, including missile sites and bases central to launching chemical or biological weapons; map; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Voss of Norway to Frierson Mee & Kraft as first agency to handle advertising for Voss bottled water brand in US; billings estimated at $6 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   4.87   4.80   5.76        3-month T-bills   3.97   3.98   5.00        6-month T-bills   4.09   4.02   5.17        10-yr. T-infl.   3.61   3.62   3.60        10-yr. T-note   4.56   4.57   6.12        30-yr. headline: Where's the Bottom? It May Not Be Here Yet
abstract: Continuing stock market bearishness noted as technical stocks continue to decline (S)

headline: Livent Gets $5 Million From Board
abstract: Some of Livent Inc's wealthy board members lend company, which declared bankruptcy on November 18, $5 million--enough to keep it operating for 10 days; company is seeking loans of tens of millions of dollars more to pay salaries and other expenses while it reorganizes its finances (S)

headline: MIDEAST  MEETING WILL BE CONTINUED INTO ANOTHER DAY
abstract: Peace talks between Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat continue past original October 18 deadline at Wye Conference Center in Maryland, despite more than 20 hours of personal engagement by Pres Clinton; overall mood is called serious; US officials remain optimistic; Israeli official reports progress on different issues, including security, but no complete agreement on any major issues, specifically Israel's withdrawal from more of West bank and commitment from Palestinians to change their charter, which calls for destruction of Israel; photo (M)

headline: Women Want It All, and It's All on Line
abstract: Women are fast closing Web gender gap and variety of Internet sites are springing up to capture female audience; women 50 and older are one of fastest-growing populations on line, and women now make up almost half of all Internet users in US; several sites noted; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Campaign for Bragging Rights on Wall Street
abstract: Lobbying that shapes legislation or precedes Academy Awards pales when compared with anguished phone calls made by some of Wall Street's biggest firms this week as they battle for pre-eminence in annual ranking of most influential deal makers; preliminary figures, expected to be released on Dec 31, are to investment bankers what Hollywood's gold statuettes are to actors: basis for bragging rights to market their genius as well as command lucrative fees from clients; league tables, as they are called, are compiled by Securities Data Company of Newark and are little known beyond Wall Street; but figures sway corporate execs to pick one rainmaker over another to advise on their next merger; bankers who advise companies on mergers and acquisitions are ranked, among other things, by dollar value of all announced and completed deals they worked on; this year, Goldman, Sachs beat the competition, ahead of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Merrill Lynch (M)

headline: Communication Satellites in Peril as Cosmic Storm Approaches
abstract: Implications of possible damage to any of some 600 communications satellites discussed as Earth is about to experience meteor storm in debris-strewn backwash of comet Temple-Tuttle; Ian H Rowe, chief executive of Crestech, nonprofit group that will track storm for Canada and United States, notes lesser meteor shower damaged satellite in 1993; AT&T Corp says there are at least 14 nations, mostly in Eastern Europe and former Soviet Union, that can be reached by phone only by satellite; most of satellite industry sees little threat; diagrams (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: THOMAS & BETTS CORP.,  Memphis, a producer of connectors and components for the electronics market worldwide, said it planned to buy Ocal Inc., Van Nuys, Calif., for $20.3 million in stock.    TRINITY INDUSTRIES,  Dallas, a maker of rail cars, marine and construction products, acquired MCT Holding Inc., Pittsburgh, a maker of casting products for the rail car industry. The price was not disclosed.

headline: Go Cheap Or Buy The Best?
abstract: Advice on shopping for personal computer, especially for first-time PC buyer (M)

headline: Pierre Trudeau's Youngest Son Believed Killed in Avalanche
