abstract: Michel Trudeau, 23, youngest son of former Canadian Prime Min Pierre Trudeau, is swept into mountain lake by avalanche in British Columbia and is presumed drowned (M)

headline: K-Tel Asset Plan Approved
abstract: K-Tel International Inc's board approves plan to issue equity to meet $4 million tangible-assets requirement for listing on Nasdaq stock market (S)

headline: MERCK PROFIT INCREASED BY 14% IN THIRD QUARTER
abstract: Merck & Co says profit rose 14 percent in third quarter; net income increased to $1.37 billion from $1.2 billion a year earlier (S)

headline: Wax Museum Sold to British Buyout Firm
abstract: Tussauds Group, wax-museum operator that plans to open exhibits in New York and Las Vegas over next two years, has new owner; Pearson PLC sells Tussauds to Charterhouse Development Capital for 352 million pounds, or $598 million, in cash and debt; Pearson will receive additional 25 million pounds if Charterhouse can sell bonds backed by Tussauds' income; photo (M)

headline: Markets and Economy Alike Come Off Adrenaline Highs
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, addressing Securities Industry Assn, predicts calming of stock market turmoil (S)

headline: The Annual Dance Around Capital Gains
abstract: Pros and cons of selling mutual fund whose value has fallen in 1998 before its distribution date (S)

headline: Germany's New Face: Age 22, at Threshold of Change
abstract: Carsten Schneider, 22, is about to become youngest politician ever to sit in German Parliament; he is from Erfurt, whose problems are common to many former East German towns; Schneider says one of his goals is to strengthen confidence of Germans from East, to get East German deputies to form bloc of their own, so they are not overrun; social market economic model that propelled Germany to post-World War II prosperity has begun to buckle under strain of exorbitant cost of unification and faced by more competitive global economy; photo; map (M)

headline: Accord Set For Syria And Turkey
abstract: Turkey and Syria sign accord to defuse crisis over Syrian support for guerrillas fighting for Kurdish homeland in southeastern Turkey; Syria agrees to bar military, logistic or financial aid; Turkey also sought expulsion of guerrlla leader Abdullah Ocalan, whose whereabouts are unclear (M)

headline: Conflicting Signals on Corporate Earnings
abstract: Most closely watched firms that collect Wall Street earnings forecasts, IBES International and First Call Corp, are giving distinctly different signals about how fourth-quarter profits will shake out when earnings announcements are made early next year; IBES expects overall operating profits will fall five-tenths of 1 percent in fourth quarter, but First Call expects 4.5 percent growth in earnings in quarter; main difference seems to be how each firm compares current quarter with previous one; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent account changes (S)

headline: Trading System Fails On Tokyo Exchange
abstract: Tokyo Stock Exchange's futures and options trading system fails for second successive day as programming error shuts down trading in last minute of business (S)9

headline: Wallwork Curry Adds a Partner
abstract: Wallwork Curry changes its name to Wallwork Curry Sandler to reflect appointment of Rick Sandler as partner and president; Sandler succeeds Maureen McNamara, who resigned (S)

headline: A Nostalgic Hong Kong Gives Old Governor a Big Welcome
abstract: Christopher Patten, last Governor of Hong Kong, returns to former British colony to promote his new book, East and West: China, Power and the Future of Asia; thousands of people line up at bookstores to buy copies signed by Patten--with many bursting into cheers when he appears (M)

headline: A Net Builder Who Loved Invention, Not Profit
abstract: Tribute to late Jonathan B Postel, pioneering researcher whot helped build foundations of Internet; photo (M)

headline: American Mines Traded In South African Deal
abstract: Anglogold Ltd of South Africa agrees to acquire North and South American gold assets of Minorco SA for $550 million; two companies are controlled by South African mining and investment conglomerate Anglo American Corp (S)

headline: Iraqi Cultural Elite Pine for Old Days
abstract: Iraq's one-time cultural elite suffer from crushing economic sanctions; several sophisticated professionals blame United States for destroying their way of life and shredding prospects of entire generation, interviews (M)

headline: Welcome Wagon to Make Its Visits Via Post Office
abstract: Welcome Wagon, which since 1920, used mostly women to sell products door-to-door, is ending practice in testament to changing life styles or perhaps traditional corporate desire to cut costs; Cendant Corp, owner of Welcome Wagon, is dismissing most of its 2,200 representatives and will replace them with direct marketing through mail; photo (M)

headline: It's Glossy and Flashy, A Vietnam Must-Read: FOR WOMEN IN ASIA, A NEW ERA STILL RAISES QUESTIONS
abstract: HO CHI MINH CITY—  The runaway success of a recently launched Western-style women's magazine has government officials here lamenting a moral decline and has raised accusations of illegal foreign investment, but Vietnamese women just can't get enough of Phu Nu.

headline: Kisangani Journal; Where War Is Forever, the Diamonds Are Cheap
abstract: Rebellion in Congo has been hard on diamond businesses in Kisangani; dealers say prices used to be fairly uniform when telephones worked and they could call brokers in other cities or countries; now there is no way to get in touch with outside world; with lack of foreign buyers, dealers are stockpiling what they buy, waiting for latest war to be over; meanwhile, rebels are thought to be buying up diamonds, presumably to help finance war; photo; map (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    TUESDAY     BankAtlantic Banc    Browning-Ferris    Brush-Wellman Inc    General Dynamics     St Joe

headline: Public Anger In Moscow Is Tempered In Private
abstract: Russian Government's public expressions of outrage at US bombing of Iraq and the recall of its Ambassador from Washington are tempered in private by Russian officials (M)

headline: Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Insider-Trade Case
abstract: Craig Ryan Spradling, former associate of New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, pleads guilty, US District Court, NY, to insider trading for misusing confidential information about one of firm's clients just a month after he was hired; Spradling says he made $48,000 illegally by buying securities of Loctite Corp in 1996, shortly before company received takeover bid from Henkel KGaA of Germany; Cleary Gottlieb was advising Henkel; Cleary had assigned Spradling to help draft documents for combination (S)

headline: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS IN $65 MILLION DEAL FOR MICRODYNE
abstract: L-3 Communications Holdings will acquire Microdyne Corp for $65.5 million (S)

headline: Deciphering a Scribble
abstract: Cliff Crouch letter, responding to Oct 1 article, decries cartoon depiction of Newton computer and impact on device

headline: 2 NATO Generals to Warn Milosevic of Air Raids
abstract: NATO ambassadors in Brussels order top military generals, Gen Wesley Clark of US and Gen Klaus Naumann of Germany, to Belgrade to again warn Pres Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that he faces air strikes unless his troops withdraw from Kosovo province or return to barracks by October 27; Serbian attacks against ethnic Albanian villages persist, preventing tens of thousands of refugees from returning home, despite earlier agreement to withdraw; photo (M)

headline: Social Security's Fate
abstract: Sidney R Katz letter agrees with November 1 article on Social Security reforms (S)

headline: U.S. Lawyer A Champion Of Victims In Rwanda
abstract: Pierre-Richard Prosper discusses his decision to give up comfortable lawyer's life in Los Angeles to work in Tanzania for UN war-crimes tribunal; Prosper has become first prosecutor to get genocide verdict involving killings in Rwanda in 1994, and he also persuaded judges to include rape among crmes constituting genocide; 35-year-old son of Haitian immigrants lived in New York and later worked for Los Angeles district attorney's office prosecuting gang members (S)

headline: Merwin F. Kaminstein, 63, Retail Executive
abstract: Merwin F Kaminstein, former retail executive, dies at age 63 (S)

headline: German Giants Spinning Off Big Businesses
abstract: Streamlining of corporate Germany, which has been under way for several years, has accelerated with recent announcements by Siemens AG, Viag AG and Metro AG to spin off huge chunks of their empires, which employ tens of thousands of people; three companies do not necessarily add up to trend and each company is motivated by different reasons, but analysts say revamping reflects growing pressure on European conglomerates to shed businesses that drag down overall profit as well as effects of global competition; until recently, most of restructuring in German industry has been accomplished through cost-cutting (M)

headline: Another Big Day for Issues Connected to the Internet
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 8.76 points, to 9,226.75; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 0.8 points, to 1.225.49; Nasdaq composite index rises 17.27 points, to 2,180.30; graph; tables (M)

headline: EMI Operating Profit Down 22% in First Half
abstract: EMI Group PLC reports profit from operations for first half of fiscal year ended September 30 fell 22 percent, compared with year-earlier period, to $65.9 million (S)

headline: F.C.C. Fines Brittan for Phone Slamming
abstract: Federal Communications Commission fines Brittan Communications International Corp $1.12 million for illegally switching consumers' long-distance phone service (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; It's still early, but chip makers may be turning things around.
abstract: Market Place column on some recent positive signs in beleaguered semiconductor industry; notes that Intel Corp projected increased sales for third quarter, Advanced Micro Devices Inc reported surprise return to profitability, and Motorola projected new growth; says most analysts expect more positive signs in December quarter, but substantial caveats remain since growth these companies are reporting is relative to severely depressed numbers of recent quarters (M)

headline: Place 'to Make A Little Noise'
abstract: Internet site Black Voices (www.blackvoices.com) offers something for everyone, including news of current events about blacks, specific clubs and activities, cooking and many other subjects (M)

headline: IN MY... BAG: BOBBI BROWN
abstract: Makeup artist and new mom Bobbi Brown describes what she carries in her bag; photos (S)

headline: Top Sweden Ferry Line To Eliminate 800 Jobs
abstract: Stena Line AB, to cut 800 jobs in its Nordic operations in effort to shrink costs (S)

headline: Bad Faith Is Charged as Talks With Mexican Rebels Open
abstract: Current talks between Zapatista rebels and mediators are not going well; there is no sign of peace between Mexican Government and rebels in Chiapas, and little reason to hope for settlment any time soon; map; photo (M)

headline: Yes, Even a Bill Collector Can File for Bankruptcy
abstract: Profile of Commercial Financial Services, Tulsa, Okla, company that specializes in collecting delinquent credit card accounts, which recently filed for bankruptcy; company's founder, William R Bartman, who received this years's Oklahoma Venture of the Year Award, his wife Kathryn and company's other co-founder, Jay Jones, have all resigned; publicly, Tulsa business leaders express confidence company will solve its problems; photo (M)

headline: Dow Back Above 9,000 on Expectations of Fed Rate Cut
abstract: Stock prices rise on hopes that the Federal Reserve Board will lower interest rates at its policy-making meeting; Dow Jones industrial average closes up 91.66, to 9,011.25; Standard & Poor's 500 stock index gains 10.15. to 1,135.87; Nasdaq composite index gains 13.69 to 1,861.68; Russell 2000 index gains 1.06 to 390.42; graph; chart on some stocks with large price percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: And the Winners Are . . .
abstract: Newsletter Director's Alert publishes list of America's top ten directors as ranked by more than 100 other directors; list (S)

headline: Workbook Is Powerful, Methodical
abstract: Quicken Financial Planner from Intuit assessed (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of Dec 10 article on dance instruction on line regarding Web address of one site (S)

headline: Media; A Year of Living Dangerously
abstract: UPN, though struggling, has no plans to go out of television network business; its affilated stations are grumbling about 40 percent drop in viewers, but have few options; network desperately needs some hit shows, but studios reportedly are wary of development deals with UPN for now; graph; photo (M)

headline: Japanese Sales Were Inflated, U.S. Medical Company Says
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp says its Japanese subsidiary improperly inflated sales by millions of dollars of a medical device, used in patients with heart problems, that it was forced to recall last month; Food and Drug Administration is investigating whether Boston Scientific should have notified Federal regulators before it changed its method of manufacturing the device, known as a stent; company executives say routine internal review detected that subsidiary reported $40 million to $50 million in sales of inventory to distributors that were not true sales; chief financial officer Larry Best says subsidiary may have overstated sales in earlier years by further $40 million; two executives in charge of company's Japanese operations have offered to resign (M)

headline: Levi Strauss begins a far-reaching marketing campaign to reach gay men and lesbians.
abstract: Levi Strauss & Co, intensifying its efforts to reach younger, more fashion-conscious consumers, is embarking on its most ambitious marketing campaign aimed at gay men and lesbians (M)

headline: An Insurance Benefit You May Never See
abstract: National Assn of Insurance Commissioners requests that Society of Actuaries update tables to reflect Americans' longer life spans (S)

headline: Korean Conglomerate Proposes a Bailout Deal
abstract: Ssangyong Group asks creditor to bail out its two construction companies to avert bankruptcy; in exchange, company will sell Ssangyong Oil Refining Co, one of its most profitable businesses, and cement-making operations of Ssangyong Cement Industrial Co, as well as other assets by first half of next year (S)

headline: DAYTON HUDSON MAY SELL OR SPIN OFF MERVYN'S STORES
abstract: The Dayton Hudson Corporation may get rid of its Mervyn's unit, a chain of 269 department stores selling midpriced merchandise, unless Mervyn's improves sales in 12 to 18 months. Dayton Hudson, the fifth-largest United States retailer, declined to say if it would sell or spin off Mervyn's, which accounts for about 15 percent of annual sales. Sales at Mervyn's stores open at least a year have fallen from totals at the same time last year. Analysts have been calling on Dayton Hudson to sell Mervyn's so that it can focus on expanding its highly profitable Target discount stores. Shares of Dayton Hudson, which is based in Minneapolis, rose $1.375 each, to $38.75.

headline: Media Edge Wins Fort James Account
abstract: Fort James Corp in in Norwalk, Conn, says it had ended a review by naming Media Edge in New York to handle media portion of its account (S)

headline: A New Electronic Paperback To Read on Planes and Trains
abstract: Librus Inc, Bellevue, Wash, to introduce this fall an electronic book, Millenium Reader, at cost of under $200; users will be able to go to Librius storefront on Internet, browse site and download encrypted texts to Reader; photo (S)

headline: A Farewell to Art
abstract: Retired Neiman Marcus chairman Stanley Marcus, 93, and wife, Linda, will sell their collection of Southwestern art at Sotheby's on December 2 (S)

headline: The New, Unsinkable Stock Options
abstract: Stock market analysts find that corporations are developing hair-trigger response to market dips as they relate to executive and employee stock options pricing; chart (M)

headline: Ruling Party In Iraq Bars Inspectors From Offices
abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein's Government bars inspectors from Baghdad city headquarters of his ruling Baath Party, barely two days into crucial round of surprise arms inspections in Iraq (M)

headline: A Well-Designed Heavyweight With a Taste for Disk Space
abstract: Appraisal of 1999 World Book Family Reference Suite; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Enlists Russians to Spot Nuclear Smuggling
abstract: United States, in effort to prevent nuclear weapons and materials from being smuggled out of Russia, announces plans to train Russian customs agents in identifying and arresting smugglers; US Customers Service plan includes training Russian agents at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Engergy Department's nuclear reservation in Paso, Wash (M)

headline: Shopping on the Web? No, Still Just Browsing
abstract: Two studies find that on-line retailing has still not caught on with American shoppers (S)

headline: Deadline Extended For Indonesian Banks
abstract: Indonesia agrees to extend deadline for banks to repay about 134 trillion rupiah, or roughly $16.7 billion, in emergency loans to four years (S)

headline: Fiercer Aetna Sets Its Sights On Dominating Health Care
abstract: Aetna Inc, which transformed itself in less than three years from an insurance giant known into hard-driving managed-care company, surprised industry insiders and investors by agreeing to buy ailing health care business of Prudential Insurance Co of America for $1 billion; seen making risky bet that it can dominate nation's health care system; new Aetna will have contracts with more than half nation's 500,000 practicing doctors outside the Government and role in determining medical care of 18.4 million Americans; photo; graph (M)

headline: For OPEC's Richest, Natural Allies of Size
abstract: Oil industry experts see Exxon Corp-Mobil Corp merger giving combined firm more leverage in dealings with Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries members, reversing OPEC's quarter-century of primacy in relationship; deal and British Petroleum's planned acquisiton of Amoco set stage for new partnerships with large oil-producing nations that could help stabilize prices, but could curtail search for oil in non-OPEC nations, where production is more costly (M)

headline: Air France Pilots Accept Rules on Stock Purchases
abstract: Biggest pilots' union at Air France agrees that pilots must buy at least 4 percent of airline's shares before they can win representation on its board, setting floor for level of equity participation deemed acceptable when state sells shares early next year (S)

headline: Yeltsin, Back in Hospital, Meets China Leader
abstract: Russia's Pres Boris Yeltsin, after six weeks of labored effort to rebound from bronchitis, develops high fever and pneumonia; is again hospitalized at Moscow's Central Clinic Hospital, where he meets with China's visiting Pres Jiang Zemin; clinic stay is his fifth since bypass heart surgery in 1996 (M)

headline: GE Capital And Goldman Buy Thai Debt
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group Inc, in conjunction with GE Capital Corp, agrees to pay 23.6 billion baht ($645 million) for about third of loans left over from Thailand's unsuccessful auction of assets seized from defunct financial companies; will pay 21 percent of face value for loans, most backed by land and buildings; agrees to drop any contracts made before auction with original debtors seeking to buy back their loans at steep discount; will pay more if recovery rate hits set level; two Thai companies revise offers and pay combined 3.7 billion baht, 26 percent of face value, for two other lots of loans (M)

headline: Business Travel; U.S. airlines are in a bit of a dust-up over 'sizers' for passengers' carry-on luggage.
abstract: Business travel news roundup; many airlines are drawing harder line against oversized carry-on luggage; Continental Airlines, bucking trend, has installed bigger overhead bins in planes and seeks to block United Airlines from using baggage 'sizers' at airport security checkpoints that also serve Continental; World Tourism Organization study finds leisure time is likely to decline for many people, accelerating trend to shorter, more frequent vacations (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Corn prices weaken on expectations that warm, dry weather this weekend in the Midwest will lead to bumper crop and ample supply; December contract falls 2.5 cents, to $2.1875 a bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: TRW MAY SPLIT ITS AUTO AND SPACE BUSINESSES
abstract: TRW Inc may split its automotive business from its space and military unit as a way to increase company's ailing stock price (S)

headline: Intel Gets a Think3 Stake
abstract: Intel Corp buys undisclosed minority stake in Think3 Inc, maker of computer-aided design software (S)3

headline: Big Problem, Big Problems: Getting to Work on Global Warming
abstract: Time is running out on resolving conflicts that stand in way of implementing 1997 Kyoto agreement on cutting emissions of gases that are believed responsible for global warming; outline of chief problems and possible solutions (M)

headline: Ford Introduces Sport Utility-Pickup Truck
abstract: Ford Motor Co's Lincoln luxury division introduces combination sport utility-pickup truck, the Blackwood, as part of effort to lure younger buyers and perdict evolution of light-truck market (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CORNERSTONE CONSTRUCTION AND MATERIALS INC.,  Neptune, N.J., a unit of Hanson P.L.C., acquired the 50 percent of Gifford Hill-American Holdings Inc. it did not already own from Ameron International Corp., Pasadena, Calif., for $28.5 million in cash and debt.    BEACON FIDUCIARY ADVISORS INC.,  Boston, a money management firm, agreed to buy Constitution Management Co., another Boston-based money management company, for undisclosed terms.

headline: COVENTRY HEALTH WILL SELL FLORIDA UNIT FOR $95 MILLION
abstract: Coventry Health Care Inc to sell its Principal Health Care of Florida unit to Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida for $95 million (S)

headline: Spy Agencies' Ex-Analyst Charged With Selling Secrets to Soviets
abstract: A former code-breaking analyst at the top-secret National Security Agency was charged today with spying for Moscow for the last three years of the Soviet Union's existence.    David Sheldon Boone, a 46-year-old former enlisted man who worked for both Army intelligence and the N.S.A. during his 21-year Army career, was arrested by F.B.I. agents on Saturday at an airport hotel outside Washington, and made an initial appearance today in Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va. The Government charged that from 1988 until 1991, Mr. Boone passed top secret documents to a K.G.B. officer he knew as ''Igor,'' revealing, among other things, what the United States knew about the capabilities of Soviet tactical nuclear weapons. In return, he was paid more than $60,000 by the K.G.B., the Government said.

headline: U.S. Still Unsure on Northwest-Continental Deal
abstract: Antitrust talks between Justice Department and Northwest Airlines end inconclusively, with lawyers for airline unable to overcome Clinton Administration's objections to Northwest's bid to buy controlling stake in Continental Airlines (M)

headline: Mubarak Visits Syria in Effort To Defuse Crisis With Turkey
abstract: Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, in sign of Arab concern over growing tensions between Turkey and Syria, flies to Syria in effort to defuse potential crisis in Middle East; Turkey has accused Syria of harboring Kurdish rebels, who have been fighting for self-rule in southeastern Turkey (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Robert H. Perkins; Berger Small Cap Value Fund
abstract: Profile of Berger Small Cap Value Fund manager Robert H Perkins, 58, who forecasts rebound in small-cap stocks; photos; graph; chart (M)

headline: FEDERAL-MOGUL TO SELL STOCK TO CUT DEBT IN COOPER DEAL
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp will sell 14 million shares of stock to raise $703.5 million; will use proceeds to reduce debt (S)

headline: Chinese Enterprise Makes Bond Payment
abstract: Guangdong Enterprises (Holdings) Ltd, whose financial arm was shut down by Chinese Govt in October after defaulting on $2 billion in debts, makes coupon payment of almost $22.2 million on $500 million 10-year Yankee bond due 2007 (S)

headline: Service Takes a Holiday; These Days the Customer Isn't Always Treated Right
abstract: Customer service is becoming oxymoron at retail stores nationwide, falling victim to stiff competition that has forced retailers to cut costs by reducing staffs; University of Michigan survey of 200,000 shoppers finds increasing dissatisfaction with customer service provided by retailers, with rate of satisfaction far below what is was in 1994; rare exception is Container Store, Dallas-based chain where employees are trained to think of themselves as counselors or problem-solvers; manufacturer of storage products and closet organizers considers customer service a 'core competency' and not just frill; trains salespeople for 185 hours first year, compared industry average of below 10, and often hires its best customers; photos; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Cotton prices fall steeply amid speculation that poor quality of the smallest crop in nine years will lead to few buyers; cotton for December delivery falls 1.98 cents, to 63.58 cents a pound (S)

headline: KING HUSSEIN JOINS TALKS ON MIDEAST AS OPTIMISM RISES
abstract: Optimism rises that Israel and Palestinians will reach some kind of settlement as Jordan's King Hussein joins Pres Clinton at talks; Americans and Palestinians are pressing for comprehensive interim accord, clearing way for final round of peace talks, while Israelis have suggested possibility of partial accord; Clinton meets separately with Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel before the three dine together; State Sec Madeleine K Albright then meets with Arafat while Clinton meets with Netanyahu; Hussein also meets with Arafat and Netanyahu; photo (M)

headline: After a 7-Year Summer, Economic Leaves Turn
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, addressing group of economists, contends US economic outlook has weakened measurably; J P Morgan economists warn of recession in 1999 (S)

headline: Classic Responses to the Big Crash
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column reports that the crash of her Micron Millenia computer and her husband's ability to fix it brought home to her the fact that to love computers means to love the process of computing, not just the things you can do with them; drawing (M)

headline: In Mideast, Clinton Appears To Put the Issue Out of Mind
abstract: Pres Clinton, during his Mideast mission, is seen able to insulate his political woes back home from his peace mission; Sen Arlen Specter, who accompanies Clinton on his trip, declares 'He's boring in. It may well be that his collateral problems are giving him more motivation for success here'; Pres, Mrs Clinton and Chelsea Clinton visit Bethlehem with Yasir Arafat and his wife, Suha; Clinton visits Masada with Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and his wife, Sara; photo of Clinton; map (M)

headline: Keeping Internet Safe For Young Chatters
abstract: Bill Teel describes his job of monitoring Headbone Zone (www.headbone,com), a chat room for children 8 to 14, which is run out of a former grange headquarters in downtown Seattle; his rules for protecting confidentiality of children using site as well as his curbs on type of talk allowed on site noted; Teel photo (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS with ANTHONY MAZZOCCHI; Rebuilding a Platform For the American Worker
abstract: Steven Greenhouse interviews Labor Party leader Anthony Mazzocchi, who comments on party goals and platforms; photo (M)

headline: Fedex Pilots Union Announces A Tentative Pact With Company
abstract: Pilots union at Federal Express reaches tentative agreement on labor contract that would improve pay and work schedules (M)

headline: 2 Dutch Pension Funds Are Branching Out
abstract: ABP and PGGM, two biggest Dutch pension fund managers, agree to pay 3.6 billion guilders ($1.9 billion) for control of Netherlands' Nationale Investeringsbank NV (S)

headline: APOLLO TAKES 20% STAKE IN BERLITZ FOR $100 MILLION
abstract: Berlitz International Inc, world's biggest language-services company, says that a Leon Black buyout fund will invest $100 million for 20 percent stake and that its largest shareholder, Benesse Holdings International Inc, will invest $55 million to help company expand; under agreement, Berlitz will issue $100 million of convertible debentures to Apollo Management IV (S)

headline: Allied Signal Case Back to Lower Court
abstract: Allied Signal says Federal appeals court haa given jurisdiction over the company's attempt to expand the board of AMP Inc with its own directors back to a district court judge; expects judge to lift preliminary injunction that barred board election (S)

headline: Sidi Saye Journal; The Thirsty Lift a Glass To a River And Qaddafi
abstract: Sidi Saye marks end point of Libya's Great Man-Made River, $25 billion project that is delivering vast quantities of fresh water hundreds of miles across barren desert to residents of nation's parched coast; project is dream of Libyan leader Col Muammar el-Qaddafi; it is believed to be largest civil engineering project under construction; map; photo (M)

headline: Canada Agrees to Reduce Barriers Against U.S. Farm Products
abstract: Canada, moving to head off border blockade by angry American farmers, agrees to lower barriers to United States farm exports but not to cut its own meat and grain exports; pledges, after months of talks involving trade and agriculture officials, to let US farmers export grain by rail more easily, to revise health rules on imported livestock and to end burdensome testing requirments for wheat disease; American farm leaders call for end to blockade threat (M)

headline: OFFICIALS PREDICT HURRICANE'S TOLL WILL EXCEED 7,000
abstract: Rescue workers throughout Central America struggle to reach scores of remote peasant settlements left battered and isolated by Hurricane Mitch as authorities in Nicaragua and Honduras predict combined death toll may exceed 7,000; focus of Nicaraguan rescue efforts is Posoltega region, located at foot of Casitas volcano, 50 miles northwest of capital of Managua, where 800 people are confirmed dead in mudslides and at least 2,000 are reported missing; Pres Carlos Flores Facusse, in grim television address, describes 'panorama of death, desolation and ruin' throughout entire country; numerous deaths and widespread damage to property and crops also reported in El Salvador and Guatemala; photos; map (M)

headline: Big Banks Cut Prime Rate
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp, Citicorp, Nationsbank Corp and some other big US banks lower prime rate to 8.25 percent, from 8.50 percent (S)

headline: Business Travel; Frequent-flier plans are expected to look more alike next year, and miles may no longer expire.
abstract: Randy Petersen, publisher of Inside Flyer magazine, says 1999 will bring less variety among US airlines' frequent-flier programs and disappearance of miles that expire; Federal Aviation Administration emergency order issued last week, affecting fuel storage in Boeing 747's, will not force operators of these planes to change their flight patterns, despite initial reports to the contrary; Budget Rent-a-Car will start renting electric vehicles this week at its Los Angeles International Airport location; cars, offered in conjunction with EV Rental Cars, will be available at special daily rate of $39.95 through early February (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Spain Making Contact With Basque Rebels
abstract: Spain's Prime Minister, Jose Maria Aznar, authorizes Govt to talk with people close to leading Basque guerrilla group to test trustworthiness of rebels, who recently announced indefinite cease-fire; has said that peace talks cannot be held directly with rebel group until it permanently renounces violence (M)

headline: Textron Names New Chairman
abstract: Textron Inc names its chief executive, Lewis Campbell, its new chairman effective on Feb 1, replacing James Hardymon, who is retiring (S)9

headline: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY TO EXPAND PLANT CAPACITY
abstract: Carpenter Technology Corp will invest $113.6 million to expand its Pennsylvania melt shop and add finishing capacity at its Talley Metals Inc plant in South Carolina (S)

headline: Hedge Fund Seeks Buyer or Partner for a Major Part of Its Business
abstract: D E Shaw & Co, big New York hedge fund and broker, is seeking partner or buyer for its stock-related trading business; unit, part of broad strategic alliance with BankAmerica Corp, collapsed in October when BankAmerica announced that it had lost $372 million in bond trading venture with Shaw; move indicates shakeout in hedge funds continues despite resurgent markets (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Taped Gates Testimony Shown at Microsoft Trial  In two hours of videotaped questioning shown at the Microsoft antitrust trial, William H. Gates, the chairman of the company, professed ignorance of several key charges in the Government's suit, including allegations that he was involved in plans to bully competitors like Apple Computer and Netscape Communications to step back from Internet software markets that Microsoft sought to dominate.

headline: Rome Journal; American Blondes Bumble to Top of Italian TV
abstract: Tall, blonde American actresses are among wave of American stars, most speaking fractured Italian with heavy American accent, of Italian TV variety shows; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Intel Outlook Bodes Well For the Sector
abstract: Intel Corporation's announcement that its fourth-quarter results will exceed Wall Street estimates not only bolstered its stock to a new high, but analysts say it bodes well for a broad range of technology stocks, particularly those tied to personal computer (Market Place column) (M)

headline: 2 Asian Tigers Gird for Battle to Get Lion's Share of Financial Trading
abstract: HONG KONG—  A battle is intensifying between two of Asia's largest financial centers as a rapidly liberalizing Singapore and an increasingly interventionist Hong Kong seek to gain the upper hand in lucrative financial sector trading.

headline: Baan Shares Tumble After It Forecasts Loss
abstract: Stock of Baan Co NV falls more than 27 percent after company unexpectedly predicts loss for the quarter (S)

headline: Markets Battered, Then Bolstered
abstract: Week's stock market performance reviewed; Dow Jones industrial average closed down 3.3 percent for week, at 9,016.14; European stocks also fell; graphs of stocks in news; tables (M)

headline: Mac, Windows And Now, Linux
abstract: Linux operating system, developed in 1991 by Linus Torvalds, student at University of Helsinki, is becoming more popular, especially among technically savvy computer users; beginners and those technically faint of heart are better served by staying with Windows or Macintosh; interest in Linux system has come largely through Internet-based newsgroups and mailing lists around the world; Linux loyalists say operating system is simply better than Windows; major benefit of Linux is that all information surrounding it is completely open, even its source code, which means anyone can customize it or improve the system; photo of computer screen display of Linux format (L)

headline: SERVICEMASTER IN STOCK AND DEBT DEAL FOR LANDCARE
abstract: Servicemaster Co to buy Landcare USA Inc for more than $250 million in stock and assumed debt and will combine acquisition with its Trugreen-Chemlawn unit (S)

headline: Jean Crockett, 79, First Woman To Lead the Philadelphia Fed
abstract: Jean Andrus Crockett, first chairwoman of Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and first chairwoman of finance department at Wharton School of University of Pennsylvania, dies at 79; photo (S)

headline: ALLIANT FOODSERVICE SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 1,200 WORKERS
abstract: Alliant Foodservice Inc, one of largest closely held United States food service distributors, says that it will lay off up to 1,200 workers, or 10 percent of its work force, in attempt to deliver food at 'lower costs and higher value' (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Interbrand Group, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group, acquired Avalos & Bourse Communicacion Visual, Buenos Aires, which will be renamed Interbrand Avalos & Bourse. Terms were not disclosed.  * Ogilvy One Worldwide, New York, a unit of WPP Group P.L.C., acquired Marcom, Warsaw. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: J.A.L. President Sees Fall in First-Half Profit
abstract: Japan Airlines Co president Isao Kaneko says first-half operating profit will be lower than expected because of decline in sales attributed to Japan's weak economy (S)

headline: The Other Shotgun In an Oil Marriage?
abstract: Herbert Schmertz, former Mobil public affairs vice president, jokingly cites his success in making Mobil seem bigger than it was in relation to Exxon as factor in planned merger of oil giants; photo (M)

headline: To the Beat of the Business Meeting
abstract: James Schembari discusses dance piece satirizing business meetings, featuring businessmen from Greenwich, Conn, that will be presented at benefit for Peter Pucci Plus Dancers; photo (M)

headline: Primark-Dow Jones Pact
abstract: Primark Corp to buy Dow Jones & Co Edgar Direct unit for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Hyundai Group to Close 25 of Its Companies
abstract: Hyundai Group, South Kore's largest industrial group, to shut down about 25 of its 62 companies by mid-1999 as part of its efforts to focus on its most profitable business lines (S)

headline: Ho! Ho! Ho! Boohoo-hoo!
abstract: The holiday season seems to bring out the best and the worst in bosses. We've all heard stories about workers who are fired on Christmas Eve, but then again, Scrooge himself ended up giving the long-suffering Bob Cratchit a raise. What holiday horror stories have emerged from your workplace? Or, to give the management world's guardian angels their due, how have the holidays melted the coldest corporate hearts? Send your anecdotes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    PAKISTAN: TALKS WITH INDIA ON KASHMIR -- For the first time since India and Pakistan conducted nuclear tests in May, their Foreign Ministers met in Islamabad to discuss ways of easing military tensions in the region and resolving their conflict over the disputed territory of Kashmir. Little of substance was expected to emerge from the three days of talks, but a Pakistani spokesman described a productive day of negotiations while the Foreign Ministers, K. Ragunath of India and Shamshad Ahmed of Pakistan, looked on without commenting.   Celia Dugger (NYT)

headline: Dow Drops 33.98 Points, but Technology Shares Surge
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average fells 33.98 points, to close at 8,863.98; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips 1.94 points, to 1,128.26; Nasdaq composite index gains 4.57 points, to 1,865.62; graph; chart (M)

headline: And the Winner Is . . . The Money Market?
abstract: Investors are beginning to pay attention to their money market funds, which currently are garnering better results than stocks; chart (M)

headline: Families Mix Vacations And Holidays To Build Ties
abstract: More familes are coming to discover that togetherness at Christmas is not something necessarily confined to the home and are now traveling to distant places or taking cruises; while holiday decorations in cities such as New York, Boston and Chicago have long lured vacationers, smaller cities are eagerly trying to lure tourist dollars and hotels are seeking to fill rooms during what has traditionally been slow season by assembling packages tied to Christmas travel; some familes comment on their experiences of vacationing during Christmas; photo (L)

headline: Monitors Call Nigerian Vote Fair, With Room to Improve
abstract: Officials who monitored Nigeria's local Government elections say, despite widespread logistical problems, voting was fair and is positive step toward presidential elections in February 1999; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar surges against Japanese yen on talk that Tokyo's plan to strengthen troubled banking system will not take effect soon; dollar rises to 116.83 yen in New York, from 114.28 on Sept 19; graph; chart (S)

headline: J. Reese Phifer, 82, Founder Of Aluminum Screen Empire
abstract: J Reese Phifer, founder of Phifer Wire Products Inc, aluminum screen company that dominates industry, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: Citigroup Says It Will Cut 10,400 Jobs
abstract: Citigroup plans to eliminate about 10,400 jobs, or about 6 percent of its work force, well beyond several thousand positions it suggested would be cut as recently as October; undisclosed but substantial number of jobs cuts will involve layoffs; Citigroup says 65 percent, or about 6,760, of the cuts will be overseas; about 3,640 positions will be in US; Citigroup employees in New York will not bear brunt of US cutbacks; chart (M)

headline: Malaysia Money Supply Grew 3.3% in November
abstract: Malaysia's central bank reports money supply grew 3.3 percent in Nov from Nov 1997 and 0.9 percent from Oct; gain may be sign that economic slowdown is bottoming out (S)

headline: Uganda AIDS Vaccine Test: Urgency Affects Ethics Rules
abstract: Article in series, Dead Zones, about AIDS crisis in Africa, notes that Dr Roy Mugerwa is about to begin AIDS vaccine trial in Uganda that will be one of most promising and ethically contentious experiments in history of medicine; ethical guidelines in past have made clear that vaccines should be tested in developed countries, where health care is excellent, before they are used in places without safety net, like Uganda; with AIDS, for first time, international medical community has done away with that necessity; people infected with HIV virus in rich countries have access to drug combinations that extend their lives; there is no such reason for optimism in Africa, where AIDS threatens to destroy entire generation; unless someone comes up with vaccine, that is unlikely to change before millions more die; map; photo (M)

headline: Tip Off Iraq? France Says It Couldn't, And Wouldn't
abstract: Senior French officials say France was not told by US or by Britain precisely when two countries planned to attack Iraq and could not have tipped of Baghdad; suspicions were raised that Iraqis learned of imminence of attack, whereupon they sent letter pledging to allow arms inspectors to begin work once again (M)

headline: Japanese Minister Warns About Economy
abstract: Japan's Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa says it is too early to conclude that nation's economy has bottomed out; Miyazawa apparently refers to comments last week by Economic Planning Agency head Taichi Sakaiya, who said recent indicators show economy will not deteriorate further (S)o

headline: The Right Tools
abstract: Letter by Smith College junior Heidi Haghighi on Nov 29 article discusses importance of attending college that provides paid internships that allow her opportunity to gain on-the-job training during sumnmer vacations prior to her entering full-time work force

headline: BP Amoco Sees $2 Billion Charge
abstract: British Petroleum Co's $61 billion purchase of Amoco Corp is expected to result in $2 billion in restructuring charges for new entity, BP Amoco PLC, in two years after it is formed; charges will include severance costs of eliminating 6,000 jobs, legal and regulatory expenses and investment banking fees (S)

headline: A Contemporary Bookstore
abstract: Blaxk equivalent of Amazon.com Internet site can be found at www.mosaicbooks.com, which offers variety of books about blacks, as well as some by black and Hispanic authors; most of books listed on site cannot be purchased directly and require orders be placed through bookstores; sketch of Mosaic Web page (M)

headline: Bookstore Goliaths Fax to the Finish
abstract: Bookselling heavyweights Barnes & Noble and Amazon.com Inc traded terse news releases following Barnes & Noble's acquisition of Ingram Book Co, which fills more than 58 percent of orders for Amazon, electronic bookstore (M)

headline: INTEL SHARES RISE ON FORECAST OF SALES INCREASE
abstract: Intel Corp shares rise 6 percent after company reiterates forecast that fourth-quarter sales will rise 8 to 10 percent from third quarter (S)

headline: Delta Sets 2% Raise For Workers in U.S.
abstract: Delta Air Lines Inc to give its 50,000 American employees 2 percent raise, part of an effort to appease pilots who made pay concessions in a 1994 cost-cutting plan; 2 percent raise comes as Delta also shifts money out of profit-sharing plan and adds it to employees' base salaries; airline's 9,000 pilots must approve pay increase because they are covered by labor contract (S)

headline: UPN Begins Agency Search
abstract: UPN broadcast television network, which is owned by Chris-Craft Corp and Viacom Inc, begins review of advertising account in search of outside agency to handle it (S)

headline: Digital Music
abstract: Jason Freidenfields letter says MP3 compressed music format is indistinguishable from CD format (S)

headline: Pearson Receives U.S. Approval To Buy Simon & Schuster Unit
abstract: Pearson PLC says it has received Justice Department approval of its $4.6 billion purchase of education unit of Simon & Schuster, but it is moving forward without major investor, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, which backed out of its part of $600 million deal (M)

headline: Resolutions For Happy PC Year
abstract: New year's resolutions for computer afionados (S)

headline: 4 Foreigners Are Found Beheaded In Chechnya
abstract: Severed heads of four kidnapping victims identified as three Britons and New Zealander are found on side of road in Chechnya, breakaway region on Russia's southern border that emerged undefeated from brutal war two years ago only to be engulfed by wave of kidnappings and crime (M)

headline: Acteal Journal; Where Killings Defiled a Church, No Forgiveness
abstract: Some 2,000 people gather at graves of 45 people, mostly women and children, massacred year ago in Acteal, Mexico, church; military helicopters interrupt re-enactment showing men in police uniforms taking part in massacre, deadliest single attack in Chiapas since Zapatista rebellion began; residents who fled small pro-Zapatista village in Chiapas return after six days in forest, but continue to fear attack from larger nearby pro-Government community; map; photos (M)

headline: Law Firms White & Case and Brown & Wood Discuss a Merger
abstract: Partners at New York law firms White & Case and Brown & Wood are discussing merging their practices to create law firm that would be among nation's 10 largest; many big firms say they need to be larger and have offices in cities throughout the world to serve their multinational clients better; many of these clients are merging themselves (M)

headline: The Dow Breaks Its Fall As Most Averages Advance
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 5.93 points, to close at 8,371.97; Nasdaq composite index rises 19.72 points, or 1.15 percent, to 1,737.35; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.75 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,068.09; graph; chart (M)

headline: New European Bank Offers A Degree of Rate Flexibility
abstract: European Central Bank, at last meeting before introduction of single currency, signals there will be no immediate cuts in interest rates when euro is introduced in January 1999; sets narrow one-month interest-rate corridor around main lending rate of 3 percent in move apparently aimed at smoothing money market operations and avoiding rate volatility in infancy of new currency; Wim Duisenberg, bank president, says move is intended to demonstrate that bank may not be amenable to further easing of rates in foreseeable future; photo (M)

headline: Anheuser-Busch Earnings Grow
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Companies says third-quarter earnings rose 3.8 percent, to $408.3 million; revenue rose to $3.12 billion from $3.10 billion (S)

headline: Bailed-Out Hedge Fund Cutting 18% Of Its Staff
abstract: Long-Term Capital Management Inc lays off 33 people, or about 18 percent of its 178 employees; layoffs mostly involve people in fund's Greenwich, Conn, and London offices and affects several senior researchers and traders; there are also a few layoffs in Tokyo office; no partners lose their jobs (S)

headline: CBT AGREES TO BUY KNOWLEDGE WELL FOR $52 MILLION
abstract: CBT Group PLC acquires Knowledge Well for $52 million in stock (S)

headline: Iraq's Move From Brink Is Greeted With Relief
abstract: Iraq has found few Arab friends in its latest showdown with United Nations, but its shift away from confrontation is greeted in Arab world with statements of relief that could complicate US efforts to maintain military pressure (M)

headline: Two Popular Categories Beating the S.& P. 500
abstract: A rare phenomenon has enveloped some stock mutual funds during the 1998 home stretch. On average, funds in two of the more popular stock fund categories are actually beating the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the benchmark that has been trouncing active fund managers for years.    According to Lipper Inc., the S.& P.  returned 7.63 percent from the end of October through last Thursday. The average capital appreciation fund, by contrast, returned 8.86 percent over that time and the average growth fund returned 7.69 percent. (Micro-cap funds, which would never invest in a company in the S.& P. 500, really surged, providing a 10.55 percent return over the same period.)

headline: KOHLBERG KRAVIS TRIMS ITS STAKE IN SAFEWAY
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co trims its stake in Safeway Inc by selling 20 million of Safeway's common shares; Safeway says sale is intended to put more of company's shares into public hands (S)

headline: Bosses to Love and to Lean On
abstract: On the Job column invites readers to send in stories about bosses that have performed acts of kindness; drawing (S)

headline: General Enters Israel Politics; Shadow Falls Left and Right
abstract: Gen Amnon Lipkin-Shahak resigns from Israeli army to enter politics; he is expected to announce his candidacy for Prime Minister; he is expected to present himself as centrist candidate in elections in spring; most opinion polls show him trouncing Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu; Shahak has portrayed himself in past as political moderate who supports peace effort; Shahak is expected to join forces with Dan Meridor, Likud member who has already announced his candidacy for Prime Minister; Shahak has said he would yield to Meridor if polls show him to be running stronger against Netanyahu; photos (M)

headline: B.A.T. to Quit Making Cigarettes in Singapore
abstract: BAT Industries says it will stop making cigarettes in Singapore and dismiss about 300 employees, 80 percent of its work force in city-state (S)

headline: Killing Shocks Russia
abstract: The killing of Galina V. Starovoitova, a defender of democratic reforms, unsettled her old allies, who claimed her as the latest victim of Russia's corrupt political climate.   Article, page 9.

headline: UBS Considering Sale Of Trade Finance Unit
abstract: UBS AG, Swiss banking giant, might sell its trade finance unit to focus on money management and investment banking, which offer higher returns (S)

headline: ELSCINT TO SELL UNIT TO GE MEDICAL FOR $100 MILLION
abstract: Elscint Ltd to sell its diagnostic imaging unit for $100 million to General Electric Co medical-systems subsidiary (S)

headline: Cargill Set to Buy Main Unit of Continental Grain, Its Chief Rival
abstract: Cargill Inc agrees to buy Continental Grain Co; terms undisclosed; analysts estimate price exceeded $300 million; companies will combine storage and processing businesses; nearest competitor will be Archer Daniels Midland (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Bills Held Up With Time Running Out  A long-sought compromise to let high-technology companies hire more foreign workers has been derailed in the Senate, and infighting in the final hours of the 105th Congress is threatening final passage of two other cornerstones of the information-technology industry's legislative agenda.

headline: An All-Star Team of Balloonists Sets Out to Conquer the World
abstract: All-star team of long-distance balloonists pilots 160-foot-high balloon from its launching pad at Marrakesh, Morocco, to begin voyage they hope will take them around world in 10 days; Richard Branson, billionaire chief executive of Virgin Group, is captain of balloon; flying with him is Steve Fossett, American commodities broker, and Per Lindstrand, head of British company that built balloon, Lindstrand Balloons Ltd (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  BankAmerica  Foremost  Highwoods Pptys  Piccadilly Cafe.  Protective Life  Teleflex

headline: A Trial Will Test China's Grip on the Internet
abstract: Forthcoming trial of Lin Hai, computer executive, heralds new electronic battleground for China's political dissidents and security forces determined to preserve Communist Party control; Lin is charged with 'inciting subversion of state power' by giving tens of thousands of Chinese E-mail addresses to hostile foreign publications (M)

headline: ARROW AGREES TO BUY 2 ELECTRONICS BUSINESSES
abstract: Arrow Electronics Inc agrees to buy Bell Industries' electronics distribution group and Richey Electronics Inc for about $280.5 million in cash; Arrow will pay $185 million for Bell Industries unit and $95.5 million for Richey (S)

headline: Lull in the Party for Year-2000 Stocks
abstract: Article offers reasons for decline in stock values of companies that are helping corporate America deal with year 2000 computer glitch; graph; cartoon (M)

headline: World Trade Body Is Struggling to Select Next Chief
abstract: Diplomats from four nations are vying to succeed Renato Ruggiero as Director General of World Trade Organization amid global economic strains that complicate process; representatives of 132 member nations meet, Geneva, to set new deadlines for process, which is behind schedule; candidates are Roy MacLaren (Canada), Hassan Abouyoub (Morocco), Mike Moore (New Zealand) and Suphachai Phanitchpaphak (Thailand); importance of post to organization's success noted (M)

headline: Let No Bad Chip Tear Asunder
abstract: Betty Lo Mann tells what it is like to be married to Steve Mann, who for 20 years has pursued dream of developing a networked computer that would slip onto the human body--his own--as easily as a layer of clothing; he has fashioned for Betty a cyborg suit of her own that is electronically connected to him; photo (M)

headline: Columbia Hospital Sales
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp sells Chicago-based Michael Reese Hospital and Grant Hospital to Doctors Community Healthcare Corp of Scottsdale, Ariz, for $63.4 million in cash as part of hospital chain's restructuring plan (S)

headline: Business Travel; Those flying to Milan from another European city may soon have to pay for a pricey taxi ride.
abstract: TRAVELERS flying into Milan from other European cities after Oct. 25 may want to double-check their destination before they leave. According to a compromise worked out last week by the European Commission and the Italian Government, most major European airlines are scheduled to move about two-thirds of their flights on that date from Linate Airport, which is only five miles from the center of the city, to Malpensa International Airport, which is 33 miles out.    Malpensa, where a new terminal is set to open later this month, is already used by American carriers flying from the United States.

headline: In Election, Kazakhstan Gets a Dose Of the West
abstract: Akezhan Kazhegeldin is in election race against his erstwhile political patron, Pres Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan; Kazhegeldin claims his press aide was attacked by masked men, a weekly close to him was firebombed and he was shot at; Nazarbayev has nurtured image abroad as relative moderate, but he has moved to consolidate his grip; his much-energized KGB successor agency has carried out Soviet-style character attack against Kazhegeldin; Adam Smith Albion, American expert on region, says thuggishness in Kazakhstan politics is reminiscent of how Soviets treated political figures they did not like (M)

headline: Hewlett-Packard's Earnings Exceed Wall St. Estimates
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co reports fourth-quarter earnings of $710 million, or 68 cents a diluted share, decline of 12 percent compared with $806 million, or 75 cents a share in period year earlier; special charges of about $170 million reduced earnings by 11 cents a share; without charges, Hewlett-Packard earned 79 cents a share, exceeding analyst estimates; company also says revenue and growth in orders remain weak (M)

headline: A New Computer Microphone Is Able to Double as a Mouse
abstract: Philips Electronics introduces a multifunctional device called Speech Mike, which allows user to talk and listen to a computer at a distance and also has a trackball for controlling the computer; photo (S)

headline: Europe to Study AT&T Venture
abstract: AT&T Corp and British Telecommunications PLC will face four more months of scrutiny by European Union over planned $3 billion venture to offer voice, data and Internet services to multinational corporations; delay seen as indication that companies may have to scale down plans to secure regulatory approval (S)

headline: Panel Finds French Errors In Judgment On Rwanda
abstract: French parliamentary committee on French military role in Rwanda concludes that succesive Governments made 'errors of judgment,' but absolves France of any responsibility for mass killings in 1994; French press charged that military advisers helped train Rwandan forces that carried out slaughters; committee criticizes UN for delaying military action, and pins blame for that on international community, led by US (S)

headline: Senior Aide Implicating Bin Laden In Terrorism
abstract: Government officials say unidentified senior aide of exiled Saudi terrorist Osama bin Laden has been talking to US investigators for two years; say informer pleaded guilty to terrorism in secret proceeding in Federal court, Manhattan; at least one operative of bin Laden's group in East Africa concluded over year ago that informer was Sidi Tayyib, businessman who was married to one of bin Laden's relatives (M)

headline: Oil Industry Ending a Year to Remember
abstract: With oil prices averaging $13.13 a barrel in the fourth quarter, down 34 percent from year ago, decision by Texaco Inc chief executive Peter I Bijur not to make five-year forecast during meeting with industry analysts reflects feeling on part of many oil executives that pace of change in 1998 has been extraordinary; year ago, country's three largest oil companies, Exxon, Mobil and Texaco, were getting ready to report their biggest quarterly profits in their history; oil prices averaged $19.94 a barrel, well above $14 most companies calculated as break-even point; major factors for decline in oil prices are: Asian recession, decision by OPEC not to cut enough output to end oil glut and warm weather (M)

headline: Software That Can Make A Grown Company Cry
abstract: Article on boom in number of corporations using or considering use of computer software programs known as enterprise resource planning; such programs coordinate manufacturer's entire business from time raw materials are delivered to time customers pay invoices; photos; graphs (L)

headline: Ignoring Europe's Rate Decline, U.S. Markets Take a Fall
abstract: US stocks fall broadly on projections of reduced sales and earnings; Dow Jones industrial average closes at 8,879.68, down 184.86 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Internet Stocks Fall Sharply As Investors Take Profits  Shares of Yahoo fell $11.5625, to $165, and America Online declined $7.375, to $137.125, as most Internet stocks slumped on profit taking after recent increases. Although shares of the chip maker Intel rose $6.125, to $103.6875, after the company projected stronger-than-expected revenue for the quarter, it was not enough to rally the Nasdaq, which decreased 3.51 points, to 1,862.11.    Market gauges fell as investors pondered what seems little better than an even chance that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates again next week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 40.16 points, to 8,823.82, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index shed 7.29 points, to 1,120.97. [Page C7.]

headline: Kimberly-Clark Revises Structure
abstract: Kimberly-Clark Corp will reorganize along product lines, rather than geographic regions, to help sales and speed introduction of products worldwide (S)

headline: U.N. Report: 'Iraq Did Not Provide the Full Cooperation'
abstract: Excerpts from Richard Butler's report to Sec Gen Kofi Annan, as provided by United Nations, on Iraq's rebuf to UN arms inspectors (M)

headline: GENUINE PARTS GAINING REST OF UAP OF CANADA
abstract: Genuine Parts Co to acquire remaining 80 percent of UAP Inc of Canada it does not already own for $225 million (US) in cash (S)

headline: Brazil's Slump Sends Car and Beef Exports Down in Argentina
abstract: Leading auto makers in Argentina have temporarily idled plants and are reporting drop in car sales, first concrete sign that recession in Brazil may be slowing Argentina's economy; while Government officials are optimistically predicting 4.8 percent growth in 1999, recent cutbacks in auto factory man-hours and shrinking auto exports to Brazil are seen as suggesting much weaker economy ahead; beef prices and other Argentine agricultural exports are falling in price, in part also due to slowdown in sales to Brazil, buyer of 30 percent of Argentina's exports (M)

headline: A MILLION GHOSTS: A special report.; Revenge or Justice? Cambodians Confront the Past
abstract: Special report, A Million Ghosts, finds Cambodia is being forced to confront grisly past in wake of collapse of Khmer Rouge and emergence of former top leaders Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea who may face trial for atrocities during 1970's when more than million people were massacred; while many Cambodians say past should be buried in interest of national conciliation others, led by human rights groups, say country will suffer torment until it heals wounds of recent past through judicial process; plans by UN for possible internationally sponsored trial of Khmer Rouge leaders for crimes against humanity noted; map; photos (L)

headline: From Factory to the Top of Saturn
abstract: Profile of Dr Cynthia Mary Trudell, who will become first woman to run a car division for an American or foreign auto maker when she takes over General Motors Saturn division on January 1; Dr Trudell has spent most of last 19 years in auto factories and has accumulated kind of experience that GM has concluded it needs in senior executives, but has seldom found among its men; Trudell photo (M)

headline: Hitting the Virtual Slopes All Year Round
abstract: On-line ski information includes equipment reviews, resort news, club announcements and ski-area jobs; photo (M)

headline: A Champagne Evening Awash in Gloom
abstract: Meeting of international finance ministers and central bankers in Washington ends in gloom, with world financial crisis hanging over IMF meeting (M)

headline: Suspect in Embassy Bombings Moves Closer to Extradition
abstract: German official says American officials indicated they would not seek death penalty for suspected aide to Osama bin Laden, which could clear major hurdle to win man's extradition from Germany; bin Laden is thought to be leader of terrorist group that bombed American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in August; Germany's highest court has dismissed appeal by suspected aide, Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, who has been fighting extradition since his arrest on charges of conspiring to murder Americans abroad and use weapons of mass destruction; Salim denies all charges (M)

headline: WHEN NATURE RAGES: A special report.; The Life of a Hurricane, the Death That It Caused
abstract: Hurricane Mitch wreaks greater death and destruction on Central America than any other hurricane in modern history, with rain, not winds, doing most of the damage; torrential downpours spawn floods and avalanches that kill over 10,000 people, erase villages and destroy much of infrastructure in Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador and Nicaragua; freakish behavior of storm is major reason it caught governments and people off guard, but high death toll also owes something to poverty and politics; maps; photos (M)

headline: G.E. Profit Rise Meets Estimates
abstract: General Electric Co says its third-quarter profit rose 13 percent, matching expectations, to $2.28 billion from $2.01 billion a year earlier (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: U.S. Sees Brooklyn Link to World Terror Network
abstract: Alkifah Refugee Center, Brooklyn, which prosecutors say evolved into American outpost of Osama bin Laden's international terrorist organization, began around 1986 to raise money and recruit fighters to help United States-backed Afghan rebels and closed in 1993; served for many years as gathering place for fringe group of terrorists involved in World Trade Center bombing and other attacks; one of Trade Center bombers, Mahmud Abouhalima, told prosecutors in 1993 that he twice turned to Wadih el Hage to buy arms for Brooklyn associates; United States apparently had been tracking el Hage for at least year before embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania (M)

headline: Ex-Compliance Officer and 3 Charged
abstract: Marisa Baridis, former compliance officer at Morgan Stanley and previously at Smith Barney, is one of four people charged with insider trading in 13 stocks; SEC suit and simultaneous settlement filed in Federal court charges group used information provided by Baridis (S)

headline: Singapore Trades Hong Kong Index
abstract: Singapore International and Monetary Exchange introduces its Hong Kong stock index futures amid opposition from Stock Exchange of Hong Kong (S)

headline: Indonesia's Leader Warns of 'Disintegration' From Strife
abstract: Student demonstrators clash with soldiers in Jakarta as Indonesian Pres B J Habibie warns that continued protests could lead to 'disintegration of the nation'; scores of students are treated at hospitals after about 4,000 demonstrators, some of them throwing gasoline bombs, challenge security forces guarding Parliament building; photo (M)

headline: Phoenix Buys Mutual Funds From Zweig
abstract: Phoenix Investment Partners to buy mutual-fund business run by Martin Zweig for as much as $164 million in cash; it is acquiring just mutual funds and closed-end funds managed by Zweig DiMenna Partners LP (S)

headline: Renault and Fiat Plan To Merge Foundry Units
abstract: Renault, French auto company, intends to merge most of its foundry operations with those of Italian car maker Fiat SpA; merger will be carried out through Fiat's foundry subsidiary, Teksid SpA; Fiat and Renault will be shareholders in Teksid, holding 66.5 percent and 33.5 percent, respectively (S)

headline: Castro Criticizes an Old Friend, Mexico
abstract: Cuba's Pres Fidel Castro, once circumspect in criticisms of longtime ally Mexico, openly derides contemporary Mexican policies at economic conference in Havana; scores North American Free Trade Agreement, and accuses Mexican Govt of turning back on third world and allowing American culture to overwhelm Mexican traditions; Mexican Govt officials express irritation and dismay; member of ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party calls remarks intervention in country's internal affairs (M)

headline: Oracle Data Base Takes Aim at Windows
abstract: Oracle chairman Lawrence J Ellison to introduce at Comdex computer trade show, Las Vegas, Nev, new version of data base program that would do away with operating system almost entirely on powerful computers known as servers that act as control centers of large computer networks; will introduce server appliance computer industry executives say might prove more difficult for rival Microsoft Corp to defuse than Oracle's earlier network computer; graph of market share in relational data bases field; photo of highly wired bus Ziff-Davis staffers are driving to convention (M)

headline: Judges in Spain Assert Pinochet Can Face Trial
abstract: Panel of 11 senior Spanish judges, in landmark ruling, decide unanimously that Spain has legal right to bring criminal charges against Chile's former dictator, Gen Augusto Pinochet, and to seek his extradition from Britain; judges decision is based on international law, including conventions on genocide and torture, but contrasts with ruling by High Court in London; photo (M)

headline: INTEL TO BUY MAKER OF COMPUTER NETWORKING PRODUCTS
abstract: Intel Corp to acquire Shiva Corp for about $185 million (S)

headline: Criimi Mae Court Filings List Millions in Unsecured Loans
abstract: Criimi Mae Inc names Prudential Securities Inc and First Union Corp among its largest unsecured creditors in Chapter 11 bankruptcy filings (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A poor showing by Chrysler illustrates the pitfalls of all-stock merger deals with foreign companies.
abstract: Financial bane of Detroit auto makers has been laggard shares of their stocks; those have tended to sell for only seven to nine times their earnings per share, less than half market average for big companies; investors fear American auto industry's reputation for faltering badly during each recession, and refuse to pay higher multiples of earnings, even as auto makers have amassed huge cash reserves and cut their long-term costs; weak performance of Chrysler Corp's stock since last May, when its merger agreement with Daimler-Benz AG was announced, is seen illustrating pitfalls of all-stock merger deals with foreign companies; Daimler-Benz has traded at a higher multiple in German market, where investors have regarded auto stocks more favorably (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Wieden & Kennedy Pursues Miller From New York
abstract: Wieden & Kennedy's New York office is leading pitch for creative portion of Miller Lite beer account, with billings estimated at $150 million, in review being conducted by Miller Brewing Co (M)

headline: A Marine General Who Studies Cultures as Well as Bomb Targets in the Gulf
abstract: Profile of Gen Anthony C Zinni, Commander of United States Central Command, who oversees all American forces from Sudan to Pakistan, including forces in Persian Gulf; he says rather than going directly against Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq, US may have to opt for patient containment, as in case of Cuba and North Korea; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Orders Inspectors and Relief Staff Out of Iraq
abstract: United Nations, after warning from US that military strike on Baghdad may be imminent, abruptly evacuates more than 230 foreign staff members from Iraq, including all weapons inspectors; another 41 people from various agencies will depart on Nov 12, leaving only essential staff members behind; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAY  None

headline: Chase Reviews Nazi-Era Role
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp says that it is investigating allegations that it froze accounts of Jewish customers in Paris during Nazi occupation of France before formal orders to freeze accounts were issued; Chase, one of largest American banks, says it is also examining whether its Paris office was 'overly cooperative' in providing banking services to Germany during occupation and whether assets seized by Nazis and Vichy Govt were ever returned (S)

headline: Kosovo Killings Anger U.N.; NATO Weighs an Air Strike
abstract: Security Council schedules emergency meeting for Oct 1 to condemn massacres of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo that witnesses attribute to Serbian forces; Britain calls emergency session; Council, which has demanded immediate end to attacks on civilians by Serb-dominated Yugoslav Army, is expected to condemn Pres Slobodan Milosevic's forces; Council, with no troops at its disposal, remains divided on what to do next; NATO completes planning for possible air strikes, but any ultimate action will depend on go-ahead from Clinton Administration (M)

headline: Passing On a Clean Drive
abstract: Ernest Kessler letter, responding to Oct 8 article, says it was very informative to learn about kinds of information stored on computer's hard drive

headline: Bank of England Lowers Rate a Quarter-Point
abstract: Bank of England cuts its benchmark interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 7.25 percent, reflecting concern about global financial turmoil and fears of recession among British exporters and manufacturers (M)

headline: Choice for Economics Post Spurns Offer by Schroder
abstract: Jost Stollman, German Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroder's choice for Economics Minister, spurns offer on grounds that Economics Ministry is being eviscerated; move dashes Schroeder's stated hopes of striking happy balance between promoting economic growth and strengthening country's generous social welfare system; Stollman's exit is seen as strongest sign yet that new Government will be more left-wing than pragmatic; suggests much of political power in Govt lies with Oskar Lafontaine, left-leaning chairman of Social Democratic Party who will lead Finance Ministry--which is acquiring new responsibilities from Economics Ministry; Stollman photo (M)

headline: Carbon Paper Still Messy, Still in Use
abstract: Market for carbon paper still exists, although much reduced owing to advent of NCR (no carbon required) paper, copying machines, computer printers and other technology; many small businesses use business forms with one-time carbons attached; 'cc,' for carbon copy, still appears at the end of many a memor composed on personal computer and sent via E-mail; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.38   4.07   5.57        3-month T-bills   4.32   4.31   5.12        6-month T-bills   4.37   4.33   5.17        10-yr. T-infl.   3.77   3.78   3.53        10-yr. T-note   4.84   4.85   5.83        30-yr. T-bond   5.23   5.26   6.06        Telephone bd.   6.89   6.92   7.35        Municipal bds.   5.13   5.13   5.37          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Memo From Moscow; Impeachment Over Sex? Try Genocide or Treason
abstract: Russian Parliament is trying to impeach Pres Boris N Yeltsin over accusations of genocide, treason and abetting murder, and almost no one gives it second thought; most people expect proceedings to continue past time when Yeltsin ends his second term and leaves office in 2000; Communist Party and its allies on far right inspired and have managed impeachment from its start in May; photo (M)

headline: French Drug Makers to Combine in $10.4 Billion Stock Deal
abstract: French drug makers Sanofi SA and Synthelabo SA to merge to form Sanofi-Synthelabo in stock swap valued at $10.4 billion; stocks of both companies fall; Elf Aquitaine, which controls Sanofi, and L'Oreal, which controls Synthelabo, will retain big holdings in new company; Jean-Francois Dehecq will be chairman and Herve Guerin vice chairman (M)

headline: SBC COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY 4% OF CONCENTRIC NETWORK
abstract: SBC Communications Inc will buy 4 percent of Concentric Network Corp for about $21.9 million as part of deal to sell Concentric's Internet-based data services to SBC's business customers (S)

headline: Fed Was Worried About Misinterpretation
abstract: Minutes of Federal Reserve's deliberations prior to September 29 interest-rate cut of 0.25 percent show central bank decided to limit cut out of fear that bigger reduction may have exaggerated its concerns about risks of economic slowdown; decision to cut rates second time on October 15 was made despite continued concern among some members of Federal Open Market Committee that move would be interpreted in markets as signal that bank saw bad news on horizon (M)

headline: ING Groep of Netherlands to Cut 1,200 Jobs
abstract: ING Groep NV says it will dismiss 1,200 workers as it lowers its 1988 profit expectations (S)

headline: Florence L. Walsh, 37, Lucent Finance Executive
abstract: Florence L Walsh, finance executive at Lucent Technologies, dies at age 37 (M)

headline: Lending Without a Net; With Wall Street as Its Banker, Real Estate Feels the World's Woes
abstract: Article describes aggressive approach of CS First Boston head Andrew D Stone in amassing more than $5 billion worth of commercial real estate loans and equity investments in New York and $24 billion nationally in less than three years; drastic changes in real estate markets as result of global stock market turmoil described; drawings; graphs (L)

headline: Aid Groups Press U.N. for New Effort to End Sudan's Civil War
abstract: Private aid groups, currently sending millions of dollars worth of food and medicine to relieve starvation and suffering in Sudan, are pressing the United Nations to make a vigorous new effort to end the nearly 30-year civil war there instead of merely feeding its victims.

headline: Waiting for Other Shoe to Drop in Japan
abstract: Japan discloses details of proposed 81.86 trillion yen ($708 billion) budget for next fiscal year; big deficit in budget intended to lift economy out of recession leaves Government will only small window to spur growth before it must deal with looming debt burden; Government plans to issue record 71.13 trillion yen in bonds, including 31 trillion yen in new bonds, to cover 40 percent deficit (M)

headline: Fright, Misery and Anger Fuel Serb's Plan
abstract: Threats of air strikes against Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic are producing one result that US Government says it does not want: strengthening rather weakening control of Milosevic; US officials say Milosevic may accede to some of demands on Kosovo and avert calamity of NATO bombs; but as pressures of outside military action have accelerated in past week, so Milosevic has introduced new repressive measures; Milosevic has created atmosphere of victimization that has turned smoldering anger about his miserable economy into anger at the West, and at US in particular; map; photo (M)

headline: German Official Restates Independence on Rates
abstract: Bundesbank chief economist Hermann Remsperger reiterates that German interest rates are at low levels and says German central bank will not allow any interference with its independence in days before introduction of new European currency, the euro (S)
