headline: Business Confidence Plunges in Japan
abstract: Bank of Japan survey shows Japan's corporate managers are most pessimistic they have been in four years as economy languishes in recession; but they do not expect conditions to worsen in months ahead; quarterly survey's main index measuring confidence of 703 major manufacturers registers score of -51, worse than forecast of -44, and much worse than -34 in last survey in June (S)

headline: Mentor Raises Takeover Bid For Quickturn
abstract: Mentor Graphics Corp raises bid for Quickturn Design Systems to $14 a share in cash, matching bid by Cadence Design Systems Inc; will seek only 14.9 percent of company to avoid setting off Quickturn's poison pill defense (M)

headline: Buying a Car? Location, Location, Location
abstract: Grey-market car dealers in Germany make their profits from price differences in Europe and lack of tariff barriers among member countries in European Union; these dealers buy cars at lower prices in other countries and import them to Germany, where they can undercut standard dealers' prices; grey-market dealers see little to fear from advent of euro, saying that consumers already are aware of price differences and car makers are unlikely to equalize prices; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes; Grace & Rothschild, New York, is named as first agency to handle two accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $3 million: Medcast Networks, Atlanta, and Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, NY (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar dips as nervousness slips into markets ahead of announcement in Brazil that could include currency devaluation; dollar falls to 117.75 yen, from 119.10 on Oct 26; graph; chart (S)

headline: MCI Value Passes AT&T
abstract: MCI Worldcom Inc passes AT&T Corp in stock-market value; MCI Worldcom's market value climbs to $116.77 billion; AT&T's value increases to $113.35 billion (S)

headline: France Offers To Lead Force Sent to Kosovo With Monitors
abstract: France offers to lead allied force that will protect international observers in Kosovo; move is seen as effort to dismiss doubts about France's support for NATO in Kosovo in wake of charges that Maj Pierre-Henri Bunel passed bombing plans to Serbia (M)

headline: Strong Capital Starts A Network of Its Own
abstract: Strong Capital Management forms mutual funds network, Prime Managers, to offers investors funds of eight other no-load families, without transaction fees (S)

headline: Treasury Set to Auction Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of 3-  and 6-month bills and a 52-week bill. Trading in Treasury securities and on futures on the Chicago Board of Trade is closed today because of Columbus Day.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding 3-month bill was 3.79 percent, and 3.91 percent on the 6-month bill.. The rate for the 52-week bill was 3.96 percent.

headline: Genentech Earnings Double for Quarter
abstract: Genentech Inc reports earnings of $63.4 million in third quarter, up 97 percent from $32.1 million a year earlier; revenues rose 15 percent, to $163.1 million from $142.3 million (S)

headline: NABORS TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF DRILLING EQUIPMENT
abstract: Nabors Industries to acquire Bayard Drilling Technologies for about $225.5 million (S)

headline: Japanese Index Falls 800 Points
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 stocks falls 799.55 points, or 5.8 percent, to 13,026.06, its sharpest decline since August 1991 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Brazil Plans $80 Billion In Cuts and Tax Increases  The Brazilian Government of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso detailed a three-year, $80 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases in a bid to restore the nation's flagging credibility in world markets and prepare the way for a rescue program led by the International Monetary Fund.    United States officials reacted cautiously, and international investors warned that the measures could easily stall in the Brazilian Congress. The blueprint calls for $23.5 billion in savings for 1999, with about $11 billion of that amount coming from tax increases and $7 billion from Federal spending cuts. [Page A1.]

headline: Women on the Web
abstract: To the Editor:    I am the co-editor of Wench, one of the sites described in (''Women Want It All, and It's All on Line,'' Oct. 22) as ''fairly shallow and obsessed with sex.'' Sex is hardly the primary topic of Wench's articles and essays, and when it is discussed it is treated intelligently and respectfully.

headline: A Slight Climb in Rates
abstract: Bank Rate Monitor survey of 200 lenders finds that average rate on 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages rose 0.05 percent, to 6.84, in past week (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.75   4.88   6.07        3-month T-bills   4.46   4.52   5.22        6-month T-bills   4.46   4.52   5.24        10-yr. T-infl.   3.84   3.83   3.71        10-yr. T-note   4.67   4.75   5.79        30-yr. T-bond   5.09   5.15   5.96        Telephone bd.   6.75   6.77   7.15        Municipal bds.   5.17   5.19   5.26          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Business Travel; United Airlines is installing new passenger-friendly equipment at several domestic airports.
abstract: United Airlines is installing new customer-friendly equipment at number of United States airports as part of a $200 million, three-year program to improve airport processes and make travel easier for its passengers; new services include mobile check-in podium at check-in counters when there are long lines; December issue of PC Computing magazine conducts 'hand-held PC torture test' with editors rating 13 machines for performance; magazine gives 3Com's Palm III its highest rating; Radisson Hotels Worldwide, Hilton Hotels Corp and Ritz-Carlton, Chicago, offer new services for travelers (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Chinese Reminded: No Opposition Allowed
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin delivers speech making clear that China's economic reforms are not prelude to Western-style democracy, and warns that those who challenge Communist Party's supremacy would be quashed; speech provides vigorous defense of Government's recent decision to try three of country's most prominent democracy activists on criminal charges for their efforts to organize opposition political party; trials of Wang Youcai and Qin Youming open this week; family of China's most senior dissident, Xu Wenli, is told he will also stand trial this week; photo (M)

headline: Former Salesman Settles
abstract: Sean P Brennan, former vice president for CS First Boston Investment Management Group, Credit Suisse Group affiliate, agrees to pay $50,000 to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charge that he distributed misleading marketing materials about the fund; is barred from industry but has right to reapply in five years (S)

headline: Bertelsmann Plans Inquiry On Its Role During Nazi Era
abstract: Bertelsmann AG, German conglomerate, is appointing committee of scholars to investigate its activities during Nazi era; Bertelsmann's chairman Thomas Middelhoff says decision is in response to recent article in Swiss magazine Die Weltwoche, which contended that Bertelsmann misled public about its activities during Hitler regime and that it had also published pro-Nazi books in 1930's and 40's; accusations are also in current issue of The Nation in article by Hersch Fischler, German sociologist and researcher who wrote article for Swiss magazine, and John Friedman, journalist and documentary film maker; Bertelsmann withdrew its corporate history from its Web site for evaluation after Swiss article was published (M)

headline: Times Company Promotes Two
abstract: New York Times Co says Raymond E Douglas has been promoted to corporate chief information officer and Ellen Taus, company treasurer, has received additional title of vice president (S)

headline: As Microsoft Trial Gets Started, Gates's Credibility Is Questioned
abstract: Antitrust trial against Microsoft Corp begins, Federal District Court, Washington, DC, with pointed personal attack by Justice Department prosecutor David Boies on credibility and integrity of company chairman, William H Gates; opening argument by Govt includes taped deposition, in which Gates denied knowing much, if anything, of main charges leveled against company as well as involvement in key meetings in which Microsoft allegedly offered chief competitor, Netscape Communications Corp, chance to divide Internet software market; is followed by presentation of more than dozen memos and E-mail messages written by Gates which clearly show he and other senior Microsoft executives not only knew about matters in question but had forcefully directed them; Boies portrays company as obsessed with crushing competitors, and willing to use every tool at its disposal, including threats and financial inducements, to force or persuade other companies to drop any planned or existing alliances with Netscape; photo (M)

headline: Big Amount Withdrawn From Equity Funds
abstract: Investors made net withdrawals of $11.2 billion from equity mutual funds in August, biggest outflow on record and first month in eight years that more money flowed out of stock funds than went in (M)

headline: Paine Journal; Pinochet's Arrest Revives Buried Fears in Chile
abstract: Arrest of Gen Augusto Pinochet in London, on charges of human rights violations, revives deadly political grudges in Paine, town of grape and citrus growers in Chile; photo; map; mothers and sisters of men who disappeared after coup against Salvador Allende in 1973 speak bitterly of their loss and humiliation at hands of former soldiers and paramilitaries; Paine's turmoil began in late 1960's when landless farmers squatted on unused ranch land; invasions increased when Allende came to power in 1970 and socialist activists helped peasants organize cooperatives; movement came to violent end in 1973 (Paine Journal) (M)

headline: Anwar's Arrest and Injuries Shake Faith in the Country : In Malaysia, Sense of Disbelief
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  When Anwar Ibrahim appeared in court here with bruises around his left eye and on his arms — injuries that he asserted had been inflicted by the police — it was a jolt for Malaysians, who just a month earlier regarded Mr. Anwar as the heir apparent to become Malaysia's next leader.

headline: 2 Oil Giants To Combine Gas Stations
abstract: Phillips Petroleum Co and Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corp to combine their gas station chains and refineries into joint-venture company called Diamond 66 (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Mixed Signals From the Fed; If the Water's Fine, Why Are Those Sharks Still Circling?
abstract: Market Place column on surprise interest-rate cut by Federal Reserve focuses on what might have provoked the Fed because there has been nothing in recent economic figures that indicated need for immediate and drastic move (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Listed
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:   Hellenic Telecommunications Organization S.A., Athens, Greece, an initial offering of 43.83 million ordinary shares, each share representing two American depository shares. A global offering, consisting of United States/Canada offering, international offering and Greek domestic offering. Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: Leftist Chosen To Assemble Government In Turkey
abstract: Turkey Pres Suleyman Demirel asks Bulent Ecevit, veteran left-wing politician known for his honesty, to form new Government week after it fell in corruption scandal (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: PINOCHET'S IMMUNITY CLAIM -- A lawyer for Gen. Augusto Pinochet told the highest court in Britain that as a former head of state the general was immune from prosecution for acts committed in his official capacity.  The 82-year-old Chilean general, who governed from 1973 to 1990, was arrested last month in London at the request of Spain, which wants him extradited to face charges of crimes against humanity. A lower court ruled that the arrest was illegal.   Sarah Lyall (NYT)

headline: E. T. returns to Earth to sell safe driving in a broad-based campaign coming from Arnell.
abstract: ET, the alien of the 1982 film, will be focus of safe-driving ad campaign created by Arnell Group Brand Consulting for Progressive automobile insurance; campaign is emblematic of increasing cross-pollenization between the popular and commercial cultures; photo (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- Who Says Talk Is Cheap; What Is the Sound of One Voice-Over Actor Yapping?
abstract: Article on lucrative field of voice-over acting in television and radio advertising; some voice-over actors, including Carlos Alazraqui, Lorenzo Music and Don LaFontaine, comment on tangible and intangible benefits of working in the field; drawings; photos (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: Swiss Inflation Rate At Zero for the Year
abstract: Swiss consumer prices fall in December at their fastest annual rate in 39 years, pushing average inflation this year to zero, as rents and imported commodity prices fall in Europe's slowest-growing economy (S)

headline: Turkish Bank in Talks To Buy Gasoline Retailer
abstract: Turkiye Garanti Bankasi AS, Turkey's fifth-largest bank, and its parent, Dogus Holding, are in talks to acquire Petrol Ofisi, state-run gasoline retailer, for about $1 billion (S)

headline: A FUND OF TROUBLE: A special report.; As Economies Fail, the I.M.F. Is Rife With Recriminations
abstract: Special Report, A Fund of Trouble, on recriminations and criticisms besetting International Monetary Fund, as world's finance ministers gather in Washington for annual meeting of IMF and World Bank; just about everything that could have gone wrong in world economy has: worst downturn in Japan since World War II, economic meltdown in Russia, depression in Indonesia that is plunging 100 million people below poverty line, and deep fears over what happens next in Latin Amreica; what makes this year's meeting of IMF most remarkable is that harshest criticisms are directed at monetary fund itself, and, by extension, at United States Treasury, which is viewed as power behind the fund; 53 years after IMF was created, it is under attack from all sides, charged not only with worsening a bad situation by misjudging the economics, but with being politically tone-deaf in some of most volatile capitals in world, from Jakarta to Moscow; photos (L)

headline: Child's Close Call Aided Nun's Way To Sainthood
abstract: Benedicta McCarthy, whose miraculous recovery after taking lethal dose of Tylenol is attributed to prayers to Edith Stein, will attend Mass in St Peter's Square, where Pope John II will pronounce Edith Stein a saint and martyr for Roman Catholic Church; photo (M)

headline: Serbs in Kosovo Said to Rely Now on Arrest and Torture
abstract: Western diplomats and dissident Yugoslav officials say forces of Pres Slobodan Milosevic appear to be turning to politically motivated arrests to counter rapidly spreading influence of rebels in Kosovo Province; moreover, assassination last week of guerrilla comander, which was initially thought to be result of feud within rebel ranks, is now described as the first of what they predict will be series of back-and-forth retaliatory attacks; Yugoslav officials say that Govt, by restoring to traditional methods of repression, can strike at rebels and avoid a NATO reaction; photo (M)

headline: NATO OPENS WAY TO START BOMBING IN SERB PROVINCE
abstract: US and its allies approve order clearing way for NATO to begin bombing campaign in Serbian province of Kosovo within four days, but White House says agreement to end crisis with Serbs appears imminent; senior American and NATO officials say significant progress was made in talks between special US envoy, Richard C Holbrooke and Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic over oppression of ethnic Albanians; say Milosevic has agreed to end all police and military operations in Kosovo, withdraw forces in verifiable way and make unilateral statement pledging partial autonomy in province; say he appears ready to allow force of 2,000 monitors, mostly civilian, into Kosovo; caution that differences remain over exact makeup of international mission; say Milosevic's reluctance to pledge cooperation with international war crimes investigations is also outstanding issue; Pres Clinton expresses guarded optimism over developments, noting Milosevic has failed to keep promises in past; says while US and allies prefer to settle issue peacefully, military force will be used if Milosevic fails to keep word; photos (M)

headline: Once Again, Drug Giants Can't Get Along
abstract: American Home Products and Monsanto call off proposed merger after chief executives fail to reach power-sharing agreement (S)

headline: Freed U.N. Worker Describes 317-Day Chechnya Abduction
abstract: Vincent Cochetel, French UN aid worker, describes ordeal of being held captive for 317 days by in Chechen kidnappers (M)

headline: Agnellis Begin Exor Takeover Bid
abstract: Giovanni Angelli e C, a trust, begins $1.6 billion takeover offer for Luxembourg-based investment company Exor Group, which owns 19 percent of Club Mediterranee and 20.5 percent of Rockefeller Center Properties, among others (S)

headline: Crisis With Iraq: Clinton Accepts Iraqs Promise to Allow Weapons Inspections
abstract: WASHINGTON--President Clinton said today that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had unconditionally retreated and once again had vowed complete cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors. That vow will be tested quickly, Mr. Clinton said, and American and British forces that nearly struck Iraq on Saturday will remain poised to act.

headline: Salomon Cuts 100 Bond Jobs
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney Inc cuts 100 jobs in US bond trading, research and sales in New York to reduce costs as result of trading losses in global markets; firm is expected to dismiss additional employees in its equities unit week of Oct 26, and after that, in investment banking (S)

headline: Tiny Step to Help the Cease-Fire in Kosovo
abstract: Ethnic Albanian rebels in Kosovo, Serbia, release Serbian police officer Goran Zbiljic after American diplomats intercede; release is seen tiny advance in effort to prop up fragile cease-fire, as international monitors help in small ways to defuse tensions; photo (M)

headline: New Moves On Rushdie Exposing Iranian Rifts
abstract: Iran's Sept move dissociating itself from death threats to British author Salman Rushdie continues to expose fissures among Iran's rival centers of power; protests by conservatives underscore powerful constraints still facing Pres Mohammad Khatami's relatively moderate Government as he seeks to reshape Iran's image (M)

headline: Finding Opponents on Line
abstract: letter by Charles George, responding to Oct 29 article, offers some suggestions for finding opponents for Internet games

headline: BankAmerica Names Finalists in Review
abstract: BankAmerica Corp selects finalists to compete for its advertising account, with billings estimated at $90 million to $100 million (S)

headline: Rabin's Lot Is Rancor, In Death As in Life
abstract: Israel holds first nationwide memorial for Prime Min Yitzhak Rabin, who was assassinated in 1995, signaling concerted effort to transform him from partisan hero into figure of consensus or national symbol of peace; politicians of all stripes gather at his grave in Jerusalem, broadening mourning that, until recently, has been domain of only centrists and leftists; as Israelis vent feelings in discussion groups nationwide, it remains clear that trauma of assassination remainly at least partly undigested and unresolved, as is fate of peace accord with Palestinians signed recently by Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu; photos (M)

headline: Comeback Time For Latin America?
abstract: Interview with Lehman Brothers director Jose M Barrionuevo, who comments on prospects for Latin American financial markets, which he says are on rise; photo (M)

headline: BLIND TRUST: A special report.; A Hedge Fund's Stars Didn't Tell, And Savvy Financiers Didn't Ask
abstract: Special report on downfall of Long-Term Capital Management; examines question of why seasoned financiers around world did not recognize problems with hedge-fund giant earlier; Long-Term borrowed heavily, made risky investments and nearly failed; shrewd financiers like Sanford I Weill, co-chief exec of Citigroup, one of few Wall Street execs to speak publicly about Long-Term, acknowledges that when it came to doing business with Long-Term Capital Management, he did not know enough about dangerous bets that fund was making; concedes that sheer star power of funds' financial brain trust blinded him to huge risks Long-Term was taking; fund's managers included two economists who last year shared Nobel Prize, former govt officials and bond traders known for generating immense returns; downfall of Long-Term provides rare window on clubby world of high finance, where decisions about where to steer vast sums can be made with few questions asked; table lists notable investors in Long-Term Capital; photos of Weill, Antonio Fazio, head of Italy's central bank, and David Komansky, chmn of Merrill Lynch (L)

headline: PHELPS DODGE TO CLOSE 2 COPPER MINES AND CUT 680 JOBS
abstract: Phelps Dodge Corp will eliminate about 680 jobs as it closes two copper mines, in New Mexico and Chile, because of continued low copper prices (S)

headline: Savings Bonds Perk Up In a New Incarnation
abstract: New type of US savings bonds, so-called inflation-indexed variety introduced in September, pay more than traditional Series EE savings bonds, with yields close to that of conventional 30-year Treasury bonds, and offer resistance to effects of inflation; photo (M)

headline: Pakistani Premier Prevails in Clash With General
abstract: Gen Jehangir Karamat, Chief of Staff of Pakistan's Army, is uncharacteristically forced to resign after publicly criticizing Prime Min Nawaz Sharif and proposing stronger military role in making policy; Government has been able to exercise authority over military without dire consequences because of profound changes in political structure since landslide election of Sharif 18 months ago that have strengthened prime minister while weakening army; generals have ruled Pakistan for almost half of 51-year history, and prime ministers have been dismissed in earlier clashes; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES, Greensboro, N.C., said it would sell its Madison Yarn division to Carolina Mills Inc., Maiden, N.C., to finance expansion.    SPRINGS INDUSTRIES, Fort Mill, S.C., a maker of home furnishings and specialty fabrics, said it would close one plant and expand another in Griffin, Ga., cutting 300 jobs as it modernizes its towel manufacturing business. The move will cost about $26 million.    KERR-McGEE CORP., Oklahoma City, the oil and chemical company, said it was laying off about 70 people in the Oklahoma City area and Houston.

headline: Former Prime Minister Sues French Newspaper
abstract: BRUSSELS—  Edith Cresson, a European commissioner and former French prime minister, has sued a French newspaper for libel after it alleged that she was involved in irregularities in the awarding of European Union contracts.

headline: You Call That An Interest-Rate Cut?
abstract: Many analysts call Federal Reserve's slight reduction in short-term interest rates insufficient to cushion weakened economies or deter investments in US Treasury bonds (S)

headline: Netanyahu Is Seeking Way to Soften a Fall
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu all but conceded that he expected his Government to fall on Monday and threatened to call new elections so he could avoid the humiliation of being evicted from office. He added that he would try one last time to get a majority of Parliament to stand behind his tough posture toward the Palestinians. His Cabinet said it would not hand over more West Bank land to the Palestinians on Friday, provoking an angry Arab response.     Article, page A3.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Publicard Inc will acquire closely held Greystone Peripherals Inc (S)

headline: Japan's Finance Minister May Step Down at End of the Year
abstract: Finance Min Kiichi Miyazawa, key figure in efforts to revive Japan's economy, suggests he would step down formally from politics and from his Cabinet post at end of year; such a move would raise questions about Japan's economic policy, because Miyazawa has more credibility and connections with West than other Japanese politicians; it is unlikely that his resignation will lead to dramatic changes in Japan's economic policy (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen declines for sixth day on speculation that Government's plan to increase consumer spending and invigorate economy will not work; dollar settles at 122.52 yen, up from 121.57; graph; chart (S)

headline: Far Becomes Much Nearer As Web Touches an Island
abstract: Remote island of Tristan de Cunha, whose population is under 300 people, is located about midway between South America and Africa; island's inhabitants have been brought closer to rest of world thanks to Internet, which is available for E-mail use by all islanders who have access to one personal computer; cost of communicating is high, with satellite link charge of $5 or more a minute; Brian Baldwin, island's administrator, has put together Web site, www.st-helena-org.ndi rect.co.uk/tristaninfo. htm, to make island better known; map (M)

headline: Politics Again Leaves U.S. Financial Overhaul in Limbo
abstract: Financial Services Competition Act, measure supporters say would modernize nation's financial system and make it more globally competitive, is languishing in Congress victim of political squabbling; would eliminate barriers separating banks, insurance companies and brokers and allow them to merge into new financial conglomerates; has been bogged down because of disagreement between Treas Sec Robert Rubin and Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, use as issue in Senate election campaign between Senate Banking Committee chairman Alfonse D'Amato and Democratic challenger Charles Schumer, and because of veto threat by Pres Clinton (M)

headline: From Many Devices That Measure Body Fat, Many Answers
abstract: Kris Goodfellow report on devices that measure body fat; finds wide variation and inaccuracy; photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: Sherwood Outdoor, New York, names Brian T Turner president, new post; Jamison Cawdrey Advertising names Tom Geary vice president and creative director, succeeding Jean Shorter, who left; Select Communications names Wolfgang Schaefer worldwide planning director, new post; Wenner Media names Deborah Cavanagh to new post of executive director for group marketing; National Geographic magazine names Will Tifft advertising director, new post; Entertainment Weekly names Fred Nelson vice president for marketing and promotion, succeeding Daniel Osheyack, who joins People magazine as associate publisher for marketing (S)

headline: Executive Resigns At Cliff Freeman
abstract: David Angelo, executive vice president and co-executive creative director at Cliff Freeman & Partners advertising agency in New York, resigns; duties will be absorbed by creative directors Cliff Freeman, Arthur Bijur and Eric Silver (S)

headline: Pushing Harder for Access to Cuba
abstract: Dozen news organizations press to open news bureaus in Cuba despite general cutbacks in foreign news reporting; have gotten United States Government waivers, but only CNN and now Associated Press have won Cuban permission for permanent correspondent; photo (M)

headline: Patents; Ringing in the new year with a little assistance from some freshly minted inventions.
abstract: Gregory Alexander, David Volk and Steven Goldenbogen patent a vending machine that allows shoppers in music stores to create custom CD from music stored in a computer...Two Japanese investors, Akira Nakada and Hisanori Katou, patent system of generating music with foot, hand, shoulder and elbow movements...Annette Pappas patents pantyhose with three legs, one to be held in reserve in case of a run...David McAllister patents hald-held tool with a series of small parallel blades that he says can reduce wrinkles...Yukio and Masako Iwamoto of California patent 'hydraulic system for serving food' (M)

headline: Republicans List Terms for I.M.F. Payout
abstract: Republican Congressional leaders present Clinton Adm with list of lending conditions that they want imposed on IMF in order for Congress to approve $18 billion in new money for IMF; list is not made public, but Congressional officials say it includes demand that IMF open its books for public scrutiny, that it end its practices of lending to foreign govts at below-market interest rates, and that it shorten lending perod on most loans (M)

headline: XTRA CALLS OFF SALE TO INTERPOOL AND APOLLO
abstract: Xtra Corp says its sale to Interpool Inc and Apollo Management LP has been terminated and it is renegotiating transaction (S)

headline: Financial-Services Combination Planned
abstract: Irish Permanent PLC and Irish Life PLC will merge in all-stock deal; Irish Life shareholders will control 67.3 percent of merged company (S)

headline: R&B FALCON SAYS MOBIL CANCELS $146 MILLION CONTRACT
abstract: R&B Falcon Corp, fourth-largest US drilling contractor, says Mobil Corp canceled offshore drilling contract valued at about $146 million because of R&B's equipment and personnel deficiencies (S)

headline: Treasury's Schedule of Auctions Includes a Sale of 52-Week Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills as well as a 52-week bill.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.52 percent and a six-month bill was 4.53 percent.

headline: Computer Haves and Have-Nots in the Schools
abstract: Computers are becoming key teaching tool in nation's schools, and educators are facing problem of how to deal with wide gap of technical expertise between those students who have computers at home and those who do not; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Presses Milosevic as Pullout of Serb Forces in Kosovo Slows
abstract: United States and NATO work to keep military pressure on Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic as he continues to resist withdrawing Serbian troops and police from Kosovo; American envoy Richard C Holbrooke threatens possible use of force, meeting, Paris, of US, Russia and European powers that coordinate Balkans policy; Milosevic seems determined to challenge NATO's resolve (M)

headline: A French Oil Company That Doesn't Act the Part
abstract: Thierry Desmarest, chairman of Total SA, says he was able to allay fears of investors after his company, one of France's two big oil companies, acquired Petrofina SA of Belgium for $11.6 billion in stock; in Desmarest's five years as chairman, Total has increased production, sales and profits in era of slumping oil prices; France's other large oil company, Elf Aquitaine, presents stark contrast; productivity at Elf continues to lag far behind Total, and company continues to struggle to throw off legacy of decades of state control; photos; chart (M)

headline: Credit Lyonnais Plan Wins First Approval
abstract: Credit Lyonnais SA wins European Union approval to pay off its debt to French Government in a lump sum instead of handing over a percentage of its profits for 16 years, first step toward its sale to private investors next year (S)

headline: But Is It Going to Rain?
abstract: Weatherplanner Web site offers glimpse of long-range forecasts; photo (S)

headline: STC BROADCASTING BUYS FIVE NORTH DAKOTA TV STATIONS
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc says its television broadcasting affiliate, STC Broadcasting, acquired five television stations in North Dakota from Meyer Broadcasting Co for $63.8 million; stations, all affiliates of NBC, are KFYR, Bismarck, KVLY, Fargo, KUMV, Williston, KMOT, Minot, and KQCD, Dickinson (S)

headline: Montreal Journal; Canadians, Estranged, Even in Their Pop Culture
abstract: Quebec is divided from rest of Canada, and not just by its use of French language and desire of many to secede from Canada; Quebecers smoke more, get divorced more and are said to be more stressed out than people in rest of Canada; basic difference is way Quebecers see their country; Claude Meunier, host of wildly popular television program in Quebec, says Quebecers are eager for their French language and culture to survive; photo (M)

headline: Discounted Urns And No Overhead
abstract: Russel D Harmon comments on his business selling cremation urns at a discount directly to the public over the World Wide Web; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: WARNING ON PINOCHET CASE  Britain's Lord Chancellor -- the Government's chief law officer -- said the legal system risked being brought into disrepute by the Augusto Pinochet case. Lord Derry Irvine referred to the decision by the House of Lords, the highest court, to set aside its own ruling in November that the former Chilean dictator did not have immunity from prosecution because he was a former head of state.    (Reuters)

headline: Finding a Mate to Build a Portfolio
abstract: Abby Ellin column describes some ways that novices can start investing in stock market; drawing (M)

headline: Patents; Congress has extended its protection for Goofy, Gershwin and some moguls of the Internet.
abstract: Copyright Term Extension Act, approved by Congress on Oct 7, extends life of copyright protection for works created on or after Jan 1, 1978, to life of author plus 70 years, an increase of 20 years, and extends copyrights for works created for hire and owned by corporations to 95 years, up from current 75; it thus keeps copyrights for several of Walt Disney Co's most lucrative cartoon characters, including Mickey Mouse, from becoming public property in next few years; Congress also approves On-Line Copyright Infringement Liability Limitation Act, which protects Internet service providers from liability for unwittingly transmitting material that infringes on copyright (M)

headline: State of the Art
abstract: Peter H Lewis to write weekly column called State of the Art, starting next week; column will discuss new products and developments in electronics industry of interest to consumers

headline: Cyberpaths Leading Toward the Joys of Reading
abstract: Alice Keim advises on computer software for teaching reading noted; photo (S)

headline: 25 Stations Renew Game-Show Deals
abstract: King World Productions Inc renews Wheel of Fortune and Jeopardy on 25 television stations, securing broadcast of its hit shows in 36 percent of US for at least two more years (S)

headline: Short Week's Climb to New Heights
abstract: Assessment of stock market performance during week of November 23 to 27; graphs; charts (L)

headline: G.M. Reportedly to Combine U.S. and Foreign Operations
abstract: General Motors Corp will combine its domestic and international automotive operations; company is expected to announce shakeup on Oct 6; combined automotive operations will be led by G Richard Wagoner Jr,, president of North American operations, who is expected to become GM's chief operating officer and possibly its president; this would make him likely successor to John F Smith Jr, GM's chairman, chief executive and president; Wagoner has been unable to reverse erosion of GM's market share in North America since he took post four years ago; GM's domestic and foreign design engineers have been collaborating for years on new sedan design that would be manufactured worldwide; consolidation of management responsibility at top would partly reflect this new effort (M)

headline: Years of American Secrecy Has Kept a Chasm Wide
abstract: For 13 years, case against convicted spy Jonathan Jay Pollard has symbolized darker aspects of normally warm relationship between United States and Israel while also exposing fissures long dividing American and Israeli Jews; time and again, Pollard case has emerged from diplomatic wings and crept toward center stage whenever United States and Israeli leaders sat down to talk; yet despite strong emotions in both Israel and in this country produced by Pollard's life sentence, exact nature of his crimes has never been fully clear; photos of Pollard and his (former) wife, Anne Henderson Pollard (M)

headline: More Signs of Strength In the Economic Data
abstract: US productivity reportedly rises by 2.3 percent annual rate in third quarter 1998; producer prices and retail sales rise in October; Japanese economy continues to languish; International Monetary Fund and more than dozen nations announce $41.5 billion loan package to help shore up Brazilian economy and currency (S)

headline: Howard W. Chalk, 76, Former Ad Executive
abstract: Howard Wolfe Chalk, advertising executive, dies Dec 12 at age 76 (S)

headline: Frederick Wilkinson Jr., 77, Executive at Macy's
abstract: Frederick D Wilkinson Jr, one of first black executives at Macy's and, later, at American Express Company, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline: Avoiding Log-Offs
abstract: Richard Gordon letter about staying on line while using AOL (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Still Another Hedge Fund Seems to Be in Financial Peril
abstract: Market Place: Ellington Capital Management, an Old Greenwich, Conn, investment firm, has unloaded hundreds of millions of dollars of mortgage-related securities in last two days; firm, in response to margin calls from its lenders, appears to have been forced to liquidate much of holdings in its hedge funds, while developing plan with some of its lenders that would allow it to remain in business; Ellington manages about $1 billion in capital; company was founded late in 1994 by Michael Vranos (M)

headline: Judge Rules for a Student In a Free-Speech Case
abstract: Federal Judge Rodney Sippel rules in Missouri that Woodland School District in Marble Hill violated high school student's free speech rights by suspending him for remarks made on his personal Web site; ACLU brought suit on behalf of Brandon Beussink (News Watch) (S)

headline: About-Face for British Newspaper That Scourged Gay Laborites
abstract: British newspaper The Sun, in sudden about-face, says it will no longer reveal identities of gay men or women except in cases of 'overwhelming public interest,' because public opinion is tolerant of private behavior and finds unwarranted intrusion offensive; paper started week with editorial warning that Britain is run by cabal of gays and with mocking photo of Min Nick Brown (S)

headline: Nerve-Gas Element Was in El Al Plane Lost in 1992 Crash
abstract: Spokesman for El Al Israel Airlines says that El Al cargo plane that crashed in Amsterdam six years ago was carrying chemical that can be used in manufacture of deadly nerve gas Sarin; but spokesman for Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu says that chemical was not toxic and had been ordered by Israel to test gas masks and other filters designed to protect against chemical agents (M)

headline: Israel Is Rethinking Its Stand on Lebanon
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cut short a trip abroad to reconsider the Israeli Army's 20-year occupation of southern Lebanon after the killing of seven Israeli soldiers there in the last week and a half.

headline: North Korea Said to Drop Demand on Atom Inspection
abstract: North Korea reportedly drops demand that US pay hundreds of millions of dollars for right to inspect huge underground center American intelligence agencies fear could be used to make nuclear weapons; reportedly suggest they would be willing to allow US to inspect center in exchange for food to ease famine that has plagued country for years (M)

headline: Pay to Be Forfeited At Tokyo Exchange
abstract: Executives at Tokyo Stock Exchange will return part of their salaries to take responsibility for recent computer problems (S)

headline: Relief Effort In Honduras In Dire Need Of Resources
abstract: Honduran authorities struggle with meager resources to deal with catastrophic damage from torrential rains and floods spawned by Hurricane Mitch; nationwide death toll climbs to 583, with 279 reported missing; thousands remain trapped by flooding in remote regions; between 600,000 and two million people are homeless; most major roads and bridges have been destroyed by flood waters or blocked by mudslides after week of relentless rain; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.00   4.85   5.60        3-month T-bills   4.47   4.43   5.15        6-month T-bills   4.48   4.42   5.08        10-yr. T-infl.   3.79   3.77   3.53        10-yr. T-note   4.83   4.76   5.83        30-yr. T-bond   5.34   5.32   6.20        Telephone bd.   6.91   6.98   7.42        Municipal bds.   5.14   5.16   5.43          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: NBC Again Finds Itself on the Downside of Dominance
abstract: NBC is finding itself on downside of television dominance as aging shows are failing to get big ratings and new shows little promise; NBC's ratings are off by more than 20 percent this fall, a figure higher than NBC expected when it calculated how badly it would be hit by departure of Seinfeld; problems that Scott Sassa, new president of entertainment, will encounter discussed; graph; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Platinum futures rise to three-month high; graph (S)

headline: SAUDI IS INDICTED IN BOMB ATTACKS ON U.S. EMBASSIES
abstract: Federal grand jury in Manhattan returns 238-count indictment charging Saudi exile Osama bin Laden in bombings of two US Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in Aug and with conspiring to commit other acts of terrorism against Americans abroad; Government officials offer two rewards of $5 million each for information leading to arrest or conviction of bin Laden and Muhammad Atef, his chief military commander; prosecutors also unseal earlier indictment, issued in June, that includes similar but less detailed charges against bin Laden; new indictment accuses him of leading vast terrorist conspiracy from 1989 to present, in which he is said to have been working in concert with Sudan, Iraq and Iran and terrorist groups to build weapons and attack US military installations; photos (M)

headline: Dissident From Shanghai Arrives in New York
abstract: Yao Zhenxian, Chinese dissident fleeing new round of arrests of democracy activists in Shanghai, arrives in New York City and announces that he and other opponents of Chinese Government plan demonstration at United Nations on Dec 10 to protest crackdown (M)

headline: Rhone-Poulenc and Hoechst Agree on Start of a Merger
abstract: Rhone-Poulenc SA and Hoechst AG agree to combine their pharmaceutical and agricultural units into equally owned new company, Aventis, as first step of merger; Aventis, based in Strasbourg, France, will be world's second-largest drug maker and top seller of agricultural products; investors react negatively, with stocks of both companies dropping sharply; companies will merge their remaining operations within next two to three years, after selling off chemical and other side businesses (M)

headline: STEWART & STEVENSON TO ADD BAGGAGE TRACTOR MAKER
abstract: Stewart & Stevenson Services agrees to buy TUG Manufacturing Corp (S)

headline: ESCALADE CANCELS DEAL TO SELL SPORTING-GOODS BUSINESS
abstract: Escalade Inc cancels its agreement to sell its sporting-goods business to Sportcraft Ltd (S)

headline: Tips: Grease for the Gears of City Life
abstract: New York City residents who rely on services provided from variety of persons such as doormen, parking garage attendants, persons in service industries, hairdressers and others respond in kind with generous tips at Christmas, much more so than persons living in other cities; chart offers suggestions on what to tip help in Manhattan; photo (M)

headline: Few Signs Of Advances For Women On Boards
abstract: Latest annual survey by Catalyst, nonprofit women's research group, finds that boards of directors of 71 Fortune 500 companies are made up entirely of men; New York Times survey yielded several responses, ranging from 'no comment' to saying there is an ongoing search for women directors to explaining that it is company policy to appoint those most qualified regardless of gender, race or age; graph (M)

headline: Suddenly Within Reach, Millions in Sunken Treasure
abstract: Visa Gold Resources, Toronto company, has been awarded five-year contract for salvage rights to treasures that lie sunken in Cuba's territorial waters; Spanish galleon known as Santissima Trinidad, which went down in fierce hurricane in 1711 loaded with $400 million worth of gold bullion, silver ingots and coins, has lain undisturbed for centuries, guarded by Fidel Castro's gunboats since 1959; some feel Cuban waters contain richest concentration of sunken Spanish treasure anywhere, but recovering ships and their loot is formidable task; only tiny fraction of sunken treasure around globe has ever been found (M)

headline: CANADIAN INSURER IN $840 MILLION DEAL FOR TIG
abstract: TIG Holdings Inc, property and casualty insurer, says that it agreed to be acquired by Canadian insurer Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd for about $840 million in cash (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Republicans in Agreement On Bankruptcy Overhaul  House and Senate Republicans agreed on a sweeping overhaul of the bankruptcy system, making it more difficult for consumers to walk away from their debts and handing the banking and credit-card industries a victory.

headline: Stocks Rise Again, Buoyed by Technology and Internet Shares
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 14.81 points, or 1.25 percent, to record 1,202.84; Nasdaq composite index jumps 51.89 points, about 2.5 percent, to record 2,138.03; has risen nearly 50.7 percent since Oct 8 low; Dow Jones industrial average rises 85.22 points, to 8,988.85; graphs; tables (M)

headline: Tiptoeing Back to the Oilfields
abstract: Energy analysts assess recent uptick in stocks in companies that serve oil drilling industry; Standard & Poor's Oil and Gas Equipment Index fell 56 percent since November 5, 1997; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Big Board Posts a 1.4% Drop In Its Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: New York Stock Exchange says open positions on exchange fell 1.4 percent in month ended Oct 13, to 4.15 billion shares; on American Stock Exchange, uncovered short sales decreased by 4 percent, to 195.4 million shares; charts (M)

headline: Xcacel Journal; Voice of the Turtles Opposes a Hotel Development
abstract: Beach at Xcacel, Mexico, is one of world's most important nesting areas for sea turtles, and state government's sale of Xcacel to Sol Melia, Spanish conglomerate that plans to build 450-room hotel there, sets off one of Mexico's most bitter environmental battles; Sol Melia says that environmental protection will be factor in hotel's design; map; photos (M)

headline: Nucor Cuts Its Prices for Hot-Rolled Steel
abstract: Nucor Corp cuts hot-rolled steel prices by 7.4 percent, to $250 per ton, to counter cheaper Asian imports (S)

headline: Human Guides in Jungle of the World Wide Web
abstract: Problem of retrieving information from increasingly tangled World Wide Web is being addressed by Mining Co (www.miningco.com) by building its information gathering power on people called guides, who are scattered all over the world; each guide, specialist in particular topic, is responsible for searching the Internet and listing and building best areas on that topic; there are now 639 guides in more than 20 countries; guides tend to keep search results from overwhelming users by eliminating irrelevant and repetitive Web sites (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Acquirers take on greater risks to become more competitive in a new-era utilities business.
abstract: Group of major utilities announce number of costly transactions aimed at helping make them more competitive in deregulated market; deals also demonstrate how shareholders in these companies are facing greater risk and may have to wait longer for payoff; among recent transactions is PP&L Resources' move to acquire 13 power plants in Montana for $1.6 billion (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: Attacks Breed a Complex Unease About U.S. Goals
abstract: Use of force against Iraq stirs unease around world; only Russia has publicly vented irritation at US decision to punish Saddam Hussein, but Middle Eastern governments watch attacks with consternation, many speculating about link to Pres Clinton's impeachment woes (S)

headline: '60 Minutes II' Is Set For a Jan. 13 Debut
abstract: CBS announces that a new CBS News program, 60 Minutes II, spinoff of 30-year-old Sunday evening news program, will make its debut on Wednesday, Jan 13, at 9 PM and will have Wednesdays from 9 to 10 PM as its regular time slot (S)

headline: Malaysia Accuses U.S. of Inciting Lawlessness, But the Vice President Stands by His Remarks : Gore Opens APEC Rift With Praise of Reform
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  Malaysia accused the United States on Tuesday of inciting the overthrow of a "constitutionally elected" Malaysian government, as the escalating dispute among Asian and Pacific nations over how to handle human rights issues deepened divisions on the opening day of a key regional economic conference.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Soros Making Some Changes In His Funds
abstract: George Soros, one of world's most famous investors, is making several changes in his Quantum Group of mutual funds after poor investment returns in recent months of global financial turmoil, with some funds showing declines of more than 15 percent so far this year; Quantum Emerging Growth fund, which Soros proposes to close, lost 31.16 percent of its value as of Oct 22; Soros, in letter to shareholders, says S Nicholas Roditi, star fund manager of recent years, is taking temporary medical leave of absence, that Quantum proposes to merge funds Quasar International and Quantum Industrial Holdings and that it will close Quantum Emerging Growth; Stanley F Druckenmiller, chief investment strategist for Soros Fund Management, will temporarily take over Roditi's duties (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Conquering the Internet
abstract: News analysis of proposed acquisition of Netscape Communications Corp by America Online Inc; nation's largest on-line service hopes to beat Microsoft Corp in race for dominance of on-line media and electronic commerce; would acquire leading Internet brand and enlarge its wired audience by absorbing millions who visit Netscape's popular Net Center site on World Wide Web if $4 billion deal is completed; photo (M)

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: All financial markets and banks in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of the Christmas holiday. Most overseas markets were also closed.    Financial markets will reopen on Monday.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: ANOTHER SWITCH ON A-WEAPONS -- Prolonging a German zigzag on NATO's nuclear policy, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said his country had the right to suggest that the alliance renounce first use of nuclear weapons. The proposal was first aired last month by Foreign Minister Joshcka Fischer, but then appeared to be abandoned.   Roger Cohen (NYT)    RUSSIA: DEATH PENALTY IN DOUBT -- Russia will probably have to revoke its promise to abandon the death penalty because of violent crime, the Itar-Tass news agency quoted President Boris N. Yeltsin's human rights adviser, Vladimir Kartashkin, as saying. Mr. Yeltsin imposed a moratorium on capital punishment in 1996 after Russia joined the Council of Europe, whose statutes bar members from conducting peacetime executions.   (Reuters)

headline: Building Her Own Boat, In Tune With Tradition
abstract: Tina Kelly article describes her experience at Corey Freedman's boat-building workshop in Seattle, Wash, at which she and other students built Aleutian sea kayaks known as baidarkas; photos (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFINGS
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: POSSIBLE OIL IMPORTER -- Russia is in danger of becoming an oil importer after years of having been one of the largest petroleum producers, First Deputy Prime Minister Yuri D. Maslyukov, left, said. Mr. Maslyukov, who is in charge of economic policy, said that production had been falling for 10 years and that urgent action was needed to reverse the decline, the Interfax news agency reported. Last year the production of crude oil totaled 2.25 billion barrels.   (AP)    RUSSIA: INQUIRY ON TV BRIBERY -- Parliament will investigate allegations that executives ceded their right to revenue from shares in the ORT television network to President Boris N. Yeltsin. One legislator said the transaction amounted to a bribe in disguise, Interfax reported.   (Agence France-Presse)

headline: HOMESTAKE MINING TO TAKE CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
abstract: Homestake Mining Co plans to take third-quarter pretax charges of $188 million because of continued low gold prices (S)1

headline: In a Game, Crime Pays, If You Are Organized
abstract: Computer game Gangsters: Organized Crime noted; photo (News Watch) (S)

headline: Ciba Is Set For a Merger With Clariant
abstract: Ciba Specialty Chemicals and Clariant, two of largest players in rapidly growing specialty chemical industry, are merging in share swap valued at about $7 billion; new company will sport Clariant name but Ciba butterfly logo (M)

headline: OMNIPONT AND TWO COMPANIES SETTLE COLLUDING CHARGES
abstract: Omnipoint Corp, Mercury PCS II LLC and 21st Century Bidding Corp settle Federal charges that they used special codes to avoid competing for lucrative digital phone licenses; Justice Department accused companies of colluding at Federal Communications Commission auction that lasted from August 1996 to January 1997; companies settle charges by agreeing not to engage in similar practices in future, and Federal antitrust enforcers are not expected to seek damages (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE  FRANCE: BRIBERY INQUIRY ENDS  Investigating judges have completed their inquiry into Roland Dumas, head of France's highest administrative tribunal, the Constitutional Council, and his relationship while he was Foreign Minister with Christine Deviers-Joncour, a lobbyist for Elf-Aquitaine, the oil company. The two, as well as four former Elf Aquitaine executives, have three weeks to respond before prosecutors decide whether to try them on bribery charges.    Craig R. Whitney (NYT)    BRITAIN: CHARLES HEARS ABOUT MARIJUANA  Prince Charles, left, renewed a debate about marijuana when he asked a woman with multiple sclerosis whether she had tried using it to relieve pain. British newspapers reported that Charles, visiting a day-care center in Cheltenham, had told the woman, Karen Drake, that he had heard that marijuana could benefit people with multiple sclerosis.   (Reuters)    RUSSIA: AUSTERITY BUDGET GAINS  The Communist-dominated lower house of Parliament voted, 303 to 65, for initial approval for an austerity budget for 1999, after Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov had threatened to resign if the draft failed. The coffers are so bare that the budget calls for Government spending of $29 billion and revenues of $24 billion. The United States Government spends $30 billion a week.   (AP)    RUSSIA: 5 SUBCRITICAL A-TESTS  Russia conducted five subcritical nuclear tests at an Arctic testing range in the autumn, Deputy Nuclear Energy Minister Lev Ryabev said, contradicting previous denials. The Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty does not prohibit such tests, because the amount of plutonium used cannot create a nuclear explosion. But critics say that even limited tests could encourage full-scale tests.   (AP)    BOSNIA: MILITARY AND SCALE OF AID  The military consumes just about the total yearly aid to the country, said Ambassador Robert Barry of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Mr. Barry gave no specific figures. But Bosnia is receiving a $5.1 billion reconstruction package that international donors have agreed for the period from 1996 to 1999.   (Reuters)    MIDDLE EAST    CYPRUS: TALKS ON USING RUSSIAN MISSILES  President Glafcos Clerides will go to Athens next week for talks on whether to deploy a Russian-built missile system that Turkey has pledged to prevent on the divided island. Cyprus was said to be considering putting the S-300 missile systems temporarily on Crete, a move that Greece also reportedly favors.   (Reuters)    ISRAEL: BETHLEHEM SERVICE ON THE WEB  The International Christian Embassy, an evangelical Protestant group in Jerusalem, introduced its Virtual Holyland Web site in time for a Christmas service today from Shepherd's Field near Bethlehem. The page is www.virtualholyland.com.  Deborah Sontag (NYT)    ASIA    INDONESIA: MIDNIGHT MASS CANCELED  The Roman Catholic Cathedral in Jakarta scrapped midnight Christmas Mass because of security fears after violence against the minority Christian population, an official at the Vatican Embassy said.  (Agence France-Presse)    JAPAN: TAX REMAINS STABLE  The consumption tax will not rise despite an advisory panel's warning that an increase is inevitable, Chief Cabinet Secretary Hiromu Nonaka said. Former Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto was widely blamed for pushing the world's second largest economy into recession by raising the tax last year, from 3 to 5 percent.   (Agence France-Presse)    CHINA: 11 DRUG DEALERS EXECUTED  The special economic zone of Shenzhen executed 11 drug dealers, a local newspaper reported. The Intermediate People's Court sentenced 17 people for drug-related crimes, and the 11 given the death penalty were taken to be shot. Shenzhen, bordering Hong Kong, is a conduit for heroin refined in Yunnan.  (Reuters)    AFRICA    SIERRA LEONE: LIBERIANS ASSIST SECURITY  About 1,000 soldiers flew from Liberia to augment a West African intervention force around Freetown. The 5,000-member force is strengthening security after rebel attacks near the capital, United Nations observers said.  (Agence France-Presse)    ZAMBIA: REGIONAL MEETING POSTPONED  A regional meeting in Lusaka on a cease-fire in Congo has been postponed because of the holiday season, an aide to President Frederick Chiluba said.  (Agence France-Presse)    THE AMERICAS    MEXICO: INQUIRY ON PRI CAMPAIGN SPENDING  Electoral authorities named a commission to investigate accusations of illegal spending in the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, campaign of 1994 that led to President Ernesto Zedillo's election.   (NYT)   Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

headline: Salomon to Delay Bonuses For Review by New Managers
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney, amid signs that turmoil at Citigroup may not be over, informs employees in internal memorandum that they will have to wait month longer than usual to collect their annual bonuses; memo says Michael A Carpenter and Victor J Menezes, two executives in charge of managing combined entity's corporate banking group, need additional time to figure out bonuses (M)

headline: Lockheed Says Declining Sales Contribute to Sagging Profits
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp again cuts forecasts for 1998 and 1999 profit, citing falling sales and mounting production delays; its shares drop 11 percent (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Prospectus; At Cybersuds events, members of New York's new-media community look for partners, strategic and otherwise.
abstract: Evolution of New York New Media Association's Cybersuds events, begun in 1994, from industry party to trade show indicates how quickly New York's new-media industry has emerged and matured; drawing (M)

headline: Israel Battles New Foreign Foe: Music
abstract: Israeli parliament tries to counter wide influence of American popular culture with bill to require that half of songs on national radio stations be in Hebrew; Israeli music itself is melange of East and West, with heavy Middle Eastern and Mediterranean influences that mix with rock; photo; critics see hopeless attempt to legislate tastes (S)

headline: Patents; A host of products offer new ways to make the holiday season just a little bit more inventive.
abstract: Patents column examines host of new products linked to Christmas trees and other holiday decorations; examples cited (M)

headline: Making Math Seem as Natural as Breathing
abstract: J C Herz reviews computer game Devil Dice by THQ; photo (M)

headline: Some Digital Services Face 5% U.S. Tax
abstract: Federal Communications Commission, adopting middle ground between industry and consumer groups, imposes 5 percent tax on money commercial television broadcasters may some day generate from use of new high-definition television spectrum; agency says new rule offers simplicity and certainty and will recover for taxpayers part of commercial value of spectrum; broadcasters say fee is too high and will discourage innovation, while some consumer groups say it will effectively allow broadcasters to use spectrum, considered to be public resource, for many commercial purposes without adequately compensating Government; broadcasters are betting new system will enable viewers to use television sets in same ways as computers to gain access to Internet for ancillary services--which is what rule adopted by Commission will tax (M)

headline: Soon to Be Legal Tender, From Vatican to Distant Oceans
abstract: European central bankers meet in Brussels to discuss how best to spread euro, new single currency, into Europe's nooks and crannies and to faraway colonies and independent lands when adopted in January 1999 (M)

headline: House Votes $100 Million To Aid Foes of Baghdad
abstract: Senate is expected to approve bill recently approved by House that would let Clinton Administration spend $97 million to aid Iraqi opposition groups seeking ouster of Pres Saddam Hussein; Pres Clinton seeks some changes in bill, but is likely to support it; bill would also provide $2 million for Radio Free Iraq and calls for Clinton to press for United Nations international tribunal to charge Hussein and others with with war crimes (M)

headline: Anniversary Sets Germans To Quarreling On Holocaust
abstract: Germany marks 60th anniversary of Nazi rampage against Jews known as Kristallnacht with rites that reflect division over how to balance duties of memory with new thirst to move beyond Holocaust's shadow; Ignatz Bubis, leader of Germany's small Jewish community, clearly criticizes Chancellor Gerhard Schroder for new readiness to suppress memory, rite at Berlin synagogue attended by Schroder and other leading dignitaries; photo (M)

headline: Listen Up! Who Said We're Nice?
abstract: J D Bierdorfer reviews latest edition of Jellyvision and Berkeley Systems' computer trivia quiz game You Don't Know Jack; photo (M)

headline: South Korea's Filmmakers Roll Into Action to Protect Foreign-Movie Quota
abstract: SEOUL—  Six years ago Ahn Sung Ki played two of his greatest film roles — one as a North Korean soldier left behind in the South during the Korean War, the other as a South Korean intellectual who volunteered to go to Vietnam as a soldier in the South Korean Army.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Minutes Show Concern Over Perception of Cuts  The Federal Reserve decided to limit its rate cut on Sept. 29 to a quarter of a percentage point because it was worried that a bigger reduction might exaggerate its concerns about the risks of an economic slowdown, according to minutes of the deliberations.

headline: Oil Is Down, but Don't Count It Out
abstract: Opportunities for investing in oil stocks discussed in light of industry's current woes; worldwide demand is expected to rise only 0.5 percent this year, compared with average annual rate of 2.3 percent over past decade; many experts expect prices to rise gradually to $17 a barrel within year, from current $11; drawing; graphs of stock prices of leading companies (M)l

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against Japanese yen for fourth consecutive session on expectations that Federal Reserve will cut interest rates a third time this year; dollar drops to 114.28 yen, from 115.25 on Oct 16; graph; chart (S)

headline: Dissent on Mac OS
abstract: Peter Haynes letter, responding to Oct 29 article, says that while article is generally on target with regard to Macintosh operating system, PC has vastly more programs, applications, utilities and browsers

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar rises; graphs; table (S)

headline: Japan Financial Institutions Weigh Merger
abstract: Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd, Japan's third-largest lender, and Fuji Bank Ltd, sixth largest, are considering joining forces with Yasuda Trust and Banking Corp in trust-banking venture (S)

headline: HOSPITALITY PROPERTY BUYS 17 MARRIOTT HOTELS
abstract: Hospitality Property Trust, hotel investment trust, says that it agreed to buy 17 hotels from Marriott International for $201.7 million (S)

headline: Handling a Tough Audience
abstract: Alice Keim reviews Reading Blaster Vocabulary, computer program for children; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against the mark as Germany's central bank declines to cut interest rates; dollar trades at 1.6601 marks, down from 1.6657, in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: Paul Gitlin, 83, Pioneering Literary Agent to Stars
abstract: Paul Gitlin, lawyer and literary agent, dies at age 83 (S)

headline: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE ADDING CONTINENTAL GENERAL
abstract: Central Reserve Life Corp agrees to purchase Continental General Corp from Western and Southern Life Insurance Co for $84 million (S)

headline: Leveling the Trading Field
abstract: Broadcast.com, which broadcasts audio and video on Internet, will carry quarterly earnings conferences that 100 largest Nasdaq companies conduct for analysts (S)

headline: Dog Days for Some Ebay Critics
abstract: Pet advocates protest Ebay.com's on-line auction sales of dogs; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WORLD SATELLITE NETWORK INC., Minneapolis, which delivers television programming to private cable systems by satellite, agreed to be purchased by WSN Acquisition Corp., a Texas company, for about $15.8 million in cash.    PIONEER NATURAL RESOURCES CO., Irving, Tex., the oil and natural gas exploration company, will eliminate as many as 170 jobs and consolidate its Houston and Oklahoma City offices to save about $30 million a year.

headline: Tax Issue Slows Momentum for Early U.K. Entry
abstract: LONDON—  For advocates of Britain's entry into economic and monetary union, including the government of Prime Minister Tony Blair, things had been going remarkably well in recent months.

headline: Golden Cycle Raises Its Offer for Global
abstract: Golden Cycle LLC raises its bid for shares of Global Motorsport Group Inc to $20 a share, topping rival bid from Stonington Partners; Golden Cycle's bid values Global Motorsport shares outstanding at $103.6 million; Stonington offer values shares at $101.1 million in cash (S)

headline: AT&T Buying Vanguard to Extend Reach
abstract: AT&T Corp says it agreed to acquire Vanguard Cellular Systems Inc for about $900 million in stock and cash; AT&T seeks to further exploit success of its new Digital One Rate pricing plan, plan that has shaken up wireless communications business by eliminating long-distance fees and 'roaming' charges for using phones outside of home areas; Vanguard's Cellular One operates wireless systems that would help link AT&T's systems and save AT&T money when its customers range far afield (M)

headline: Media Talk; 3 Producers See Potential In a Hollywood Tale
abstract: Edward Pressman and Ken Lipper have bought interest in movie rights to David McClintick's book Indecent Exposure, on David Begelman's fall from power at Columbia Pictures from producer Elliott Kastner; three men are negotiating with Film Four to finance film; photo (M)

headline: BANK GIANT: THE EXECUTIVES -- A Chief Executive Comes Up Short; Infighting and Trading Losses Undo Hopes for Independence
abstract: Profile of Bankers Trust Corp chairman-chief executive Frank N Newman, who has been forced into act he firmly opposed as recently as five months ago: sale of Bankers Trust; links decision to sell bank to huge trading losses and nasty internal strife; photo (M)9

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Cotton prices drop 3.3 percent on concern demand will weaken because of global economic turmoil, despite one of smallest crops in years; December contract falls 2.35 cents, to 69.1 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Japanese Stocks Rise on Bond Market's Recovery
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 stocks gains 91.22 points to 13,797.95, level that is 10 percent below its mark of year ago; Government bond prices gain (M)

headline: One Man's Long Love Affair With Gadgets Plain and Fancy
abstract: Benjamin Cheever essay on his longtime fascination with collecting all types of gadgets; says his interest stems from desire to possess foreign objects, and that the intricacy of even the simplest device is so far beyond his comprehension as to be miraculous; drawing (M)

headline: Microsoft Memo Offers A Glimpse Of Gates 2.0
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates, in long memo to staff, spells out main opportunities and threats he sees for software giant in next five years; holds Microsoft's is in its strongest position ever in computer industry; sees personal computer remaining main business and technology platform from which Microsoft stretches into main-frame systems and hand-held consumer-electronics devices; says Internet will continue to bind these products into Microsoftian whole, if company continues to ward off threats posed by IBM, Netscape Communications, Oracle and Sun Microsystems; memo, apparently aimed at showing Gates focuses on business in face of antitrust suit, also implicitly indicates Gates is withdrawing from operational management of Microsoft to become company's chief technologist; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: No Winners in a Game Of Asset Shuffling
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co shares drop after Lilly announces plan to unload its PCS Health Systems unit to Rite Aid Corp (S)

headline: Check the Calendar
abstract: Kenyan government reportedly announces establishment of commission to study Year 2000 problem, with report due in April 2000; Alan and Lori Dechert of Sacramento, Calif, ask for trademark protection for calendar they hope governments will adopt declaring year after 1999 to be 0 of Global Era (S)

headline: Serb Troops in Kosovo Seem to Halt Operations
abstract: Serb artillery in Kosovo Province is silent for second day in a row, leading Western oficials to conclude that Pres Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has ordered his troops to halt obvious operations against separatist rebels; in last two weeks Milosevic's forces have completed punishing offensives against ethnic Albanian villagers and the rebels they support; photo; map (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Is Reportedly Seeking U.S. Acquisition
abstract: Deutsche Bank, eager to buy concern that will enhance its international investment banking business, has been scouting out prospects, including Bankers Trust Corp, Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc and J P Morgan & Co; Deutsche Bank and Bankers Trust decline to comment on reports in Financial Times of London that their banks are in 'preliminary talks' about possible merger (M)

headline: Bubbles and the Fed
abstract: Letter from Bert Ely on Nov 15 article on Alan Greenspan, chairman of Federal Reserve, and American economy (S)

headline: Technological Wet Blanket
abstract: To the Editor:    The elevators in the new 12-story building of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Washington go one step beyond the TransAmerica Building's fuzzy logic system, as described in ''Elevator Technology: Inspiring Many Everyday Leaps of Faith'' (Dec. 3).

headline: IN MY... CARD HOLDER: John S. Reed
abstract: He is one of the financial world's most powerful men, yet he doesn't carry a wallet. ''Really, I never have,'' said John S. Reed, co-chairman of Citigroup, the largest financial company in the world.     So what does Mr. Reed do with his greenbacks and credit cards? Somewhat reluctantly, he produces a money clip with $1 bills on the outside and pulls out a small leather holder for his cards.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Soybean prices rise 4.4 percent after Government cuts its crop forecast by more than 100 million bushels, to 2.77 billion; November contract rises 23.5 cents, to $5.64 a bushel (S)

headline: Damage Moderate as Storm Hits Florida
abstract: Hurricane Mitch hits Florida after being downgraded to tropical storm; causes only moderate damage, mostly in Keys (S)

headline: INFINITY SHARES UP 12.5% IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
abstract: Shares of Infinity Broadcasting Corp, radio division of CBS Corp, rises 12.5 percent in their first day of trading; stock closes at $23.0625--$2.5625 above offering price of $20.50--on trading of 52.9 million shares (S)

headline: Frankincense and Frugality; Shoppers Are Making Lists and Flocking to Discounters
abstract: Discount merchandisers are winning nation's shopping wars, cashing in on consumers' growing appetite for bargains; and they are likely to keep their edge through Christmas and Hanukkah frenzy, at the expense of old-line department stores and some specialty chains; graph; photos (M)

headline: Confidence Buckling as Markets Plunge
abstract: Global financial crisis and plunging stock market are unnerving nation's more affluent families, making them more cautious in their spending; optimism has fallen significantly in households with incomes above $50,000 that were optimistic about financial situation before summer's sharp selloff in stock market, compared with families with lower incomes and little exposure to stock market that have shown no change in level of optimism; charts (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Increase
abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports open positions on short sales rose 0.6 percent in month ended Dec 15, to 3.95 billion shares; American Stock Exchange reports uncovered short sales fell 2.3 percent, to 175.55 million shares; tables (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: PINOCHET'S DEFENSE -- A British law that provides immunity to former heads of state would have protected even Adolf Hitler from arrest and prosecution in Britain, lawyers for Gen. Augusto Pinochet told Britain's highest court. General Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, is resisting extradition to Spain, which wants him to face trial in connection with crimes allegedly committed during his rule.   Sarah Lyall (NYT)

headline: Expecting the Worst, Leisurely
abstract: Most of 800 publishers, editors, subscription agents, advertising directors and investment bankers who gathered at conference sponsored by Magazine Publishers of America in Orlando, Fla, express concern about potential for sluggish advertising sales in 1999 in light of downturn in European and Asian economies; photo (M)

headline: Compaq to Sell PC's Directly to Consumers
abstract: Compaq Computer will start selling personal computers directly by telephone and over Internet at prices lower than those charged by local dealers; company is taking step to fend off potent rival, Dell Computer, which has always marketed its machines directly and now threatens Compaq's market lead; plan may anger some local dealers who will lose sales (M)

headline: Account Decisions From Media Companies
abstract: Viacom Inc's Blockbuster Entertainment Corp unit has consolidated creative and strategic duties on its account at Southfield, Mich, office of W B Doner & Co; combined billings, estimated at $103 million last year, are expected to increase in 1999; Barnes & Noble Inc expands its relationship with New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day by naming agency to handle its consolidated account, with billings estimated at more than $40 million (S)

headline: A. Stephens Hutchcraft Jr., 68; Was Chief of Kaiser Aluminum
abstract: A Stephens Hutchcraft Jr, a senior exec of Kaiser Aluminum Corp, dies at 68 (S)

headline: The F.C.C. Faces Internet Regulation
abstract: Federal Communications Commission is caught in fierce debate over whether and how telephone companies that provide Internet connectors should be regulated; one battle is over how Baby Bells and smaller local telephone companies split revenue for providing Internet access; chart (M)

headline: Push to Buy Palm Shows Aggression Is Consistent
abstract: Aggressive business tactics of Microsoft Corp are illustrated by its offer in August to acquire software business behind 3Com Corp's popular Palm Pilot hand-held computer; offer was not accepted by 3Com executives (M)

headline: C.I.A. Denies That It Withheld Reports on Russian Corruption
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency says it provided Clinton Administration many reports on corruption of senior Russian officials; denies analysts censored themselves after concluding that senior officials did not want evidence of corruption to obstruct doing business with Russian leadership (M)

headline: Pilots Say Fedex Rebuffed Latest Bid to Avert Strike
abstract: pilots say fedex rebuffed latest bid to avert strike**Leaders of pilots' union at Federal Express Corp say company has rebuffed its latest effort to restart contract talks; say action greatly increases chances of strike during peak holiday-package shipping season next month; union says it will ask company to submit to binding arbitration in final attempt to avert strike; pilots have said they are willing to compromise on their pay demands (M)

headline: Pinochet's Spanish Pursuer: Magistrate of Explosive Cases
abstract: Balthasar Garzon, stubbornly independent and controversial Spanish magistrate who succeeded in getting Scotland Yard to arrest Chile's former dictator, Gen Augusto Pinochet, has suddenly moved closer to setting important legal precedent that could make retirement of former dictators uncomfortable; was ridiculed at start of efforts to pursue notorious right-wing generals in South America for human rights crimes committed in 1970's and 1980's, for which they had been granted amnesty at home; had earned high profile in Spain by investigating explosive issues; his involvement in South America began in 1996 with criminal investigation after several Spanish legal associations asked him to look into charges of torture, disappearance and killing of Spanish citizens in Argentina during country's military rule, from 1976 to 1983; photo (M)

headline: Yeltsin Tells Of His Anger Over Killing Of Lawmaker
