abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin sends his top law-enforcement officials to St Petersburg to investigate killing of Galina V Starovoitova, leading liberal politician and defender of Russia's democratic reforms (M)

headline: Priorities Straight
abstract: National unions of pharmacists and doctors in Jordan, who called for boycott of US drug companies as protest against United States attacks on Iraq, exempt Pfizer's anti-impotence drug, Viagra, from boycott (S)

headline: Monsanto's Profits Are Hurt By Product Development Costs
abstract: Monsanto Co reports 15.5 percent decline in third-quarter earnings; profit before charges fell to $87 million from $103 million a year earlier; Monsanto, which also makes drugs, says sales rose 15.7 percent, to $1.99 billion from $1.72 billion; sales were aided by $140 million payment from Pfizer Inc under marketing agreement for Monsanto arthritis drug that is expected to go on the market in 1999 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises sharply against US dollar on comments from Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa in support of weaker dollar; in New York, dollar trades at 117.82 yen, down from 119.31 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Is the Time Right for Market Timing?
abstract: Mark Hulbert article on strategies employed by market timers, compared with buy-and-hold investors, during market downturn; chart (M)

headline: FORSTMANN LITTLE PLANS TO SELL COMMSCOPE SHARES
abstract: Forstmann Little & Co plans to sell 6.75 million shares of Commscope Inc valued at $102 million in public offering and distribute additional 450,000 shares to investment firm's partners (S)

headline: Bank of England Cuts Key Rate by Half-Point
abstract: Bank of England lowers its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, to 6.25 percent, third cut in as many months; cites persistent 'deterioration across the economy' as reason for rate cut (M)

headline: Java's Universality Is a Threat to Microsoft
abstract: Java, programming language at issue in the contract dispute between the Microsoft Corp and Sun Microsystems, is fundamentally different from other computer languages like C, C++, Pascal or Basic because it is intended to be used over networks, especially by many kinds of computers running different operating systems; from programmer's point of view Java makes all operating systems equal and that poses serious threat to Microsoft, whose market dominance is based on fact that Windows is industry standard (M)

headline: Drug Maker To Close Plants And Cut Jobs
abstract: Johnson & Johnson, world's fifth-largest drug maker, announces that, in move to bolster lagging earnings, it will take $800 million charge in fourth quarter in part to close 36 plants and cut 4,100 jobs, about 4 percent of its global work force; eleven of plants are in United States; cuts come as Johnson & Johnson struggles to keep pace with its competitors; in third quarter, company posted 11 percent increase in earnings. one of worst performances in the industry, while most of its competitors had gains of some 16 percent (M)

headline: New Rules Alter Plans for Diesel Engines
abstract: Auto industry's broad plans to start putting diesels into millions of vehicles early in next century are thrown into confusion after California environmental regulators vote to eliminate more lenient pollution standards currently imposed on diesel-powered vehicles; regulators say it will be almost impossible to design diesel engines to meet new standards; there will be virtual ban on diesel engines in California once new rules are phased in between 2004 and 2007; state accounts for tenth of nation's auto sales; auto industry had been counting on diesels to improve fuel efficiency, but many American environmentalists are dubious about diesels (M)

headline: Choosing a Nanny
abstract: Judith S Lederman letter, responding to Oct 8 article, says position of a nanny is more than a job, it should be viewed as a profession

headline: Under Prodding, 2 Apologize for Cambodian Anguish
abstract: Nuon Chea and Khieu Samphan, former Khmer Rouge leaders, apologize, under prodding by Cambodian reporters, for suffering they caused Cambodian people; photos (M)

headline: Starwood Ends An Equity Swap
abstract: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide terminates financing arrangement with affiliates of Merrill Lynch & Co, Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc and what was Nationsbank before it merged with BankAmerica; termination involves repurchase of about eight million Starwood shares for $255 million (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY    None

headline: Norwich Union Buys Business From Hartford
abstract: Norwich Union PLC acquires London and Edinburgh, general insurance company, from Hartford Financial Services Group for 315 million pounds ($524.2 million) (S)

headline: Excerpts From Videotape of the Gates Deposition Played in the Courtroom
abstract: Excerpts from videotaped testimony by Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates at antitrust trial

headline: Compressed Data; Reporters Get the Story On Silicon Real Estate
abstract: John Chambers of Cisco Systems and Larry Ellison of Oracle, in what could be new trend among computer industry chiefs, have both invited reporters to their homes for private social events in last two weeks (M)

headline: ALLIED SIGNAL'S MOVES ON AMP STILL DELAYED
abstract: US District Court Judge James T Giles says he does not have power to decide whether Allied Signal Inc has resolved conflict-of-interest questions in its bid to expand board of AMP Inc as part of $9.8 billion takeover; Giles says he cannot lift his order blocking Allied Signal's so-called consent solicitation of AMP shareholders on board-packing plan while it is under appeal to US Appeals Court; decision throws another block in front of Allied's bid for AMP (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar weakens in response to probable House vote to impeach Pres Clinton; graphs; table (S)

headline: C.I.A. Said to Reject Bomb Suspect's Bid to be Spy
abstract: Ali A Mohamed, former sergeant in US Army who is being held in connection with terrorist campaign of Osama bin Laden, was rejected in 1980's when he offered himself to CIA as spy; CIA officials decided that Mohamed, who was officer in Egyptian military at time, was too unreliable to be useful agent inside Egypt (M)

headline: Moscow Memo; Primakov's Silence Raises Worries, and the Ruble
abstract: Russian Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov's silence over last six weeks on nation's fiscal crisis worries economists, financiers and politicians; Primakov, never gregarious, has been almost Delphic on subject of Russia's economic policy since taking over day-to-day management of Govt on Sept 11; there has been no shortage of pronouncements: he has pledged to start paying both current and back wages to state workers and military, to start collecting more taxes and to improve management of 40,000 companies in which Russian Govt has stake (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Fall on Concern About Slowdown in Exports  Stocks fell for the first time in three sessions, led by Procter & Gamble and other companies that depend on exports after Union Carbide warned that slow Asian sales would crimp fourth-quarter earnings.    The Dow Jones industrial average fell 42.49 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 9,027.98. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 6.32 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 1,181.38. The Nasdaq composite index declined 5.89 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 2,034.75. In the bond market, Treasury prices rose as the yield on the the benchmark 30-year issue fell to 4.99 percent, the lowest since Oct. 19. [Page C9.]

headline: Holiday Shopping Off to Good Start
abstract: Department store executives express cautious optimism about sales for 1998 holiday season as unexpectedly warm weather brought hordes of shoppers to malls during Thanksgiving weekend; photo (M)

headline: Doner Is Named As Agency for May
abstract: May Department Stores Co names W B Doner & Co to handle creative, strategic planning and research duties for 10 of its chains; duties were previously handled in-house (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Howard B. Moss; Harbor International Growth Fund
abstract: Article assesses performance of Harbor International Growth Fund and its manager, Howard B Moss; photo (M)

headline: Germany Is Bolder, Irritating Its Allies
abstract: New Government of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder is using bold, often challenging, directness that is radical departure from other post-war German administrations; Schroder has bitterly attacked what he calls Germany's unfairly high contributions to wasteful European Union budget; his Foreign Minister, Joschka Fischer, has suggested that NATO change its nuclear policies; and Finance Min Oskar Lafontaine makes clear that American-style global capitalism is not to his taste; many younger Germans are enthusiastic about new Government's freewheeling style, but shock to United States, and to European allies, has been palpable; photo (M)

headline: Smoke Without the Mirrors; For Cigar Makers Big and Small, the 90's Were Good Years
abstract: Following on coattails of expensive cigars, sales of brands such as Swisher Sweets, White Owl and Dutch Masters, which sell for considerably less, have surged in last five years as result of cigar craze; industry officials, however, say boom has already peaked, with glut at upper end of market; note sales in the United States rose to $1.4 billion in 1997 from $192 million in 1992, but also note that growth is expected to be flat this year; Americans are expected to buy four billion machine-made cigars this year--10 times as many as hand-rolled premiums--33 percent increase in five years, according to Cigar Association of America; in dollar terms, however, pricier hand-rolled imports now account for about half revenue growth, with premium imports quadrupling to 400 million in last five years; photos of making cigars; charts on sales (L)

headline: The Drama of Impeachment, From 130 Years Ago
abstract: New Web site offers excerpts from coverage of Pres Andrew Johnson's impeachment, which he survived by one vote in 1868; drawing (S)

headline: Southwest Air to Try Its Continental Wings
abstract: Southwest Airlines, no-frills, discount carrier that has made its name flying short hops between secondary airports, plans to offer its first nonstop, transcontinental service for $99 one way on Thanksgiving Day; airline is playing down significance of inaugural flight from Oakland to Baltimore and back, calling it one-time test; Southwest has strong incentive to lengthen its flights because of new Federal law that will eventually charge $3 a passenger each time a plane takes off and lands (M)

headline: A Needle in the Internet Haystack
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on trying to use the Internet to help her 9-year-old daughter with a homework project; says it was an all-or-nothing experience that happened to work out this time; drawing (M)

headline: Microsoft Sets Push for Corporate Market
abstract: William H Gates, chairman of Microsoft Corp, says next battleground for personal computer industry is industrial-strength corporate computing--lucrative domain of firms such as IBM, Sun Microsystems and Oracle; in speaking of 'PC model'--hardware and software as separate businesses, says outcome of battle is not much in doubt as PC model takes over rest of the industry; Microsoft, however, has not really cracked sizable market for heavy-duty computing tasks such as securities trading or travel reservations systems, but upcoming announcement by Nasdaq stock market that it plans to move one of its key systems from a mainframe computer onto cluster of powerful PC server computers, running Windows NT, opens possibilities (M)

headline: Microsoft's New Turf: Digital Speakers
abstract: Microsoft Corp is introducing digital speakers for the personal computer that it says will better take advantage of its Windows 98 system and eliminate need for sound card; photo (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Cent Vt Pub Svc  Oxford Inds    TUESDAY  Grt Atl & Pac Tea  Hillenbrand  Nalco Chem  Pall  Puget Sound Enrgy

headline: Rizo de Oro Journal; Under Siege, Zapatistas Keep Their Profile Low
abstract: Zapatista rebels in Rizo de Oro and scores of other villages across Indian regions of Chiapas State in Mexico are keeping a low profile, although there are subtle signs everywhere of presence of Zapatista rebel army; since June Zapatistas have suspended their demonstrations, following Govt crackdowns aimed at destroying Zapatista town administrations; photo; map (L)

headline: King Hussein Ails. His Brother Waits.
abstract: King Hussein's cancer has inspired those around him in Jordan's ruling circles to plan for seamless transition that king himself envisioned when he named his younger brother, Crown Prince Hassan, as his successor more than three decades ago; 51-year-old Crown Prince, in rare interview, talks about close relationship with king, his aspirations for regional peace and irritation with those who criticize his manner as overly erudite and intellectual; photo; Hassan has been standing in since king went to Mayo Clinic for cancer treatment more than three months ago (M)

headline: Long War Saps Spirit And Money In Congo
abstract: Residents of Kinshasa, Congo, once euphoric, are increasingly weary of nation's war against rebels, war that has drawn in seven of Congo's neighbors; Congo Pres Laurent Kabila refusees to meet with rebels; many in Kinshasa think officials should meet with rebels; photo; map (M)

headline: NABORS INDUSTRIES OFFERS TO ACQUIRE POOL ENERGY
abstract: Nabors Industries Inc offers to acquire its rival, Pool Energy Services Co, for $486 million (S)

headline: ISRAELIS THREATEN TO ABANDON TALKS, THEN BACK DOWN
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu backs down from threat to abandon Maryland peace talks after Palestinian and Israeli security officials meet with Central Intelligence Agency Dir George J Tenet and apparently make progress on key security issues; American official says little of substance changed in security talks; calls threat to leave ploy intended for Israeli domestic consumption (M)

headline: Foes of Mahathir See U.S. Misstep : Clinton Exhorts Asia To Pursue Reforms
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  Opposition politicians said Wednesday that Vice President Al Gore's speech here supporting political reform in Malaysia had hurt their cause and strengthened Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad's rule.

headline: FORD CREDIT PLANS TO BUY THE PRIVATELY HELD AMI LEASING
abstract: Ford Credit Co, financing arm of Ford Motor Co, agrees to buy AMI Leasing Group; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: NBC Says Time Is Right As It Picks an Executive
abstract: NBC officially names Scott Sassa as executive who will lead network's entertainment division, installing him as president of entertainment in place of Warren Littlefield; NBC president Bob Wright also makes clear network's plan to have Sassa replace Don Ohlmeyer, who heads NBC's entertainment operations as president of its West Coast divison, when Ohlmeyer completes his contract in January 2000 (M)

headline: Microsoft Denied Access to Scholars' Tapes
abstract: Federal appeals court in Boston rules unanimously that scholars should be granted First Amendment privilege similar to those of journalists, denying Microsoft Corp access to research of Michael A Cusumano, professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and David B Yoffie, professor at Harvard Business School; Microsoft sought unpublished notes and tapes of interviews conducted by professors for use in its defense in antitrust suit brought by Government; suit contends that Microsoft used its market power illegally to thwart competition from its main rival for Internet browser software, Netscape Communications Corp; two companies' rivalry is focus of book, Competing on Internet Time: Lessons From Netscape and Its Battle With Microsoft by Cusumano and Yoffie (M)

headline: Sales for G.M. Last Month Were Better Than Expected
abstract: General Motors Corp is rebounding faster than expected from strike that shut down most of its North American factories during summer; GM reports September vehicle sales totaled 393,364 cars and light trucks, 3.1 percent decline compared with year-earlier but less of drop than analysts had expected; GM closed 1998 model year selling 4.6 million light vehicles, down 2.6 percent; GM's market share bounced back to 31 percent, level it was at before strike began; company officials deny that GM is offering larger incentives than its rivals; charts (M)

headline: Cardinal Health Is Acquiring Allegiance Hospital Supply
abstract: Cardinal Health Inc says it will buy Allegiance Corp for $4.5 billion in stock and assume $890 million of its debt (M)

headline: U.S. Is Joining 2d Suit Against Hospital Chain
abstract: Justice Dept announces that it has joined lawsuit filed by whistle-blower against Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, bringing new allegations that company defrauded Federal health programs through scheme involving bogus expense claims; action is second instance since October of Government's joining a whistle-blower suit against Columbia/HCA; both suits contend that health giant systematically cheated Federal programs like Medicare out of millions of dollars by routinely overstating expenses in filed reports (M)

headline: Talks on Global Warming Treaty Resuming Today
abstract: International negotiators are set to resume talks in Buenos Aires over details of global treaty to fight global warming with expectations greatly lowered (M)

headline: HICKS, MUSE TO BUY BOOKER SEED UNIT FOR $48.9 MILLION
abstract: Hicks Muse Tate & Furst Inc says it will buy Danish horticultural seed business L Daehnfeldt AS for about $48.9 million from British food wholesaler Booker PLC (S)

headline: Projected Costs of Year 2000 Bug Jump
abstract: Cap Gemini Group survey shows spending in major Western nations on Year 2000 computer bug has jumped 93 percent since April to $494 billion from $256 billion; finds US is further along with businesses having spent 61 percent of their projected Year 2000 budgets, compared with European average of 48 percent; but Americans remain more wary, with 83 percent expressing confidence that all 'mission critical' systems will be ready, compared with 95 percent of European companies (S)

headline: NBC to Name New President For Network Entertainment
abstract: NBC plans to name Scott Sassa as president for entertainment division, replacing Warren Littlefield; NBC has decided to move Sassa from his current job as president of NBC's station division, to set up transition period during which Sassa could work under NBC's top entertainment executive, Don Ohlmeyer, before taking over for Ohlmeyer, when he decides to step down; Ohlmeyer is expected to leave when his contract expires in 2000; photos (M)

headline: Allianz and Munich Re To Trade Some Holdings
abstract: Allianz AG reaches accord with Munchener Ruckversicherungs-Gesellschaft AG (Munich Re) on previously announced restructuring; will get Munich Re's holdings of some 15 percent of Allianz of America and nearly 4 percent of Alliaz Lebensversicherungs AG, its domestic unit; Munich Re will get nearly 6.5 percent of Allianz's Ergo Versicherungsgruppe AG unit and about 6.9 percent of American Re Corp (S)

headline: Mergers May Not Be Music to Investor Ears
abstract: Analysts say excess capacity, other factors driving new wave of giant corporate mergers, cut across many industries and are likely to spur more and more mergers; study by Prof Mark L Sirower finds merged company's stock usually underperforms its peers long afterward; graph (M)9

headline: Cartoonists Old and New Are Drawn to the Net
abstract: Cartoon sites on Web described; photos of on-line cartoonists Peter Sinclair (Alex's Restaurant) and bill amend (Foxtrot) (M)

headline: Charles Delafield, 93, Utility Executive
abstract: Charles B Delafield, former executive for Consolidated Edison, dies at age 93 (S)

headline: Bayer Takes U.S. Partner in Herbicides
abstract: Bayer AG and Paradigm Genetics agree to collaborate in developing new herbicides; Paradigm will receive as much as $40 million to use its biotechology expertise to identify genes that could be effective in herbicides (S)

headline: 3-Way Effort Seems to Slow Bombings By Terrorists
abstract: Increased cooperation by American-Israeli-Palestinian anti-terrorist agencies may be hindering bombing efforts by terrorists; such difficulties, faced by Hamas and a local counterpart, Islamic Holy War, seem evident in bombing in Jerusalem market that may have been work of either group; relatively small primitively rigged charge was packed in car that apparently caught fire before the explosion, giving police precious moments to remove scores of intended victims; photo (M)

headline: Williams Buys the Rest of Volunteer Energy
abstract: Williams Companies buys remaining 50 percent of Volunteer Energy Corp that it does not already own for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Playing Movies Like a Growth Stock
abstract: Profile of Artisan Entertainment, Lions Gate Entertainment and Stratosphere Entertainment, companies set up by financiers to cash in on profit potential of low-cost independent films; companies seek to both buy and produce films; tables; photos (M)

headline: The Debacle That Buried Washington; Long After the S.& L. Crisis, Courts Are Handing Taxpayers a New Bill
abstract: US Court of Federal Claims Chief Judge Loren A Smith is about to assess damages in first big test case stemming from 1980's savings and loan crisis; size of award to Glendale Federal Bank, California savings and loan that nearly collapsed, could set tone for other settlements and may cost taxpayers anywhere from $4 billion to $50 billion; photos (M)

headline: Some Oil Countries to Maintain Limits
abstract: Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Kuwait and Oman agree to extend production cuts set in June that have helped prop up falling oil prices; also agree that deeper cuts should be made (S)

headline: PICKER INTERNATIONAL TO BUY AN ISRAELI IMAGING BUSINESS
abstract: Elscint Ltd, Haifa, Israel, to sell its computed tomography division to Picker International Inc for $269.5 million (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Expected
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: CONCENTRA SHARES UP 93% ON ORACLE'S $43 MILLION OFFER
abstract: Stock of Concentra Corp rises 93 percent after Oracle Corp says it will buy company in cash tender offer for $43 million; under the offer, Oracle must acquire 51 percent of Concentra stock at $7 a share (S)

headline: Assets of a Bombing Suspect: Keen Wit, Religious Soul, Angry Temper
abstract: Article profiles 26-year-old Abdallah Mohammed Fazul, man accused of playing central role in bombing of US Embassy in Kenya on August 7, killing 11 Americans and over 200 Kenyans; he grew up impoverished in Comoros Islands as brilliant student of Koran with angry temper; left for Pakistan 11 years ago to continue education but fell under sway of terrorists, launching holy war against US; remains at large with $2 million reward on his head; photos; map (M)

headline: A FORMER TOP CHRYSLER EXECUTIVE IS SET TO RETIRE
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG says Dennis Pawley, who managed Chrysler Corp's worldwide manufacturing, will retire in Jan, first top executive to leave since Daimler-Benz's takeover of Chrysler (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A tale of executives and egos: When does the board decide it's time to tell a chief he must leave?
abstract: Market Place column on issue of when board of directors decides it is time to tell chief executive to leave focuses on Smithkline Beecham chief executive Jan Leschly, who has denied reports that he is retiring, and John R Stafford, chairman of American Home Products; says both executives have had failed mergers this year that can be attributed to their refusals, in separate deals, to share power; holds if stock price is gauge for dismissal, Stafford will not be leaving any time soon because shares of American Home are up 26.8 percent; Leschly may not so fortunate because Smithkline shares are up 20 percent on speculation of Leschly's imminent departure and resulting merger with Glaxo Wellcome (M)

headline: U.N. Tries to Cajole Iraq Into Cooperating on Arms Inspections
abstract: The Security Council called on Iraq today to resume cooperation with United Nations weapon inspectors, alluding to prospects for faster progress on easing economic sanctions against Baghdad if it heeds the call.    That and several somewhat conciliatory statements by various members of the 15-member Council followed a periodic review today of Iraq's compliance in eliminating its weapons of mass destruction.

headline: Media Talk; Advice About Clothing And a Snug Fit for the Ads
abstract: Special 'Clotheskeeping' issue of Martha Stewart Living magazine has only one advertiser, the Gap, which prompts some misgivings in magazine industry; photos (S)

headline: BUSINESS: DIARY
abstract: Northwest Airlines finished buying a controlling stake in Continental Airlines, though in response to regulatory concerns it bought fewer shares than it originally wanted. . . . AMR, parent of American Airlines, agreed to acquire Reno Air, a struggling discount carrier in the West. . . . The threatened pilot's strike at Federal Express was put off by 60 days, until well past Christmas, to allow more time for negotiations. . . . A meteor shower that some experts feared would disrupt satellite communications passed harmlessly.

headline: Medical Concern Job Cuts
abstract: Molecular Biosystems Inc to cut 40 jobs, or more than 28 percent of its work force, in an effort to save $5 million a year (S)

headline: Not Blind, Not Rodents, Not Evil
abstract: Bat enthusiasts, with variety of Web sites, are out to prove that the creatures are not evil and that fears are irrational; several sites notes; photos (M)

headline: A Bankruptcy Rush, Just in Case
abstract: Lawyers across US report surge in bankruptcy filings as bankruptcy bill makes its way through Congress to Pres Clinton; Clinton reportedly plans to veto legislation; photo (M)

headline: Continental Airlines Posts Record Net Before Charge
abstract: Continental Airlines reports record third-quarter earnings, excluding previously announced one-time charge, and acknowledges publicly for first time that Clinton Administration might file suit to block Northwest Airlines from buying controlling stake in Continental; Continental says net earnings declined 34 percent, to $73 million, because of $77 million after-tax charge to retire older jets; excluding charge, profit soared more than 31 percent, to $150 million from $114 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue grew 12 percent, to $2.11 billion, compared with $1.89 billion in 1997 (M)

headline: U.S. General Defends Chats At Panmunjom
abstract: PANMUNJOM—  The U.S. general in charge of military negotiations with North Koreans in this truce village has defended informal gatherings with North Korean Army officers, saying that cutting off such contacts would close an important channel for easing tensions.

headline: JAPAN ANNOUNCES $195 BILLION PLAN TO REVIVE ECONOMY
abstract: Japan announces $195 billion economic stimulus package, its largest package in eight years of economic malaise; increases amount of plan by about $47 billion in last week, boosting effect that it will have on the economy and underscoring anxieties in Tokyo and around world about Japan's recession and risk that it will drag down rest of world's economic growth as well; package in many ways is last-ditch attempt by Prime Min Keizo Obuchi to demonstrate his resolve to pull Japan out recession (M)

headline: People
abstract: SF Interactive names Rob Middleton to new post of principal and media services director; Asher & Partners names Christopher Wauton to new post of vice president and account planning director; Draft Worldwide names Geoffrey Kehoe to new post of senior vice president and group account director (S)

headline: Japan Drafts Economic Plan and It Is Met With Skepticism
abstract: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic party released draft plan to bolster economy, but financial markets and analysts are skeptical, saying package is hodgepodge of measures that will have little effect (S)

headline: Home Resales Fell Last Month
abstract: National Association of Realtors says home resales fell 1.1 percent in September, to annual rate of 4.68 million; median price of a home fell 1.2 percent, to $131,300 from $132,900 in August (S)

headline: Port-au-Prince Journal; Whose Rock Is It? And, Yes, the Haitians Care
abstract: US and Haiti are engaged in war of words over ownership of Navassa Island, uninhabited outcropping in Caribbean island barely two miles square, rich in insect species organic fertilizer; pledge by Interior Department to protect island from interlopers has raised ire of Haitian Govt, which has threatened to take matter to international tribunal; US has controlled island off Haiti's southwest peninsula for more than 140 years, but all except one of 24 Haitian Constitutions since country gained independence from France in 1804 have described island as inalienable part of Haitian territory; basis of US claim is Guano Islands Act of 1856, which authorized US vessels to establish sovereignty on any abandoned or unclaimed island with rich reserves of fertilizer from bird droppings; maps; photo (M)

headline: Pope Asks World Effort for Balkan Victims
abstract: Pope John Paul II visits Croatia; is welcomed in capital of Zagreb by Pres Franjo Tudjman; calls for reconciliation throughout former Yugoslavia; urges world to do more for victims of Balkan war that ended not so long ago, and is raging in Kosovo, Serbia; photo (M)

headline: Lords in London Hear Appeal on Pinochet Immunity Decision
abstract: England's High Court is asked by lawyers for Spanish authorities to overrule decision that granted Gen Augusto Pinochet immunity from prosecution for 'savage and barbarous crimes' in 17 years that he ruled Chile (M)

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS RATES AGAIN; WALL ST. SURGES
abstract: Federal Reserve unexpectedly cuts overnight lending rate by quarter-point, to five percent, to encourage more lending and bolster economy by making it cheaper for businesses and consumers to borrow; Wall Street, stunned, responds with powerfull rally that sends Dow Jones average up 330 points; chairman Alan Greenspan acts on his own authority after consulting with members of Fed's policy-making committee; board also approves quarter-point cut, to 4.75 percent, in discount rate on loans from Federal Reserve to banks; statement refers to likelihood of slowdown and need to sustain economic growth in 'context of contained inflation'; several banks respond by reducing prime rates, which may lead to slightly lower rates on consumer loans and mortgages; Dow Jones closes at 8,299, highest level since August 26; bond prices also surge, although dollar falls against yen; chronology of market events since Sept 23; graphs; Fed's abrupt action prompts speculation that another financial institution may be in trouble, which might further damage fragile market psychology; Greenspan's recent expressions of concern quoted (M)

headline: Brazil Stocks Gyrate, Falling From Highs Inspired by I.M.F. Bailout
abstract: Brazilian stocks gyrate wildly in December, mostly downward, after soaring earlier on what analysts called excessive optimism about International Monetary Fund bailout; more irrational selling is expected as Congress balks at adopting austerity program; trading volume has plunged, with low liquidity magnifying small movements; most foreign investors have fled (M)

headline: Stockholders Reject Plan to Move British Auto Supplier to U.S.
abstract: Small shareholders in LucasVariety PLC, British-based auto components and aerospace company, vote by hair's breadth for company to remain in Britain rather than move its headquarters to Buffalo, NY, as both management and big American investors wanted; battle had assumed jingoistic overtones, since most of Britain's automotive industry is now owned by American, Japanese or German concerns; LucasVariety employs 56,000 people and has recorded sales of $7.8 billion; it is one of world's biggest producers of automotive brakes and counts General Motors and Ford among its main customers; former Lucas Industries PLC of Britain bought Variety Corp of Buffalo in 1996 to form LucasVariety (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   5.19   4.84   5.92        3-month T-bills   4.43   4.41   5.11        6-month T-bills   4.41   4.43   5.19        10-yr. T-infl.   3.74   3.74   3.54        10-yr. T-note   4.71   4.80   5.85        30-yr. T-bond   5.07   5.16   6.04        Telephone bd.   6.80   6.84   7.37        Municipal bds.   5.10   5.11   5.33          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Keeping Walgreens on Main St.
abstract: Interview with Walgreen Co chief executive L Daniel Jorndt on his strategy for nation's largest drugstore chain; he stresses convenience, pays close attention to details and is pulling stores out of strip malls; photo (M)

headline: Women on the Web
abstract: Rosemary Pepper letter says Oct 22 article on Internet sites of interest to women was off the mark in describing the network she helped found, Estronet

headline: Europeans, But Not U.S., Rejoice At Ruling
abstract: Many European leaders hail British ruling that former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet can be extradited to Spain; United States officials and legal experts seem uneasy with idea that former Government leaders can be held responsible by foreign courts; United Nations Human Rights High Comr Mary Robinson sees ruling heartening human rights defenders around world; photo (M)

headline: Ex-U.S. Attorney Admits Investor Fraud
abstract: John A Field 3d, former Federal prosecutor who also served as top enforcement officer of Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and Marcus K Dalton, described as professional con artist and telemarketing expert, plead guilty to racketeering and conspiracy charges in telemarketing plot that cheated would-be investors of more than $80 million; as part of plea bargains, Field and Dalton helped authorities conduct sting operation in which Federal agents created fake mutual fund, purportedly dealing in foreign currencies, and used it to infiltrate operations known as 'boiler rooms' that sell fraudulent investments to the public (M)

headline: MATRIA HEALTHCARE TO BUY GAINOR MEDICAL MANAGEMENT
abstract: Matria Healthcare Inc will buy Gainor Medical Management, largest US provider of obstetric care in home, for about $130 million (S)

headline: Partners to Seek Rest Of Argentine Chain
abstract: Royal Ahold NV and Argentina's Velox Retail Holdings to bid through their joint venture for remaining 48 percent of Argentine supermarket Disco SA in deal worth about $158.9 million (US) (S)

headline: U.S. Plans to Keep Up Pressure on Saddam : 'Cat and Mouse' Over
abstract: PARIS—  With United Nations arms inspectors no longer able to function in Iraq, the Clinton administration intends to apply open-ended, direct military pressure on the Baghdad regime until the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, finds a way to clear his country's record on clandestine weapons, a senior American official said Monday.

headline: Big Board Revises Its Trading-Halt Limits
abstract: New York Stock Exchange says it will take an 800-point intraday drop in Dow Jones industrial average to halt trading in US equity markets in fourth quarter; changes take effect Oct 1; 800-point intraday drop in Dow industrials will halt trading for one hour if decline occurs before 2 PM, for 30 minutes, if between 2 and 2:30 and have no effect between 2:30 and 4 (S)

headline: Daimler Holders Swap Old Shares
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG says its shareholders swapped 97 percent of their shares in company into stock of forthcoming DaimlerChrysler AG, enabling company to avoid accounting charges of 54.9 billion German marks, or $33.5 billion, as it buys Chrysler Corp (S)

headline: Economic Turmoil's Latest Turns Raise the Level of Anxiety in U.S.
abstract: World economic crisis spreads nervousness in United States; Japan is strangely optimistic, with stock prices soaring on hopes for big infusion of government money into banks (S)

headline: Microsoft Accused of Sabotaging Witness's Computer Program
abstract: Princeton University computer-science expert Dr Edward W Felten accuses Microsoft Corp in Federal court of sabotaging computer program he had written to demonstrate key point in Government's antitrust suit against Microsoft; Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson becomes visibly angry at idea that Microsoft might have taken advantage of information it acquired through court to sabotage Government's case (M)

headline: Discovering That Nature Moves to City Rhythms, Too
abstract: Robert Sullivan article on nature as revealed in urban setting, such as Portland, Ore, where he lives; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; In the Battle for Advertisers, Parties, Parties Everywhere
abstract: Conde Nast magazine company will be host at four parties over two nights when American Society of Travel Agents holds its annual conference in Los Angeles (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CARBIDE/GRAPHITE GROUP,  Pittsburgh, a maker of graphite and calcium-carbide products, said it planned to dismiss 100 workers and close some operations at a plant in St. Marys, Pa., by January.    FRESH DEL MONTE PRODUCE INC.,  Coral Gables, Fla., a producer of bananas, pineapples and melons, said Hurricane Mitch had caused an estimated $35 million in damage to its plant in Guatemala, affecting 10 percent of its worldwide banana crop.

headline: Money Isn't Everything, Especially in Retirement
abstract: James H Chapman letter lauds Fred Brock's October 4 column on money needed for retirement (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nasdaq and S.& P. Indexes Reach New Record Highs  Talk of a possible merger between Mobil and Exxon sent stocks higher. The Nasdaq composite index climbed above 2,000 for the first time since July 20. It rose 31.23 points, to 2,016.44, setting a new high just two points above its previous top of 2,014.25.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Netscape Co-Founder Plans To Invest in VCR Alternative  A co-founder of Netscape Communications is expected to announce today that he has invested in one of two companies developing digital television recording systems, a technology intended to replace the traditional home VCR.    The investment by Marc Andreessen in Replay Networks Inc., a small Silicon Valley start-up, would be an important vote of confidence for the systems, which enable viewers to watch, store and retrieve programs in novel ways, including recording a complete program that is already in progress, automatically recording programs that meet certain criteria -- for example, movies with a particular actor -- and skipping commercials. [Page C2.]

headline: For Japanese Tourists, It's First Stop Las Vegas
abstract: Japanese tourists, as economic woes continue, make Las Vegas, Nev, their main travel destination; graphs; photo (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   4.94   4.95   5.53        3-month T-bills   4.43   4.43   5.12        6-month T-bills   4.42   4.42   5.12        10-yr. T-infl.   3.82   3.82   3.54        10-yr. T-note   4.82   4.82   5.85        30-yr. T-bond   5.29   5.29   6.10        Telephone bd.   6.86   6.86   7.42        Municipal bds.   5.15   5.15   5.42          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: PENNZOIL TO TAKE $115.6 MILLION CHARGE IN THIRD QUARTER
abstract: Pennzoil Co says it will take $115.6 million of charges for debt refinancing, foreign projects, low oil and gas prices and weather problems, giving it a loss for third quarter (S)

headline: Middle East Accord in Peril As Both Sides Appeal to the U.S.
abstract: Israel and Palestinians appeal to US to salvage land-for-security peace accord, which has been severely tested by pattern of postponements by Israel's Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, who has again delayed presenting it Cabinet for ratification because of persistent pressure from right-wingers; he is demanding that US wrest from Palestinians written timetable for arresting 30 fugitives wanted for terrorism; Palestinians accuse Netanyahu of political brinksmanship; accuse Israel of taking advantage of delays to establish footholds for new settlements on West Bank, which would be illegal once agreement takes effect; implore US to compel him to move beyond impasse; Statye Dept spokesman says Palestinians have submitted acceptable security plan, meeting their obligations for accord to take effect, and that US believes there is no reason to delay implementation; photo (M)

headline: Neckties at Work: Untangling the Knot
abstract: Sun Park letter says suit and tie are the proper attire at work (Dec 6 article)2

headline: SHARES DROP AS TELXON REPORTS SECOND-QUARTER LOSS
abstract: Stock of Telxon Corp, maker of bar-code transmitters, plunges 45 percent after company says it experienced second-quarter loss instead of profit and warns of third-quarter deficit (S)

headline: Momentum Awards For Work on Internet
abstract: Several Internet-related companies and executives are honored for leadership and innovation at Momentum Awards ceremony (S)

headline: Raytheon Widens Layoffs; Lower Earnings Foreseen
abstract: Raytheon Co says it will expand layoffs to about 14,000 jobs, and will not meet Wall Street's expectations for third-quarter earnings (M)

headline: LIFE FINANCIAL CANCELS DEAL WITH FIRSTPLUS FINANCIAL
abstract: Life Financial Corp cancels agreement to be acquired by Firstplus Financial Group Inc for $138 million (S)

headline: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN SETS UP TO $1 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc will repurchase as much as $1 billion more of its stock by 2000 (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: GUIDANT CORP.,  Indianapolis, a maker of products used in cardiac rhythm management and vascular intervention, said it would split its stock 2 for 1 after its shares rose 70 percent this year.    RYDER SYSTEM INC.,  Miami, a provider of logistics and transportation solutions, plans to buy back as many as 3 million shares, or 4.2 percent of its common stock. The company has about 71.2 million shares outstanding.

headline: Not Showing This Week: Gates's Taped Testimony
abstract: Microsoft Corp's lawyers at antitrust case, in pursuing laborious cross-examination of David Colburn, America Online senior vice president, foil plans by Justice Department to close the week with much-anticipated--and in Microsoft's case, much-dreaded--videotaped questioning of its chairman, William H Gates (M)

headline: BEA SYSTEMS SHARES FALL ON SALES GROWTH WARNINGS
abstract: The stock of BEA Systems Inc., the No. 2 maker of software for airline reservation systems, lost about half their value yesterday after the company issued a surprise warning that sales growth would slow because customers had delayed orders. Shares plunged $13.0625, to $13.9375, in trading of 20.2 million shares, making it the most active United States stock. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., blamed recessions in Asia and economic slowdowns elsewhere for the delay in corporate purchases. BEA was founded in 1995.

headline: Details Given, and 5 More Charged, in Tanzania Bombing
abstract: Federal prosecutors, in first detailed account of August 7 bombing of US Embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, say it was carried out by group of men who detonated bomb packed with car batteries and oxygen tanks, apparently to enhance lethal force of explosion; say explosion, which killed 11 people including one bomber, and wounded 80 others, was photographed by one suspect who later fled; identifies five men as followers of Saudi exile Osama bin Laden, who is suspected of organizing simultaneous attacks on embassies in Tanzania and Kenya as well as other acts of terrorism against Americans abroad; listed as Fahad Mohammed Ali Msalam, Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, Khalfan Khamis Mohammed, Sheik Ahmed Salim Swedan, Mustafa Mohammed Fadhil; their photos (M)

headline: Shares of Telecom To Be Sold to Public
abstract: France will sell France Telecom SA shares to public for 390 francs, or $67.90 each, raising at least $6.4 billion; sale is heavily oversubscribed, as is sale of France Telecom's convertible bonds; institutional investors will pay extra 10 francs per share (S)

headline: Force in Bosnia Fails at One Task: A Pullout
abstract: Patrols in Bosnia by American and other NATO forces have become mostly routine, although troops still run into roadblocks, angry crowds and illegal weapons caches, but mission has not figured out how to leave; nobody in Clinton Administration will admit there is no end in sight, for fear of further irritating Congress, but evidence is clear; NATO has broken ground on new headquarters near Sarajevo, UN is spending $34 million to buff up its camps and extend runways at Tuzla; photos; map; many central promises of Dayton accords remain unfulfilled; Sarajevo's streets bustle, but most of country remains economically listless; unified government barely exists, and then only under foreign pressure; NATO commander Gen Wesley K Clark sys 99 percent of military task is completed, but warns of very high risk of fighting if forces dare to go home (M)

headline: CLINTON IS SENDING BOMBERS AND G.I.'S TO PERSIAN GULF
abstract: Pres Clinton orders substantial new forces to Persian Gulf, including B-1 and B-52 bombers, and warns Pres Saddam Hussein that US is prepared to strike Iraq without further warning; Clinton, in Veterans Day speech at Arlington National Cemetery, says US will be compelled to act unless Iraq immediately permits resumption of United Nations inspections of weapons facilities; UN withdraws virtually all of its inspection officers from Iraq in anticipation of major US attack; Defense Sec William S Cohen announces major buildup of air and ground forces in region; says 4,000 troops will be sent to defend Kuwait in case of Iraqi attack (M)

headline: Roth I.R.A., Much Ignored, Is Worth Getting to Know
abstract: Article describes advantages of investing in Roth IRA's (L)

headline: China's Global Bond Offering Sends Several Messages
abstract: China is expected to raise at least $500 million from foreign investors, becoming first Asian country to issue international bond since Russia devalued its currency and defaulted on its debt in August; investors appear to be crowning China as Asia's best borrower outside Japan; offering is a bit of muscle-flexing by a country that wants everyone to heed Asia's new economic order; some bankers and investors say that China is raising fresh capital because many of its neighbors cannot, at least without paying for more for the privilege (M)

headline: Jewish Groups Fight for Spoils Of Swiss Case
abstract: Jewish humanitarian groups, plaintiffs' lawyers and concentration camp survivors are split over how to divide $1.25 billion paid by Swiss banks to settle Holocaust-related suits and potentially billions more in new claims; only small fraction of Swiss settlement will go to heirs of Jews who had prewar Swiss bank accounts; Jewish charitable groups have been preparing competing proposals to distribute rest of funds; some lawyers and survivors argue money should be paid directly to those who suffered; success in Swiss case has also spurred competition among class-action lawyers to bring new suits against European banks, insurers and manufacturers; drive once spurred by moral outrage may be dissolving into battle over power and money; photos (M)

headline: Poland's Consumer-Credit Industry Grows Quickly
abstract: Article on Lukas SA, Poland's largest consumer-credit business, which seized initiative, despite rapidly mounting international competition, in business that has been crucial in bolstering internal demand, which has in turn helped give Poland highest growth rates in Eastern Europe (M)

headline: Microsoft Plans To Continue Java Support
abstract: Paul Maritz, Microsoft Corp's general manager in charge of dealing with software developers, says company is 'absolutely' going to support Java and will continue to do so as long as there is a desire for it; announcement comes in wake of Federal court ruling that ordered company to change its Java software; in that ruling the court found Microsoft had violated its licensing contract with Sun Microsystems, inventor of Java language, by altering it so it was tailored for Microsoft's Windows and incompatible with Sun's Java technology (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; Something Un-Chinese Haunts a Graduate: Choice
abstract: Li Wei, physics major at Nanjing University expresses some regrets over heeding advice of parents to pursue doctoral studies and to reject well-paying job at Procter & Gamble's headquarters in Beijing; his dilemma reflects that of entire generation of Chinese, whose career choices have expanded dramatically in fast-changing society in which modernity, money and capitalism pull in one direction and tradition, family and Communist ideology in other; photo (M)

headline: Denmark's Central Bank Cuts Rates Again
abstract: Danish central bank cuts interest rates again because three reductions in last seven weeks failed to weaken nation's currency (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Freeze in California Decimates Citrus Crop  A four-day freeze has destroyed more than a third of California's annual citrus crop, inflicting nearly $500 million in damage and leading to predictions that orange prices would triple.     Across California, cold air from the Gulf of Alaska sent temperatures below freezing on Monday, with readings in the high teens and low 20's in the agriculturally rich Central Valley yesterday -- the worst cold spell since a 10-day freeze in 1990. Officials pronounced the lemon crop a near total loss in the valley and said perhaps half the state's orange crop was lost as well. [Page A1.]

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Hog prices rise 1.9 percent after US says it will donate pork to Russia; December contract for lean hog carcasses rises 0.65 cent to settle at 35.85 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Australia Fund Manager In British Acquisition
abstract: AMP Ltd will buy National Provident Institution of Britain for 1.3 billion pounds ($2.2 billion) in cash (S)

headline: N.A.S.D. Will Seek Global Market Ties
abstract: *National Association of Securities Dealers says it will seek affiliations with eight international stock markets, including those in Tokyo, Paris and Mexico City (S)

headline: Exiles Sue Castro in Spain
abstract: Foundation for Human Rights in Cuba, an exile group in Miami, files suit in Spain against Pres Fidel Castro for human rights abuses (S)

headline: Officials Accused of Atrocities Losing Places to Hide, Scholars Say
abstract: Legal scholars say arrest of former Chilean dictator Gen Augusto Pinochet by Scotland Yard on warrant by Spanish magistrate shows growing significance of international human rights law; say it suggests that officials accused of atrocities have fewer places to hide, even if they are carrying diplomatic passports (M)

headline: Troubled Small Bank To Be Merged in Japan
abstract: Hanshin Bank Ltd agrees to take over Midori Bank Ltd of Kobe, Japan, in stock swap valued at 61.82 billion yen ($499 million); two banks will form lender named Minato Bank Ltd, starting business on April 1 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 11 European Nations Move To Lower Interest Rates  Eleven European nations simultaneously cut their interest rates to a nearly uniform low level in the most coordinated action yet toward European monetary union.

headline: People
abstract: Jim Hunn is named to new position of partner and chief creative officer at Earle Palmer Brown (S)

headline: Five Japanese Banks Raise Mortgage Rates
abstract: Five major Japanese banks will raise mortgage rates by as much as 0.8 percent in January 1999, first sign that soaring interest rates will squeeze already embattled Japanese consumer; interest rates have recently been rising as Government sinks deeper into debt while trying to lift economy out of recession with expensive stimulus measures (M)

headline: A Fanfare For the Vanities Of 1998
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson (Market Watch) column on vagaries of 1998 markets suggests awards for year's financial flubs and feats; photos (M)

headline: FAIRCHILD SAYS IT WILL BUY REMAINING 15% OF BANNER
abstract: Fairchild Corp to buy remaining 15 percent of Banner Aerospace Inc that it does not already own, for about $40 million in stock (S)

headline: Locked Together, Mideast Negotiators Chafe
abstract: Description of distrustful political atmosphere at Wye Plantation conference center on Maryland's Eastern Shore, where Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat continue to be suspicious of one another; photo of State Sec Madeleine K Albright, Middle East envoy Dennis Ross, and Netanyahu and Arafat talking over lunch (M)

headline: Volt in $35 Million Deal
abstract: Volt Information Sciences Inc., a United States staffing company, agreed to buy Gatton Computing Group Ltd., a British provider of contract computer staff, for $35 million in cash. The New York-based Volt, which reported revenue of about $1.7 billion in 1998, said it expected the purchase to help earnings in its 1999 fiscal year. The London-based Gatton reported $68 million in 1998 revenue.

headline: PHARMERICA HIRES ADVISER TO WEIGH ALTERNATIVES
abstract: Pharmerica Inc hires Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to advise it on strategic alternatives; company says it has eliminated 46 jobs as part of streamlining and its chief operating officer Robert Della Valle has resigned; also reports third-quarter loss of $127.4 million (S)

headline: The German 'Volk' Seem Set to Let Outsiders In
abstract: German concept of 'Deutschen Volke,' defining German people by bloodlines in way that stirs memories of Nazism, is poised to change, at least legally, with immigration reform that would allow close to three million foreign residents become citizens; change comes as Germany aims to turn Berlin into capital of 'new Europe,' but transition to 'land of immigration' involves profound psychological and generational shift; outraged conservatives see 'multicultural playground' (M)

headline: Preacher to the Doubters in Japan
abstract: Profile of and interview with Marty Whitman, 74, whose Third Avenue Value fund, bucking trend, has invested heavily in Japanese stocks; photo (M)

headline: Stake in Nigerian Bank for Saudi Prince
abstract: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia buys 13.7 percent stake, worth about $12 million, in United Bank of Africa PLC of Nigeria; Prince becomes largest shareholder in bank (S)

headline: Dentsu Considering A Burnett Stake
abstract: Leo Burnett Co and Dentsu agree to proceed with talks to form strategic alliance that would include acquisition of minority stake in Burnett by Dentsu (S)

headline: Small Telephone Company Is Victim of Credit Squeeze
abstract: Telegroup Inc, small international telephone carrier that was flying high just six months ago, is on verge of running out of cash and is weighing takeover offers from at least two communications companies, including Primus Telecommunications Group and IDT Corp (M)

headline: Toyota Earnings Decline by 20%
abstract: Not even solid sales in the United States and a weak yen that made those sales more valuable could save the Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car maker and one of its most financially sound companies, from a decline in profits.    Expenses largely unrelated to Toyota's core auto business chipped away at the company's consolidated earnings, which fell 20 percent, to 192.6 billion yen, or $1.6 billion at current exchange rates, in the six months that ended Sept. 30.

headline: All These Hard Feelings!
abstract: Bankrupt FPA Medical Management Inc terminates $4.8 million severance deal of founder Seth Flam after paying only $255,000 (S)

headline: Patents; Software that tracks the amount of time browsers spend on Web sites and how they use them.
abstract: Thinking Media Corp has new patent for method of tracking how people respond to Internet advertisements and commercial Web sites; company says its approach is singular because rather than count number of ads or Web-site pages sent out by Internet server computers, it counts sites or ads actually received by browser software on individual computers (M)

headline: It Was a Beastly Celebration
abstract: Top financial planners attend reception at American Museum of Natural History's dinosaur room hosted by RCN Corp chairman David C McCourt, whose company offers integrated phone, video and data services (S)

headline: ASHLAND TO TAKE A CHARGE OF $57 MILLION IN 4TH QUARTER
abstract: Ashland Inc will take after-tax charges of $57 million for previously announced severance packages, relocation of headquarters and environmental cleanup (S)

headline: A Virtual Pilgrimage Is Complete With Souvenirs
abstract: New Internet Web site, Jesus2000.com, offers 'Virtual Pilgrimage to the Holy Land,' complete with religious trinkets for sale; photo (News Watch) (S)

headline: A survey of teen-agers will help advertisers decipher the infinite meanings of 'whatever.'
abstract: Survey, called Teen Link, yearlong qualitative look at booming teen-age market by Bates USA and conducted by Teen-Age Research Unlimited, is intended to offer marketers insight into growing demographic group that spent estimated $91.5 billion to $122 billion last year and is significantly changing way products are sold (M)

headline: Zimbabwe's Ex-President Convicted of Sodomy
abstract: Rev Canaan Banana, former President of Zimbabwe, is found guilty of sodomy by court in Harare and faces up to 22 years in jail; Banana, 62, apparently jumped bail and fled to Botswana, where he is said to be seeking political asylum; Banana is Methodist minister; he has denied all charges; he was convicted on charges stemming from incidents with young men assigned to him as bodyguards, gardeners and cooks when he held largely ceremonial post of President from 1980 to 1987; topic is embarrassment to Pres Robert Mugabe, who has publicly referred to gay Zimbabweans as 'worse than pigs or dogs' (M)

headline: NATO Plans to Intensify Its Pressure on Milosevic in Stages
abstract: Senior American and NATO officials say that NATO effort to persuade Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to back down is following a clear track; say it is designed to ratchet up political and military pressure, while providing him with various opportunities to change his mind (M)

headline: Program Notifies You of E-Mail If You Can Stay Off the Phone
abstract: Mailpush Express gives a notice of new E-mail on the computer screen even when the user is off line (S)

headline: Next They'll Say Betty Crocker Isn't Real, Either
abstract: Mindscape, which markets popular software program Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing, explains that 'Mavis, is fictional creation; calm authoritative voice of 'Mavis' has taught six million students to type, using games, music and humor; photos (M)

headline: British Military Supplier Expanding in Norway
abstract: Vickers PLC, Britain's fourth-largest military company, agrees to buy most of Ulstein Holding AS of Norway for 304 million pounds ($502 million) in cash; Vickers will assume 42.5 million pounds of Ulstein debt (S)

headline: Samsung Repays a Sixth Of Its Foreign Debt
abstract: Samsung Electronics Co of South Korea repays one-sixth of its $6.5 billion foreign-currency debt, using in part money raised through five domestic bond sales (S)

headline: U.S. Threatens Europe With 100% Tariffs
abstract: Clinton Administration threatens to place 100 percent tariffs on wine, cheese and other imports from Europe if European Union does not lift its trade restrictions on bananas sold by American companies; Sir Leon Brittan, European trade commissioner, says European nations will challenge such duties in World Trade Organization; Jay Ziegler, spokesman for office of US trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, accuses European Union of having failed to change its trade policies after being ordered to do so by World Trade Organization (M)

headline: So Far, 'Medicare Plus Choice' Is Minus Most of the Options
abstract: Government officials prepare to mail bulletins and handbooks to retirees participating in Medicare, most of whom have little understanding of rules governing old system and new Medicare Plus Choice program; Medicare HMOs across US are raising charges and paring benefits; photo; charts (L)

headline: Eisner's Tell-Little Tale Of His Magic Kingdom
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews Michael D Eisner book Work in Progress, first-hand account of his years at ABC, Paramount Pictures and Disney; photo (M)

headline: America Online Adds 40 Retailers
abstract: America Online adds 40 new retailing partners, including Toys 'R' Us Inc, to shopping section of its on-line services, bringing total to 110 (S)

headline: Before the Renovation, Consider the Returns
abstract: James Schembari column offers advice to baby-boomers set on remodeling or renovating their homes; drawing (M)

headline: Indispensable Man
abstract: News analysis of Pres Pres Clinton visit to Israel and West Bank; even though Clinton suffered lukewarm greeting from Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and his effort to save Wye peace agreement faces uncertain success, there is little question that he is engaged in critical mission and has made himself indispensable authority figure in blood feud between Israelis and Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When Bristol-Myers Squibb shakes up things, where are the executives likely to land?
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co annoucnes series of high-level appointments that raise questions on Wall Street; Charles A Heimbold Jr, chairman and chief executive, plans to retire in 2001, and Kenneth Weg, executive vice president, plans to leave a year earlier; Donald J Hayden Jr is named president of company's worldwide medicines group; Richard J Lane, president of US medicines, will assume new responsibilities for worldwide franchise management and for consumer medicines business in US and Japan; Christine A Poon will become president of international medicines; John L McGoldrick, general counsel, is also named president of medical devices group; Michael F Mee, chief financial officer, will assume additional responsibilities for global business services (M)

headline: The real winners in electronic commerce are turning out to be the credit-card companies.
abstract: Credit-card companies have appeared to awaken to reality that second only to plastic, the Internet is best thing that ever happened to the industry; at end of November, typical E-commerce site can send up to 2.5 percent of its revenue to credit-card companies to cover transaction fees; given estimated sales of roughly $40 billion this year, credit-card companies expect to reap hundreds of millions of dollars in transaction fees (M)

headline: Why Do Chip Makers Look So Chipper?
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin column on rise in value of microchip stocks; interview with Dataquest semiconductor research director Ron Bohn; photo (M)

headline: Brand Futures Names a Chief
abstract: Ira Matathia is joining Brand Futures Group in New York in new position of chief exec (S)

headline: Mexico Weighs Voting by Its Emigrants in U.S.
abstract: Mexican Government weighs extending vote to estimated 10 million migrants living in US, as suggested in recent study performed at behest of Congress; study found millions of potential votes are at stake, perhaps 15 percent of electorate; offers detailed logistical options and budget estimates for extending vote; opposition leaders praise study as long-overdue attempt to extend suffrage to migrant workers who have been disenfranchised both in Mexico and US; allies of Pres Ernesto Zedillo in governing Institutional Revolutionary Party lampoon proposals as too costly and complicated; while political loyalties of Mexicans in US is matter of dispute, conventional wisdom holds that their vote would favor opposition since many migrants are thought to blame ruling party for economic debacles that forced their emigration (M)

headline: British Utility Makes Offer For New England Electric
abstract: Britain's utility industry makes its second big American takeover foray in week with $3.2 billion cash offer for New England Electric System, major electricity supplier in Massachusetts; purchase proposal by National Grid Group PLC, which operates Britain's electric transmission system, reflects increased opportunities seen by foreign utilities in US, where many states are deregulating their utilities and opening them to competition (M)

headline: Russia to Lower Two Key Tax Rates
abstract: Russian Government to lower corporate tax rate to 30 percent from 35 percent and lower value-added tax rate to 14 percent from 20 percent to stimulate industry and spur consumer spending (S)

headline: Chinese Investment Trust Defaults on Bond Payment, Stirring Fear
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp says China's Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corp has failed to make interest payment of $8.75 million on $200 million bond; move could intensify fears of debt crisis in China; it is first time Chinese company has defaulted on international bond since Chinese Communist authorities came to power in 1949; Government shut down company on Oct 6, after it became clear that company was sinking under hundreds of millions of dollars in debt; nation's largest investment company, China International Trust and Investment, has not encountered financial difficulty yet; Moody's Investors Service has placed its debt on review for possible downgrading (M)

headline: Downfall of a Peacemaker; Heir Apparent's Departure May Signal Strain at Citigroup
abstract: Resignation of Citigroup president James Dimon, who was assigned to smooth out merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group, may signal strain at Citigroup; there is speculation that Steven D Black, senior Citigroup executive, and other executives close to Dimon are considering quitting; co-chief executives John S Reed and Sanford I Weill decline to comment, though in interview on Nov 1 both spoke fondly of Dimon and optimistically of Citigroup's prospects; chart; photos (M)

headline: Checking Out New Software
abstract: Q. How can I tell whether certain software applications I am interested in will run under Windows 98? Products in stores are often in boxes printed before Windows 98.

headline: Journalists in New Media Meet to Form an Association
abstract: New media reporters and newsroom expatriates hammer together framework of new association of on-line journalists; members will ideally help on-line world understand journalism and help hidebound journalists understand new media (S)

headline: BMC Is Expected to Buy Boole & Babbage
abstract: BMC Software Inc is expected to announce acquisition of Boole & Babbage Inc for nearly $1 billion in stock (M)

headline: Trial Raises Fear on Hong Kong Autonomy
abstract: Hong Kong crime boss Cheung Tze-Keung is sentenced to death for arms smuggling and kidnapping two Hong Kong tycoons; photo; verdict opens new debate about whether China is encroaching on judicial authority of Hong Kong; Cheung committed crime in Hong Kong but was arrested in Guangdong Province and tried there, although lawyer tried to have case moved to Hong Kong (S)

headline: Livent Weighs Its Options, One of Which Is Bankruptcy
abstract: Executives of Livent Inc, financially troubled Broadway theater company, are discussing whether the company should file for bankruptcy protection or take another action to appease creditors who are owed hundreds of millions of dollars; other options include selling the company or finding investors willing to put more money into the business; bankruptcy lawyers and theater executives who have business dealings with Livent say most likely action is for company to file for Chapter 11 (M)

headline: Tutorials and Realistic Tools
abstract: Dulcie Leimbach reviews Art Dabbler, children's art software from Metacreations; photo (M)

headline: China Expert On Missiles Is Arrested On Return
abstract: Stanford University colleagues say Hua Di, top Chinese missile scientist who has lived in United States since 1989, was arrested in Jan on his first trip home and awaits trial for allegedly revealing state secrets; he had been assured by Chinese security officials that he would not be arrested; American Embassy says it has raised issue with China; Stanford officials have protested to Pres Jiang Zemin; colleagues express concerns about his health (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Hurt by Market Swoon, Merrill Lynch to Cut Jobs  Merrill Lynch said it would eliminate about 3,400 jobs, or just more than 5 percent of its global work force. About 2,000 of the staff reductions will be in the United States. The brokerage firm was the first American financial company to announce cutbacks primarily in response to the world's economic troubles, but other Wall Street firms are expected to follow.    Merrill Lynch also reported a loss of $164 million, or 49 cents a share, for the third quarter after taking a $430 million charge to pay for the job cuts. [Page A1.]    Intel Profits Surpass Expectations  Craig R. Barrett, president and chief executive of Intel, reported third-quarter results that surpassed analysts' expectations by 8 cents a share. Mr. Barrett said the results at the leading maker of personal computer chips reflected ''growth across nearly all of our geographies and product lines, including strong microprocessor sales.'' [C2.]

headline: Exposure in Emerging Markets Is Hampering Drive for Profitability : European Banks Put in a Tight Corner
abstract: LONDON—  When finance officials of the leading industrial countries gather in Washington this weekend to assess the impact of the crisis spreading through the world's emerging market economies, European bankers will have a particularly painful story to tell.

headline: China Appears Ready for Trial Of a Leader of Outlawed Party
abstract: Wang Youcai, founder of China's suppressed Democracy Party, will be tried on December 17 on charge of colluding with foreign enemies to incite subversion of state power (S)

headline: Should You Bristle at These Hedges?
abstract: Article on recent entrance of mutual fund companies into hedge-fund business; drawing; graph (M)

headline: Netanyahu to Submit Pact to His Cabinet
abstract: After a new push by Washington, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will present the agreement reached last month on a further Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank to his Cabinet this morning, American officials said.    Mr. Netanyahu has been delaying a Cabinet meeting to approve the deal, which was supposed to have taken effect on Monday, because of a dispute over when the Palestinians will arrest 30 people wanted by Israel. Israeli officials insisted that the Palestinians put in writing a list of the suspects and a timetable for arresting them.

headline: Anti-Semitism Rising in Switzerland, Study Finds
abstract: Study by Swiss Government commission finds rise in open expression of anti-Semitism in reaction to debate over Switzerland's responsibility to compensate Holocaust victims (M)

headline: Better Business Bureau Says Nuclear Group Ran False Ads
abstract: Better Business Bureau tells nuclear industry to change ads bureau says falsely claim that nuclear reactors make power without polluting air and water or damaging the environment; finding, which nuclear industry says it will take into account in planning its next campaign, contradicts central argument industry has used in last few years to justify its existence; it also inserts Better Business Bureau into new field: electricity marketing battle in California and parts of New York and Pennsylvania, among other states, that offer consumers a choice among suppliers; ads were produced by Smith & Harroff Inc; consumer group Public Citizen says group has drafted complaint to file with Federal Trade Commission if offending ads run again (M)

headline: Armenians, Bitter Over Enclave, Let the Oil Boom Pass By
abstract: Azerbaijan will not cooperate with Armenia on pipeline that would take Azerbaijan's oil to the Mediterranean until the two countries settle their dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian enclave in Azerbaijan that has been held by its ethnic Armenian residents since 1994; Armenia, which has no oil reserves, would apparently rather forgo pipeline revenues than compromise on enclave (M)

headline: Profit Woes Cause Broad Stock Losses
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 126.16 points, or 1.4 percent, to 8,695.60, its lowest level in six weeks; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 25.26, or 2.2 percent, to 1,141.20; Nasdaq composite index falls 62.39, or 3.1 percent, to 1,966.92; graph; chart (M)

headline: Bin Laden Denies Role in Embassy Bombings
abstract: Osama bin Laden reportedly tells Taliban rulers of Afghanistan that he had no role in deadly bombings of two American embassies in Africa, but he does not regret what happened; bin Laden says he knows and respects some of men suspected in Aug 7 bombings in Kenya and Tanzania; Federal authorities have indicted at least 14 people, including bin Laden, in their investigation of embassy bombings and what investigators have called global terrorist organization; United States intelligence authorities consider bin Laden one of world's most dangerous terrorists (M)

headline: 44 Mexico City Policemen Held in Graft Case
abstract: 44 Mexico City police officers are arrested on variety of charges in anticorruption crackdown ordered by city's new police chief; warrants for some had been issued as long as six years ago, but had never been served (M)

headline: In the Offing: Where to Place A Bet on a Post-Embargo Cuba
abstract: Miami investment adviser Thomas J Herzfeld plans to offer closed-end Cuba fund to invest primarily in companies permitted to do business there and in Cuban businesses if trade embargo is lifted (S)

headline: China Grows Impatient With Its Ailing Banks
abstract: Government shutdown of prominent state-run investment company Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corp shows that China may finally be getting tough with insolvent financial institutions; until now, prestigious state-run companies with good connections to central Government have been able to rely on bailouts, often based on endless debt restructuring, but leaders have become alarmed at looming economic crisis; another critical factor in fate of Guangdong International has been political revamping in Guangdong Province, which enjoyed breakneck development with skimpy regulation until it recently came under greater scrutiny from Prime Min Zhu Rongji (M)

headline: Finding Factoids, Made Easy
abstract: New Internet search engine, Edgar-Online People, is set to begin operating; it will include Securities and Exchange Commission records on corporate executives (S)

headline: Media Metrix Plans Merger With Relevant Knowledge
abstract: Media Metrix will acquire Relevant Knowledge, its Atlanta-based archrival; financial terms of all-stock deal undisclosed (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: Astra's Earnings Decline As Drug Pact Is Revised
abstract: Astra AB says third-quarter profit fell 7.6 percent to 2.24 billion kronor ($289.3 million), from 2.42 billion kronor a year earlier; pretax profit fell 14 percent (S)

headline: Questions Arise About Swiss Report on Raul Salinas's Millions
abstract: Secret report by Swiss police says that although some of more than $100 million in Swiss bank accounts of Raul Salinas de Gortari--brother of former Mexican President--came from investment fund, much of it was drug money he laundered with help of Carlos Peralta Quintero, old friend who is one of Mexico's richest figures; suggests Swiss explanation of money may have problems of its own since most of informers against Salinas appear to be former drug traffickers or former aides, security guards and associates of Salinas brothers, and nearly all are identified by pseudonyms; details about Salinas's purported dealings are often general and sometimes vague, and there is little explanation of how he might have exercised influence with police and military agencies to allow smugglers to operate freely (M)

headline: Giving New Meaning To Endowing a Chair
abstract: Columbia University business school offers to name classroom seats and student lockers in honor of alumni who contribute $2,500 or $5,000 to school (S)

headline: Drawing With a Girl as a Guide
abstract: Dulcie Leimbach assesses Orly's Draw-a-Story, children's art software from Broderbund; photo (M)

headline: Germ Weapons: In Soviet Past Or in the New Russia's Future?
abstract: Belated discovery of research on new and deadlier generation of germ warfare weapons by Russian military officers in Kazakhstan just as Soviet Union was ending its confrontation with West in 1980's fuels fierce debate in Washington over whether military is heeding Pres Boris Yeltsin's 1992 order to abandon germ warfare; discovery of animal testing of highly contagious Marburg virus at remote laboratory complex near Stepnogorsk in final days of cold war has led Clinton Administration officials and Republicans in Congress to assert that Russia is still secretly researching germ weapons; US officials say while there is scant hard evidence to support suspicions, Moscow's reluctance to open up military bases is ominous sign; skeptics of Western aid programs that pay salaries to former Russian germ scientists to thwart their recruitment by rogue or terrorist states say Moscow's lies about germ warfare program in past make trust and cooperation impossible; note Yeltsin has banned Russian experts from discussing any aspect of country's germ history and has retained several generals instrumentsl in Soviet program; worry particularly that research may be quietly proceeding on some of least known Soviet advances, such as 'bio-regulators' or germ compounds capable of controlling human moods, heart rhythms and sleep patterns; supporters of Western programs say while Russia may not be trusted unconditionally, partnership is best chance for verifying Moscow's claim to have renounced germ weapons; photos; map (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO.,  Los Angeles, said it would eliminate 100 jobs from its British work force of 341, as part of a worldwide cost-cutting plan.    STROH BREWERY CO.,  Detroit, the maker of Old Milwaukee and Schlitz beers, plans to close its brewery in Tampa, Fla., in January, laying off 154 workers.
