UNICOM CORP.,  Chicago, a utility holding company, plans to sell 76 natural-gas and oil-fired power plants in Illinois by the end of 1999.

headline: Just How Green Can a Middle School Get?
abstract: just how green can a middle school get**Bill Donohue article on environmental-based education, such as the kind practiced at Environmental Middle School in Portland, Ore, where study of environmental problems is integrated into all lessons; students at Environmental, a public magnet school whose students come from neighborhoods throughout the city, score above average on writing and math tests; photo (M)

headline: Schroder Aide Typifies New German Subtlety
abstract: Article profiles Germany's Interior Min Otto Schily, who typifies new class that has come to power and is changing country's political culture; new breed of politicians has more checkered past and more nuanced allegiances; represent departure from scene of more predictable German--solid, solemn and unsurprising--which US and allies find disorienting; Schily comments; photo (M)

headline: He Finds Gold in New York's Swamps
abstract: Marc A Matsil, chief of Natural Resources Group of New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, is the man in charge of protecting the city's ecosystem and also spearheads Parks Department's aggressive acquisition of 2,000 acres of wetlands and woodlands on fringes of the city; photo (M)

headline: Balloonists Set Down 10 Miles Off Oahu
abstract: Three balloonists are forced to ditch their craft, ICO Global Challenge, in Pacific Ocean 10 miles north of Hawaiian Islands, ending most nearly successful attempt by any ballonist to achieve a nonstop trip around the world; flight does not set a distance record, but has a notable success in crossing Asia from one end to the other (M)

headline: Data Venture By Toyota And Sony
abstract: Sony Corp and Toyota Motor Corp have reached agreement with Internet Initiatives Japan to create company that will offer Japanese businesses a cheaper way of sending data over telephone lines than is currently available; new company will compete directly with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, which controls more than 90 percent of burgeoning market in data communications in Japan; given that Toyota has significant stake in Teleway Japan Corp, which has fiber optic network, new company may lease its pipelines from Teleway; Teleway is in process of merging with KDD, nation's largest long-distance telephone service provider, and Toyota will end up with somewhat less than 10 percent of merged company (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: SCHRODER AND YELTSIN MEET -- Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany met President Boris N. Yeltsin and said Russia could draw on eastern Germany's experience of making the transition from a planned economy to the free market. Mr. Schroder indicated that he saw Germany's role as an advocate for Russia in global financial organizations.   (Reuters)    RUSSIA: BANKS IN NEED OF MILLIONS -- Russia will need to find at least another $588 million to stabilize its teetering commercial banks, the chairman of the central bank,  Viktor Gerashchenko, said. The banking sector was exposed to huge debts owed to foreign creditors when a Government-imposed moratorium on loan repayments expired last Friday.   (Agence France-Presse)

headline: Vote in Quebec May Be Last Fling With Secession
abstract: Quebec Premier Lucien Bouchard is locked in do-or-die election with Liberal Party leader Jean Charest that will decide to large extent on November 30 whether province's long flirtation with secession will succeed at last; Bouchard has promised that if his Parti Quebecois is re-elected, he will hold third referendum on separation, probably by 2001; Charest says there will be no referendum if he is elected--threat political analysts say could take away separatists' last opportunity to win since passion for independence is waning; province's continuing exodus of English-speakers has been largely offset by declining local birth rate, and large influx of immigrants tends to vote against secession; last referendum in 1995 fell 50,000 votes short; map; photos (M)

headline: Poles and Jews Feud About Crosses at Auschwitz
abstract: Catholic demonstrators in Poland have placed 240 crosses around Auschwitz walls, forming Christian sea around death camp that was nexus of Nazi attempt to annihilate Jews; self-styled guard is Kazimierz Switon, former Solidarity Union who says he is defending Poland against the Jews; photos; map; anti-Jewish oratory by Switon and vociferous followers escalates atmosphere clouded by Polish fears of Jewish claims for restitution of property taken from them during war; Prime Min Jerzy Burek has promised several times to remove crosses but has not done so; Kalman Sultanik of World Jewish Congresses emphasizes that crosses are deeply offensive and symbolize persecution, especially at death camp where 90 percent of those murdered were Jews (M)

headline: Changing of the Guard, and Coverage, at Forbes
abstract: Forbes magazine plans increased focus on technology industry as source of both advertising and news stories; William Baldwin, well-known technophile, is succeeding James W Michaels, 77, as editor and new publisher, Richard Karlgaard, will keep his office in California's Silicon Valley area, where staff will be increased; graph of circulation of top financial magazines; photos (M)

headline: In Drive on Dissidents, China Gives 4th Severe Sentence in Week
abstract: China sentences 42-year-old Zhang Shanguang to 10-year prison sentence for providing intelligence to hostile foreign organizations; charges related to interview about farmer protests with US-financed Radio Free Asia; Zhang, who is fourth dissenter to receive lengthy prison sentence in week, previously served seven years for organizing independent labor union in 1989 (M)

headline: 2,750 More Layoffs at Oilfield Concern
abstract: Halliburton Co to cut 2,750 more jobs and take fourth-quarter charge of $24 million; says fourth-quarter earnings will be lower than analysts expect (S)

headline: U.S. Indictment: 'Detonated an Explosive Device'
abstract: Excerpt from indictment returned in Federal District Court in Manhattan against Saudi exile Osama bin-Laden

headline: Indonesia Denies It Failed to Pull Out Troops From East Timor
abstract: Gen Wiranto denies that Indonesia has not reduced number of its troops in disputed East Timor after it had announced withdrawal (M)

headline: Judge Weighs Move in Allied-AMP Takeover Fight
abstract: Federal District Court Judge James T Giles says he will consider lifting an October 8 injunction that prevents Allied Signal Inc, now engaged in $9.8 billion hostile bid for AMP Inc, from trying to put its own directors and officers on AMP's board (M)

headline: At the U.N., Nations Are Urged to Prepare for 'Millennium Bug'
abstract: Delegates from more than 120 countries attend first global convention of government represenatives to deal with so-called Millennium bug, held at United Nations; some of countries represented have not yet set up national projects to deal with problem; some last-minute attendees, notably France, express skepticism about extent of threat; common assumption is that most of world is far behind United States in preparing for 2000; Garter Group, consulting firm, projects that 30 countries, including Russia and China, are in highest-risk category, and that two-thirds or more of all businesses and government agencies in those countries will run into at least one major problem (M)

headline: AUTOMATIC DATA AGREES TO BUY VINCAM FOR $295 MILLION
abstract: Automatic Data Processing Inc says that it agreed to acquire Vincam Group Inc, employment management contractor, for $295 million in stock (S)

headline: F-16's Attack Iraqis After Missiles Are Fired at Allied Jets
abstract: US warplanes attack Iraqi air-defense battery for second time in week as Iraq carries out threat to fire on American and British aircraft patrolling 'no flight' zones; strike missile site outside southern city of Tallil; map (M)

headline: Bent Out of Shape by Flexibility
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews book The Corrosion of Character: The Personal Consequences of Work in the New Capitalism by Richard Sennett; photo (M)

headline: Prospect of Gramm Reign Worries Wall St.
abstract: Defeat of Sen Alfonse M D'Amato means that Sen Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican with combative streak, is expected to become next chairman of Senate Banking Committee, prospect that is worrying many on Wall Street and in financial services industry; reason is that Gramm last October single-handedly halted a bill, sought by financial services industry, to sweep away Depression-era restrictions just as measure was about to receive Senate approval; Gramm has criticized Securities and Exchange Commission's efforts to improve investor education; banking committee oversees, in part, nation's securities industry, and Gramm has clashed with SEC chairman Arthur Levitt on variety of issues; Independent Bankers Association of America executive director Kenneth Guenther says D'Amato defeat does not bode well for prompt enactment of financial restructuring legislation; Gramm issues statement supporting financial modernization measure; photo (M)

headline: The Bubble Is Back, Compliments Of the Fed
abstract: Interview with Merrill Lynch & Co investment strategist Charles I Clough Jr on stock market recovery and investment outlook; he holds Federal Reserve has reflated equity market bubble; photo (M)

headline: Head of GE Capital Services Resigns in Shake-Up
abstract: Gary C Wendt resigns as head of GE Capital Services, financial-services arm of General Electric Co; Dennis D Dammerman is named chairman and chief executive of unit and chairman of parent company; Denis J Nayden is promoted to chief executive of GE Capital; Keith S Sherin replaces Dammerman as chief financial officer of GE; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.88   4.70   5.52        3-month T-bills   4.34   4.30   5.02        6-month T-bills   4.37   4.34   5.14        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.80   3.54        10-yr. T-note   4.51   4.56   5.79        30-yr. T-bond   4.96   4.98   6.00        Telephone bd.   6.72   6.76   7.25        Municipal bds.   5.09   5.10   5.29          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Soccer's Din Threatens Poet's Rest In Spain
abstract: Construction of soccer field, Alfacar, Spain, near site of park commemorating 1936 execution of poet and playwright Federico Garcia Lorca by fascists during Spanish Civil War and mass graves of some 4,000 other slain leftists stirs controversy; poet's sister, Isabel Garcia Lorca leads opposition; map (M)

headline: PEP BOYS PLANS TO SELL 100 EXPRESS STORES TO AUTOZONE
abstract: Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack, says it will sell 100 of its Express auto parts stores to larger rival, Autozone Inc, for $108 million and will close nine others as it focuses more on supercenters that offer services and tires (S)

headline: Turkey's Ties To Syria Sink To War in All But the Name
abstract: Tension between Turkey and Syria rises to point of undeclared war; Syria is angry over Turkey's blossoming friendship with Israel and accuses Turkey of unfairly diverting water from rivers that flow through both countries; Turks charge Syria supports separatist terror by Kurds (S)

headline: The Dawn of HDTV, Ready or Not
abstract: Limited number of television stations will begin broadcasting digital signals on Nov 1, or soon after; initially, digital broadcasts will be on channels separate from conventional channels used by each station; ABC plans to broadcast first network high-definition program on Nov 1--the 1996 remake of Disney film 101 Dalmations; about two-thirds of nation's television households receive their programs by cable, and cable industry is fighting hard to avert any Federal requirement that they transmit broadcast networks' digital programming; map; photos (M)

headline: What the S.& P. Knew That the Dow Didn't
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer (Portfolios, Etc) column on unusual divergence between Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, up 26 percent for year, and Dow Jones industrial average, up only 17 percent; chart compares two indexes since 1997 (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar is lower as tension eases in Middle East and uncertainty continues about further reductions in interest rates; in New York, the dollar settles at 1.6677 marks, down from 1.6841 marks late Friday (S)

headline: 2 Consultants Merge As AAR/Bob Wolf
abstract: AAR North America and Bob Wolf Partners, consulting companies that help advertisers and agencies with reviews, merge to form AAR/Bob Wolf Partners (S)

headline: A Rough Trip for Yeltsin Adds to Worries About Health
abstract: Pres Boris Yeltsin abruptly cuts short three-day visit to Central Asia after doctor announced he was suffering from bronchitis and slight fever; Kremlin's record of covering up his health problems leaves commentators questioning whether Yeltsin's illness was more serious; has compounded sense that nation lacks fully functioning leader during one of its gravest economic crises; photo (M)

headline: Music Business Helps to Ease Decline in Seagram's Profits
abstract: Seagram Co says fiscal first-quarter profit fell less-than-expected 18 percent; profit fell to $95 million from $116 million a year ago; Seagram begins its $10.4 billion tender offer for Polygram NV (S)

headline: PETERSEN TO ACQUIRE MAGAZINES FROM CURTCO FREEDOM
abstract: Petersen Companies agrees to acquire six magazines from Curtco Freedom Group for $60 million (S)

headline: The Medium as Message, as Well as the Punch Line
abstract: J C Herz evaluates computer game Gex: Enter the Gecko, which features a couch-potato lizard that serves as a guide through parodies of television and film genres; game was developed by Crystal Dynamics, published by Midway for Playstation, $44.99, and Nintendo 64, $59.99; photos (M)

headline: Gadgets to Go Gentle Into Age; A Market Grows and Modernizes as Demand Increases
abstract: Leaders in home health care industry have enjoyed robust growth as population ages, but market is becoming increasingly competitive for medical devices and gadgets; numerous companies are stepping into the fray with Government encouraging home health care to save money on institutional care; they include such big public companies as Invacare Corp and Sunrise Medical Inc as well as smaller, private manufacturers and dealers such as Rice Home Medical, New Abilities Systems Inc and Gould's Discount Medical, division of Mobilectrics Co; graphs; photos (M)

headline: EUROPEAN BANKS, ACTING IN UNISON, CUT INTEREST RATE
abstract: 11 European banks, in most coordinated action yet toward European monetary union, simultaneously cut their interest rates to nearly uniform low level; moves comes month before nations adopt euro as single currency and marks drastic shift in policy; central banks of 11 euro-zone nations reduce their benchmark interest rates by at least 0.3 percent; cuts are intended to help boslter European economies by making it cheaper for businesses and consumers to borrow; map shows lower interest rates in European nations (M)

headline: WPP Unit Assigned New Kellogg Line
abstract: Kellogg Co will assign advertising for new line of cereals, Country Inn Specialties, to J Walter Thompson USA, part of J Walter Thompson Co; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: New Mergers May Conjure The Ghosts Of Nazis Past
abstract: Relationship between American Jews and German companies has come to fore again through collision of two trends: wave of big mergers between German and American companies, and growing number of lawsuits against German and other companies seeking compensation for Holocaust-era wrongs; David A Harris, executive director of American Jewish Committee, says sentiment against buying German products fades with every passing year, especially among younger Jews; Roman Kent of American Gathering of Holocaust Survivors says time has only increased his anger about Nazi atrocities, and his organization's members still do not buy German products; photos (M)

headline: BILLION-DOLLAR BETTOR: A special report -- The Man Behind the Curtain; Hedge Fund Wizard or Wall St. Gambler Run Amok?
abstract: Profile of John William Meriwether, founder of Long-Term Capital Management, hedge fund that was bailed out by consortium of big international banks and brokerage firms last week; chart; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Refuses to Buy North Korea Access
abstract: SEOUL—  A U.S. special envoy, Charles Kartman, said Thursday that he had flatly rejected a North Korean demand for a reported $300 million for access to an underground facility in which the North is suspected of developing nuclear weapons.

headline: F.C.C. Says Sprint and Telmex Overcharged on Some Rates
abstract: Federal Communications Commission says joint venture created by Sprint Corp and Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, committed anticompetitive practices in the long-distance market and rejects venture's proposed rates charged to other long-distance carriers; gives it 30 days to explain why its long-distance license should not be reviewed; says consumers have had to pay much more than they should to reach friends and relatives in Mexico; charges carriers with not acting quickly enough to bring rates down and to ensure meaningful competition; Sprint and Telmex official rebut allegations; say pricing was not unreasonable and that venture met all required conditions of its license (M)

headline: French Major Held in Spying At NATO Panel
abstract: Maj Pierre Bunel, French military officer at NATO headquarters in Brussels, is arrested on suspicion of telling Serbia about targets alliance was planning to bomb if Serbian forces failed to halt attacks against civilians in Kosovo Province; is accused of passing top secret documents to Serbian agents (S)

headline: Prospectus; For start-up companies looking for corporate investors, it pays to know that philosophies differ from East to West.
abstract: Janet Stites (Prospectus) column discusses problems start-up companies encounter when looking for investors; notes that for many entrepreneurs, luck may be simple geography; discusses different attitudes toward venture financing at established technology companies on East and West Coasts that have resulted in very different environments for beginnings of of high-tech start-ups in Silicon Alley and Silicon Valley; diagram (M)

headline: True North goes to court for arbitration on the value of its stake in Publicis Communications.
abstract: Publicis SA and True North Communications are back in court again as True North submits dispute over valuation of its stake in Publicis to arbitration in London court; True North executives contend that book value of True North investment in Publicis is higher than value of Publicis shares that True North would receive in merger deal (M)

headline: Illusions Shattered in St. Petersburg
abstract: Slaying of reformist legislator Galina Starovoitova has shattered hopes for democracy in St Petersburg, where 'democrat' is still not quite dirty word it has become elsewhere in Russia; democrats, when in power, did little to improve life of city, dominated by ailing defense industry; politically-motivated murders have become commonplace; photo (M)

headline: Panics Always Start In Left Field
abstract: Louis Uchitelle (Economic View) column says depite economic problems in Asia and Russia, consensus view of economists is that US economy will slow next year as consumers pull back on both their extraordinary spending and extraordinary borrowing to finance their spending, but notes almost no economist forsees recession (M)

headline: Waste Management Settles Holders' Suit
abstract: Waste Management Inc agrees to help set up $220 million fund to settle class-action lawsuit that accused its recently acquired subsidiary, USA Waste Services Inc, of falsely portraying its financial condition (S)

headline: Gramm Seems To Doom Vote For the Passage Of Banking Bill
abstract: Bill to overturn Depression-era restrictions on financial services industry seems doomed as Sen Phil Gramm threatens to tie up Senate in procedural maneuvers out of his longstanding opposition to portions of bill; Democratic and Republican Senate leaders say they have nearly 90 votes to pass measure; majority leader Trent Lott adds to unrelated 'poison pill' amendments to bill, which has effect of shelving measures unless Gramm's opposition ends (M)

headline: Economic News And an Accord On I.M.F. Push Stocks Higher
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average climbs 97.07 points, or 1.14 percent, to finish at 8,592.10; Standard & Poor's 500 index gains 12.74 points, or 1.17 percent, to 1,098.67; European and Asian shares are higher; graph; chart (M)

headline: Disarming a Giant: U.S. Case Stresses Anticompetitive Pattern by Microsoft
abstract: Analysis of Microsoft Corp antitrust case; as trial moves into its fourth week, Microsoft finds itself trying to deflect a flood of charges of threats and bribes; computer giant is countering with argument that there is lack of evidence that consumers are being hurt by company's tough business tactics; photo of David Boies, Justice Department's top antitrust lawyer in case (M)

headline: BANK OF NEW YORK ANNOUNCES PLANS TO BUY BACK STOCK
abstract: Bank of New York Co will buy back up to 18 million shares of its stock (S)

headline: The One Who Waved the Internet Wand
abstract: Brief biographical sketch of Jake Winebaum, who runs Walt Disney's Internet business; photo (S)

headline: Easter Seals Presents Awards
abstract: Easter Seals names recipients of its ninth annual E.D.I. Awards, for Equality, Dignity and Independence, which honor communications judged to enhance independence of people with disabilities; winners in print and broadcast advertising listed (S)

headline: I'll Always Love You, but Is It Time to Move On?
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on her sentimental attachment to her Apple Powerbook 160, which she bought in 1992 and which is seriously outdated now (M)

headline: Gardner Is Leaving Ammirati Puris Lintas
abstract: Stephen H Gardner, president of New York office of Ammirati Puris Lintas, is leaving to open consulting company in New York; position will not be filled (S)

headline: Speculation Rises on Which Companies Are Ripe for Mergers
abstract: Article on speculation on future bank mergers in light of Deutsche Bank AG's acquisition of Bankers Trust Corp (M)

headline: More Attacks on Iraq Possible
abstract: The U.S. warned that Iraq may try to rebuild its weapons programs and that additional American strikes may be needed soon. Page A12.

headline: Russia Raises Specter of a Loan Default
abstract: Russia tells Western bankers it will renege on terms of repaying $28 billion in Soviet-era debt to creditors, effectively paving way for default on interest payments next month; country is facing collapsing currency, yawning budget deficit and deteriorating economy (M)

headline: BRITAIN ARRESTS PINOCHET TO FACE CHARGES BY SPAIN
abstract: Britain arrests former Chilean dictator Gen Augusto Pinochet, in London for back surgery, after Spain seeks his extradition for presumed murder of hundreds of Chilean and Spanish citizens; likely legal struggle over highly unusual arrest could have wide implications for prosecution of alleged human rights violators under international law; Chilean Government demands his release, holding he has diplomatic immunity; Chileans remain deeply divided over his legacy; Spanish Judge Baltasar Garzon issued international arrest warrant; photo (M)

headline: Free Spirits at the Family Table
abstract: Abby Ellin (Preludes) article on parental concern about jobs and income of their children, which she says is one of the more often-voiced questions at holiday time (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: START TREATY BACKED -- The commander of the strategic missile force, Gen. Vladimir Yakovlev, backed ratification of the Start II arms-reduction treaty with the United States, saying Russia's nuclear weapons will soon reach the end of their service life. The United States Senate ratified the treaty in 1996. But the Communist-led opposition in the Russian Parliament has blocked ratification, contending that dismantling the weapons would harm security and be too expensive.   (AP)    RUSSIA: STATE OF EMERGENCY IN CHECHNYA -- The Chechnya Parliament declared a one-month state of emergency to combat a wave of crime in the breakaway republic. Four Western hostages were beheaded there last week. On Monday the Parliament refused to let President Aslan Maskhadov call up army reservists to pursue criminal gangs.   (AP)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Dec 6 article on margin maintenance rules for Internet stocks; example cited was incorrect (S)

headline: BellSouth Loses Court Decision
abstract: BellSouth Corp loses court challenge to legal restrictions that prevent it and other regional Bell companies from entering $70 billion long-distance business until they open local markets to competition; Federal appeals court rejects company's constitutional challenge to 1996 Telecommunications Act, upholding Federal Communications Commission's refusal to allow it to offer long-distance service in North Carolina (S)

headline: QUINTILES TO PURCHASE RESEARCH CENTER FROM HOECHST
abstract: Quintiles Transnational Corp takes steps to expand its clinical and preclinical drug development by announcing plans to buy research facility in Kansas City, Mo, from Hoechst Marion Roussel Inc for $93 million (S)

headline: The heady world of automotive campaigns includes a spinoff, a consolidation and a blitz.
abstract: Nissan Motor Corp USA discusses with its longtime agency, TBWA/Chiat/Day, spinoff of retail dealer advertising portion of its account to form stand-alone shop to be named Blacktop Advertising; dealers have complained that recent TBWA/Chiat/Day campaigns stressed entertainment over hard-selling product pitches; Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America has consolidated its national advertising at Deutsch Inc; Daimler-Chrysler AG plans multinational advertising blitz heralding its formation through merger of Daimler-Benz AG and Chrysler Corp (M)

headline: Yeltsin Swings His Ax (Then Retreats to His Hospital Bed)
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin visits Kremlin office long enough to dismiss four top aides and proclaim that he is retaking control of his Govt's skidding tax-collection and crime-fighting agencies; returns immediately to Moscow hospital to where he has been treated for pneumonia for past 15 days; photo (M)

headline: A Russian Plan To Extend Debt Angers Lenders
abstract: Russia's Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov approves plan to restructure $14 billion in defaulted Russian Treasury bonds, but move quickly draws criticism from foreign creditors, who complain that they were not consulted about details and that Russia is forcing bad deal upon them (M)

headline: Business Travel
abstract: Time is growing short for frequent fliers to cash in certain of their airline miles; Royal Caribbean's ship Monarch of the Seas has canceled scheduled voyage after striking reef while leaving St Maarten in French West Indies; Disney Cruise Line's second ship, Disney Wonder, will be delivered next spring, but its maiden voyage is not scheduled until Aug 15; ship will miss most of traditional summer cruise season; recent passenger aboard Carnival Paradise, industry's first smoke-free cruise ship, was put off in Nassau, the Bahamas, where he had to pay his own way home; Carnival says passengers were warned that ship was for nonsmokers (Business Travel) (M)

headline: For Deutsche Bank, New Stock Liquidity
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG, marking clear turnaround from its traditional buy-and-hold strategy, will combine its equity holdings into several unincorporated units with aim of actively managing its portfolio; Deutsche Bank's shareholdings are reported to be worth more than $24 billion (S)

headline: Aid Trickling From the Sky To the Isolated In Honduras
abstract: Mexican Air Force helicopter delivers food and medicine to residents of Orocuina, one of many small hamlets in Honduras that have been without electricity or clean water for over week because of damage caused by Mitch, one of freakiest hurricanes in history; Orocuina is in Choluteca Province, which was particularly hard hit by storm; local river and all its tributaries flooded, knocking out dozens of bridges, including major ones; many houses were swept away, and children are falling ill; people are feeling desperate (M)

headline: Spanish Judge Investigating Rights Abuses In Argentina
abstract: Spanish Judge Baltazar Garzon, who seeks extradition of former Chilean dictator Gen Augusto Pinochet, is also probing role of Emilio E Massera, retired Argentine admiral, and other former Latin American military officers in Chilean military operation that sought capture of Chilean exiles abroad and their return to Chile for execution; inquiry has spurred Bolivian opposition to demand local probe of Pres Hugo Banzer, former military dictator; Argentine Pres Carlos Saul Menem, who pardoned Massera and other military officers involved in political kidnappings in Argentina, backs Chile's stand that former military leaders should be tried in own nations and opposes extradition of Argentine military officers; Massera is under house arrest in Argentina in case involving seizure of newborn infants from mothers who were then apparently executed (M)

headline: MELLON AND ABN AMRO FORM VENTURE IN CUSTODY SERVICES
abstract: ABN Amro NV forms alliance with Mellon Bank Corp to provide global custody services in joint venture that will initially focus on financial institutions worldwide; venture, to be called Amro Mellon Global Securities Services, will market its services worldwide except in Mellon's home market, US, and markets where Mellon has existing alliances (S)

headline: But Consumer Groups Unhappy
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Until last year, pharmaceutical companies wishing to advertise on radio or television faced an odd conundrum.

headline: AIDS Is Everywhere, but Africa Looks Away
abstract: Article in series on AIDS in Africa describes how shame is causing people to look away from problem; AIDS is flooding hospitals in Africa, changing face of work places and producing hundreds of thousands of orphans, but stigma attached to AIDS keeps many sufferers silent; AIDS epidemic is everywhere in sub-Saharan Africa; in several countries, one out of four people is now infected with virus and will probably die within 10 years; but to go to a village and ask if anyone is suffering from AIDS, answer will likely be no; it is hard to find anyone who publicly admits to being HIV-positive; many go to the grave with their secret, so great is the stigma; experts say problem of discrimination against people with AIDS virus is particularly severe in Africa, where little has been done to study or attack the stigma; experts say that the shame people feel and treatment they suffer at hands of their communities has far-reaching consequences for efforts to fight spread of virus and treat the sick; photos; map (L)

headline: OBITUARY : Russell Smith, 71, Composer Of Opera and Symphonies
abstract: Russell Smith, 71, an American composer whose music won a wide audience in Europe, died Sept. 25 in Munich of cancer.

headline: Clinton Warns U.S. Will Fight Cheap Imports
abstract: Pres Clinton says for first time that US will not tolerate 'flooding of our markets' with low-cost goods from Asia and Russia, particularly steel, that are threatening jobs of American workers; Clinton's statement comes after White House meeting of top executives of steel companies and United Steelworkers of America, which helped get out vote for Democrats last week, playing pivotal role with other unions in party's success in midterm elections; Clinton's remarks create apparent conflict in US policy, which until now has indirectly encouraged economically troubled countries to export their goods (M)

headline: For Veterans Of Britain, Top Honors In France
abstract: Dozen or so surviving British veterans of World War I gather in London on 80th anniversary of end of war to receive one of France's highest distinctions, Chevalier Cross of the Legion of Honor, and to hear that they have not been forgotten; two years ago France presented medal to all French veterans of war (M)

headline: Get It Wholesale on the Net: A Web Site for Coupon Clippers
abstract: Val Pak Direct Marketing Systems, one of nation's largest distributors of coupons, starts ambitious Web site (www.valpak.com) that allows visitors to type in their ZIP codes and types of businesses they are interested in; Val Pak then displays list of coupons that Web surfers can reproduce using their computer printers (S)

headline: Istanbul Journal; Fearless Turks' Big Fear? Oil Tankers
abstract: Possible use of Bosporus Strait as transit route for huge amounts of oil found under and around Caspian Sea causes concern among Turks, who say it poses environmental threat since Bosporus passes through center of Istanbul, home to 10 million people; Bosporus, 17 miles long and just 700 yards wide at narrowest point, is one of world's most strategic waterways; as sole maritime link between Black Sea and Mediterranean and open ocean beyond, it is vital passageway not just for trade but for projection of military might, political power ands cultural influence; maps; photo (M)

headline: Phone Upstarts Scramble for Capital
abstract: Article on market corrections in start-up telecommunications company junk bonds, described by Goldman Sachs underwriter group head Lawrence R Buchalter as more severe than that of equity market; chart; photo (M)

headline: Aetna Profit Hurt by Costs of Year 2000 Bug
abstract: Aetna Inc says third-quarter operating profit fell 6.1 percent because of costs to fix its so-called year 2000 computer software bug; profit fell to $152.2 million from $162.1 million a year earlier; revenue rose 17.5 percent, to $5.44 billion from $4.63 billion (S)

headline: People
abstract: Ted S Barton is named to vacant post of executive vice president and creative director at Publicis & Hal Riney; Kim Macalister, president and general manager at J Walter Thompson Singapore, is named to new position of director for total communications planning at J Walter Thompson Co, New York; Powell Blue, chief operating officer for Australia at DDB Needham Worldwide Pty Ltd, is named to new position of chief operating officer at DDB Needham Los Angeles; Helane Naiman is named to head new New York office of Media Partnership Corp, as senior vice president and account director; J Steve Davis joins Qorvis Media Group as president and chief operating officer; Tom DiJulio is named vice president and creative director at Crosby Marketing Communications, succeeding Walt Hampton, who resigned; Steve Giannetti, associate publisher of Prevention magazine, part of Rodale Press Inc, is promoted to publisher, succeeding Kim Wallace, who is named vice president and group publisher of Rodale Press; Jacki Gordetsky is named marketing director for Time Inc Health, which publishes Health and Hippocrates magazines, succeeding Sonda Miller, who resigned (M)

headline: Microsoft Quits A Media Venture
abstract: Microsoft Corp to sell its 10 percent stake in Real Networks Inc in a move to compete head to head against the company, which is the market leader in technology that sends sound and video over the Internet; industry analyst says move clears way for Microsoft to make all-out assault on streaming-media market place, in which users see, hear and see audio and video over the Internet (S)

headline: When Nobody Has the Number
abstract: Article longs for time when dialing directory assistance meant hearing real, and helpful operator; notes that since breakup of Bell system, computerized or far-flung operators are often unable to locate correct numbers; photo (M)

headline: As Stocks Drop, Bond Prices Leap
abstract: Fears of further losses gripped financial markets around the world yesterday, driving down stock prices and driving many investors into the relative safety of United States Treasury securities, which surged for the biggest one-day gain in more than a year. An extended rally in bonds has pushed yields down  to 31-year lows.

headline: Korean President Presses Overhaul of Industries
abstract: South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung, battling recession, plans to meet with heads of five biggest conglomerates, Hyundai, Samsung, Daewoo, LG and SK groups, to press for corporate overhauls (S)

headline: Stocks Streak: Eight Rallies In Eight Days
abstract: Stock prices rise for eighth consecutive trading day, longest winning streak in more than two years; Dow Jones industrial average gains 94.23 points, to close at 9,320.98; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 16.32 points, to record 1,241.81, and Nasdaq composite index 1.47 points, to record 2,181.77; Russell index of small stocks gains 2.13 points, to close at 410.41; graph (M)

headline: Coca-Cola is battling to consolidate its recent gains over Pepsico in a turf war in Venezuela.
abstract: Article on Coca-Cola Co's intense marketing campaign in Venezuela, which for 50 years was one of few places in the world where its rival Pepsico Inc held overwhelming lead over Coke (M)

headline: Clear Channel to Buy Jacor For $2.8 Billion in Stock
abstract: Clear Channel Communications to pay $2.8 billion in stock for Jacor Communications; combined company would rank third in radio revenues, behind CBS Inc and Chancellor Broadcasting Co, and second in number of stations; would have two or more radio stations in six of nation's 12 largest markets (M)

headline: Iran Closes 'University' Run Covertly By the Bahais
abstract: Iran, as part of crackdown on Bahai faith, its largest religious minority, has shut down stealth university where volunteer faculty was educating nearly 1,000 students; school was started in 1987 in reaction to virtual ban of Bahais from Iranian universities; operated so quietly that many Bahai officials abroad and many intellectuals within Iran were unaware of it (M)2

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Symantec Corp., Cupertino, Calif., the software products marketer, to Partners & Simons, Boston, as creative agency for corporate advertising, and Carat Freeman, Wellesley, Mass., a unit of Aegis Group P.L.C., as media agency. Billings on those assignments, which had been handled by Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.    * Shaw's Supermarkets, East Bridgewater, Mass., to Greenberg Seronick O'Leary & Partners, Boston, to handle its account, which had been handled by Mintz & Hoke, Avon, Conn. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

headline: Individuals, Not Institutions, Hold Most Foreign Stocks
abstract: Study by Citibank finds individuals, not institutional investors, hold bulk of foreign stocks (S)

headline: Profit Slides 45% At Societe Generale
abstract: Societe Generale SA reports third-quarter 1998 operating profit slid 45 percent, to $319 million, compared with year-earlier period (S)

headline: F.D.A. Assigning Arnold More Work
abstract: Food and Drug Administration expands its relationship with Arnold Communications by naming shop as advertising agency of record for its tobacco and other marketing communications programs (S)

headline: Blair Says Use of Force Is 'Global Reality'
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain, in tough-talking assessment of air attacks, says he is determined to build broad consensus on dealing with Iraq; urges doubters and critics to understand new 'global reality' that modern diplomacy must be backed up by force (M)

headline: South Africa Truth Commission May Withhold Its Report
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission is on verge of withholding its final report in face of court challenges from ex-Pres F W de Klerk and African National Congress, both apparently accused of gross human rights violations during apartheid era; Abp Desmond Tutu, panel chairman, is furious at last-minute tactics; says panel will reluctantly delete reference to de Klerk, but needs time to fight legal challenge; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Lifetime Internet Access Faces Uncertain Future
abstract: Atbigger.net, internet service provider that promised unlimited lifetime Internet access for one-time fee of $59, plus another $10 for lifetime E-mail account, filed for bankruptcy last week; at last minute, Brigadoon.com paid undisclosed sum for company's assets and has vowed to keep company alive (S)

headline: Investor Response Shows Quirks of Internet Deals
abstract: Trading in Netscape Communications stock indicates that America Online's proposed acquisition of Netscape might be called off; Netscape traded at value equal to 0.47 times value of America Online's shares, sometimes more; that is exactly opposite of normal trading pattern in which stock of takeover targets trades at discount to stated purchase price; Netscape released statement saying proposed transaction would involve exchange of 0.45 share of America Online for each share of Netscape; analysts say some investors knew too little about deal (M)

headline: Margin Rule Tightens For Internet Stocks
abstract: Number of brokerage houses, concerned about wild swings in prices of hot Internet stocks, are requiring investors who buy these stocks on margin to put up more of own money to maintain holdings; increases vary from firm to firm and do not apply to all investors; table of stocks with higher margin maintenance requirements at Charles Schwab & Co (M)

headline: Earnings at J. P. Morgan Tumble by 60%
abstract: J P Morgan & Co's third-quarter earnings plunged greater-than-expected 60 percent; profit from operations fell to $122 million from $396 million in year-earlier period; net earnings fell to $156 million; Morgan says it will bolster profits by cutting expenses in 1999 by $400 million; this includes making deeper job cuts than 5 percent, or 800 to 900 job cuts, that bank already announced (M)

headline: Business Backers Still Cheering G.O.P.
abstract: Republicans appear unlikely to lose support of business leaders as GOP continues to press for impeachment of Pres Clinton; photo (S)

headline: Possible I.M.F. Bailout Stirs Brazilians' Bitter Memories of 80's
abstract: International Monetary Fund is considering cost and wisdom of bailing out Brazil from its deepening economic crisis; Brazil had bruising experience with fund in 1980's, and effects linger; IMF says it is negotiating substantial aid package for Brazil, but issue is so sensitive that Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who hopes to be re-elected on Oct 6, has not announced formal request to fund for assistance (M)

headline: Sonic Automotive Seeks More Dealers
abstract: Sonic Automotive Inc chairman and chief executive Bruton Smith says company will take advantage of slide among rival auto-dealership stocks to buy up independent dealers ahead of its competitors (S)

headline: Sticker Shocks In Euro Land
abstract: Eleven European countries are set to formally adopt euro as their common currency; change will make wide price differences on identical goods in different countries more transparent but is not expected to make them disappear; retail price variations of consumer products can be as great as 50 percent from country to country, result of distinctive market conditions that are likely to persist for years; prices of several products noted; photos (M)

headline: Hong Kong's Chief Offers No Economic Initiatives
abstract: Hong Kong chief executive Tun Chee-hwa, in his second annual policy address, offers little hope for beleaguered economy; says Government remains committed to free-market principles and to maintaining Hong Kong dollar's peg to US currency; says Government will run budget deficit significantly higher than shortfall of 21 billion Hong Kong dollars that was forecast in June (S)

headline: German Green Evolves From Revolutionary to Pragmatist
abstract: Joschka Fischer, leader of environmentalist Green Party in Germany, is to hold talks with Pres Clinton as part of German delegation led by Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroder; his presence suggests that he will emerge as foreign minister in coalition Govt of Social Democrats and Greens now being formed; photo (M)

headline: Out of work for a year, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco's cartoon endorser now faces Government charges.
abstract: Trial will begin tomorrow on Federal Trade Commission charge that R J Reynolds Tobacco Co, unit of RJR Nabisco, committed unfair trade practice by using Joe Camel character to attract children and adolescents to cigarettes; trial will start one year after company retired the advertising symbol; photo of Joe Camel ad (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.06   5.13   5.44        3-month T-bills   4.34   4.39   5.11        6-month T-bills   4.36   4.39   5.12        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.80   3.53        10-yr. T-note   4.80   4.77   5.86        30-yr. headline: Flex Time for Everyone? It's Closer Every Day
abstract: William M Mercer Inc poll of more than 1,800 employers finds percentage of companies offering flex time to employees has risen from 40 percent in 1993 to 61 percent (S)

headline: Fielding the Competition
abstract: More than 40 major league stadiums and arenas in United States and Canada have been named for corporate sponsors, about half of all venues for professional baseball, football, basketball and hockey; chart shows year-to-date stock performance of these corporate sponsors (S)

headline: Irish Company Buying Brick Maker in Britain
abstract: CRH PLC agrees to buy Ibstock PLC for 326 million pounds ($547 million); buys 50.7 percent of Ibstock shares (S)

headline: Media Talk; A Gore's Foray Into Secret Service
abstract: Kristin C Gore, Vice Pres Al Gore's daughter, has written essay for Harvard Lampoon satirizing type of person who might be drawn to life of Secret Service agent; she lauds Service; says she did not intend to express disrespect; photo (M)

headline: German Trade Surplus Narrows to $5.26 Billion
abstract: Germany's merchandise trade surplus narrowed to 8.6 billion marks ($5.26 billion) in August from 10-year record high of 14.2 billion marks in July (S)

headline: Arafat and Netanyahu Trade Threats as Tensions Rise on the Peace Accord
abstract: Israeli and Palestinians move closer to carrying out their land-for-security peace plan as leaders play to home front with tough talk and subordinates negotiate key technical details; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat threatens new Palestian uprising, Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu demands public disavowal of violent threats and Min Ariel Sharon advises Jewish West Bank settlers to grab every possible hill before Israeli troop withdrawal begins (M)

headline: No-Frills Look at Retirement
abstract: Plan Retirement Quick and Easy, product of Individual Software Inc, assessed (M)

headline: Magazine's 'Little Joke' Has Promoter Fuming
abstract: David Watkins, president and chief executive of Icon Life Style Marketing, firm that planned and promoted the ballyhooed 29th birthday party, New York City, for the rap impressario Sean (Puffy) Combs, criticizes New York magazine for listing RSVP phone number sent to 1,200 invited birthday guests; Watkins and executives at Coombs's label agreed to disinvite reporters who wrote the story; Combs photo (M)

headline: Venezuelans Elect An Ex-Coup Leader As Their President
abstract: Hugo Chavez, former paratrooper and leader of failed coup six years ago, sweeps to victory in Venezuela's Presidential election, defeating Yale-educated businessman, Henrique Salas Romer, with more than 50 percent of votes; is first leader in 40 years not to come from country's dominant political party; his meteoric rise among legions of disaffected voters smashes old-line party machinery but fans fears of leftist dictatorship; euphoric supporters, hoping for end to decades of poverty amid oil wealth, fill streets of Caracas with music, fireworks and blaring horns; Chavez says first priority will be improving education, health care and creating jobs; takes aim at national oil monopoly, Petroleos de Venezuela, warning that its budget and operations should be subordinated to national, rather than corporate goals; photo (M)

headline: Dow Ends Day Unchanged, In a Mostly Sluggish Session
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes unchanged at 8,706.15; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes down 0.76 point, to 1,110.84; Nasdaq composite index falls 12.48 points, to 1,788.43; graph; chart (M)

headline: Gunmen Kill Israeli; Peace Deal in Doubt
abstract: Two days before an Israeli-Palestinian summit meeting near Washington, gunmen believed to be Palestinian militants shot and killed an Israeli and seriously wounded another today as they bathed in a hillside spring outside Jerusalem.    Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, pressed by hawkish members of his Cabinet to resist a peace deal, said after the ambush that there was ''no chance, at this stage, of signing an agreement'' at the American-sponsored talks scheduled to begin on Thursday at Wye Plantation in Maryland.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of article and chart in October 11 quarterly Mutual Funds Report on hypothetical retirement portfolios of five money managers, which misstated cumulative returns and total values; chart (S)

headline: Greenalls Group Selling Pubs to Nomura Unit
abstract: Greenalls Group PLC of Britain says it will sell 1,241 pubs to Tudor Street Acquisitions PLC, subsidiary of Nomura International PLC for $612 million (US) (S)

headline: Suharto Says His Millions Were Earned, Not Stolen
abstract: Suharto, former President of Indonesia, defends himself against charges of corruptly amassing huge personal fortune; says he is a good saver and landlord; estimates of his wealth range up to $40 billion; photo of demostrators calling for broader investigations of corruption under Suharto (M)

headline: India's Hottest Political Issue: The Price of Onions
abstract: Shortage of onions is producing long lines, high prices and anger in many Indian cities, threatening to topple Hindu nationalist state governments in Delhi and Rajasthan in November elections; maps; photo (M)

headline: DELAWARE JUDGE VOIDS QUICKTURN ANTI-TAKEOVER PLAN
abstract: Delaware court voids potent but controversial anti-takeover plan adopted by Quickturn Design Systems Inc, easing way for proxy fight in which Mentor Graphics Corp is trying to oust board and force company to accept its $215 million hostile offer; upholds Quickturn bylaw change that lets company delay by up to 100 days special shareholders meeting on Mentor slate (S)

headline: Boards Likely To Consider Exxon-Mobil Combination
abstract: Boards of Exxon Corp and Mobil Corp reportedly will meet next week to consider possible merger agreement; both companies confirm they are discussing ways to combine; statement sends stock of both companies soaring; merger talks come against backdrop of severe pressure on Lucio A Noto, head of Mobil, to find new reserves of oil and natural gas and to keep big projects profitable at time of deep decline in oil prices (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    ITALY: VOTE OF CONFIDENCE -- Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema won a vote of confidence from the Chamber of Deputies, the lower house of Parliament, for his newly formed government, the first to include Communists in Italy since 1947.   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)    RUSSIA: AN OPTIMISTIC YELTSIN -- President Boris N. Yeltsin said that Russia's economic plight remained difficult but that the country was already starting down the long road out of crisis. Mr. Yeltsin's views are not shared by most officials. Russia is deep in recession, has no clear recovery plan and is threatening to print more money if it does not secure foreign loans. An aide also said that Mr. Yeltsin is fed up with speculation over his ailments and feels hurt that even former allies have fanned the gossip about his health.   (Reuters, Agence France-Presse)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.13   5.04   5.75        3-month T-bills   4.43   4.37   5.10        6-month T-bills   4.42   4.33   5.08        10-yr. T-infl.   3.77   3.72   3.54        10-yr. T-note   4.76   4.73   5.95        30-yr. headline: Rancor Rules Out Progress At Peace Talks in Mexico
abstract: Angry invective and rancor thwart progress between Mexican Govt mediators and top leaders of Zapatista rebels at two days of peace talks in Chiapas; maps (M)

headline: Trying to Revive Itself, E.D.S. Lures Chief From Cable and Wireless
abstract: Electronic Data Systems, seeking marquee leader able to restore its primacy in computer services, names Richard H Brown, chief executive of Cable and Wireless PLC, as its own chairman and chief executive; Brown will replace Lester M Alberthal Jr, who resigned in August (M)

headline: Limerick (Stab City, No Less) Rebounds
abstract: Limerick, Ireland, 1,000-year-old city of 52,000 people, is seen losing its inferiority complex; few years ago, third-largest Irish city was known in rest of country as a bad place to visit, but you wouldn't want to live there, either; city has changed for the better, as Ireland's economy has boomed (M)

headline: Turning Her Passion Into a Park
abstract: Ilene Marckx and her neighbors in Federal Way, Wash, succeed in turning one of the last unspoiled bogs in the region into 58.4-acre West Hylebos State Park; photo (M)

headline: 5 Companies In Korea Plan To Shed Units
abstract: South Korea's five largest conglomerates pledge to shed more than half their subsidiaries, bowing to intense Government pressure aimed at reorganizing economy; chiefs of conglomerates come to terms in meeting with Pres Kim Dae Jung and his top policy makers; under agreement, Samsung Group will cede Samsung Motor Co to Daewoo Group, which will give Daewoo Electronics Co to Samsung; agreement establishes core areas of business for five largest conglomerates--Hyundai, Samsung, Daewoo, LG and SK, in that order of size--and number of companies each has to give up; Hyundai to shrink to 30 companies from 63, Samsung to 40 from 65, Daewoo to 10 from 41, LG to 30 from 53 and SK to 20 from 42; photo (M)

headline: In the Rough With Makers Of Golf Clubs; Sales Decline as Products Fail to Attract New Buyers
abstract: Golf-club industry is enduring serious retrenchment, with sales off 10 to 20 percent in 1998 despite sharp rise in interest in golf; prices are falling and inventories rising as golfers become more cost-conscious; new United States Golf Association rules could make it more difficult for manufacturers to devise next great advance that might spur demand; Callaway Golf Co, largest club maker, has been among hardest hit; graphs; table of club prices; photos (M)

headline: Telefonica Investing $3.8 Billion in Brazil
abstract: Telefonica SA, Spain's biggest telephone company, says it will invest $3.8 billion to expand its telephone networks in Brazil(S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AT HOME NETWORK CO.,  Redwood City, Calif., the provider of high-speed cable Internet services, acquired Full Force Systems Inc., the developer of interactive TV set-top box software, for undisclosed terms.    COLUMBIA/HCA HEALTHCARE CORP.,  Nashville, sold its home care operations in Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, North Carolina, Oklahoma and Tennessee to Amedisys Inc., for a total of $24 million.

headline: Utility Resurrects Reddy Kilowatt
abstract: Northern State Power Co is resurrecting Reddy Kilowatt, lightning-bolt character that promoted use of electricity, in advertising and direct marketing materials, sharing spotlight with recently created sibling, Reddy Flame, which represents Northern States natural gas operations (S)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON IS BUYING A RIVAL'S SKIN CARE BUSINESS
abstract: Johnson & Johnson agrees to acquire skin care business of S C Johnson & Son Inc; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: 2 Had Scores to Settle With Israelis
abstract: Youssef Sughayer and his brother-in-law, Suleiman Tahayneh, are identified as Palestinians who were killed when their car-bomb blew apart in Jerusalem market on Nov 6, wounding 24 people; photos (M)

headline: Fiat Announces Big Production Cut
abstract: Fiat SpA to trim production by about 28,000 units in November and December, amid signs of slower economic growth in Italy (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: It May Be Snail Mail, but Technology Gets It Where It's Going
abstract: Article describes computer technology utilizing advanced digital imaging and optical character recognition used by US Postal Service in routing bar-coded, machine-printed, and hand-addressed mail; diagram (M)

headline: Even the Rich Can Suffer From Income Inequality
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column on new focus by social scientists on damage that income inequality inflicts on rich and poor Americans; inequality is prompting workers to postpone marriage and seek more education; men and women want, but are unable, to cut working hours when children are born (M)

headline: A Russian Bank Countersues Lehman
abstract: Unexim Bank wins court order in Moscow to block accounts of Lehman Brothers Holdings, arguing that Lehman defaulted on obligations to it; its action comes after Lehman Brothers won court order blocking British bank accounts of Unexim, maintaining it had defaulted on $25.9 million payment due on Sept 11; Lehman also wins court orders to block accounts of Inkombank, asserting it defaulted on $87 million payment, and accounts of SBS-AGRO, Russia's largest private bank, saying it defaulted on $15 million debt (S)

headline: TRITON REVIVES $222 MILLION STOCK-PURCHASE RIGHTS SALE
abstract: Triton Energy Ltd is reviving a sale of stock-purchase rights that is related to a plan by the buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc to invest as much as $350 million in Triton; Triton delayed the $222 million sale last week after starting talks with what is described as widely known oil company that was interested in investing in Triton; says talks were not moving quickly enough to justify further delay (S)

headline: TENNECO CUTS 1,000 JOBS, TRIMMING WORK FORCE BY 2%
abstract: Tenneco Inc will cut 1,000 jobs, or about 2 percent of its work force; says it will step up cost-cutting measures, resulting in fourth-quarter pretax charge of $95 million to $105 million; reports third-quarter earnings fell to $93 million from $105 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Ex-Biogen Chief Says He Quit Over Conflicts With Chairman
abstract: James R Tobin says he resigned as Biogen Inc's president and chief executive over conflicts with its chairman, James L Vincent (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Federal Reserve Reports Growth Eased in November  Economic growth slowed in many parts of the country in November, and inflation remained absent as wage pressures lessened, the Federal Reserve said.    Export industries shrank, farms were under stress and retail sales were weaker than expected, the Fed said in its latest economic assessment, known as the beige book. The latest reading could point to a future cut in interest rates. The Fed has reduced borrowing costs three times since the end of September, most recently on Nov. 17. [Page C3.]

headline: AIDS Takes a Toll on Africa, Even After Death
abstract: Article in series on impact of AIDS epidemic on Africa: Dead Zones. The Culture of Mourning; finds that across Africa, as AIDS epidemic has gnawed through people like a conqueror worm, number of dying is so great that it is changing the culture of death itself; UN notes there are 5,500 AIDS-related deaths every day in Africa; on a continent where death has always been communal rather than a private matter, poverty and emotional exhaustion are taking their toll; the poorest go unshrouded, a shoveful of ashes into a common pit; thousands of graves are left with no marker grander than the favorite cup or spoon of the deceased, smashed in loving memory of them; people in all walks of life shamefacedly confess that they no longer have the money or energy to mourn as they feel tradition demands; photos; map shows demographics of AIDS in Africa (L)

headline: World War I Sets Off A New Battle In France
abstract: A day after France's Socialist Prime Minister called for the rehabilitation of French soldiers executed for refusing to fight in a World War I battle that cost 300,000 French lives, the country's Gaullist conservative President, Jacques Chirac, today called the Prime Minister's remarks ''inopportune.''    The 1917 battle, along a ridge road called the Chemin des Dames, remains a sensitive subject in France as it prepares to celebrate the 80th anniversary of the Nov. 11 armistice that ended the war.

headline: Treasuries Off As Stability Aids Markets
abstract: US bond prices fall for first time in three days; price of benchmark 30-year bond falls 19/32, to 105 26/32; yield rises to 5.12 percent, from 5.08 percent; graph on 2-year Treasury notes; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Taking the Economy's Pulse?
abstract: Former Council of Economic Advisers chairman Herbert Stein letter disputes October 18 article implying that US economic expansion has not been as strong as believed (M)

headline: Zeneca Seeks Buyer For a Chemicals Unit
abstract: Britain's Zeneca Group PLC is seeking buyer for its specialty-chemicals unit, which could fetch at least $1.5 billion (S)

headline: German Bank Buys A Polish Stake
abstract: Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank AG, Germany's second largest bank, acquires 37 percent stake in Bank Przemyslowo-Handlowy SA, Poland's third-largest publicly traded bank, for about 1 billion marks, or $607 million (S)

headline: U.N. Report Faults Big Accountants in Asia Crisis
abstract: World's five largest accounting firms are coming under increasing pressure to strengthen their auditing procedures in Asia and other emerging markets after giving approval on financial statements of Asian financial institutions that then collapsed; study by United Nations Conference on Trade and Development concludes that Asian crisis would have been detected sooner if banks and companies had been forced to follow stronger accounting rules than those now in use in most Asian countries; urges Big Five firms to do same strong auditing tests on financial statements in Asia that they do in US and Europe; World Bank is also pressing accounting firms to do more to get Asian banks and companies to use better accounting (M)

headline: Russian Financial Woes Take a Toll in Cigarettes
abstract: Most Western tobacco companies, after committing nearly $1 billion to build new factories in Russia, are hit with heavy losses since financial turmoil took hold this summer, but they say they will remain in market until economy picks up again; Russia's debt default and devaluation of ruble in mid-August devastated consumer purchasing power; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Uses E-Mail From Netscape to Contest Antitrust Case
abstract: Microsoft Corp, in effort to refute central accusation in Government's antitrust case, produces secret E-mail message from Netscape Communications Corp's chairman-co-founder James Clark seeking Microsoft's cooperation, offering to stay out of its way and suggesting that Microsoft invest in Netscape; E-mail, written on Dec 29, 1994, is introduced to suggest that it was Netscape, not Microsoft, that initiated some of elements of what Government portrays as illegal offer by Microsoft in June 1995 to divide with Netscape the market for software used to browse Internet's World Wide Web; Microsoft's lead lawyer John Warden frequently tries to goad James Barksdale, president and chief executive of Netscape, to concede key points in Microsoft's defense--namely, that Netscape's browser is widely distributed despite Microsoft's allegedly unfair business practices; Barksdale makes few concessions (M)

headline: Opening A Window To Muni Bond Prices
abstract: Investing column notes municipal bond arena has long been cloaked in mystery, and some brokers have used this secrecy to mark up muni bonds by big amounts; says this may be changing: Bond Market Assn, industry group, has started posting daily transactions on its Web site, giving potential buyers and sellers free access to prices, yields, credit ratings and other information; key data is gulf between bond's high and low prices for previous day and resulting yield to call and yield to maturity from those prices; charts (M)

headline: Italy Tightens Rules on Lending of Art
abstract: VENICE—  By the end of her days here, Peggy Guggenheim, with her private gondola, bevy of exotic lap dogs, bizarre signature sunglasses and earrings that doubled up as wall hangings, had become a monstre sacré and herself one of the sights of the city.

headline: Canada Drops Currency Trigger
abstract: Bank of Canada abandons its policy of regular, predictable intervention in currency markets in defense of Canadian dollar in favor of more discretionary approach; decision marks formal abandonment of bank's policy of intervention in currency markets whenever US dollar moves 70 basis points against Canadian dollar in either direction from previous day's official close (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: TORY REBELLION -- William Hague, left, the Conservative Party leader, found himself at odds with one group he thought he could count on, the Tory peers in the House of Lords. Mr. Hague dismissed his party's leader in the House of Lords, Viscount Cranborne, for striking a deal that could let 10 percent of the 759 hereditary peers retain their voting rights. Mr. Hague later endorsed the same legislative proposal himself, prompting the entire Tory leadership of the Lords to resign their front bench posts. Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Guatemala Cover-Up Charged in Killing of Bishop
abstract: Political controversy in Guatemala surrounding murder nearly six months ago of Juan Gerardi, Roman Catholic bishop and outspoken human rights advocate, continues to grow, while solution to his slaying appears further away than ever; despite mounting evidence to the contrary, Guatemalan Govt continues to maintain that killing was a crime without a political motive; however, Roman Catholic Church and human rights groups contend that elements of Guatemalan armed forces were involved in killing, and point to increasingly bizarre turns case has taken as proof of official cover-up; as result, Gerardi's death has become a major test of 1996 peace accord that brought an end to 36 years of civil war in Guatemala and was supposed to install principle of civilian supremacy; photos of Gerardi and of Rev Mario Orantes Najera, who has been charged with killing (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen gains for first time in six days on speculation that an income-tax cut and spending plan to be announced will help overcome recession; dollar falls to 121.72 yen from 122.52 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: YEN WEAKENS.  A rally in Japan's currency faltered after Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa dashed some hope that the Government would cut a sales tax to stimulate the economy. The dollar rose to 120.30 yen from 119.99.

headline: U.S. Forces Set to Strike Iraq in Hours If Called On
abstract: Clinton Administration and Defense Department officials say weaponry United States planned to use against Iraq remains in Persian Gulf and could be used to strike within hours; says planned attack, called off by Pres Clinton 15 minutes before it was to begin, relied entirely on forces already in region; photo (M)

headline: Balloonists Cross China And Leave The Mainland
abstract: Three-man crew of ICO Global Challenge become first balloonists to cross Asian continent from one end to the other and the first to fly over towering Himalayan range; are relaxing over Yellow Sea after contronting series of crises; map (M)

headline: Hanging On to the Net
abstract: Kelsey S Gray letter say use of software that enables Internet users to stay on-line when they are not using it is unfair to other users and the Internet service provider

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Schwab, for Now, Bests Merrill on Strength of On-Line Trading
abstract: Market value of Charles Schwab Corp rises to $25.5 billion, slightly higher than that of Merrill Lynch & Co and second only to Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co in securities industry, as stocks of Internet-related companies continue to soar; recent speculation that Merrill might buy Schwab to gain Internet presence now seems far-fetched given huge increase in Schwab's stock price; Schwab has transformed itself from traditional broker that specialized in discounted fees into company that does most of its business on line; Merrill has delayed plans to offer limited on-line trading; graph (M)

headline: Newell Buying Rubbermaid in $5.8 Billion Deal
abstract: Rubbermaid Inc will merge with Newell Co in stock swap valued at about $5.8 billion; merged company will be called Newell Rubbermaid; Newell's chairman William P Sovey will be chairman of new company and Newell's chief executive John J McDonough will be chief executive; Rubbermaid's chief executive Wolfgang R Schmitt will stay on as vice chairman; graph (M)

headline: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES TO CUT 10% OF ITS WORK FORCE
abstract: Huntington Bancshares Inc will cut 1,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, in effort to increase profits (S)

headline: COMPX INTERNATIONAL WILL ACQUIRE THOMAS REGOUT
abstract: Compx International Inc., a maker of ergonomic furniture and computer supplies, has agreed to acquire Thomas Regout Holdings N.V., a closely held Dutch maker of ball bearing furniture slides, for $53 million. Compx, based in Mauldin, S.C., had annual revenue of $108 million last year. Thomas Regout has annual sales of about $59 million. Its main plant is in Maastricht, the Netherlands. It also has a plant in Grand Rapids, Mich., which accounted for 29 percent of the company's sales this year. Compx also said yesterday that it had closed its acquisition of Timberline Lock Ltd., a maker of office-furniture locks, for $7.9 million.

headline: DATABANK: October 5-9; On Friday, the Bear Took a Holiday
abstract: After mauling the markets all week, especially technology, financial and small-capitalization issues, the bear took Friday off, allowing investors to go on a bargain-hunting spree amid optimism that interest rates would be cut further.

headline: Credit Ratings Lowered At 7 Japanese Banks
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp cuts cut ratings of 7 big Japanese banks: Daiwa Bank Ltd, Sumitomo Bank Ltd, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd, Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd, Sakura Bank Ltd, Sanwa Bank Ltd and Tokai Bank Ltd; warns most face mounting bad debts and 'substantial' net losses (S)

headline: South Africa's Press to Face Bias Inquiry
abstract: South Africa's Human Rights Commission says it will open probe into racism in press, using its powers of subpoena and arrest if needed; commission head, Barney Pityana, says probe is aimed at spurring debate about nature, meaning and incidence of racism he holds is endemic in nation; some editors see carefully timed effort to keep news organizations from criticizing Pres Nelson Mandela's Government on eve of national elections (M)

headline: ARAFAT AND NETANYAHU IN PACT ON NEXT STEPS TOWARD PEACE; MODEST DEAL TO 'REBUILD TRUST'
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and Israel's Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, after nine days of tortuous negotiations, sign modest agreement restoring life to Middle East peace effort and opening way for talks on final resolution of 50-year-old fight over possible Palestinian state; Pres Clinton presides over signing ceremony at White House, joined as host by visibly ailing King Hussein of Jordan; agreement in part serves to commit both sides to actions already promised in 1993 and 1995 agreements reached in Oslo; sets detailed timetable for withdrawal of Israeli forces from 13 percent of West Bank in three phases over 12 weeks, beginning soon after ratification, bringing to 40 percent total territory Palestinians control fully or partly; provides for specific steps by Palestinians to fight terrorism and formally amend charter to expunge clauses calling for Israel's destruction; Arafat pledges never to leave peace process or to return to violence and confrontation; Netanyahu says agreement will make Israel and entire region secure; Clinton urges both to carry out commitments and to have courage enough to withstand inevitable attacks from enemies of peace; photos (M)

headline: GLAMIS GOLD MAKES BID FOR RAYROCK RESOURCES
abstract: Glamis Gold Ltd, US gold producer, makes unsolicited offer to buy Rayrock Resources, Canada, for more than $150 million (Canadian) or $97 million (US) (S)

headline: Wal-Mart's Quarter Profit Jumps 27%
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says profit rose better-than-expected 27 percent in fiscal third quarter ended Oct 31; net income climbed to $1.01 billion from $792 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 16 percent, to $33.51 billion from $28.78 billion (S)

headline: Chester Lasell, 90, Ex-Brokerage Firm Head
abstract: Chester H Lasell, former president of Morgan Stanley & Co, dies from injuries suffered in recent automobile accident at age 90 (S)

headline: Mouse Manipulations
abstract: Arnie Huberman letter, responding to Oct 1 article, says it is unnecessary to purchase cleaning kit for computer mouse; describes how he regularly cleans his mouse

headline: Despite Tests Stacked Against It, eBook Passes
abstract: Michelle Slatalla assesses Rocket eBook, the electronic book from Nuvomedia; text of books is downloaded to the device via the Internet and displayed on backlighted screen; drawing (M)

headline: KEARNY FEDERAL TO BUY FIRST BERGEN FOR $62.4 MILLION
abstract: Kearny Federal Savings Bank to acquire First Bergen Bancorp for about $62.4 million (S)

headline: Operator? Give Me the World Wide Web and Make It Snappy
abstract: Group of communications, software and financial services companies plans to announce alliance aimed at creating standards for speech recognition that will push electronic commerce and Internet beyond boundaries of personal computer, potentially making it accessible to anyone with telephone; aim is to expand ability to perform Internet transactions or retrieve data from World Wide Web by using speech-recognition technology to translate spoken words into data commands transmitted via Web; companies say their so-called V-Commerce telephone access will break down last barrier remaining between mass of consumers and Internet; they envision new Internet platform controlled by voice that will display information on small portable screen; companies in alliance include Motorola Inc, SAP AG, Visa International, Broadvision Inc and Nuance Communications, unit of SRI International (M)

headline: Insurer Must Pay $100.5 Million in Redlining Case
abstract: Richmond, Va, jury orders Nationwide Insurance Co to pay $100.5 million in damages to local housing group called Housing Opportunities Made Equal that accused insurer of refusing to sell homeowner policies to black residents; it is first of many complaints brought by housing groups against insurers to go to trial; verdict could influence insurance sales around country; Andrew M Cuomo, Secretary of Department of Housing and Urban Development, praises verdict; Housing Department provided $1.5 million for research on discrimination that helped group build its case; Nationwide says it will appeal verdict (M)

headline: Prodi Takes a Swipe At D'Alema for Way Majority Was Formed : Italy Gives Mandate To Former Communist
abstract: ROME—  Massimo D'Alema became the first former Communist to lead a Western European government on Monday when he succeeded in obtaining the support he needed to form Italy's 56th postwar government.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Brazil's dozen phone spinoffs come to trade in New York.
abstract: Market Place column on spinoff of 12 holding companies from giant Telebras, Brazilian Government monopoly; notes that under trading arrangement just started on New York Stock Exchange, investors can buy American depository receipts in any of dozen successor companies to Telebras; start of trading in spinoff telephone company coincides with growing political controversy in which privatization of Telebras has emerged as central issue; in series of illegally tapped telephone conversations between Communications Minister Luiz Carlos Mendonca de Barros and president of National Development Bank, Andre Larea Resende, published in weekly news magazine, the two men can be heard disparaging one group of bidders and passing information to rival group of bidders that included a former business partner; both men deny any wrongdoing (M)

headline: Aetna to Buy Prudential's Health Care Business for $1 Billion
abstract: Aetna Inc agrees to buy Prudential Health Care from Prudential Insurance Co of America for $1 billion, creating nation's biggest managed-care company with 22.4 million customers, including 18.4 million in health maintenance organizations and other managed health plans; chart (M)

headline: Some Big Ideas Wash Up One Bulb at a Time
abstract: Andrew C Revkin article on man's slow, subtle degradation of his environment, whose effect might only be noticeable after decades; cartoon (M)

headline: BANKERS TRUST SHARES FALL AFTER RATINGS ARE CUT
abstract: Shares of Bankers Trust Corp fall after Fitch IBCA lowers its rating on company's debt, citing concerns about earnings prospects (S)

headline: Berlin Debates Spielberg Holocaust Video Offer
abstract: Jewish Museum in Berlin begins talks with Steven Spielberg over possibility of housing his vast video history of Holocaust, as debate intensifies over how to recall Hitler's destruction of European Jewry in emerging new center of Berlin; museum is to open in 2000 (M)

headline: El Paso Energy Purchase
abstract: El Paso Energy Corp acquires 46 percent of East Asia Power Resources Corp of Philippines from Van Der Horst Ltd of Singapore for $70 million (S)

headline: South Africa's Al Gore Tries for a Common Touch
abstract: South Africa's Deputy Pres Thabo Mbeki, who is virtually certain of becoming country's next President, is trying to emerge from shadow of Pres Nelson Mandela by using common touch to reveal himself to suspicious South Africans; visits his hometown of Engcingwana, where he reminds members of his Xhosa ethnic group of his own credentials in struggle for South Africa; lived in exile for more than 30 years, earning degree in economics from University of Sussex; is rarely seen in anything than double-breasted suit and silk tie and is clearly ill at ease in public eye; map; photo (M)

headline: CONSOLIDATED CIGAR CONSIDERS POSSIBLE MERGER OR SALE
