abstract: Consolidated Cigar Holdings is considering merger, recapitalization or sale of company; reports net income for three months ended Oct 3 fell to $8.3 million, compared with net of $16.8 million a year ago (S)

headline: Fighting in a Corner of Kosovo Stops, for the Moment
abstract: American diplomats persuade ethnic Albanian rebel commanders and Yugoslav Army officers to pull some of their forces from what seemed certain combat in Gornja Lapastica in Serbian province of Kosovo; map; photo (M)

headline: A Store Adds Vitual Floors
abstract: Moss, interior design store in SoHo, adds four new floors that exist only within computer program; customers can reach new floors only through virtual elevator reached via Macintosh G3 computer with large-screen monitor in store; photo (M)

headline: A Phone Fee Quirk Benefits New Providers
abstract: Local phone company upstarts that focused their sales efforts on Internet service providers are profiting nicely on the fees that one local phone pays another when one of its customers calls one of the other's; Internet service providers' calls are mostly incoming, and their incoming calls are mostly from customers served by Bell customers, which have had to pay the upstarts millions of dollars a year as a result; Bell companies and GTE contend they should not have to pay these reciprocal-compensation fees on Internet calls because calls to cyberspace are inherently long distance, not local; Federal Communications Commission is expected to intercede on practice (M)

headline: New Violence Prompts Netanyahu Warning on Pullout
abstract: Palestinian mob beats Israeli soldier and seizes his gun in West Bank, prompting warning from Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu that he might halt further Israeli troop withdrawals under new land-for-security accord with Palestinians; violence also erupts in East Jerusalem after Palestinian is killed by assailant believed to be Jewish serial stabber responsible for attacks on several Arabs in last year; map; photo (M)

headline: Primestar Drops Plan to Buy Satellite Venture
abstract: Primestar Inc, satellite television service owned by group of cable operators, abandons $1.1 billion plan to buy direct-broadcast satellite venture of News Corp and MCI Worldcom Inc; announcement comes from Justice Department, which had filed civil antitrust suit in May to block Primestar from entering direct-broadcast satellite business (S)

headline: Financial Times Picks Avrett Free
abstract: Financial Times, published by Pearson PLC, names Avrett Free & Ginsberg in New York as the first agency to handle its account in the United States; billings are estimated at $3 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: The Next Trouble Spot in the Balkans: Montenegro
abstract: Unrest is building in Yugoslav republic of Montenegro, where Pres Milo Djukanovic and other leaders say they would like to remain part of Yugoslavia, but not if federation with Serbia means submitting to autocracy or Slobodan Milosevic, Yugoslav President; Montenegrins, who for most part have no ethnic or religious quarrels to pick with Serbia, say they hope to create open and democratic society as example of how all Yugoslavs should be able to live; are falling back on tradition of smuggling to achieve goals, arguing that this is only way to subsidize government cut off financially by Belgrade; smuggling has become problem for Western countries that praise Montenegrans for challenging Milosevic; map (M)

headline: NETSCAPE AGREES TO ACQUIRE ATWEB FOR $95.1 MILLION
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp to buy closely held Atweb Inc, an on-line Web site services company, for about $95 million in stock and options (S)

headline: McCann Unit Buys Agencies in 3 Countries
abstract: McCann Relationship Marketing acquires Direct Response Co in Australia, ISD in Japan and Common Sense in Spain (S)

headline: Dow Posts 14.94-Point Gain On Hopes for Rising Profits
abstract: Stock prices rose on New York Stock Exchange and other markets on November 19; Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 14.94 points, to 9056.05; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 8.13 points, to 1,512.61, and Nasdaq Composite 22.24 points to 1,919.68; graph (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: HERSHEY FOODS CORP., Hershey, Pa., named Michael Pasquale head of its candy and pasta businesses, making him the probable successor to the current chief executive, Kenneth Wolfe. Mr. Pasquale, who headed Hershey's North American chocolate business, was also nominated to the company's board. Also promoted was Raymond Brace, to senior vice president for operations.     LANDS' END INC., Dodgeville, Wis., said David Dyer will return to the catalogue retailer as its president and chief executive, succeeding Michael Smith who resigned. Also, William Ferry, vice chairman of sales, resigned.

headline: Lessons of a Long, Hot Summer
abstract: Near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management LP revealed flaws in basic investment assumptions; fund's strategy of spreading its bets among many markets in various nations failed to protect it and complicated last-minute rescue; derivatives markets and other new kinds of investments hailed as ways to offset many risks proved clumsy and prone to panic; use of borrowed money for speculation, mainstay of many professional investors, occured on scale so large and complex that lenders, trading partners and regulators could not respond to fund's troubles as they had expected; markets apparently remain vulnerable to similar crises despite return to more normal market conditions; table of fund's investments; graphs showing spread on interest rate swaps and percentage of borrowed money to invested capital of fund, other hedge funds and brokerage firms; photos (L)

headline: Dispute Over New Wrinkle In Problem Of Year 2000
abstract: Computing's Year 2000 problem has new wrinkle stemming from purported timekeeping flaw discovered in August 1997 by Prof Jace Crouch of University of Michigan. and subsequently described at length on the Internet by Michael Echlin, programmer with Atomic Energy Canada Ltd; timekeeping flaw, know as Crouch-Echlin Effect, was noted by Crouch in testing aged 286 machine for compliance, and showed odd malfunctions when he decided not to reset the date to current time since he was using computer for word processing and date it logged made no difference; Echlin, learning of Crouch's findings, set up experiments on several computers that suggested Crouch's problems were not isolated; Douglas de Lacey, who oversees computer systems at Cambridge University school, says jury is still out on what is happening; de Lacey reported encountering Crouch-Echlin effect on two aging computers of his own; some critics say claims by two men are reckless, noting Crouch and Echlin have set up small firm that markets software to identify and neutralize the problem; photos (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices drop 2 percent as moderate weather weakens demand for heating fuel and leaves ample supplies in storage; November contract falls 4.3 cents, to $2.041 for 1,000 cubic feet; graph; chart (S)

headline: Jordan Accepts Suharto Relative, Ex-General
abstract: Jordan offers citizenship to Prabowo Subianto, former Indonesia general and ex-Pres Suharto's son-in-law, who has been living in Amman for four months; he refuses offer; eleven soldiers he once commanded go on trial on charges of abducting and torturing political dissidents (M)

headline: Russell Athletic Selects West Wayne
abstract: Russell Athletic unit of Russell Corp selects West Wayne to handle its advertising, marketing and public relations account--previously handled by BBDO New York; annual billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million (S)

headline: A Fund's Letters Can Cool Love's Fire
abstract: Article on need for investors to heed warnings from mutual fund officials about risks of investing (M)

headline: I Don't Know Who You Are, but You're Toast
abstract: More and more people are using the Internet to play computer games with other people rather than with their own computers; human-to-human competion has always added to the fun of television-cosole game systems like Nintendo and Sony Playstation, but it has taken off with computer users only in the last few years, when smarter computers, programs and fundamental improvements in Internet itself made on-line games seem to come to life with dazzling graphics and blazing speed; many of the most advanced CD-ROM computer games that permit multiple players do not require Internet and can be played on a local area network, or LAN; photos (L)

headline: Rising Russian Imports Fuel Dispute With U.S. Steel Makers
abstract: Russia and United States are engaged in trade war over hot-rolled steel; American steel makers brought anti-dumping case in Washington against Russia, Japan and Brazil, contending that their foreign competitors are selling steel below cost in United States, at grave damage to domestic industry; Russia is not biggest exporter of hot-rolled steel to US, but Russian producers have been squeezed by drop in domestic demand and collapse of their markets in Southeast Asia, and they have stepped up their shipments to US; imports of Russian steel rose to 2.2 million tons in first seven months of 1998; in Magnitogorsk, heart of Russian steel industry, exports to US are matter of survival (M)

headline: Software Users' Rights (Hah!)
abstract: Katie Hafner reviews book Bad Software, by Cem Kaner and David Pels; photo (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY     None

headline: Japan to Sell Shares In Telephone Giant
abstract: Japanese Ministry of Finance announces global public offering of one million shares of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp; Government expects to raise 855 billion yen ($7.5 billion) (S)

headline: Bank Sees Blundering
abstract: In a history of the world financial crisis, the World Bank has concluded that the International Monetary Fund and the United States Treasury made crucial blunders by pushing Asian countries to send their interest rates soaring.     Article, page A20.

headline: GPU Sells 23 Power Plants to a French-Linked Company
abstract: GPU Inc, holding company that owns utilities in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, announces sale of 23 power plants to Sithe Energies, major independent power producer and affiliate of Vivendi SA of France; deal, for $1.68 billion, is another major step in transforming utility industry in Northeast under deregulation; it will make Sithe largest independent power producer in nation and one of largest suppliers of electricity in region (M)

headline: Thyssen and Dover in $1.1 Billion Deal
abstract: Thyssen AG agrees to buy elevator business of Dover Corp for $1.1 billion (S)

headline: Grim Assessment by U.N. of Asia Crisis
abstract: International Labor Organization report concludes that social costs of Asian economic crisis are far higher than initial estimates and are 'dramatically worsening'; says lack of social welfare programs make hardest-hit countries, like Indonesia, 'fertile ground for breeding social unrest' (M)

headline: The Misery Of Babylon In the Age Of Hussein
abstract: Frustrations of modern Iraq are especially poignant in and around Babylon, whose ancient glory is invoked by Pres Saddam Hussein but whose people struggle under deprivations caused by eight years of economic sanctions; photo; map (L)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: THE NEW EUROPE -- Importing the Ways of Wall St.; For Investment Firms, Euro Spells Opportunity
abstract: American investment banks are competing to export more of Wall Street's ways to Europe as profit expectations heighten with imminent introduction of the euro; many financial specialists are forecasting profound changes in way continental European markets operate, with increasing pressure on Europeans to follow ways of Wall Street; with only one currency, European companies will increasingly be evaluated by equity investors and fund managers across broad range of competition where pricing and performance are no longer disguised by national currencies or local scales of importance (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UTILICORP UNITED INC.,  Kansas City, Mo., an international gas and electric company, plans to buy back the remaining 18 percent of Aquila Gas Pipeline Corp. it does not already own for $8 a share, or $43.2 million.    CROMPTON & KNOWLES CORP.,  Stamford, Conn., a specialty chemicals maker, will close its Painesville, Ohio, synthetic rubber plant and cut 125 jobs by mid-1999 as it moves production into a joint venture with Desc S.A. de C.V. of Mexico.

headline: Chang Chong-Jen, 93, Model for Character in Tintin Comic
abstract: Chang Chong-Jen, Chinese painter and sculptor who was model for character in Tintin cartoons, dies at age 93; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: PROSECUTORS SEE NO BIAS IN PINOCHET CASE -- Prosecutors told the House of Lords that its decision to let Gen. Augusto Pinochet be arrested in England and held on a Spanish extradition petition was not tainted by bias. The former Chilean dictator's lawyers want the Lords to set aside the ruling because of disclosures that the law lord who cast the decisive vote, Lord Hoffmann, was associated with Amnesty International. A decision on the appeal is expected on Thursday.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    RUSSIA: BILL TO PRINT MONEY -- The Parliament passed a bill to print $1.2 billion, to help the Government pay workers and pensioners, among others. With inflation at 70 percent this year, the infusion could push prices higher.   (AP)

headline: How Do We Measure The Virtue of Charity?
abstract: Gary A Waters letter on September 27 article on whether to support charity or buy goods (S)

headline: Cable and Wireless Ends Telecom Italia Plan
abstract: Cable and Wireless PLC, Britain, says it dropped plans for European partnership with Telecom Italia SpA because of management discord at Italy's No. 1 phone company; has been in talks with Telecom Italia about creating world's second-largest carrier of international calls (S)

headline: Uganda's Helping Hand to Congo Rebels Raises Questions About Motives
abstract: Uganda's huge military presence in Congo, ostensibly to protect its border from attack by rebel militias raises suspicions that real interest may be Congo's wealth in natural resources, notably its gems; map (M)

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO BUY SHIPBUILDER FOR $415 MILLION
abstract: General Dynamics Corp says it will buy Nassco Holdings Inc for $370 million in cash and assumption of $45 million in debt (S)

headline: Sailing for the Masses: Wind, Water, Plastic; Easy to Learn and Easy to Afford, New Tiny Boats Are Proving Popular
abstract: Peter Johnstone, head of Escape Sailboat Co of Portsmouth, RI, is trying to revitalize flagging sailboat industry by making small, affordable sailboats made of plastic; fewer people sail today, and far fewer new sailboats are sold, than in 1960's and 1970's; The Escape, an 11.5-foot dinghy, is Johnstone's magic formula for reversing trend; Escape is not loaded with high technology, but it uses technology to achieve two goals that could prove crucial to luring masses to sailing: Escape is cheap, and easy to use; basic Escape model sells for just $2,000; photo of Johnstone, drawings of three of most popular small sailboats (M)

headline: Autumn Rally Taking Stocks Back to Highs
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes week at 8,975.46, up 59.99 points for day and 4.46 percent for week; price of 30-year bond has tumbled this week; its yield ended at 5.38 percent, up from 5.15 percent a week earlier; graphs; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: MCI Expected To Announce Job Cut Plan
abstract: MCI Worldcom Inc intends to cut about 2,000 jobs, or 2.7 percent of its 75,000-member work force; far fewer employees will lose their jobs as result of MCI's $37 billion takeover of Worldcom Inc than some in industry had expected (M)

headline: STARWOOD TO SELL 35% STAKE IN TRADE SCHOOL OPERATOR
abstract: Starwood Hotels and Resorts is exploring ways to sell its 35 percent stake in trade school operator ITT Educational Services Inc, worth about $258 million (S)

headline: Estimates for On-Line Shopping Exceed the Most Bullish Forecasts
abstract: Holiday sales figures for Internet retailers show huge season, stronger even than most bullish predictions, with on-line sales expected to reach $5 billion; Boston Consulting Group reports year-to-year sales grew more than threefold during recent holiday season, with apparel sales especially strong, reaching $300 million from less than $100 million in 1997; photo (M)

headline: When the Mind Is the Matter; Mental Disability Cases Pose Painful Workplace Issues
abstract: Discrimination claims against employers based on mental disability became largest single category of disability claims in 1997; in 1992, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission recorded 91 complaints of discrimination on basis of emotional or psychiatric impairment, or 9.1 percent of all disability claims; by 1997, number jumped to 2,789, or 15.3 percent of claims; guidelines issued last year by EEOC and recent Supreme Court opinion could help employees win more cases; graph; drawing (M)

headline: The Purpose of Put Warrants
abstract: Letter by Greg Maffei, chief financial officer at Microsoft Corp, replies to Nov 22 article by discussing Microsoft's position on put warrants

headline: Publicis in Deals With Asian Agencies
abstract: Publicis SA acquires stakes in and forms affiliations with ad agencies in Asia; terms undisclosed; in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Publicis acquires Wet Desert as well as agencies specializing in direct marketing, public relations and design; agency will be renamed Publicis-Wet Desert; Jeanet Yeo will conitnue to head agency as director; in Lahore, Pakistan, Publicis acquires 60 percent stake in Headstart, which will be renamed Publicis; in Hong Kong and China, Publicis forms affiliation with Ad Link that could lead to acquisition (S)

headline: TENET HEALTHCARE FINDS MANAGER FOR MEDICAL SCHOOL
abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp says Drexel University has agreed to manage Philadelphia medical school, opening the way for Tenet to acquire eight affiliated hospitals for $345 million (S)

headline: Quentin Crewe, 72, Bon Vivant Who Was Unfazed by Disability
abstract: Quentin Crew, British journalist and author who traveled world and vastly enjoyed life despite lifelong affliction with muscular dystrophy, dies at age 72; photo (S)

headline: Just Hours Before Deadline, Mexicans Draft an Austerity Budget
abstract: Mexican lawmakers reach compromise on country's most austere budget in modern times, just hours before constitutional deadline; full Congress is expected to adopt package, which includes deep spending cuts and increases in tariffs and fuel prices (M)

headline: Stock Prices Rise Again; Dow Up 49
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average is up 49.69 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,466.45; gain leaves Dow up 7.08 percent for year and less than 10 percent below its July 17 peak; Standard & Poor's 500 index rises 5.97 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to 1,062.39; Nasdaq composite index jumps 27.78 points, or 1.71 percent, to 1,648.73, and is up 5 percent for year; Russell 200 index surges 9.58 points, or 2.8 percent, to 352.45; graph; chart (M)

headline: Close Election Complicates Brazilian Economic Reform
abstract: Road to Brazilian economic reform is looming longer and more complex as official election returns indicate Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso is barely squeaking to victory and governors allied to him will face runoff later in month; though exit polls suggested Cardoso would take approximately 56 percent of vote, official tallies show him winning 51.2 poercent with 56.1 percent of vote counted; his allies did poorly in many of country's most populous and politically influential states, weakening his hand going into negotiations for overhauling way Government spends money (M)

headline: AOL Offering Cash To Lure Chat Users
abstract: America Online authorizes on-line incentive company, Cybergold, to pay 50 cents to every person who downloads and installs AOL's chat software, called Instant Messenger (S)

headline: Boston's Smart-Card Meters Don't Need Quarters
abstract: City of Boston and Fleet Financial Group unveil 200 new smart-card parking meters near Boston University; cards incorporate a microchip that allows users to store up to $100 electronically; photo (S)

headline: Bombay Journal; 50 Years Later, Gandhi's Killer Is Gagged in India
abstract: Interview with Indian playwright Pradeep Dalvi, whose play about assassination of Mohandas K Gandhi 50 years ago was banned after seven performances in Bombay on recommendation from Hindu nationalist-led Government, which regarded it as threat to law and order; photos (M)

headline: Ames Reaches a Deal to Buy Hills Stores
abstract: Ames Department Stores to acquire Hills Stores Co for about $124 million, plus assumed debt of $206 million, creating fourth-largest discount retailer in nation (S)

headline: Serbs Display a Death Site; Identity of Remains Not Known
abstract: Serb authorities show foreign reporters remains of several people buried on mountain near former hideout of Kosovo Liberation Army; photo; map; Serbs say it appears people were killed by guerrillas several months ago (S)

headline: Merrill Lynch to Cut 3,400 Jobs In Big Setback for New York City
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 3,400 jobs, or just more than 5 percent of its work force, because of global economic turmoil.    The firm is the first big financial company to announce cutbacks linked primarily to the world's troubled markets. Other Wall Street firms, which along with Merrill Lynch had swelled their ranks on the fat profits of the rampant bull market, are expected to follow suit. Merrill Lynch said it expected ''a much more challenging environment ahead'' for financial companies.

headline: European Union Forecasts More Growth
abstract: European Union Commission predicts continued growth for 15-nation bloc, though it trims its previous forecast for 1999; lastest forecast for growth in gross domestic product is 2.4 percent, down from 3 percent forecast in March; commission says 1998 GDP growth will be higher than forecast in March, 2.9 percent instead of previously expected 2.8 percent (S)

headline: Dalai Lama Tells Clinton of Chinese Balkiness
abstract: Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, meets with Pres Clinton, Washington, DC; presses for talks with China aimed at gaining some autonomy for Tibet; United States says Clinton agrees with him on need for direct talks; he also meets with Vice Pres Al Gore, Hillary Rodham Clinton and State Sec Madeleine K Albright (M)

headline: Cheaper Thinkpads Still Classy
abstract: International Business Machines Corp introduces new line of Thinkpad notebooks designed for individuals seeking all-in-one portable PC that can serve as replacement for desktop computer; prices range from $1,499 to $2,499 (State of the Art column); drawing (M)

headline: Without Banned Arms, a 4th-Rate Power
abstract: Analysts say that with his latest act of brinkmanship, Pres Saddam Hussein is closer to what he wants most: keeping secret cache of biological and chemical weapons while gaining support for end to economic sanctions crippling Iraq; say threat that Hussein might someday unleash biological and chemical weaponry makes him world figure; say without them, he is just another tyrant presiding over impoverished third-world country; photo (M)

headline: ARCO LAYING OFF 900 AND CUTTING COSTS BY $500 MILLION
abstract: Atlantic Richfield Co will cut 900 jobs, or 4.5 percent of its work force, and reduce costs by $500 million (S)

headline: Snags in Searches
abstract: Don Hauptman letter on Nov 26 article on locating people via Internet warns search can put people sought in danger (S)

headline: LIBRARY/CAR SITES; It Comes Down to Price
abstract: World Wide Web offers array of car buyers' tools beyond price and feature comparisons; most popular are on line shopper referral services; photo (M)

headline: Gates Case Made In E-Mail to Staff
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates sends E-mail to his executive staff holding America Online's planned purchase of Netscape Communications Corp undercuts Government's antitrust case; holds Netscape's $4.2 billion price shows Microsoft's decision to give away Internet browser was not predatory even though it forced Netscape to follow suit; Justice Department disputes stand (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Listing of recent advertising account changes (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Behind the Odds; Computers Keep Gamblers, and the Casinos, Happy
abstract: Computer technology has made spinning reels on slot machines purely decorative; symbols that appear reflect results from computer chip that serves as random number generator; computer allows far greater range of possible combinations and thus outcomes than traditional slot machines could manage (M)

headline: Not Just Leaving the Light On; Motel 6 Is Still a Cheap Sleep, but With New Strategies
abstract: Motel 6, stubbornly utilitarian chain for most of its 36 years, is aggressively selling franchises; is spending $600 million to overhaul all 85,000 rooms at its 781 existing motels; is considering entering extended-stay market, fast-growing niche that offers low-priced rooms with separate sleeping, working and cooking areas for guests who need rooms for week to several months; chief executive, Georges Le Mener, comments on changes; Motel 6 is owned by Accor SA of France; graph; photo (M)

headline: Singapore Carrier May Buy Taiwan Stake
abstract: Singapore Airlines Ltd might buy as much as 25 percent of China Airlines, the Taiwanese national airline, in move that would make it Taiwan carrier's largest foreign investor; 25 percent stake would cost about $318 million (S)

headline: U.S. Help for Mexican Military Has Not Curtailed Drug Traffic
abstract: Ambitious United States effort to help train and equip Mexico's armed forces to pursue drug smugglers is in shambles, souring US-Mexican relations; US officials say tensions over failed strategy, faltering US-supplied helicopter fleet and continuing reports of Mexican military corruption have led them to ask Mexico's commanding generals to reassess program; Mexico's military seized on drug fight as way to protect its budget; has pursued effort with secrecy and independence, raising questions about whether US is strengthening powerful and sometimes autonomous military forces at expense of civilian institutions; graph of US spending on anti-drug training; photo (M)

headline: The Cameo Appearance
abstract: Michelle Cottle column offers advice to shy worker whose company often organizes after-hours food- and drink-filled social events (M)

headline: HOECHST AND KOHLBERG KRAVIS HALT TALKS
abstract: Hoechst AG and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co end talks on Kohlberg Kravis's purchase of Hoechst's paint unit called Herberts (S)1

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BELGIUM: FOOD AID FOR RUSSIA -- The European Commission proposed a $480 million package of food aid for Russia to offset shortages that are feared this winter because of the financial crisis and the worst harvest in four decades. The European initiative followed the conclusion of an agreement between the United States and Russia on Friday.   (Agence France-Presse)

headline: GTE PLANS TO SELL 7% OF ITS LOCAL PHONE LINES
abstract: GTE Corp to sell 1.6 million, or 7 percent, of its local telephone lines as part of plan to raise $2 billion to $3 billion to invest in faster-growing businesses (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Schwab Backs Away From Some Internet Trades
abstract: Charles Schwab & Co is no longer accepting trades over Internet for first trading days of stocks expected to be particularly volatile; says it wants to protect overzealous investors from market volatility and protect itself from inordinate amount of changing and canceling of orders; other on-line trading houses say they will not follow suit (M)

headline: Spaniards Walk on Wild Side
abstract: MADRID—  Spanish shoemakers have let their imaginations run wild lately, one producing unisex black leather boots with steel-coated heels, another toying with nonidentical "twin" shoes, a third adding distinctive dark stains on imported leather from India.

headline: Esprit de Corp. Hires Toth Brand Imaging
abstract: Esprit de Corp names Toth Brand Imaging to handle its advertising account, which had been handlled in-house since 1994; billings not disclosed (S)

headline: MARRIOTT TO SELL EIGHT HOUSING UNITS TO AUREUS GROUP
abstract: Marriott International Inc will sell eight Brighton Gardens assisted-living communities to privately held Aureus Group LLC for $140 million (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Publicis SA acquires 60 percent stake in 67 Publicidad, Caracas, Venezuela; terms undisclosed (S)/

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Late Surge Propels Dow Closer to July 17 Record  Stocks rose, with a late-day surge pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to within 180 points of breaking its record high of 9,337.97 set on July 17.    The Dow finished up 103.50 points at 9,159.55. Only six weeks after sliding below 7,500, the Dow is now up about 1,275 points for the year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 10.94 points, to 1,163.55, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 8.53 points, to 1,928.21.   [Page C3.]

headline: Iraq Said to Hide Deadly Germ Agents
abstract: UN weapons inspectors conclude Iraq could be hiding two to five times more deadly germ agents than it has admitted making, as well as warheads to deliver them; say Government's systematic refusal to cooperate in recent weeks deepened suspicions, which stem from evidence gathered since end of 1991 Gulf war; say Iraq refused to turn over key log book of purchases by its germ program, refused to open buildings for routine inspections, and only belatedly made available Iraqi experts capable of helping to resolve key discrepancies (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Gary M. Lewis; Van Kempen Emerging Growth
abstract: Article assesses investment strategies of Gary M Lewis, manager of Van Kampen Emerging Growth fund in Houston, Tex; photo; chart; graph (M)

headline: Tax Value in the Attic
abstract: Booklet by Client Valuation Services, auditors, lists tax deductions for hundreds of household items (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    ITALY: BUDGET INTACT -- Italy's new Prime Minister, Massimo D'Alema, left, presented to Parliament a stay-the-course program intended to reassure Italians concerned by the fact that he is the first former Communist to head a government. Mr. D'Alema, who had already promised to adhere to the same 1999 budget drafted by his center-left predecessor, Romano Prodi, also indicated that he would not give in to Communists' demands for a 35-hour work week.   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

headline: INTEGRATED CIRCUIT REJECTS PROPOSED BUYOUT BID
abstract: Integrated Circuit Systems Inc says it will not accept possible buyout offer from group of managers because bid of $17.50 a share is too low (S)

headline: Profits at New York Times Co. Rose 18.9% in Third Quarter
abstract: New York Times Co reports that its net income rose 18.9 percent in third quarter ended Sept 27, as cost-control measures helped compensate for slight weakness in advertising revenue; company earned slightly less than $55 million compared with $46.3 million in year-earlier period; revenue totaled $682.7 million, down from $683.6 million; advertising revenue at company's flagship newspaper rose 4.62 percent, to $235 million; John M O'Brien, acting chief financial officer since April, is named chief financial officer, replacing Diane P Baker, who resigned earlier this year; chart; photo (M)

headline: CHAMPION ENTERPRISES IN DEAL TO ADD HOMES OF MERIT
abstract: Champion Enterprises Inc., the top United States maker of manufactured homes, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Homes of Merit Inc. for an undisclosed price to expand in Florida. Homes of Merit is the largest builder of manufactured homes in Florida, with 1997 sales of about $120 million. The acquisition will add six plants to Champion's existing 60 and expand its high-end production. Champion, based in Auburn Hills, Mich., has bought or agreed to buy 15 companies, including Homes of Merit, since December and is now the third-largest United States retailer of prefabricated dwellings. Champion's shares rose rose 75 cents yesterday, to $21.3125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Better Returns Drive Investment Demand : Private Equity Deals Entice Entrepreneurs
abstract: NEW YORK—  Top of the shopping list for many prospective private banking clients is exposure to private equity deals.

headline: CLINTON SAYS IRAQ CAN AVERT ATTACK BY GIVING IN TO U.N.
abstract: Pres Clinton and Pres Saddam Hussein publicly offer contradictory analyses of current Iraqi crisis and incompatible solutions; Clinton says crisis was caused by Iraq's refusal to submit to arms inspections, and that Hussein can avert a punitive strike only by agreeing unconditionally to resumption of United Nations inspections; Hussein insists that the problem has been brought on by unjust economic sanctions, and that he would agree to inspections only if sanctions were eased; photo (M)

headline: TENET AWARDS OWENS & MINOR $2 BILLION CONTRACT
abstract: Owens & Minor Inc signs eight-year, $2 billion contract with Tenet Healthcare Corp to supply its medical and surgical products; contract, which had been held by McKesson Corp, will save Tenet about $20 million a year (S)

headline: Israel Seeks Bids for Housing Opposed by Jerusalem Arabs
abstract: Israel opens bidding for state-run housing development in predominantly Arab east side of Jerusalem that has been flash point in relations with Palestinians; Prime Min Netanyahu says flatly that Jerusalem will not be divided again, and Israel will build in any part of city 'we deem worthy of building in'; action is seen as gesture to disaffected right on day after divided Cabinet approves agreement on next Israeli withdrawal from West Bank; Palestinians charge violation of agreement, and appeal to US; bids will be for first 1,000 housing units on Har Homa; photo; map; Netanyahu says virtually all is private Jewish land within Jewish capital, and is not provocation; Sec Madeleine Albright has cool but restrained reaction; Har Homa, 2,500 feet above sea level, is rare open space in Jerusalem, with commanding vistas (M)

headline: Zen and the Art of Creating a New Purism
abstract: MILAN—  If you don't know your "New Age" from your "Next Age," relax, for the ultimate in pre-millennium escapism is coming from Milan, where a new wave of designers headed by Sancita Ajumpur, Gugliemo Capone and Emi Kurebayashi are transforming the ancient philosophy of Zen into soul-searching womenswear.

headline: Arms Teams To Conduct Spot Checks In Iraq
abstract: Richard Butler, head of UN arms commission in charge of disarming Iraq, says arms inspectors will begin week of spot inspections at sites where Iraq is suspected of hiding prohibited weapons; Iraq's Foreign Min Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf, says Govt will begin testing short-range missiles, which are permitted for defense; missile program is source of deep concern for inspectors since equipment used to make and test permitted arms can also be used in banned systems; Iraq has balked at providing information on missile parts and fuel supplies (M)

headline: Unit of Burnham Acquires 5 Malls
abstract: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc says its affiliate BPP Retail LLC has acquired five retail properties for $80.1 million in first transaction in joint venture with California Public Employees' Retirement System; two plan to develop and buy shopping centers in Western United States (S)

headline: With Prod From U.S., Mideast Talks Are Moving, Slowly
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian leaders, under prodding hand of American officials, are making some progress toward interim accord, but officials describe going as slow and mistrust as still deep; photo of Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, State Sec Madeleine K Albright and Yasir Arafat (M)

headline: Albright Visits With Wife Of Dissident In Malaysia
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright meets in Kuala Lumpur with Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, wife of jailed Malaysian political leader Anwar Ibrahim, in gesture of solidarity that angers her hosts and suggests that politics could swamp economics at meeting of Asian and Pacific Rim countries; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.63   4.63   5.08        3-month T-bills   4.46   4.40   5.21        6-month T-bills   4.49   4.43   5.24        10-yr. T-infl.   3.81   3.81   3.64        10-yr. T-note   4.79   4.70   5.74        30-yr. T-bond   5.18   5.13   5.91        Telephone bd.   6.77   6.77   7.15        Municipal bds.   5.19   5.18   5.23          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Iraq Gets Reprieve as U.S. Tries Policy of Patience
abstract: Clinton Administration, week after threatening rapid and unannounced military action if Iraq failed to cooperate fully with UN arms inspections, adopts more cautious policy; signals shift away from hair-trigger confrontation to more patient approach that will gauge Iraq's sincerity during next several weeks on basis of several factors, from handing over secret documents to allowing access to sensitive sites; officials say US will be in much stronger position to take military action, and will have broader support to do so; Defense Sec William Cohen says current spat over documents is not likely to put American bombers back in air, even though failure by Iraq to comply with UN request leaves open option of military action; senior Administration official says US and Britain are waiting to see how far Pres Saddam Hussein is prepared to go to avoid full compliance (M)

headline: Experts Hail a Giant Deal, But Motorists Are Dubious
abstract: Oil industry executives and even some consumer groups expect merger of Exxon and Mobil, nation's two biggest oil companies, to have no immediate impact on consumers; expect antitrust regulators to insist that combined company sell some operations to keep it from using increased bulk to raise prices; drivers interviewed at gas pumps express concern (M)

headline: Some Painkillers for the Start-Up
abstract: Article describes common headaches associated with installation of enterprise resource planning computer programs, which coordinate manufacturer's entire operation (M)

headline: Fred Kassner, 71, Who Made Travel Affordable for Many
abstract: Fred Kassner, co-founder of Liberty Travel, dies at age 71; photp (S)

headline: Satellite Company Faulted Over Rocket Aid to China
abstract: Secret Pentagon report concludes that Hughes Space and Communications, without proper authorization, gave China technological insights that are crucial to successful launchings of satellites and ballistic missiles; says Hughes scientists helped Chinese engineers in 1995 to improve sophisticated mathematical models necessary to predict effects of wind and other natural forces on rocket launching; says Chinese had been using 'oversimplified' mathematical analysis, resulting in failed satellite launchings; concludes that Hughes provided 'defense service' to China that violated US standards against helping Beijing make better satellites and missiles and required State Dept review; Hughes says that its actions were approved at time by Commerce Dept (M)

headline: Survey Will Track Internet Audiences
abstract: Arbitron Co, which measures traditional radio audiences in local markets, anounces plans to modify its surveys to track which listeners tune in over Internet (S)

headline: Excerpts From Gates Deposition at Antitrust Trial
abstract: Excerpts from Gate's videotape deposition (M)

headline: With a Friend Like Microsoft . . .
abstract: Intel vice president Steven McGeady testifies in antitrust trial about alleged bullying tactics by Microsoft (S)

headline: DONALDSON, LUFKIN BUYS PHOENIX HOME LIFE PROPERTIES
abstract: DLJ Real Estate Capital Partners LP, real estate fund managed by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc, buys portfolio of office and retail properties from Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Co (S)

headline: Dow Sinks 40.16 Amid Fading Hopes for a Cut in Rates
abstract: Stock prices fall broadly, reversing an early advance, as investors ponder what now seems little better than an even chance that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates again next week; Dow Jones industrial average declines 40.16, closing at 8,823.32; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks declines 7.29 points, closing at 1,120.97; Russell 2000 falls 3.39, to 393.47; graph; chart on stocks with large percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of November 1 Diary item on performance of small-capitalization stocks, which misstated Federal Reserve's October actions (S)

headline: China Jails 2 Dissidents, Reinforcing Tough Stance
abstract: Chinese officials reinforce their recent effort to silence political opposition, sentencing two New York-based dissidents who had recently sneaked back into China to work to promote democratic change to three years in labor champ; officially, the two men, Zhang Lin and Wei Quanbao, are charged with hiring prostitutes and evading border police (M)

headline: Viag to Acquire Swiss Chemical Company
abstract: Viag AG says it will acquire Algroup AG of Switzerland in stock swap worth $8.7 billion; companies say merger will allow them to achieve savings of about $334 million a year, partly by shedding about 2,500 jobs; under terms of the deal, Viag shareholders, who will control 65 percent of the new company, will receive 10 new shares for every Viag share, while Algroup shareholders will get 21.7 shares for every Algroup share; photo (M)

headline: American Topics : Amish Toil Against Child Labor Laws
abstract: Daniel Mark Smucker spends each weekday working inches away from heavy presses that punch through several layers of tough leather. He is 15. In a corner of southeastern Pennsylvania where horse-drawn carriages charm the eye, the Amish teenager, who wears black britches and a pageboy haircut, toils quite happily at his father's harness factory.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Federal Express Pilots Move Closer to a Strike  Pilots at Federal Express began refusing to fly overtime and their union mailed strike authorization ballots, increasing the odds that the world's largest air freight service could be crippled during the peak season between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of October 11 item about Federal income tax extensions which referred incorrectly to interest consequences; unpaid balances accrue interest effective with April deadline at rates adjusted quarterly (S)

headline: Rule Proposed On Buybacks
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission proposes rule that would extend legal protections to companies that repurchase their own stock immediately after marketwide trading halt (S)

headline: Fighting Fire With Technology as Computers Help Out
abstract: United States Forest Service is using new technology in fighting forest fires that can pinpoint Forest Service vehicles on computerized maps, show features of land, including topography, and even presence of endangered species; system was designed to help fight forest fires that rage every year through mountains and deserts of Southern California; maps are part of system that combines global positioning device with satellite communication; is also being adapted for other Federal agencies that control land; photos (M)

headline: Trial Reviews More Microsoft Tactics
abstract: Justice Department continues to concentrate on evidence that Microsoft Corp used its monopoly position in operating-system software to have its way in all manner of competitive challenges as Government's antitrust suit enters its third month; Government offers new charges that Microsoft cajoled or threatened companies that for most part posed no obvious threat to Microsoft or Windows; contends subjects of those efforts ranged from IBM and MCI to Walt Disney Co (M)

headline: General Motors Posts Loss of $809 Million
abstract: The General Motors Corporation lost $809 million in the third quarter, mainly because of a nearly eight-week-long strike that ended on July 29 and crippled G.M.'s production in North America, the auto maker announced today.    G.M.'s loss of $1.28 a diluted share was slightly better than analysts' expectations. The company's North American operations continued to cut costs aggressively, paying less for auto parts and making factories more efficient. But today's report also showed that the company had been discounting its vehicles heavily in North America while its foreign operations were beginning to suffer from economic troubles overseas.

headline: Shifts in Symbol and Substance Muddy Quebec Vote
abstract: Reversal of symbols on campaign posters for election in Quebec is one of many reversals in election that has distracted voters, confounded experts and added layer of thick ambiguity to one of continent's most baffling political landscapes; signs that prominently feature blue and white fleur-de-lis flag, provocative symbol of Quebec separatist movement, currently belongs to anti-separatist Liberal Party and its leader Jean Charest; Charest, former leader of federal Conservative Party, who arrived in Quebec as great federalist hope to banish separatists, seems to have gone from hero to goat, with latest polls showing Liberals headed for stinging defeat; photos; map (M)

headline: U.S. Journalist Slain in Mexico, Autopsy Shows
abstract: Mexican forensic examiners say that American reporter Philip True, who disappeared while hiking through rugged mountains in western Mexico, was killed by being hit over the head and choked; earlier reports say he had died in accidental fall; Pres Ernesto Zedillo orders Federal and state authorities to spare no resources in investigating slaying; True, 50, was Mexico-based correspondent for San Antonio Express-News; had been a solo hiker since he was teen-ager (M)

headline: CHITTENDEN SET TO ADD VERMONT FINANCIAL
abstract: Chittenden Corp plans to acquire Vermont Financial Services Corp in $454 million stock-swap transaction (S)

headline: NU SKIN IN DEAL TO EXPAND FOOD-SUPPLEMENTS BUSINESS
abstract: Nu Skin Enterprises Inc, skin care and nutritional products company with $890.6 million in sales in 1997, to buy closely held Generation Health Holdings Inc to expand its food-supplements business; Nu Skin will pay 4.1 million in stock, valued at $45.1 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graphs plot decline of yen against dollar on December 22 and against US currency over past 10 days

headline: South Korea to End Pohang's Steel Monopoly
abstract: South Korea will end state-run Pohang Iron and Steel Co's three-decade monopoly of primary steelmaking business by allowing competition for first time (S)

headline: Kosovo Rebels Gain Ground Under NATO Threat
abstract: Kosovo rebels are seen gaining ground under NATO threat; though there is little combat, war in Kosovo has taken new turn; ethnic Albanian rebels are spreading their influence in places they had not operated in until NATO threats made Serbian govt withdraw many police and army units; expanding area they control without having to fight for it allows rebels to undercut American efforts to fashion negotiated settlement because rebels can gain territory while talks drag on; photo; map (M)

headline: Hyundai Completes Deal For Takeover of Kia
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co signs pact to take over 51 percent of bankrupt Kia Motors Corp and its Asia Motors unit for 1.18 trillion won ($940 million); will seek foreign investors to take stakes in company (S)

headline: Urging Millennial Penitence, Pope Is Offering Indulgences
abstract: Pope John Paul II anounces that in celebration of entering the third millenium of Christianity, penitents who do a charitable deed or give up cigarettes or alcohol for a day can earn in 'indulgence' to eliminate punishment on earth or in purgatory; church officials emphasize that indulgences depend on sincere repentance and are not a loophole for sinners; still, some liberal Catholics are embarrassed by a practice that seems to offer shortcut to salvation; indulgences are an ancient form of church-granted amnesty from certain forms of punishment, in this life or hereafter, for sin; medieval church sold indulgences, practice that drove Martin Luther to rebel, beginning the Reformation; they remain a source of theological debate between Protestants and Catholics (M)

headline: DEXTER RAISES OFFER FOR REMAINDER OF LIFE TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Dexter Corp increases its offer to acquire all stock of Life Technologies Inc that it does not already own to $39.25 a share from $37; move is in response to group of shareholders who control 16 percent of Life Technologies and have refused to tender their shares, saying $426.6 million offer substantially undervalues company (S)

headline: Arrest Raises New Issues On Tracking Rights Crimes
abstract: Former Chilean strongman, Gen Augusto Pinochet, remains sequestered under police guard in London following arrest for war crimes on warrant by Spanish magistrate; is awaiting potentially devastating court hearing to weigh extradition to Spain to stand trial for human rights violations committed during 17-year dictatorship, from 1973 to 1990; detention leaves Labor Govt of Prime Min Tony Blair embarrassed by diplomatic implications of arrest that has enraged Government of Chile, which Britain regards as ally, and presents European officials with uncomfortable implications for handling of human rights violators closer to home (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Economic Slump Bypasses Kazakhstan
abstract: Global economic slump has bypassed oil-rich Kazakhstan; virtually every global oil company has bought oil or natural gas fields in republic since it won independence in 1991 Soviet breakup; foreign companies have already pledged $50 billion in energy investment in area around Caspian Sea, world's largest inland sea; some experts believe level of interest in region has been premature and perhaps unjustified; much attention has been attracted by unproven off-shore Kazakhstan oilfield called Kashagan; judging by seismic studies, geologists say salt domes that make up Kashagan may hold giant oilfield surpassing anything discovered on Caspian (M)

headline: Hyundai Wins Auction to Take Over Kia Motors
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co wins auction for insolvent Kia Motors Corp; will reportedly write off $5.3 billion in Kia debt (S)

headline: Pirelli Buying Part Of Siemens Cable Unit
abstract: Pirelli SpA is buying part of Siemens Power Cables AG; price undisclosed (S)

headline: In Ireland, Blair Declares End to Centuries of Enmity
abstract: Tony Blair, first British Prime Minister ever to address Parliament of Irish Republic, declares end to centuries of British-Irish hostility and says London and Dublin must now work together to rescue stalled Northern Ireland peace effort; Blair emphasizes his own Irish roots, waxes nostalgic about childhood memories in Ireland and tries his tongue at Gaelic, bringing smiles to many of Irish lawmakers in attendance; event, latest in string of efforts by Ireland and Britain to move closer, is broadcast live by Irish national television (M)

headline: Wong Doody Wins Battle for Fit TV
abstract: Fit TV, 24-hour cable television network, names Wong Doody to handle its advertising account, which had been in-house; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: Hindu Nationalists Trounced in Backlash Over Onions
abstract: India's ruling Hindu nationalists suffer humiliating defeat in series of important state elections marking stunning resurrection of once-dominant Congress Party; voters, outraged by spiraling prices of agricultural staples--especially onions--sweep Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Party from office by landslide margins in Delhi and Rajasthan, where it was deeply entrenched; repudiation is expected to further undermine 18-party coalition Govt led by nationalists; eight-month-old Government is already plagued by squabbles that range from farcical to serious; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At CBS, news of a new chairman and a strong earnings report quickly lifts share prices.
abstract: Market Place column on rise in CBS Corp stock in light of appointment of new chairman, Mel Karmazin, and strong third-quarter report; says net losses fell to $43 million, from $162 million a year earlier; revenues jumped 23 percent, to $1.58 billion; earnings before taxes and other items was record $268 million, up 25.2 percent over last year (M)

headline: Swiss Company Will Cut Jobs and Shed 2 Units
abstract: SGS Holdings SA, to cut 3,500 jobs, 12 percent of work force, and shed insurance and health care units in response to loss of Asian government contracts; says reorganization will result in 1998 loss of about 300 million Swiss francs ($222 million); SGS shares drop sharply (S)h

headline: Neighbors Kill an H.I.V.-Positive AIDS Activist in South Africa
abstract: Gugu Dlamini, volunter working to persuade South Africans not to discriminate against HIV-infected people is beaten to death by neighbors in hometown outside Durban; she was accused of bringing shame on community by revealing that she was HIV-positive (M)

headline: Pumping Up a Palm Pilot By Adding a Real Keyboard
abstract: Latest accessory for handheld Palm Pilot is full-size keyboard that includes docking station into which Pilot can be plugged; this allows user to use Pilot as if it were actual laptop, PC or other regular-size computer; photo (S)

headline: AFFILIATED MANAGERS SEEKS CONTROL OF DAVIS HAMILTON
abstract: Affiliated Managers Group Inc to purchase majority stake in Davis Hamilton Jackson & Associates Inc; purchase price undisclosed (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Fed Thinks Globally, Acts Locally, to Tepid Wall St. Response; Stock and Bond Investors Brace for an End to Cuts
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson (Market Place) column discusses muted reaction from stock and bond traders to announcement by Federal Reserve that it cut by quarter-points Federal funds rate to 4.75 percent and discount rate to 4.5 percent; says traders have been expecting move and therefore responded with half-hearted applause; says investors believe this could be last rate cut for the year; notes Fed action was not enough to keep Dow Jones average from declining to 8,986.28, down 24.97 points, while other indexes posted slight advances; graph on Dow Jones average during course of trading day (M)

headline: SBARRO FAMILY SEEKS ALL OF RESTAURANT'S SHARES
abstract: Sbarro Inc makes new $388 million offer to buy 68.5 percent of Italian-restaurant chain it does not already own; under offer, stockholders of company would receive $27.50 for each of their 14.1 million shares outstanding (S)

headline: Why Christmas Waits Until January
abstract: Mark Hulbert article describes traditional performance of small-cap shares month by month; notes dramatic rise during January from 1926 to 1997; graph (M)

headline: Japanese Bridge Maker Expects to Post Loss
abstract: Sakurada Co discovers 10.3 billion yen ($88.8 million) in derivatives trading losses concealed by manager Ichiro Baba that will force it to report a loss and cut almost a quarter of its work force (S)

headline: Serb Pullback May Forestall NATO Attack
abstract: Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, under NATO threat to end his punishing offensive against ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo, orders most army units back to barracks; Western diplomats say move may forestall attack; Russia steps up warning against such action; sends Foreign and Defense ministers on unusual high-level mission to Belgrade; Richard C Holbrooke, US envoy who dealt with Milosevic in negotiating end to war in Bosnia, will meet with him in Belgrade on October 5 to discuss political plan for Kosovo; Milosevic, as he has done often in past, appears to have bowed to foreign demands in nick of time--while still accomplishing his aims; map (M)

headline: New Era Acquires Century
abstract: New Era of Networks Inc acquires Century Analysis Inc for $41 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Renegade Officer Favored in Venezuelan Election Today
abstract: Hugo Chavez, former military leader who led a failed coup attempt in 1992, is favored to win Venezuela's presidential election; vows to throw out country's legendary corruption in one swift and forceful toss; business leaders and international investors regard him as the red menace resurrected, but to the poor, he is the impatient savior who is already smashing the clubby machine of mutual favors at the top of Venezuelan politics; photo (M)

headline: Balancing Act: Finding the Right On-Line Service
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (User's Guide) column offers advice on selecting an Internet service provider (M)

headline: U.S. Diplomat Pleads for Political Solution to Civil War in Congo
abstract: Assistant Sec of State Susan E Rice ends weeklong trip to Africa by urging political solution to civil war in Congo, which has drawn in neighboring countries and threatens to widen into larger regional conflict (M)

headline: Albright Gives New Warning On Urgency In Mideast
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright warns Israel and Palestinians that time for negotiating final peace accord is running out while they haggle over interim accord; meets with Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, Jerusalem, and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, Jericho; two men agree to joint meeting with Albright (M)

headline: Driverless Trains Have Paris Debut
abstract: Article on new Meteor line of Paris Metro--first to be built since 1935 and first to be fully automated (M)

headline: With Conditions, Israel Cabinet Approves Accord
abstract: Israeli Cabinet, after two-week delay, conditionally ratifies land-for-security peace accord, attaching series of stipulations and threats that Palestinians interprete as overtures to conflict, not resolution; ratification is shaky victory for Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu; 8 of Cabinet's 17 ministers vote in favor, 5 ministers abstain and 4 vote against agreement; feeble majority in Cabinet underscores weakness of Netanyahu's coalition; photos

headline: Retail Sales Set Brisk Pace And Producer Prices Edge Up
abstract: Commerce Department reports retail sales rose 1 percent in October, twice the pace expected by forecasters; some economists see sales rise lessening likelihood of interest rate cut; Labor Department reports producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in Oct, after rising three-tenths a month earlier; University of Michigan survey shows consumers are more upbeat about their economic prospects so far in Nov than they were month ago (M)

headline: In a Pocketbook Poll, Optimism About '99
abstract: National survey by Yankelovich Partners for Lutheran Brotherhood finds 52 percent of adults polled see their families better off next year than in current year; also finds people are less optimistic about overall economy, noting 32 percent of those surveyed see some sort of downturn in 1999 (S)

headline: EXEL AND INTERCARGO, TWO INSURERS, IN $88 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Exel Ltd to buy Intercargo Corp for about $88 million (S)

headline: ABN Amro Is a Primary Treasuries Dealer
abstract: ABN Amro NV says its US investment banking subsidiary, ABN Amro Inc, has been named primary dealer of US Treasury securities by Federal Reserve Bank of New York (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DANA CORP., Toledo, Ohio, a maker of components for vehicular and industrial equipment, acquired Delphi Automotive Systems's automotive filter operations in Southampton, England, for an undisclosed sum.    PRO-FAC COOPERATIVE CO., Rochester, an agricultural cooperative with more than 600 members, agreed to buy Agripac Inc., Salem, Ore., a processor of frozen and canned vegetables, for an undisclosed price.    FINGERHUT COS., Minnetonka, Minn., a data base marketing company, agreed to acquire Bedford Fair Industries, Greenwich, Conn., a women's apparel retailer, for about $39 million in cash.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Keyes Martin is named as first agency to handle two accounts with combined billings estimated at $2.5 million: Nuova Linnea and Schering-Plough (S)

headline: Banks More Exposed Abroad, Fed Says
abstract: Federal Reserve survey shows overall American bank exposure to global markets rose substantially in second quarter; says loans by American banks to foreign borrowers rose strongly in second quarter to $487.5 billion, up 1.8 percent from $478.8 billion at end of first quarter; BankBoston Corp is reducing its exposure to some foreign markets; will cut 100 jobs in Asia, 10 jobs in Boston and two in London (S)

headline: MARKET INSIGHT
abstract: Interview with Hal W Reynolds, chief investment officer of Wilshire Asset Management, on 1998 stock market and forecasts for year ahead; photo (M)

headline: Game manufacturers are starting to look at a long-forgotten market: younger children.
abstract: Home video game manufacturers are looking at younger children, a long-forgotten market; some of games vying for Saturday morning cartoon set discussed; video game systems and their hand-held spinoffs generated around $5.1 billion in domestic sales for 1997, and sales are expected to reach $6.3 billion for 1998 (M)

headline: CONCORD EFS TO PURCHASE ELECTRONIC PAYMENT SERVICES
abstract: Concord EFS Inc to acquire Electronic Payment Services Inc for about $920 million in stock (S)

headline: Porsche Unit Narrows Review to 5 Agencies
abstract: Porsche Cars North America narrows review of its advertising account to five agencies from 12; Porsche and Goodby, Silverstein and Partners agreed to part ways in January (S)

headline: Ferdinand Marcos's Swiss Bank Legacy: Tighter Rules for Despots and Criminals
abstract: Case of some $500 million stashed in Swiss banks by former Philippines dictator Ferdinand Marcos prompts reforms that make it harder for corrupt rulers and criminals to stow assets in Switzerland; despots and crime barons, large and small, have deposited millions in Switzerland for decades without consequence for most; but Marcos fortune was different because of its size and embarrassment to the Swiss fromm lengthy efforts of country's Govt to retrieve it; it took 12 years for Marcos money to be returned to Philippines; case prompted Swiss bank regulators to make significant changes in banking's inner sanctums, which routinely had welcomed enormous sums with few, if any, questions asked (L)

headline: AT THE GATE: Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York; An Insurer's Transformation Is a Modest Bet
abstract: Article offers market predictions for Mutual Life Insurance Co of New York as it prepares for public trading; graph (M)

headline: As U.S. Presses Talks on Kosovo, Hope of Averting Air Strikes Rises
abstract: Continuation of negotiations by American envoy, Richard C Holbrooke, with ethnic Albanian leadership in Kosovo and Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, suggests that enough common ground is being found to avert NATO air strikes; Holbrooke meets with ethnic Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova and Milosevic (M)

headline: Bank of Taiwan Cuts Interest Rates
abstract: Bank of Taiwan cuts its prime lending rate by 2.5 basis points, to 7.375 percent from 7.4 percent (S)e

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: AGRIBIOTECH INC.,  Las Vegas, Nev., a turf and forage seed company, said it had hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to explore ways of maximizing shareholder value.    FOUR SEASONS CO.,  Toronto, said it planned to build an estimated $105 million resort in Tobago in its first investment on the Caribbean island.

headline: IMPEACHMENT VOTE IN HOUSE DELAYED AS CLINTON LAUNCHES IRAQ AIR STRIKE, CITING MILITARY NEED TO MOVE SWIFTLY
abstract: Pres Clinton orders 'strong sustained' series of air strikes against Iraq, defending action as unavoidable; incensed Congressional Republicans charge it is politically timed to stave off impeachment vote in House; Clinton insists attacks are in response to Iraq's refusal to live up to promise to allow UN to conduct on-site inspections for weapons of mass destruction; reiterates call for overthrow of Pres Saddam Hussein; says timing was based on report by chief UN weapons inspector, Richard Butler, that Hussein is again thwarting efforts of arms inspectors; says further delay would have given Iraq more time to disperse forces and protect weapons; Britain's Prime Min Tony Blair backs decision; denounces Hussein as serial liar who had no intention of keeping word; Hussein confirms attack in statement to nation; urges Iraqis to resist and fight, calling attackers cowards; more than 200 cruise missiles rain down on Iraq without any diplomacy or warning fired from naval vessels in Persian Gulf; are followed by attacks by Navy jets from aircraft carrier Enterprise; come 24 hours after Butler's report; targets are suspected weapons plants, Iraqi intelligence agencies and fortifications of elite Republican Guard, which substantially survived 1991 Persian Gulf War despite weeks of sustained bombing; Hussein's palace in Baghdad reportedly hit; attack, called Desert Fox, will reportedly continue for three to four days; House Republican leaders yield to eruption of crisis and delay start of impeachment hearings; Speaker-elect Robert L Livingston, in careful statement emphasizing support for troops involved, says action is being deferred; photos; map (L)

headline: Jump in Stock Of Ziff-Davis
abstract: Shares of Ziff-Davis Inc continue to rise sharply as investors absorb news of company's planned $115 million initial public offering of its on-line operation, Zdnet Group (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: START II DEBATE POSTPONED -- The Parliament again postponed discussion of Start II, the strategic-arms reduction treaty that the United States and Russia signed in 1993. The Duma Council of the Parliament delayed debate because only the liberal Yabloko Party had submitted proposals, the Interfax news agency reported. Yabloko leaders accused Communist legislators of stalling on the treaty, which the United States Senate ratified in 1996.   (AP)    BRITAIN: PINOCHET LAWYERS SEE BIAS -- Lawyers for Gen.  Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, questioned the impartiality of a decision on Nov. 25 by the Law Lords, England's highest court, denying the general immunity from arrest on charges of human rights violations. The lawyers complained that a judge, Lord Hoffmann, left, was a director of a fund-raising charity associated with Amnesty International, which joined the case against the general. A spokeswoman for Amnesty International said Lord Hoffmann was an unpaid director of the charity, but was not directly involved with Amnesty International.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Rebels Attack Serb Police Post in Kosovo
abstract: Rebels in Serbian province of Kosovo attack police post near Podujevo as truce continues to disintegrate; diplomats question whether international monitors trying to keep cease-fire from collapsing will be sufficient in number and will learn how to restore delicate balance of peace in time to prevent full-scale war in region; map (M)

headline: AT&T Official Is Qwest's Global Chief
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc hires Jack McMaster from AT&T Corp to head its international operations (S)

headline: BANKAMERICA IN $333 MILLION BA MERCHANT DEAL
abstract: BankAmerica Corp will acquire part of BA Merchant Services Inc it did not already own for $333 million in csh (S)

headline: Nasdaq Rises 37.48 Points as Technology Shares Surge
abstract: Nasdaq composite index climbs 37.48 points, or nearly 1.9 percent, to record 2,040.64; Dow Jones industrial average rises 54.33 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 9,070.47, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 10.96 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,187.70; price of benchmark 30-year bond rises 5/32, to 103 13/32; yield falls to 5.03 percent, from 5.04 percent on Dec 4; charts; graphs (M)

headline: PRIMARK IN PACT TO ACQUIRE A-T FINANCIAL FOR $35 MILLION
abstract: Primark Corp, information and technology concern, will acquire A-T Financial Information Inc for $35 million (S)

headline: U.S. Ex-Sergeant Linked To bin Laden Conspiracy
abstract: Federal prosecutors file secret charges against former sergeant in United States Army who is suspected of switching sides in war against terrorism and joining global campaign to attack Americans mounted by Saudi exile Osama bin Laden; charges are part of Federal authorities' efforts to prove bin Laden was behind bombings of two United States Embassies in Africa in August, and series of other attacks against United States soldiers in Somalia, Saudi Arabia and Yemen; they draw new ties between bin Laden and circle of Islamic militants in Brooklyn, who were implicated in World Trade Center Bombing and a plot to blow up United Nations and other New York landmarks; former Army sergeant, Ali A Mohamed, was charged in September in closed court hearing in Manhattan, and remains in custody at Metropolitan Corectional Center; his photo (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: No. 1 Bookstore Chain To Buy Top Wholesaler  Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookseller, announced the $600 million purchase of Ingram Book Group, a leading wholesaler, in a deal that an organization of independent booksellers denounced as ''devastating'' and an authors group compared to a wedding of Godzilla and King Kong.

headline: G.E. of Britain Wants Separate Military Unit
abstract: General Electric Co PLC, Britain's second-largest military contractor, will split aerospace and military businesses from rest of operations as it continues merger talks with other military companies (S)

headline: 2,000 Monitors to Go to Kosovo, but Their Power Is Unclear
abstract: Much remains unresolved about exact role and powers of Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which will send 2,000 unarmed civilians to Kosovo, Serbia, to verify that Yugoslav military and police forces end crackdown and let ethnic Albanians return to homes under accord worked out by United States envoy Richard C Holbrooke and Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic; organization chairman Bronislaw Geremek, Poland's Foreign Minister, is to meet with Serbian officials to clear way for monitors to arrive by end of week; American William Walker is leading candidate to head mission, which will be largely European (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Economic reports showing higher retail sales and producer prices diminish the prospects that Federal Reserve will lower interest rates; dollar advances to 122.72 against Japanese yen in New York trading; graph; currency chart (S)

headline: DOW JONES TO DISMISS 118 WORKERS TO REDUCE COSTS
abstract: Dow Jones & Co says it will cut costs by dismissing 118 employees, closing offices and using outside company to handle subscription telemarketing for The Wall Street Journal and Barron's (S)

headline: Many Arabs See Double Standard for Israel
abstract: There is widespread perception in Jordan that Israel enjoys form of international impunity, in spite of recent signing of new accord between Israeli and Palestinaian leaders, and resulting turnover of some occupied land to Palestinian control; many Jordanians oppose Saddam Hussein of Iraq, but they are angry that Western countries threaten to punish him for defying United Nations resolutions while not punishing Israel, which concedes it has not fully carried out Security Council resolutions regarding handing land back to Arabs and refraining from building settlements on such land (M)

headline: PALOMAR TO SELL HAIR-REMOVAL LASER UNIT TO COHERENT
abstract: Coherent Inc to buy Palomar Medical Technologies Inc's Star Medical Technologies unit for $65 million in cash (S)

headline: Letters fly fast and furious as the 2 associations representing agencies and advertisers square off.
abstract: *Dispute between two associations representing advertisers and agencies, which began when advertiser association unexpectedly extended membership to agencies, is growing more pronounced as some longtime agency executives express their qualms about invitation; concerns are being voiced one month after officials of Association of National Advertisers stunned leaders of American Association of Advertising Agencies by revealing that they would open their ranks of paying members to agencies; proposal was couched in terms of the benefits of agencies joining with clients to bolster efforts to build brands (Advertising column) (M)

headline: 'Prince of Egypt' Is No King at the Box-Office
abstract: The Prince of Egypt, animated film from Dreamworks SKG, does well at box office against intense competition from holiday films, but many people in Hollywood doubt if it will become a megahit, grossing over $100 million; film cost an estimated $75 million to $100 million to make, and Dreamworks is thought to have spent as much as $50 million promoting it; animation is considered key to Dreamworks' future because animated films are generally more profitable than life-action films, not requiring high-priced actors and generate sales of related products; photo (M)

headline: Virgina Panel Recommends Tough New Penalties on Spam
abstract: Commission appointed by Gov Jim Gilmore of Virginia recommends imposing criminal and civil penalties, including jail terms, for sending spam using Internet service providers based in Virginia (S)

headline: Is 90 Percent of Vote Suspicious? Charge Puzzles Kazakh Leader
abstract: Pres Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan expresses outrage at accusations that he terrorizes opponents; Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe expresses serious doubts that principles for democratic elections will be met in January 10 elections, in which Nazarbayev is expected to win gain new seven-year term by the usual 90 percent margin (M)

headline: Global Trend Seen in German Bank Deal
abstract: Wall Street is rife with speculation about whether new round of megamergers is at hand as Bankers Trust Corp board meets to vote on sale of bank to Deutsche Bank AG of Germany for about $9 billion (M)

headline: Settlement on Breast Implant Claims
abstract: Dow Corning Corp files bankruptcy reorganization plan that includes $3.2 billion to settle claims from women over its silicone breast implants and $1.3 billion in payments to commercial creditors; plan would end one of most controversial disputes in American corporate history and allow claimants to receive money as early as next year; chart on highlights of litigation (M)

headline: Carlson and Thomas Cook to Merge Leisure Travel in Britain
abstract: Carlson Companies, owner and franchiser of worldwide network of hotels, restaurants and cruise ships, plans to merge its leisure travel business in Britain with worldwide travel operations of Thomas Cook, one of oldest and best known names in travel; intended transaction is valued at more than $1 billion; it would make two companies major force in leisure travel with annual sales of about $42.5 billion; merger partners will likely retain Thomas Cook name and that of Worldchoice, brand name of Carlson's 412 company-owned travel agencies in Britain (M)

headline: Japanese Slump Aside, Profit Is Up at Honda and Mazda
abstract: Honda Motor Co and Mazda Motor Corp report impressive profit gains for first half of fiscal year; Honda says net profit in first half, ended Sept 30, jumped 25 percent, to 158.3 billion yen, or $1.28 billion, compared with 126.5 billion yen in period a year ago; Mazda posts net profit of 8.5 billion yen, or $69.1 million, compared with 9.7 billion yen loss in period a year earlier (M)

headline: American to Buy Reno Air For $124 Million in Cash
abstract: American Airlines will acquire struggling low-fare carrier, Reno Air, for $124 million in cash; acquisition, which could bolster presence of American in West, calls for cash tender offer for all of Reno's outstanding common stock at $7.75 per share, and tender offer for outstanding preferred stock at $27.50 per share; possible objections from Allied Pilots Assn, which represents American's 9,000 pilots, and from union representing Reno's pilots noted (M)

headline: Either War or Peace: A Vocabulary Guide
abstract: With the threat of American bombing attacks against Iraq put aside, diplomats and military analysts conducted a war of words.     ''Saddam Hussein has vast megalomaniacal ambitions,'' said Jonathan B. Tucker, a leading expert on biological and chemical weapons. And more than one frustrated White House official described Iraq's strategy as ''cheat and retreat.''

headline: Shares Are Mixed: Dow Is Up as Nasdaq Retreats Again
abstract: Stocks are mixed in volatile session as technology-heavy Nasdaq declines for second consecutive day; Dow Jones industrial average is up 16.74 points, to 7,742.98; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 3.97 points, to 984.59; Nasdaq composite index declines 25.80, to 1,510.89; graph; table shows some stocks with large price percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: U.S. Signs Accord to Protect Israel From Mass-Destruction Arms
abstract: Pres Clinton and Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu sign agreement to strengthen US commitment to safeguard Israel's security from threats of post-Soviet world; threats--from nuclear, chemical and biological weapons--stem mostly from regional rivals, like Iraq and Iran, which are also rapidly developing intermediate and even strategic-range missiles that can deliver such weapons to Israeli cities (M)

headline: Some Mergers Are Made in Weakness
abstract: Current wave of giant mergers in Europe reflects competitive weakness of some of Europe's mightiest empires; analysts say companies respond to their inability to raise prices and challenges to their market shares or business lines; deals spur stock price drops as investors remain skeptical (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Astronauts Get Mail; Microsoft Gets a Foothold
abstract: Recently completed mission of space shuttle Endeavour was first in which crew members could routinely send and receive E-mail, using notebook computers and 'smart modems' developed by NASA and software largely supplied by Microsoft Corp; astronauts sent 620 messages, most of them personal (M)

headline: Quebec Journal; Old Lingua Franca Crowds Outpost of a New One
abstract: Literary and Historical Society of Quebec, 174-year-old organization dedicated to preserving memories and achievements of early settlers in one of North America's oldest cities, finds itself in need of preservation; books in its library are overwhelmingly in English and are gathering dust in city where fewer than 2 percent of residents are English speakers and where such institutions are frowned on as uncomfortable reminders of colonial past and vestige of British power; photo (M)
