headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: SUIZA FOODS CORP.,  Dallas, said it had entered a joint venture with the cooperative Dairy Farmers of America, Kansas City, Mo., to form a large milk bottler in the Northeast.    FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP.,  Southfield, Mich., a maker of engine seals, agreed to buy the German rubber-seal maker Glockler Dichtsysteme Gunter Hemmrich G.m.b.H. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Mercury Asset Funds Open
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co says its Mercury Asset Management unit, London, has opened two new mutual funds, the unit's first offering to United States investors (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Expected
abstract: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Computer Literacy Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., an initial public offering of 3 million shares. NMS.  Dycom Industries Inc., Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., 3 million shares. NMS.  Ixos Software Aktiengellschaft, Munich, Germany, an initial public offering of $3 million American depositary shares, each representing one-fifth of one ordinary share, 1.5 in the U.S. and Canada. Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: Offerings That Include Both Fluff and Finance
abstract: Article evaluates www.women.com, network of six separate Web sites aimed at women; photo (S)

headline: TWO BIG DENTAL GROUPS PLANNING A COMBINATION
abstract: Gentle Dental Services Corp and Dental Care Associates Inc agree to combine; Dental Care holders will own 46.5 percent of new holding company, while Gentle Dental holders will own 53.5 percent (S)

headline: Hey, Guys, Can't We Just Get Real? Sincerely, Bill
abstract: David E Sanger column offers fictitious account of what US Pres Bill Clinton might say to Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad, Russian Prime Min Yvegeny Primakov and Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin during upcoming Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (M)

headline: Kim Dae Jung Points a Finger At the Barons
abstract: SEOUL—  In a society where the president is the ultimate authority figure, the former dissident Kim Dae Jung is attempting to bring unwilling conglomerates into line just the way his predecessors did it: by telling them what to do.

headline: Iraq Yields Slightly in Monitoring Dispute
abstract: Iraq allows small team of maintenance technicians to change film and make repairs on surveillance cameras, two days after vowing to cut off all cooperation with UN arms inspectors; photo (M)

headline: UNITED VIDEO SELLS $31 MILLION IN GEMSTAR STOCK
abstract: United Video Satellite Group Inc will sell $31 million of shares it holds in Gemstar International Group Ltd, which it sought to take over through $2 billion bid earlier this year (S)

headline: A Warning To Banks: Scrutinize Hedge Funds
abstract: Federal Reserve associate director Patrick M Parkinson warns that regulators might need to insist that banks scrutinize more closely--and lend less freely--to hedge funds to avoid such crises as near-failure in September of Long-Term Capital Management (M)

headline: With the Consent of China, Balloonists Fly On
abstract: Richard Branson, Per Lindstrand and Steve Fossett fly over China in bid to become first balloonists to circle world nonstop; China reversed its ban on their entry into its airspace after intercession of British Prime Min Tony Blair and Amb Anthony Galsworthy; delay in crossing China cost balloon day's time and fuel; map (M)

headline: Daimler-Benz Profit Fails to Meet Estimates
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG reports third-quarter profit of 1.27 billion German marks ($770 million), failing to meet estimates (S)

headline: CAR 54, WHERE ARE YOU?
abstract: Police-scanner fans who are bored with the local airwaves can now go on line to hear police reports from other cities; Broadcast.com offers live feeds of scanners from New York, Los Angeles and Dallas (S)

headline: March of the Sadly Bilked
abstract: Some two hundred people who have lost money in multimillion-dollar futures-market scam hold protest in Beijing, China (S)

headline: Army Pullback in East Timor Disputed by Leaked Reports
abstract: Opponents of Indonesia's control over disputed territory of East Timor say that documents leaked from Indonesian Ministry of Defense show that the army is not drawing down its forces in territory as Govt has reported (M)

headline: MORGAN PRODUCTS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ADAM WHOLESALERS
abstract: Morgan Products Ltd will acquire Adam Wholesalers, building-products concern (S)

headline: Beset at Home, Japanese Banks Abandon American Footholds
abstract: Giant Japanese banks that have invested heavily in US banks reportedly are selling off American operations at alarming rate (S)

headline: German Exports Fell in the 3d Quarter
abstract: Germany's annual export growth slows to 3.1 percent in third quarter from 10 percent in second quarter, with biggest losses in trade with Russia and Japan (M)

headline: Schroder Tells Clinton He Backs Action by NATO in Kosovo
abstract: German Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroder, meeting with Pres Clinton, Washington, says he would back decision by caretaker German Government to authorize NATO use of force over Kosovo, if necessary; indicates any authorization for use of German troops and planes against Serbia should await seating of newly elected Parliament; Clinton stresses importance of forthcoming NATO vote to authorize use of force (M)

headline: Slicing '98 Forecast by a Third, It Says That May Be Optimistic : IMF Turns Gloomy On Global Growth
abstract: WASHINGTON—  The International Monetary Fund offered an unusually gloomy forecast for the world economy Wednesday, warning of a sharp slowdown in growth to just 2 percent on average this year but admitting that even this may turn out to be overly optimistic.

headline: As Treasuries Keep Rallying, 30-Year's Yield Hits 4.88%
abstract: US Treasury prices surge for fourth consecutive session and push yields down to levels not seen since 1967; 30-year bond rises 1 10/32, to price of 109 26/32; yield falls to 4.88 percent from 4.97 percent on Sept 30; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Albanians in Kosovo Town Hide, Fearing Vengeance for Killings
abstract: Ethnic Albanians abandon streets of western Kosovo town of Pec, fearing vengeance for killings of six Serbian youths in cafe this week; revenge killings of Albanians for cafe shootings that have enraged and galvanized Kosovo's frightened Serbian minority could destroy not only the tenuous cease-fire in Kosova, but also the nearly stalled American efforts to negotiate peace (M)

headline: Another Way to Bet On the Bond Market
abstract: Chicago Board Brokerage LLC, operator of computerized Treasury trading system, unveils $1 million sweepstakes in which contestants will have to guess yield on newly issued 30-year US Treasury bond, Chicago Board of Trade settlement price of 10-year Treasury note futures contract and foreign-exchange selling rate of Japanese yen in dollars on November 17 (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CMGI INC.,  Andover, Mass., an Internet venture capital firm, said it had acquired a stake in Virtual Ink, Cambridge, Mass., a start-up company developing a low-cost system that allows computer users to hold meetings over the Internet. Financial terms were not disclosed.    GT INTERACTIVE SOFTWARE CORP.,  New York, a publisher of games for personal computers, is buying Onezero Media Inc., Boston, a closely held company that runs an Internet site about entertainment, for about $15 million in stock.

headline: Manila Journal; First Lady's Squawk Hints at Dictator's Nest Egg
abstract: Imelda Marcos, widow of late Phillipine dictator Ferdinand E Marcos, says she will sue to recover more than $12 billion in assets she claims belonged to husband; announcement comes after insisting for years that husband was not kleptocrat but public servant who made other people rich; tells local newspaper in startling admission that 'we practically own everything in the Philippines' and identifies some assets in question; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chevron Plans to Cut Jobs  And Capital Spending Joining the list of major oil companies that are retrenching in the face of low crude oil prices, Chevron announced cuts in capital spending and employment, primarily in North America.    The company intends to reduce costs by $500 million in 1999 and cut capital spending by 8 percent, to $5.1 billion, next year, mostly in its older exploration and production, refining and marketing and chemical businesses in North America. The cuts in its work force of 34,000 will be modest, the company said. [Page C6.]

headline: A surprising nonevent from some long and closely watched media services merger talks.
abstract: Leo Burnett Co, Chicago, and MacManus Group, New York, unexpectedly call off merger that would have created giant media services agency, ranking among the world's three largest; cite differences on organizational ideas (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Arms Inspectors Get Cool Reception in Iraq
abstract: United Nations weapons inspectors prepare to resume their work in Iraq; are greeted with fresh denunciations in official Iraqi press despite Iraq's new pledge to demonstrate full cooperation; condemnation may have been intended primarily for domestic consumption, but it also shows that Iraq is hardly ready to roll out welcome mat; photo (M)

headline: Dow Retreats 58 Points and Other Gauges Also Decline
abstract: Markets go lower as troubled world economy undermines investor sentiment; Dow Jones industrial average finishes off 58.45 points, or eight-tenths of percent, at 7,726.24, after plunging almost 233 points earlier in day; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks is off 38 points before rallying to close down 14.04 points, or 1.4 percent, at 988.56; on Tokyo Stock Exchange, Nikkei index is down 2.08 percent to its lowest close in 13 years; graph; chart (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.06   4.84   5.50        3-month T-bills   4.39   4.43   5.12        6-month T-bills   4.39   4.42   5.14        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.82   3.53        10-yr. T-note   4.77   4.82   5.85        30-yr. T-bond   5.25   5.29   6.10        Telephone bd.   6.82   6.86   7.34        Municipal bds.   5.13   5.15   5.41          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Trimble, Visiting U.S., Hopes for Lasting Peace
abstract: David Trimble, in Denver, Colo, when he hears he is a co-winner of Nobel Peace Prize, says real prize would be lasting peace for his country and prosperity to go with it; adds he thinks it is appropriate to share prize with John Hume; Trimble is member of delegation touring 11 American cities in three weeks promoting business with Northern Ireland (S)

headline: CANANDAIGUA BRANDS TO BUY MATTHEW CLARK OF BRITAIN
abstract: Canandaigua Brands Inc to acquire British beverage group Matthew Clark PLC for 215 million pounds, or $359 million (S)

headline: After Crackdown, Militant Group Threatens Arafat's Forces
abstract: Hamas, militant Islamic group, lashes back at crackdown by Palestinian Authority by warning for first time that it might turn guns on Yasir Arafat's police force; Maj Gen Ghazi Jabali, Palestinian chief of police, says his officers will respond, and issues orders to shoot suspected assailants; threat by Hamas contradicts its longstanding position of avoiding civil war; signals deepening crisis with Palestinian Authority following signing of Isralei-Palestinian peace accord; since thwarted suicide bombing against Israeli school bus in Gaza Strip on October 29, Palestinian police have rounded up estimated 300 Hamas followers and placed leader, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, under house arrest (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: 10 NUCLEAR MISSILES DEBUT -- Russia deployed 10 new Topol-M nuclear missiles in the Saratov region, 450 miles southeast of Moscow. The deployment was a major step for Russia's cash-shy military, because the Government does not have enough money to maintain all its armed forces and decided to concentrate on developing the single-warhead Topol-M, which has a range of 6,200 miles.    (AP)

headline: CISCO AND HEWLETT-PACKARD PLAN JOINT PRODUCTS
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc and Hewlett-Packard Co will jointly develop products that will combine voice and data-communications on Internet, using their existing partnership to enter lucrative new market (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GROUP MAINTENANCE AMERICA CORP.,  Houston, a provider of heating, air-conditioning, plumbing and electrical services, agreed to acquire Trinity Contractors Inc., Grand Prairie, Tex., a closely held mechanical and electrical contracting company. Terms were not disclosed.    MARTIN MARIETTA MATERIALS INC.,  Raleigh, N.C., bought a 14 percent stake in Meridian Aggregates Co., Englewood, Colo., a privately held producer of crushed stone, and may buy the rest of the company later.

headline: ENDOREX IN JOINT DELIVERY VENTURE WITH ELAN
abstract: Endorex Corp establishes joint venture with Elan Corp for research, development and commericalization of products using Elan's Medipad delivery systems for two drugs in undisclosed fields (S)

headline: C.I.A. Plan for Covert Iraq Action Was Reportedly Turned Down
abstract: Congressional and Clinton Administration officials say Congress late last month secretly rejected plan by Central Intelligence Agency for new covert action against Iraq (M)

headline: Quintiles to Buy Envoy for $1.7 Billion in Stock
abstract: Quintiles Transnational Corp will acquire Envoy Corp for $1.7 billion in stock (M)

headline: Web Access for the Blind
abstract: Bob Brummond runs one of about 150 services in United States which allows blind listeners who own specialized radio receiver to listen to newspapers and magazines being read and to hear exercise programs; if they have computer with Internet capability, screen reader and speech synthesizer, they can also listen to news off Web page Brummond set up; photo (M)

headline: Japanese Are Torn Between Efficiency and Egalitarian Values
abstract: Japanese drive to become more efficient to revive economy also poses threat to egalitarianism and other key values; Japan's commitment to equality is producing welfare state for inefficient, leading to growing misallocation of resources; spending to improve quality of life in remote areas helped boost budget deficit, spurring tax increase that plunged Japan into recession; heavy spending on remote school for one pupil is an example of glaring inefficiencies; graph of after-tax income distribution in major economies; maps; photos (M)

headline: DOLE TO TAKE CHARGE FOR LOSSES RELATED TO HURRICANE
abstract: Dole Food Co expects to take special charge of about $100 million in fourth quarter because of destruction caused to its Central American plantations by Hurricane Mitch (S)

headline: Citibank Sets New On-Line Bank System
abstract: Citibank will create new retail banking and investment service on Internet; new service, combining banking, brokerage and financial information, will be introduced in test markets nationwide next year; Citibank will replace core back-office computer systems that it built and maintained at cost of hundreds of millions of dollars; goal is to catch up with new generation of competitors like E-Trade and established competitors like Charles Schwab and Banc One's credit card unit; Citibank hopes its new service can help company achieve goal of having billion customers worldwide by 2010; Citicorp, bank's parent, which will merge with Travelers Group into new company called Citigroup, will start out with 100 million customers in United States and abroad; photo (M)

headline: Patrick Frawley Jr., 75, Ex-Owner of Schick
abstract: Patrick J Frawley Jr, high school dropout who made millions of dollars in business, gave millions to conservative causes and candidates, then made it his business and his life's work to combat alcohol and drug addiction, dies at age 75 (M)

headline: Chief Says AMP Would Look at Other Bids
abstract: Robert M Ripp, chairman and chief executive of AMP Inc, says AMP will have to consider any offers for the company that exceed $9.8 billion hostile bid by Allied Signal Inc (S)

headline: The New York Times Business Best Sellers
abstract: HARDCOVER    THIS MONTH/LAST MONTH

headline: Visa USA Considers Broad BBDO Plan
abstract: Visa USA weighs proposal from BBDO New York for a comprehensive campaign that would integrate its various marketing programs connected with Visa sponsorship of National Football League during 1999-2000 season (S)

headline: Media Talk; Vanity Fair Won't Run Story on Representative
abstract: Vanity Fair magazine drops plan to run article by Russ Baker disclosing Rep Dan Burton fathered illegitimate child; Burton disclosed story himself after learning about plan for article; Baker has taken story to Mike Wallace's producing team at television program 60 Minutes; photo (M)

headline: Safeway Replaces Chrysler
abstract: Chrysler Corp will be replaced in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by Safeway Inc, effective at close of trading on Nov 12; Chrysler completes its merger with Daimler-Benz AG on Nov 12 (S)

headline: As New Mexico Courts Spain, Both Sides Are Hoping to Profit
abstract: New Mexico sends 140-member trade and cultural delegation to Spain; delegation, among largest ever sent by US state to Spain, comes just months after arrival of new US Amb Edward L Romero, New Mexico businessman who traces his lineage back four centuries to village near Madrid (M)

headline: AIDS Is Blamed for Reversing Health Gains in Poorest Countries
abstract: Carol Bellamy, executive director of United Nations Children's Fund, says explosion of AIDS in world's poorest countries is turning back half a century of progress in making life healthier for children; says AIDS has virtually reversed gains in child survival in 23 countries, largely in sub-Saharan Africa; officials say AIDS pandemic, coupled with increasing vulnerability of millions of families to disruption and violence of civil wars, is forcing agencies dealing with children to rethink priorities and to introduce new programs (M)

headline: Government Blamed for Property Glut : Too Many Cranes Spoil View of Malaysia Future
abstract: KUALA LUMPU—  A city's vitality has often been gauged in Asia by the number of construction cranes dotting the skyline, and by that measure this city would seem to have one of the region's healthiest economies.

headline: Serbian Priest in Ancient Monastery Is a Thorn in Milosevic's Side
abstract: Interview with Rev Sava Janjic, Serbian Orthodox monk, voice of public opposition and thorn of conscience amid hate-filled speeches in Serbian Parliament and unrelenting repression by Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic against Kosovo's majority ethnic Albanians; photo (M)

headline: Markets Shrug Off Air Strikes and Looming Impeachment Vote
abstract: Financial markets around the world shrug off uncertainty posed by American military strikes on Iraq and looming impeachment vote in US House as investors view both events as potentially serious but have little doubt about outcome; stock prices rise in Asia, Europe and US, crude oil slumps nearly 11 percent in New York trading, to about $11 a barrel, dollar falls and bond prices slip lower; Dow Jones industrial average rises 85.22 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 8,875.82, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 18.04 points, or 1.55 percent, to 1,179.98; Nasdaq index climbs 34.52 points, or 1.7 percent, to 2,043.88; price of benchmark 30-year issue falls 11/32, to 103 24/32; yield rises to 5.01 percent, from 4.99 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Ms. Is Bought By a Concern Led by Steinem
abstract: MacDonald Communications Corp sells Ms magazine to Liberty Media for Women, new group founded by Gloria Steinem, magazine's original editor and co-founder; group includes Ms editor in chief Marcia Ann Gillespie (M)

headline: State Dept. Warning
abstract: US State Department orders departure of dependents and some other personnel from diplomatic posts in Tel Aviv, Jerusalem and Kuwait because of military action against Iraq (S)

headline: The Price of Silence
abstract: Summit Consulting Group Inc president Alan Weiss letter responds to Michelle Cottle's October 11 column on anti-Semitic remarks in workplace (S)

headline: Two Brokers Admit Taking Insider Data
abstract: Robert Breed, former broker at First United Equities, and Jennifer D'Antoni, former Duke & Co broker, plead guilty to taking secret stock information, major victory for New York State prosecutors in one of the biggest insider trading cases of recent years; nine people have now admitted guilt in case; both pleas were in connection to the use of confidential information supplied by Marisa Baridis, former compliance aide at Morgan Stanley and Smith Barney (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Dell Edges Out Compaq In Business Market
abstract: Market research figures show Dell Computer Corp has pulled ahead of its archrival, Compaq Computer Corp, in America's business computer market; Dell's 18.9 percent share in third quarter edged out Compaq's 18.4 percent; graph (S)

headline: Dhaka Journal; Defiant Author, Dying Mother and Wrath of Islam
abstract: Interview with Taslim Nasrin, Bangladeshi writer who returned home to tend to dying mother after fleeing in 1994 following arrest for allegedly blaspheming Islam; she has been forced into hiding by religious firebrands who have put $5,000 price on her head; onetime Government doctor is feminist and atheist, as well as poet, novelist, creator of erotic imagery and critic of organized religion; in heavily Islamic Bangladesh her ideas are disquieting to many and blasphemous to others; photo (M)

headline: Russia Moves To Aid Quest For Art Taken In Holocaust
abstract: Russia, at close of international conference on Holocaust-era assets, surprises chmn by handing over three secret documents that might help Jewish families recover art confiscated by Nazis in World War II; Valery Kulishov, director of restitution dept of Russian Culture Ministry, gives papers to chmn, US Under State Sec Stuart E Eizenstat, as symbol of Russia's new commitment to contribute to international database on looted art; documents described (M)

headline: PC Companies And Bells To Petition U.S.
abstract: Microsoft, Intel, Compaq Computer and Gateway reportedly will join with Bell local telephone companies and GTE to announce their allied effort to get FCC to relax regulations they say are impeding network modernization aimed at offering high-speed Internet access to more customers; seek agency waiver of many of rules requiring local phone giants to give would-be competitors access to all parts of their networks; also plan to ask for exemptions from rules barring Bell companies from long-distance business, so they can offer wide-ranging data services (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 2 Hospital Companies Sued On Charges of False Claims  The Government sued Columbia/HCA Healthcare and Quorum Health Group, contending that they had defrauded Federal health programs for more than 14 years through a scheme involving bogus expense claims.

headline: Stuffed Toys and Web Page Soothe Sick Boy
abstract: Article by Ann Kirschner describes how she created personal Web page for her 10-year-old son when he developed serious illness; says she made it interactive so people could communicate with him during his hospitalizations; says it helped him keep in touch with world; photos (M)

headline: Mac OS Is Better Than Ever
abstract: Peter H Lewis column holds that Apple Computer's new operating system software for Macintosh computers is an improvement over earlier versions and is easier to use, more elegant, more innovative and more reliable than Windows 98; says the big disappointment is that it was written specifically for Power PC chip, which means it cannot be installed on older Macintoshes based on the Motorola 68000 series microprocessors; drawing (M)

headline: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL TO CUT 600 JOBS OVER 18 MONTHS
abstract: Great Lakes Chemical Corp to eliminate 600 jobs, or about 12 percent of its work force, in next 18 months as part of plan to save $40 million a year (S)

headline: Swedish Packaging Deal By Rexam of Britain
abstract: Rexam PLC offers 380 million pounds in cash ($625 million) for PLM AB, Swedish-based packaging group; bid values PLM at 5.13 billion Swedish kronor; offer is supported by Industrivaerden AB, PLM's largest shareholder, which unconditionally agrees to sell its 23 percent stake in PLM to Rexam at offering price; graph (S)

headline: This Marriage Seems More Like a Merger
abstract: Robin L Kiam, founder of startup shampoo maker Sterling Solution is set to wed surgeon Jonathan E Aviv, inventor of device that prevents aspiration pneumonia in elderly; photo (M)

headline: Dollars Are Weapon of Choice in the War on Bacteria Peril
abstract: Article describes US efforts to expand cooperation between Russian and American biologists as part of effort to stem brain drain, discover more about Soviet germ warfare arsenal and learn from Russian strides in germ defenses; US will spend up to $6 million to upgrade security at Russia's germ bank that holds virus collection; has persuaded Europe and Japan to join it in financing International Science and Technology Center in Moscow, which tries to find peaceful work for former weapons scientists (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    YUGOSLAVIA: KOSOVO INQUIRY CANCELED -- On-site investigations into war crimes allegedly committed in the Serbian province of Kosovo were called off after Yugoslavia refused to issue visas to the investigative team, the United Nations war crimes tribunal said. The chief prosecutor, Louise Arbour, had planned to lead the team herself to  assert the tribunal's jurisdiction over crimes committed in the latest province wracked by ethnic conflict.   (Agence France-Presse)    AUSTRIA: VOTE TO RETURN ART -- The Austrian Parliament unanimously approved legislation allowing works of art seized by the Nazis and later incorporated into state museums to be returned to their rightful owners. Hundreds of Austrian Jews lost valuable artworks confiscated during Nazi rule of Austria between 1938 and 1945, as well as after the end of World War II when the Government imposed an export ban. Research in state archives this year showed that several Austrian museums had called hundreds of objects of doubtful origin their own for more than 50 years.   (Reuters)

headline: Compressed Data; Meditation in a Wired World: Stare at the Screen and Relax
abstract: Voice of Wellness creates sites on World Wide Web intended to help stressed-out people to stay centered; sites offer guided meditation exercise; photo (S)

headline: Microsoft Is Busy on Several Legal Fronts
abstract: Microsoft Corp, target of Federal-state antitrust suit, is also defending itself against separate suits by Caldera Inc, Sun Microsystems Inc and Bristol Technology Inc; suits all charge that company has tried to use its dominance to forestall competition; are noteworthy because of their parallels with antitrust case; table (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: New Loan Losses Found At Japan's Largest Banks  Japan's 17 biggest banks had $427 billion in problem loans as of March, a Government audit has found -- 12 percent more than they had reported. The Financial Supervisory Agency said it had found 49.5 trillion yen, or $427 billion, in problem loans, 5.4 trillion yen more than the banks had calculated.

headline: J&L SPECIALTY STEEL THINKS AGAIN ON USINOR TAKEOVER BID
abstract: J&L Speciality Steel Inc says special board committee has withdrawn its recommendation supporting $113 million proposal from Usinor SA to buy 46.5 percent of J&L it does not already own because of unspecified additional information received from Usinor (S)

headline: LIBRARY/CAR SITES; The Right Car at (Maybe) the Right Price
abstract: Growing segment of car-buying market does research on Web before shopping for car; one car buyer calculates that his time on line saved him $2,500 because he knew how much car cost dealer, how much markup was reasonable and which options were worth the price; photo (S)

headline: Pronouncing 'Porshe' Correctly
abstract: Chrysler president Thomas T Stallkamp, as result of upcoming Chrysler merger with Daimler-Benz, begins learning German (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Lackluster response to European rate cuts may signal price pressures for domestic stocks.
abstract: Market Place column on lackluster market response to European interest rate cuts (S)

headline: What Has Celtics' Shares Jumping Through Hoops?
abstract: Partnership shares in Boston Celtics jump 25.4 percent in two weeks, raising hopes that labor dispute may soon be solved and season may soon begin; logo (S)

headline: 2 Bates Offices Get New Accounts
abstract: Two offices of Bates USA are awarded accounts with combined billings estimated at $13 million to $18 million (S)

headline: Translating a British Paper for the U.S.
abstract: Pearson PLC continues year-old drive to boost United States circulation of British paper Financial Times to 100,000; seeks to market it as premium product and offer advertisers worldwide lure of American readership with taste and income for finer things; Robert Thomson, US managing editor, and editor Richard Lambert comment; photos (M)

headline: This Exam Is Sponsored By the XYZ Corporation
abstract: University of Wisconsin study concludes that commercial messages delivered in school settings rose 154 percent between 1990 and 1997; finds fastest-growing segment is exclusive agreements between schools and businesses (S)

headline: Drive, She Said, but Watch That Bumper
abstract: Collisions, even at extremely low speeds, can result in costly damage to automobile bumpers; new product from Exeter Technologies, called Park Zone, prevents bumpers from hitting wall or objects in garage; chart of bumper repair prices; photo (M)

headline: Canadian Steelmaker To Sell British Unit
abstract: Canadian steel producer and scrap processor Co-Steel Inc agrees to sell its British steelmaking operation, Co-Steel Sheerness PLC, to ASW Holdings PLC of Britain for about $104 million (Canadian), or $67 million (US) (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: B. F. GOODRICH CO., Richfield, Ohio, the aerospace industry supplier, said its performance materials unit planned a $5 million capacity expansion at its plant in Antwerp, Belgium.    MAIL-WELL INC., Englewood, Colo., the envelope maker, acquired Perfection Forms, a division of Continuous Forms and Checks Inc., and the Apico Corp., for undisclosed terms. Both companies are business stationery printers in Girard, Kan.    CRESCENT OPERATING INC., Fort Worth, a real estate management company, said Gotham Partners L.P. and its affiliates had cut their stake in the company to 3.88 percent from 9.81 percent.

headline: Troubled Bank Is Nationalized By Japanese
abstract: Japanese Government takes over Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, one of nation's biggest financial institutions, in first nationalization of a Japanese bank since World War II; takeover represents start of $509 billion plan aimed at stabilizing battered banks and reviving the economy; photo of Tsuneo Suzuki, president of Long-Term Credit (M)

headline: John Didcott, South African Lawyer and Judge, Dies at 67
abstract: John Didcott, South African judge known for his firm support of human rights during 23 years on bench in and after apartheid era, dies at age 67 (S)

headline: J. P. Morgan's New Cut Is 4.5% of Staff
abstract: J P Morgan & Co will cut its work force by 740 people, or 4.5 percent of work force, through either layoffs or job eliminations, by end of year (M)

headline: DAIMLERCHRYSLER TO IDLE 348 AT MISSOURI PLANT
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG to idle 348 workers at its minivan plant, Fenton, Mo, in expectation of seasonal slowdown in minivan sales; does not say how long Missouri workers will be laid off (S)

headline: Hitachi Data to Cut Staff
abstract: Hitachi Data Systems, owned by Electronic Data Systems Corp and Hitachi Ltd of Japan, says it will cut its work force by 400 employees (S)

headline: New Home on the (Texas) Range
abstract: Alice Walton, daughter of late Sam Walton and second-richest woman in America, acquires 3,200 acres near Mineral Wells, Texas, that include main house, four others, pool and outbuildings; Arkansas business leaders comment on her decision to leave state; photo (M)

headline: Nairobi Journal; Is Lewinsky's Boswell a Flatterer? Ask These Folks
abstract: Many Kenyans find book on Pres Daniel arap Moi by Andrew Morton, newly hired to write book with Monica S Lewinsky, too flattering; Morton embraces view of Moi as friend to West who has kept Kenya largely peaceful; critics hold Moi has ruled by opposing multiparty democracy, encouraging ethnic deviseness and letting corruption erode economy; photos (M)

headline: Whose Numbers to Use On Credit Card Debt?
abstract: American Bankruptcy Institute study finds only 3 percent of those filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy can repay even small part of their credit card debts; study is sure to affect debate when Congress again takes up bankruptcy legislation next year (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Long-Term Capital didn't get a bailout and didn't warrant one.
abstract: Economic Scene column on collapse of Long-Term Capital Management says Federal Reserve did not orchestrate a bailout, created no moral hazard and set no bad precedent; holds there was no bailout because Federal Reserve turned over no taxpayer money to the fund; says Long-Term Capital is not a bank, nor does its collapse appear to threaten solvency of banks, and does not deserve a bailout; drawing (M)

headline: CHEVRON BUYING RUTHERFORD-MORAN FOR $91 MILLION
abstract: Chevron Corp will buy Rutherford-Moran Oil Corp for $91 million in stock and $302 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: Hoke Simpson, 83, Former Dean At Columbia's Business School
abstract: Hoke Simpson, former dean at Columbia University Graduate School of Business, dies at age 83 (M)9

headline: South Africa Braces Itself For Report by Truth Panel
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, in report wrapping up two years of hearings into human-rights abuses during apartheid era, is expected to lay overwhelming blame on Government, but will also implicate African National Congress; some 200 people--including former Pres F W de Klerk and P W Botha, several current ANC cabinet members and Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, leader of Inkatha Freedom Party--have been notified that report will contain negative findings specifically about them; de Klerk says he will move to block report because of unfounded allegations; photo of commission chairman, Abp Desmond Tutu (M)

headline: Joint Venture Set in Drugs
abstract: The biotechnology company Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc. and a unit of Zeneca Group P.L.C. of Britain have joined forces to develop and market cancer drugs. Under the three-year agreement announced yesterday, Zeneca Pharmaceuticals, a maker of prescription drugs, and Isis, based in Carlsbad, Calif., will research and develop drugs based on the so-called anti-sense therapy developed by Isis. The therapy uses synthetically designed DNA chains that block the production of proteins causing disease. Isis values the collaboration at more than $40 million. Zeneca will develop any potential drugs and will have exclusive worldwide rights to market drugs from the venture.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Unocal Quits Afghanistan Pipeline Project
abstract: Unocal Corp withdraws from consortium that plans $8 billion pipeline to transport oil and natural gas from Turkmenistan across war-torn Afghanistan to Pakistan; has closed offices in three of four Caspian region republics in which it operated, becoming first large foreign oil company to retreat from area; cites low oil prices as key factor; political factors include concerns about Taliban, Islamic fundamentalist movement that now rules Afghanistan (M)

headline: Survivor of Kosovo Massacre Describes the Killing Garden
abstract: 42-year-old man who says he is lone survivor of a massacre in which 13 ethnic Albanians were summarily shot and killed in Golubovac village in Kosovo recalls how he was herded into a garden with other men and told to lie flat on ground; recounts how police demanded to know who were members of Kosovo Liberation Army, and then started shooting; survivor, father of eight children, is advised by Western diplomats and by researcher for Human Rights Watch not to give his name for fear of jeopardizing his safety; photo; map (M)

headline: DELUXE TO SELL TWO PRINTING UNITS AND CUT 3,900 JOBS
abstract: Deluxe Corp to sell its Social Expressions greeting card business and Paper Direct specialty printing unit to Taylor Corp for cash; also says it plans to cut 3,900 jobs to reduce costs; terms of sale are undisclosed (S)

headline: Ivory Tower Retirement Power
abstract: TIAA-CREF, private pension fund for teachers, urges schools to put new hires into retirement plans from Day One, even though its own employees have to wait for five years before they qualify for benefits; John H Biggs, fund's chief executive, says college professors at many institutions have to switch jobs to reach tenure, while many TIAA-CREF employees are clerical workers or people right of high school or college who have not settled on a career (M)

headline: GLOBAL TELESYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY NETSOURCE EUROPE
abstract: Global Telesystems Group Inc agrees to buy Netsource Europe for as much as $155 million in cash and stock (S)0

headline: Investor, Can You Spare a Dime? Fund Managers Take Pay Cuts
abstract: Buck Consultants Inc reports average 10 percent decline in stock portfolio managers' salaries (S)

headline: Opportunities Remain
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Assn of America reports 60 percent jump in mortgage refinancing while morgage rates jump up and down (S)

headline: GOODRICH WINS CONTRACT FOR BOEING REPLACEMENT PARTS
abstract: B F Goodrich Co says its Aerospace Aerostructures unit won contract worth potential $400 million to supply Boeing Co with replacement parts for planes no longer being made; will invest $30 million to build parts plant in Arkadelphia, Ark (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 11 European Countries Prepare for One Currency  After decades of dreams, diplomacy and delays, the single European currency, the euro, is close to becoming a reality. Tomorrow, 11 European countries are to lock their exchange rates to the euro, now worth about $1.17, and cede to the new European Central Bank the power to set interest rates and monetary policy. The currency will officially be introduced on Friday.

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Revenge of the Insured
abstract: Rhonda D Orin article offers advice on fighting back at health insurers; discusses importance of keeping precise records, following up on claims and questioning every rejected claim (M)

headline: F.D.A. to Let Biostar Market Flu Test Kit
abstract: Biota Holdings Ltd says its collaborator, Biostar Inc, has won Food and Drug Administration clearance to begin marketing first rapid diagnostic test kit for flu; test can be performed in doctors' offices in under 15 minutes (S)

headline: New President May Herald New Strategy For Hitachi
abstract: Etsuhiko Shoyama, executive vice president, to succeed Tustomu Kanai as president of Hitachi Ltd on April 1; unlike many previous presidents of Hitachi, Shoyama has worked extensively in audiovisual products in company's information and media business; his appointment is seen as possible desire by Hitachi to hasten its decision-making process; Shoyama photo (M)

headline: Mouse Manipulations
abstract: Dan Vanderkam letter, responding to Oct 1 article, notes different computer operating systems require different mouse movements.

headline: The Gospel, With Sugar on Top
abstract: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen (Callings) column profiles Mark Bontempo, entrepreneur who puts spiritual messages most anywhere--from baby bibs to candy he calls Testamints; notes candy has become such big seller in Christian bookstores that revenues are expected to reach $3 million this year; photo of Bontempo (M)

headline: Russian Oil: So Much, Yet So Little
abstract: Article on languishing Russian oil industry; experts believe that if major oil companies do not invest, Russia will not be able to maintain its infrastructure even at current poor level; graphs (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEF
abstract: LENOX INC., Lawrenceville, N.J., a subsidiary of Brown-Forman Corp., will discontinue operations in early 1999 at its Kirk Stieff plant in Baltimore, affecting about 75 employees.

headline: What Price 'E.R.' Syndication?
abstract: TNT, Time Warner division, is having trouble maximizing its $1 million-an-episode investment in reruns of television series ER because of opposition from another Times Warner unit, Warner Brothers television studio; Warner Brothers backs NBC claim to exclusive prime-time rights to series, forcing TNT to broadcast reruns at 7 PM; photo (M)

headline: Lessons In Fielding Harassment Accusations
abstract: Article on sexual harassment case brought against New York Mets' general manager Steve Phillips, which is being watched closely by corporate America; photo (M)

headline: KLA-TENCOR DISMISSES 200 WORKERS AND EXPECTS A LOSS
abstract: KLA-Tencor Corp dismisses about 200 workers, or 5 percent of its work force; says it expects net loss for quarter because of restructuring costs (S)

headline: RADCLIFFE, MITCHELL WITHDRAWS RESOURCE AMERICA BID
abstract: Radcliffe, Mitchell & Weiss is withdrawing its offer to buy Resource America Inc for more than $300 million (S)1

headline: S.E.C. Files Charges On Year 2000 Data
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission charges 37 brokerage firms with failing to report on their computer systems' preparations for year 2000, as required by SEC rules; NASD Regulation Inc announces that it has brought actions against 59 member firms for late filing of year 2000 information; of the firms, 37 entered into settlements, agreeing to censures and fines ranging from $2,300 to $3,200 (S)

headline: Arafat Gets a Scripted Welcome Back Home in Gaza
abstract: Yasir Arafat, cheered by schoolchildren but ignored by most adults, returns to Gaza from peace talks in United States to promote his accord with Israel to wary public; orchestrated greeting lacks euphoric spontaneity of mass celebrations of previous Israeli-Palestian accords; photo (M)

headline: Odiorne Wilde Wins Salon's Account
abstract: Salon, on-line magazine operated by Salon Internet Inc, names Odiorne Wilde Narraway & Partners as first agency to handle its ad account; billings estimated at $1 million to $2 million (S)

headline: JOB CUTS AT SUN HEALTHCARE WILL TOTAL MORE THAN 1,600
abstract: Sun Healthcare Group Inc will cut 500 jobs in third quarter and plans to cut 1,100 more by end of year (S)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.37   5.06   5.54        3-month T-bills   4.30   4.24   5.00        6-month T-bills   4.29   4.23   5.03        10-yr. headline: John Paul's Words: '2 Modes of Knowledge Lead to Truth in All Its Fullness'
abstract: Excerpts from Pope John Paul II's encyclical Fides et Ratio; photos (M)

headline: Insurers Get 2d Bid On U.S. Contract
abstract: Humana Inc and Foundation Health Systems Inc say they will get second chance to bid on $2 billion Defense Department contract that they lost to Anthem Insurance Companies Inc last year; Humana says department has agreed to reopen bidding to provide health care services for more than one million people after company protested that parts of original bidding process had been unfair (S)

headline: European Shipbuilder Ousts Chief Executive
abstract: Kvaerner ASA, Europe's largest shipbuilder, ousts its chief executive Erik Toenseth and says it will speed up sale of noncore businesses to reduce debt; chairman Christian Bjelland will act as interim chief executive (S)

headline: Challenge for Jewish President/ Weighty Matters of Conscience : A Swiss 'Facilitator' Searches for the Middle
abstract: BERN—  Ruth Dreifuss says it almost before her visitors are settled into their chairs: She will not be an alibi, a public relations prop depicting Switzerland as reconciled with its past, or a marker to paint its history with the harsh, dark lines of caricature.

headline: TRION SAYS PROPOSED TAKEOVER BY MCLEOD RUSSEL IS OFF
abstract: McLeod Russel Holdings PLC's proposed $55 million takeover of Trion Inc has been terminated by mutual agreement (S)

headline: UNION PACIFIC SELLS SKYWAY FREIGHT UNIT TO GENSTAR
abstract: Union Pacific Corp sells its Skyway Freight Systems unit to Genstar Capital LLC for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Computer-Trading Limits Are Loosened
abstract: New York Stock Exchange loosens rule that forces traders who use computer programs out of market whenever Dow Jones industrial average rises or falls 50 points, widening the collar to 150 points (S)

headline: Industry Plan Is Aimed at Selling Music Over the Internet
abstract: Leaders of Recording Industry Association of America and chief executives of five major recording companies say they will work with major technology companies to develop Secure Digital Music Initiative, standard for delivery of music over the Internet; standard would let copyright owners control distribution of their music while making it easily available for sale; Microsoft, Sony Corp, AT&T, IBM, Toshiba and America Online are supporting initiative; photo (M)

headline: Rude and Crude, but Erudite
abstract: J D Biersdorfer reviews Jellyvision and Berkeley Systems' computer trivia quiz game Head Rush; photo (M)

headline: A Coca-Trade Jungle Town Trapped by Colombia's Strife
abstract: Bloody struggle over future of Colombia, raging between shadowy groups of men and women with masks and false names, is closing in on Calamar, main transit point in coca trade; many residents have not left the town in a year; only road out is controlled by paramilitaries, who have established checkpoint a few miles from nearest military base and charge coca growers and food suppliers simply to get their products in and out of town; residents fear dying for simply coming from Calamar, which paramilitaries label a rebel support base; map; photo (M)

headline: Voice Recognition and Other Advances
abstract: Asia Remains Strong Market for Technology, Despite the Downturn

headline: REPTRON AND ALL AMERICAN TERMINATE $40 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Reptron Electronics Inc and All American Semiconductor Inc have terminated negotiations to merge two companies' distribution businesses (S)

headline: Consolidations Give Jitters to Station Operators
abstract: Gasoline dealers across nation with Mobil franchises are concerned about surviving Exxon Corp's plan to acquire Mobil Corp; cite negative impact on dealers of earlier industry consolidation; dealers are developing ever-larger convenience stores in response to shrinking gasoline profits; photo (M)

headline: Taliban Aide Casts Doubt on Giving Up bin Laden
abstract: Amb Abdelhakim Mujahid, senior Taliban official, says Afghanistan will not extradite Osama bin Laden, accused by United States of planning bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, interview at United Nations; says Muslim religious authorities will weigh response should US provide credible proof of his involvement; says bin Laden is barred from activities against other nations (M)

headline: In Jerusalem, Clinton Visits A Fellow Embattled Leader
abstract: Pres Clinton, forced to confront issue of impeachment, reluctantly interrupts efforts to rescue Middle East peace plan during visit to Jerusalem by addressing vote in Congress he says he cannot control; tells news conference his deposition in Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct case was 'difficult and ambiguous and unhelpful,' but expresses none of recent remorse about affair with former intern, Monica S Lewinsky; says coming Congressional vote on impeachment is out of his hands; reportedly makes calls to two Democratic members of House Judiciary Committee to assess situation; makes most forthright appeal to members of House to consider censure as alternative; says approximately three-quarters of American people believe it is right thing to do; dismisses calls by Republican moderates who might support censure for admission that he lied under oath; both he and Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu seem far apart and peace initiative is in doubt as each try to grapple with complex interplay of domestic and foreign concerns; Clinton receives pugnacious reception from Netanyahu, who repeatedly reminds him at state dinner of Israel's fears and determination; lectures Clinton on Jews' lonely and turbulent history in presence of Israeli leaders whose support his Govt needs; reminds Clinton of ancient Jewish ties to Gaza and Bethlehem, Palestinian-controlled areas that Clinton will visit in next two days; Clinton repeatedly affirms American commitment to Israeli security, but also promotes Wye agreement, which calls for Israel to withdraw in phases from additional 13 percent of West Bank in exchange for Palestinian steps against terrorism; joins Pres Ezer Weizman in lighting first candle of Hanukkah; places oval stone, reportedly taken from Wye River, on tombstone of late Prime Min Yitzhak Rabin; photo (M)

headline: Dow Retreats for First Time in Nine Trading Days
abstract: Stock market ends lower for first time in nine trading days, weakened by investors who sell to secure some profits from 1998 rally that accelerated at year end; Dow Jones industrial average falls 46.34 points, to 9,274.64; graph (M)

headline: Novell Awarded Damages
abstract: Novell Inc, world's largest maker of computer networking software, is awarded $25.9 million in damages from Network Trade Center Inc, now defunct, which used Novell's trademarked software without company's authorization (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Government Attacks Gates As Microsoft Trial Opens  The antitrust trial against Microsoft opened in Federal court in Washington with a pointed personal attack on the credibility and integrity of William H. Gates, the company's chairman.    Mr. Gates said in a taped deposition, part of which was shown in court, that he knew little if anything about the main charges leveled against his company. But in its opening statement, the Government sought to portray Mr. Gates as a key director of a campaign to crush his company's main rival, Netscape Communications. Microsoft will give its opening statement today. [Page A1.]

headline: BRAZIL INTRODUCES $80 BILLION PLAN FOR ECONOMIC ILLS
abstract: Brazil plans three-year, $80 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases to restore nation's credibility in world markets and prepare way for International Monetary Fund-led rescue program; plan calls for $23.5 billion in savings in 1999, with about $11 billion coming from tax rises and $7 billion from spending cuts; sets up controversial mechanisms to force states and cities to limit spending; United States Sec Robert E Rubin urges Brazil to implement plan promptly, stand Pres Clinton reinforces in talk with Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso; party leaders of Cardoso's governing coalition pledge to maintain savings targets Government will promise to IMF, but do not rule out tinkering with some controversial elements; investors react warily; photo (M)

headline: GLOBAL MOTORSPORT AGREES TO TAKEOVER BY STONINGTON
abstract: Global Motorsport Group to be acquired by Stonington Partners Inc for $101.4 million (S)

headline: 2 Big On-Line Music Stores Said to Be Discussing Merger
abstract: N2K of New York and CD Now of Jenkintown, Pa, two biggest online music stores, are preparing to merge, in first big combination of Internet retailers (S)

headline: Philip Visits Ireland and There's Talk of the Queen Going, Too
abstract: British Prince Philip visits Northern Ireland and Irish Republic in gesture aimed at spurring Northern Ireland peace effort; says he hopes for end to 'artificial divisions' separating Irish people; meets with Irish Pres Mary McAleese and Prime Min Bertie Ahern; visit is widely viewed as precursor to visit by Queen Elizabeth II (M)

headline: Clinton Asks the Views of Top Aides on the Freeing of Pollard
abstract: White House asks Government's top law enforcement and intelligence officials and key Cabinet members to recommend by early Jan whether Pres Clinton should grant clemency to Jonathan Pollard, former Navy analyst convicted of spying for Israel (M)

headline: RUTHERFORD-MORAN SAYS ITS CREDIT IS NEARLY EXHAUSTED
abstract: Rutherford-Moran Oil Corp expects to exhaust its cash and bank credit by January and is in talks with potential buyer; says without acceptable merger agreement, it might not be able to obtain financing for its oil and natural-gas exploration project in Gulf of Thailand (S)

headline: Pay-TV Dispute Flares in Spain
abstract: Canal Plus SA and Telefonica SA are unable to reach agreement to end Spain's digital television dispute; two companies could not agree on valuations for companies but they hope to continue talks aimed at creating single digital television platform in Spain (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen declines following report showing rebound in United States consumer confidence; trades at 121.18 to dollar in New York; graph (S)

headline: Browser Memos Pose Challenge To Microsoft
abstract: Internal Microsoft Corp documents released by Justice Department show Microsoft Corp was so worried about Netscape Communications Corp's lead in Internet software last year that its senior executives wanted to delay upgrade of Windows operating system to gain edge in browser battle; documents seem to cast doubt on Microsoft's defense arguments (M)

headline: OAK TECHNOLOGY CHIEF MAKES $180 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Oak Technology Inc says it received an offer to be purchased at $4.50 a share in cash from its chief executive and chairman, David D Tsang; deal is valued at $180 million (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Pat Baskin, vice president and public relations director at the public relations division of W. B. Doner & Co., Southfield, Mich., was promoted to the new position of senior vice president for corporate communications as part of a revamping that creates a communications division. Also, David Kiley was named to the new position of senior vice president for marketing communications; he had been a senior editor and columnist at the Adweek Magazines unit of VNU N.V., New York.

headline: On the I.R.S. Calendar, It's April in October
abstract: Little-known rule allows taxpayers to receive additional two-month extension for filing income tax returns, until October 15, as long as 90 percent of tax liability is already paid (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark rises agains dollar on expectations that European interest rates will not be cut in early 1999; graphs; table (S)

headline: Japan Swoons in the Spotlight; Hong Kong Winces in the Wings
abstract: Japanese industrial production contracts 1.2 percent in October, retail sales drop 5.5 percent and high rate of joblessness continues; Hong Kong's gross domestic product drops 7 percent between third-quarter 1997 and third-quarter 1998 (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    POLAND: OPENING SECRET FILES Polish legislators, overriding the veto of President Alexander Kwasniewski, pushed through a bill opening access to the files of the Communist-era secret police. The bill will allow Poles who felt they were the victims of Communist repression to see personal files compiled by the authorities before 1989 and determine if they were discriminated against and possibly who informed against them.   (Reuters)    GERMANY: A BREAK FOR DESERTERS Germany gave World War II deserters and their families another year to apply for a onetime payment of $4,500. Parliament offered compensation in May 1997 to men convicted by the Nazis of fleeing Hitler's army, after years of debate about whether they were heroes or traitors. Since then, 2,124 people have applied.   (AP)

headline: When Business Gets Religion
abstract: New monthly column (Culture of Money) by Daniel Akst focuses on how corporations are showing new concern for religion at same time that megachurches are turning to marketing consultants to enlist new members; drawing (M)

headline: Will Plan Fix Japan Banks? The Devil Is In the Details
abstract: Interview with Japan Fund portfolio manager Elizabeth J Allan, who comments on role Asia and Japan played in Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's decision to cut interest rates (M)

headline: Book Reissued in Indonesia
abstract: Book by prominent Indonesian writer Pramoedya Ananta Toer on racism and discrimination against Chinese minority is reissued, nearly 40 years after book landed author in prison for year in 1960; author hails move as starting point for improving racial relations that have deteriorated since May (S)

headline: Toyota's Other Businesses; As Company Branches Out, Investors Spin Their Tires
abstract: Plans by Toyota Motor Corp to branch out into array of new businesses raise questions among investors about company's strategy and motives; company has spent $450 million in process, or almost 10 percent of its estimated operating profits, thus far in current fiscal year which ends in March 1999; even though it has given only broadest description of plans for latest investments, conventional wisdom is that it hopes to create financial services empire, similar to General Motors Acceptance Corp, that extends well past financing car purchases; some of its outside holdings noted; photos; map (M)

headline: A Quiet Night for the Trump Clan
abstract: Manhattan real estate mogul Donald Trump says he plans to spend a quiet New Year 1999 with his family; photo (S)

headline: Virtual Meeting Held For 4,000 Who Stayed Home
abstract: *Contact Consortium holds what may be largest-ever virtual conference, called Avatars '98; convention was designed as meeting place for individuals and companies interested in virtual worlds and avators that populate them; 4,000 people attended 24-hour event (S)

headline: Week for Wishful Thinkers
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column assesses past week's performance of Dow Jones Industrial Average and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; focuses on impact on equities (M)

headline: LIVENT RESUMES TRADING AFTER NEARLY 4 MONTHS
abstract: Almost four months after the stock was halted because of accounting irregularities, Livent Inc.'s shares opened far lower when they resumed trading yesterday. In the United States shares traded briefly before being halted again. Shares on the Toronto exchange closed at 50 cents (Canadian), or 32 cents (United States), down from $10.15 (Canadian) when trading was halted on Aug. 7. Two days ago, the Toronto-based producer of ''Ragtime'' and other Broadway shows filed for bankruptcy and restated more than two years of financial results, wiping out $85.1 million of earnings.

headline: Hedge Fund Uses Its Line of Credit
abstract: Long-Term Capital Management LP borrows $500 million from line of credit provided by Chase Manhattan Corp and other banks (S)

headline: Tests Show High Mercury At Cambodia Dump Site
abstract: Initial tests of tons of waste dumped outside Sihanoukville, Cambodia, by Formosa Plastics Corp of Taiwan indicate that mercury level is thousands of times higher than safety standards permit (S)

headline: Buying a Lemon
abstract: Thomas Cooper letter, responding to Oct 1 article, notes problems he experienced with his new computer

headline: A Jew, Then an Arab, Killed in the West Bank
abstract: 28-year-old Jewish security guard is shot to death by two Palestinian gunmen in Hebron; 69-year-old Palestinian in slain in apparent act of revenge in Nablus; killings, linked to signing of Israeli-Palestinian peace accord in Washington, are seen by many as manifestation of inevitable spasm of violence that will dog peace effort, and to others as evidence that there is no genuine good will; maps; photo (M)

headline: MYERS INDUSTRIES AGREES TO BUY UNIT OF SOMMER ALLIBERT
abstract: Myers Industries agrees to buy unit of Sommer Allibert SA of France for about $130 million in cash (S)

headline: Listeners Take On Role Of the Deejay
abstract: Rachel Lehmann-Haupt evaluates Imagine Radio's Internet site (www.imagineradio.com); photo (S)

headline: Japanese Trade Surplus Shrank in October
abstract: Japan's current account surplus--broadest measure of trade in goods and services--fell 12.9 percent in October, to seasonally adjusted 1.4618 trillion yen ($12.5 billion) (S)

headline: Barnes & Noble Rattles Industry By Buying Top Book Wholesaler
abstract: Barnes & Noble, nation's largest bookseller, announces $600 million purchase of the leading wholesaler, Ingram Book Group; deal is denounced by American Booksellers Assn, which will demand a Federal antitrust investigation, and by Authors Guild; acquisition will give company access to 11 distribution centers, which will help it cut costs and reduce delivery time for its growing base of on-line customers (M)

headline: S.E.C. Proposes Rules to Speed Stock and Bond Offerings
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission proposes rules to let public companies sell their stocks and bonds more quickly and cheaply as part of comprehensive move to simplify corporate finance disclosure; central feature of package would cut paperwork and streamline way large companies disclose financial information when registering for secondary stock offerings; another proposal would let companies expand their marketing to investors during much-misunderstood time before stock sale commonly called the quiet period; commission's chairman Arthur Levitt says proposals would benefit companies and investors (M)

headline: Lord Sainsbury Is Dead at 96; Built a British Grocery Empire
abstract: Lord Sainsbury, who built grocery empire in Great Britain, dies at age 96; photo (M)

headline: In Microsoft Case, a Lot Of Not Very Much
abstract: Interview with Yale Law Prof George L Priest, who comments on second week of government's antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft Corp and impact on business; photo (M)

headline: Spanish Broadcasting Builds On Growing Radio Audience
abstract: Article profiles growth of Spanish Broadcasting System Inc, owner of dozen Spanish language music radio stations throughout US; company owner Raul Alarcon and his son, Raul Jr, comment; photo (M)

headline: Reports on Japan Economy Show Recovery Is Not Yet in Sight
abstract: Number of economic reports, including industrial production and consumer prices, indicate Japan is unlikely to begin recovery soon from its recession (S)

headline: Turks See Throwback to Partition in Europe's Focus on Kurds
abstract: Many Turks believe hope that country may again be divided along lines envisioned in 1920 Sevres Treaty may be behind new focus by European leaders on 14-year Kurdish insurgency; treaty, imposed on dying Ottoman Empire, ordained that much of country be divided among foreign powers; was scrapped with signing of new pact in Lusanne, Switzerland, in 1923 after Kemal Ataturk defeated foreign armies in series of spectacular battles; many Turks remain convinced that world is still plotting to dismember country (M)

headline: Pssst. . .We Have No Problems At This Hedge Fund. Really.
abstract: Previously tight-lipped hedge fund managers, citing fear among investors over Long-Term Capital Management fiasco, begin commenting to quell rumors (S)

headline: Angolan Rebels Still Break Diamond Embargo, Rights Group Says
abstract: Report by Global Witness, London-based human rights organization, says sale of diamonds is still underwriting war by Angolan rebels, and that UN embargo aimed at cutting off income is not working; experts estimate Unita rebels have earned $3.7 billion from diamonds since 1992 (M)

headline: U.S. Stands Firm in Calling For U.N. Inspections in Iraq
abstract: Clinton Administration sticks by its demand that Iraq allow strict United Nations inspections to resume; Samuel R Berger, national security adviser, says US stands ready to use force again to stop Iraq from developing nuclear, chemical or biological weaons; demands that economic sanctions remain in force (M)

headline: After 31 Years at Goldman, Vice Chairman Plans to Retire
abstract: Roy J Zuckerberg, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Co and longest serving partner, will retire in November; Zuckerberg is largest single shareholder in Goldman (M)

headline: 6 European Hotels Sold
abstract: Joint venture of Servico Inc and investment bank Lehman Brothers Holdings acquires six hotels in Belgium and Netherlands from City Hotels SA; purchase price is 3.04 billion Belgian francs ($87.9 million) (S)

headline: Ford Shaking Up Senior Executives
abstract: Ford Motor Co says 27 senior executives will retire or change jobs at end of year, as William Clay Ford Jr and Jacques A Nasser begin putting their stamp on company as they move toward becoming chairman and chief executive, respectively, on Jan 1; Peter J Pestillo, executive vice president and long-time ally of William Ford, is promoted to vice chairman and chief of staff (S)y

headline: Wall Street Waves Off Washington
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson (Market Watch) column says that despite the downturn in the stock market in 1974 when Pres Nixon resigned, market strategists says stocks are unlikely to plunge this time around whatever the outcome of impeachment process involving Pres Clinton; says analysts take comfort from fact that dark moods of market and economy at time of Nixon are missing now; cites Prof Richard Sylla of New York University who says better comparision might be to economy and markets during impeachment of Pres Andrew Johnson in 1868; chart on performance of market from Jan 1, 1868 to Dec 1 (M)

headline: An Encyclopedia's Roots
abstract: Letter from A Kent Hieatt comments on Dec 10 article on Encarta encyclopedia (S)

headline: A New Scandal Rocks Ireland, Provoking Turmoil in Parliament
abstract: New scandal emerges in Ireland over assertions of corruption and nepotism at highest level of Government, plunging country into national debate; debate comes after disclosure of official ruling that former Prime Min Charles J Haughey owes no taxes on $2 million gift from businessman, Ben Dunne, and that decision was made by Ronan Kelly, tax official who is brother-in-law of present Prime Min Bertie Ahern, whose political career was fostered by Haughey (M)

headline: Javier Garcia Paniagua, 61, Mexican Ruling Party Loyalist
abstract: Javier Garcia Paniagua, former senior Mexican official whose hard-line views aligned him with group within governing Institutional Revolutionary Party known as 'dinosaurs,' dies at age 61; photo (M)

headline: Kosovo's Battles Appear Headed Into the Chill of Winter
abstract: Tensions of Serbia's Kosovo province seem heading for deep freeze of winter, with thousands of uprooted ethnic Albanians still living outdoors; about 150,000 others are doubled up in homes, schools and makeshift shelters; map; photo (M)1

headline: Cartoon Characters Give Web Sites Their Master's Voice
abstract: 7th Level Inc (www.7thlevel.com) offers new software called Agent 7 that enables person to personalize a Web site with an animated character that speaks in one's own voice; cartoon images (S)

headline: Music Industry Loses a Bid To Stop Internet Recording
abstract: Judge Audrey B Collins refuses request by Recording Industry Association of America to stop Diamond Multimedia Systems from producing and shipping hand-held device that can record and play back digital music found, often illegally, on the Internet; Diamond Multimedia begins producing device, called Rio; association vows to appeal ruling (M)

headline: The Price of Silence
abstract: Katharine Weber letter responds to Michelle Cottle's October 11 column on how to treat anti-Semitic remarks in workplace (S)

headline: NEC's Elder Statesman Resigns in Scandal
abstract: Military-procurement scandal ends career of one of Japan's eminent executives, Tadahiro Sekimoto, chairman of NEC Corp; Sekimoto resigns to take responsibility for scandal that has received little attention outside Japan but has been avidly followed in business circles because of NEC involvement; Sekimoto has not been linked to scandal; Hisashi Kaneko will remain as president of NEC; total of 13 people from NEC and subsidiaries, Nico Electronics Co and Toyo Communication Equipment Co, have been arrested by Defense Agency on suspicion of overcharging Japanese military on procurement contracts; prosecutors say NEC affiliates overcharged total of nearly 1.7 billion yen, or $14.3 million; photo (M)

headline: Hindu Party Faces Test As Prices Anger Indians
abstract: Elections in New Delhi and three Indian states next week turn into referendum on Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which has led India's shaky, 18-party coalition Govt for the last eight months; campaign, for state-level offices, has been dominated by voters' anger over rising price of onions and other vegetables, issue that has put national Govt on defensive (M)

headline: Rare New Computer Virus Could Infect Web Pages
abstract: Some companies that make computer virus protection software report detecting new, though rare, viruses that can be embedded in hypertext markup language pages, documents that make up Web pages; say viruses currently are circulating only among researchers and hackers (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MEGABIOS CORP., Burlingame, Calif., agreed to acquire GeneMedicine Inc., of Woodlands, Tex., for about $38.1 million in stock, creating a biotechnology company with seven products in clinical development and partnerships with four major drug makers.    TANDY CORP., Fort Worth, a consumer electronics products retailer, said it would buy back up 5 million shares, or about 5 percent of its stock outstanding.    ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC., Costa Mesa, Calif., a pharmaceuticals and biotechnology research company, said it would buy back up to 3 million shares, or 4 percent, of its 73.8 million shares outstanding.    FAMILY CHRISTIAN STORES INC., Grand Rapids, Mich., a retailer of Christian books and Bibles, canceled its initial public offering, citing difficult market conditions.

headline: Growth in Jobs Slowed Sharply Last Month
abstract: Labor Department says employers added 116,000 workers to payrolls in October, unemployment rate held steady at 4.6 percent and hourly pay of most workers inched up slightly; hourly earnings rose by a penny, to $12.89 (M)

headline: Hedge Fund Firm Says It Covered Its Losses
abstract: Ellington Capital Management, hedge fund firm that was forced to sell many of its holdings to meet margin calls earlier this month, says losses in its three funds, while sizable, appear to be limited; by selling nearly $2 billion of its holdings over last two weeks, firm appears to have been able to meet all its margin calls (S)

headline: At Game Site, Chat Fans Find Their Voices
abstract: Comment on Mpath, digital Web site for on-line game players; photo of John Rowell or Hillbilly John, who organizes jamborees at Mplayer.com (S)

headline: 44% Rise in First Half For Suez Lyonnais
abstract: Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux SA says first-half net earnings rose 43.5 percent; profit climbed to 3.1 billion francs ($568 million) as sales increased by 9.5 percent, to 99.8 billion francs (S)

headline: Big Swiss Bank Is Shaken Up By Hedge Fund
abstract: UBS AG chairman Mathis Cabiallavetta and senior officers Felix Fischer, Werner Bonadurer and Andrew Siciliano resign--most visible casualties to date of dealings with Long-Term Capital Management LP's hedge fund; departures are designed to restore some confidence in UBS; Alex Krauer has temporarily replaced Cabiallavetta (M)

headline: Philippine Airlines To Give Up 8 Jets
abstract: Philippine Airlines Inc says it agreed to surrender eight Airbus Industrie jets to its creditors as it prepares to resume operations with smaller fleet; airline has been grounded since Sept 23 because of heavy losses and labor problems (S)

headline: A New Tack Is Taken By Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft lawyers, in new court tactic, try to show that Sun Microsystems has been guilty of same sort of anit-competitive behavior that prompted antitrust suit against Microsoft; question Sun executive James A Gosling on meetings with Netscape on possible agreement not to compete in Internet software (S)

headline: A Scramble to Save the Mideast Peace Effort
abstract: US scrambles to keep Wye Memorandum, October peace agreement between Israel and Palestinians on track; Sec of State Madeleine K Albright warns Israeli counterpart, Ariel Sharon, to adhere to timetable set in agreement and not to set new conditions; Pres Clinton attends meeting between Sharon and national security adviser Samuel R Berger in Washington, where he spent hour discussing problems (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: America Online Said to Be In Talks to Buy Netscape  America Online is on the verge of agreeing to acquire Netscape Communications, the Internet pioneer at the center of the Government's antitrust suit against Microsoft, according to executives involved in the negotiations. The deal, which may also involve Sun Microsystems, would most likely value Netscape near its market capitalization of $4 billion.    The three companies have been in talks all week and over the weekend, and a final agreement may not be reached. But people close to the negotiations say a deal could be announced as early as today. The transaction would end the independence of Netscape but clearly bolster America Online and Sun. [Page A1.]

headline: Deaths in Argentina Feed a Taste for Conspiracy
abstract: Argentines are treated to barrage of recent news coverage about suspicious deaths; deaths may simply be series of macabre concidences, but news reports have spawned vague suggestions lately that organized crime or Government of Pres Carlos Saul Menem itself is involved and blocking cause of justice; recent deaths of former presidential aide's brother and navy captain were officially attributed to suicide; list of other dead include general and another army officer who were killed in helicopter crash, two other Government and military employees who died in reported criminal assaults, and several more people who reportedly succumbed to heart attacks and brain seizures; even Pres Menem has called for reopening of probe into death of his son, thought to have been killed in helicopter accident three years ago; Menem's former wife has long expressed skepticism that crash was accident; photo (M)

headline: Republic Hires Sears Executive
abstract: Republic Industries hires Sears, Roebuck & Co senior executive vice president John H Costello as president; he succeeds Steven R Berrard, who remains co-chief executive (S)2

headline: Hampel/Stefanides Is Closing an Office
abstract: Hampel/Stevanides in New York is closing its San Francisco office after losing an NEC Computer Systems account (S)

headline: American Topics
abstract: A 77-year-old Florida man with a sleepwalking habit awoke recently to find himself up to his armpits in alligators. When James Currens, of Palm Harbor, wandered from home, he stumbled into a pond and awoke in several feet of water, his legs stuck in the mud. Several gators, some longer than 3 feet, came to visit, he said. He fended them off with his cane — sleepwalkers, take note — until neighbors heard his cries and summoned police. Mr. Currens suffered no serious injury.

headline: FUJI PHOTO MAY ENTER U.S. INSTANT-FILM MARKET
abstract: Fuji Photo Film Co is considering selling instant film and cameras in US, challenging home-market domination of troubled Polaroid Corp; Fuji is introducing new instant photo system in Europe, called Instax (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Archives Wins a Reprieve In Storing Electronic Records
abstract: National Archives and Records Administration is being given more time to figure out how to deal with voluminous E-mail and other electronic records produced daily by Federal agencies; Government has no system for storing electronic records except to print them out and file them; in process, vast majority simply get deleted; lawsuit by group including Ralph Nader's Public Citizen contends that allowing deletion of electronic records leads to loss of valuable public information; photo (S)

headline: Laundry-Room 'Education'
abstract: New General Electric washing machines will soon come equipped with Procter & Gamble detergent and fabric softener ads inside their lids (S)

headline: White House Is Said to Favor a Swift Move Against Iraq
abstract: Senior Clinton Administration officials say they lean toward using force against Iraq sooner rather than later; make contingency plans to curtail or even cancel Pres Clinton's Asia trip in event of attack; debate acting while there seems to be international disgust with Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein and he remains defiant toward United Nations; Clinton delays trip by day; Defense Department begins bolstering forces in region, sending missile cruiser Anzio to Persian Gulf (M)

headline: Raytheon Dam Financing
abstract: Raytheon Co says financing is complete for $700 million dam and power plant it will build in Philippines for San Roque Power Corp, joint venture of Marubeni Corp, affiliates of Sithe Energies Inc and Kansai Electric Power Inc (S)

headline: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP TO ACQUIRE RAMAPO FINANCIAL
abstract: Valley National Bancorp says that it agreed to acquire Ramapo Financial Corp of Wayne, NJ, for $99.6 million in stock (S)

headline: Sumitomo Bank to Cut 2,000 Jobs in 5 Years
abstract: Sumitomo Bank Ltd will cut its retail staff by 2,000, or 40 percent, in next five years; bank will separate its retail operations from its corporate business (S)

headline: Asia Satellite Gets New Owners
abstract: Societe Europeenne des Satellites and Citic, China's biggest investment company, buy control of Asia Satellite Telecommunications Holdings Ltd, forming broadcast network that stretches from Western Europe to Southeast Asia; Societe Europeenne and state-owned China International Trust and Investment Corp pay $372 million for 68 percent stake from Cable and Wireless PLC and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: U.N. Measure Skirts Outright Threat of Force Against Milosevic
abstract: United Nations Security Council adopts resolution skirting outright threat to use force against Pres Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia if he fails to remove forces from Kosovo; American officials claim resolution is all NATO would need to punish Milosevic if he steps out of line; Russia and China abstain from voting on resolution, and their representatives differ sharply with United States's and Britain's interpretation of it; Russia and China had threatened to veto resolution that permits military action by NATO or Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, whose 54 members are supplying monitors in Kosovo (M)

headline: Milosevic Says He Has Met NATO Demands on Kosovo
