abstract: Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, meeting with United States envoy Richard C Holbrooke, insists he has ordered enough forces out of Kosovo recently to avert threatened NATO attack; US official says rotation of Serbian forces in and out of province makes it impossible to know whether there was net outflow; Holbrooke leaves Belgrade; several embassies, including Americans', prepare to evacuate families and nonessential staff; Belgrade residents stock up on survival essentials; photo (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; Please, Mr. Bureaucrat, Hear My 20-Year-Old Plea
abstract: Hundreds of elderly in Beijing, China, are carrying on ancient traditon of appealing personally to higher authorities for redress of heartfelt grievances--some waiting for decades, camped outside city's Petitions and Appeals Office; many sleep in shoddy tents of canvas or plastic, cook food scrounged from garbage and use streets or nearby canal as toilet; some grievances date back to Cultural Revolution of 1966 to 1976; direct appeal to higher authorities was main means of redress when country lacked formal legal system; after Communists came to power in 1949, tradition was continued with formal appeals offices in provinces, and in Beijing for those still not satisfied; photos (M)

headline: Peru and Ecuador Sign Treaty To End Longstanding Conflict
abstract: Presidents Jamil Mahaud of Ecuador and Alberto K Fujimori of Peru, in emotional ceremony officially ending bitter conflict that has spanned generations, sign peace treaty in Brasilia opening disputed border and creating avenues for trade and development; treaty relies on Brazil, US, Chile and Argentina to outline nations' borders; terms noted; photo (S)

headline: In Coordination for the Euro, Italy Cuts Key Interest Rate to 3%
abstract: Italy's central bank cuts discount rate to record low 3 percent, from 3.5 percent, completing alignment of rates among 11 nations joining European single currency in Jan; move is bank's last independent monetary step before cedeing rate control to European Central Bank (M)

headline: DATABANK: October 26-30; Nearly Everything Came Up Roses
abstract: Buoyed by a report on Friday that showed the economy growing at an altogether respectable annual rate of 3.3 percent in the third quarter, stocks closed out their best month in more than a decade and left many wondering if August and September really happened.      For the month, the Dow was up 749.38, or 9.6 percent, the best advance since it climbed 13.8 percent in January 1987.

headline: Bacardi-Martini Selects McKinney
abstract: Bacardi-Martini USA Inc names McKinney & Silver to handle advertising and marketing for Disaronno Amaretto brand of liqueur; billings estimated at $6 million to $8 million (S)

headline: Drop Seen in Orange Crop
abstract: Agriculture Department says Florida's new orange crop will be 22 percent smaller than last year's record harvest; futures prices soar 26 percent (S)

headline: Nasdaq Sets Link With Hong Kong
abstract: Nasdaq stock market and Stock Exchange of Hong Kong agree on first steps of what could become broader alliance between two markets; National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs Nasdaq trading, and Hong Kong exchange will conduct pilot project in which 25 companies that now list on one of markets will now list on both; program is scheduled to begin around mid-1999 (S)

headline: GRAPHICS TECHNOLOGY COMPANIES SET $67 MILLION MERGER
abstract: ATI Technologies Inc acquires Chromatic Research Inc for $67 million (S)

headline: Quebec Questions
abstract: Anthony DePalma analysis contends that while result of Quebec's provincial election are muddy enough for both major parties to claim victory of sorts, and to bear some degree of defeat, real losers are those who had hoped election would provide clear sense of where Quebec, and Canada, are heading; notes that while separatists were returned to power, they could not even muster plurality of popular vote; holds that election results keep independence movement alive, but it is wounded; says that means Premier Lucien Bouchard will not call another referendum on breaking away from Canada anytime soon (M)

headline: LOCKHEED PLANS CHARGE OF AT LEAST $300 MILLION
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp will take charge of $300 million to $400 million related to accounting changes involving development costs; indicates that $7 billion potential sale to United Arab Emirates of F-16 planes might not be completed as soon as expected (S)

headline: ZIFF-DAVIS TO SHUT 3 MAGAZINES AND CUT 350 JOBS
abstract: Ziff-Davis Inc says it will stop publishing Internet Business, Equip and Windows Pro magazines and cut 350 jobs, or 10 percent of its United States work force (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: William Lovering; Bartlett Europe Fund
abstract: William Lovering, co-manager of $85.1 million Bartlett Europe fund, says way to pick best European stocks is to find companies that are likely to benefit most from impending debut of euro; photo; chart (M)

headline: Big Bonuses Expected With Merger of Deutsche and Bankers Trust
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG will reportedly give multimillion-dollar incentives to handful of top Bankers Trust and Deutsche executives to secure their services once German banking giant completes $9.67 billion acquisition of Bankers Trust; select top bankers reportedly will receive at least $10 million to stay with merged company for undisclosed period of time, to help insure that managers crucial to merger's success are in place; include at least six Bankers Trust executives and three Deutsche executives; hundreds of other employees will receive smaller incentives (M)

headline: Treasuries Fall As Investors Turn Elsewhere
abstract: US Treasury bond prices tumble; 30-year Treasury bond falls 1 13/32, to 106 29/32; yield rises to 5.07 percent from 4.97 percent on Sept 19; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: CROMPTON AND IMPERIAL IN DEALS WITH CHRISTIAN HANSEN
abstract: Crompton & Knowles Corp to sell its food and pharmaceutical ingredients unit to Christian Hansen Holding A/S for $103 million; Christian Hansen says it is buying food colorings business from unit of Imperial Chemicals Industries PLC for $55 million (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: William A. Oates Jr.; Northeast Investors Growth Fund
abstract: Profile of Northeast Investors Growth fund and independent style of its head William A Oates Jr; photo; graph; chart (M)

headline: A POLICY STRUGGLE STIRS WITHIN NATO
abstract: Clinton Adm presents NATO with far-reaching program that seeks to define what alliance has become since cold war ended, and sets out its goals for next century; but proposals are running into European opposition that threatens to undermine 50th-anniversary NATO summit meeting in Washington in April; NATO diplomats say agenda for meeting is intended partly to convince Congress that NATO is still central to American security, but it has raised European concerns that United States is trying to turn orgn into freewheeling global vehicle for its own interests (M)

headline: Sir Alan Lloyd Hodgkin, 84, A Nobelist in Nerve Research
abstract: Sir Alan Lloyd Hodgkin, English biophysicist who shared 1963 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for work in nerve research, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS: DIARY; Fed to Bankers: Go On, Beat It
abstract: Little-known Federal anti-embezzlement rule that requires bank employees in sensitive positions to be away from their desks and duties for two consecutive weeks evey year is still enforced; rule imposes hardships on many banks who are hindered by loss of key personnel (M)

headline: In Peru's Shantytowns, Cholera Comes by the Bucket
abstract: Wendy Marston article on cholera in Peru's shantytowns and efforts of health workers to monitor the disease so as to stay ahead of the next outbreak; says Peru, which had its first outbreak of cholera in 1991, is especially vulnerable because it is close to ocean, where cholera bacteria are part of natural ecology, and because its water system is poor; photos (M)

headline: Cars That Open Up To Computers, Literally
abstract: British journal New Scientist reports new car use for infrared port on Palm Pilot handheld organizers: it can duplicate signals that control some automobile security systems (S)

headline: Antidotes For Crashes
abstract: Anti-crash programs work by scanning a computer system for conflicts, glitches and corrupted files and fixing the problems; some users, however, say anti-crash programs cause more problems than they fix (S)

headline: Shares of Ubid Have Strong Trading Debut
abstract: Shares of on-line auction company Ubid Inc begin trading, closing at $48, up from $15 offering price (S)

headline: Cultivating A Cult Audience; Fast Company Magazine Takes 'Community of Readers' Idea To New Extremes
abstract: Article profiles Fast Company, technology oriented business magazine published by Mortimer B Zuckerman aimed at young entrepreneurs; photo (M)

headline: This Might Be What You Need For Those Papers, Mr. Bond
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co offers Capshare 910, a handheld digital scanner that can capture and store an image, text, or data when it is swept over it; information can then be observed on small LCD screen in front of the device, or sent by cable to an E-mail address or hard drive, or delivered via infrared signal to a printer; cost of device is $699; photo (S)

headline: KN ENERGY SAYS LAGGING DEMAND WILL LOWER EARNINGS
abstract: KN Energy Inc warns fourth-quarter and full-year earnings will be far lower than analysts' forecasts (S)

headline: New Role As Umpire May Bring More Risk
abstract: Middle East peace agreement gives Central Intelligence Agency a new and potentially risky role in safeguarding security for Israel and Palestinian Authority; pact empowers intelligence operatives to referee disputes involving handling of suspected terrorists, to monitor who is arrested and jailed by Israeli and Palestinian authorities and to help establish sophisticated and reliable border checkpoints (M)

headline: Updated Art-Ware Classic
abstract: Dulcie Leimbach assesses Kid Pix Studio Deluxe, children's art software from Broderbund; photo (M)

headline: A Premium of Billions Will Vanish on Accounting Ledgers
abstract: Exxon Corp will use pooling of interests accounting method for its merger with Mobil, move that will erase from its ledgers $50 billion premium it has agreed to pay; method, usually used for mergers of equals, greatly restricts how combined company can run many parts of business (M)

headline: In a country run by the military, a station manager sees talk radio as a democratic duty.
abstract: Gremah Boucar, newly honored by Committee to Protect Journalists, offers simple news broadcasts and open-mike programs on his Niger radio station; his willingness to reflect diverse political viewpoints has sometimes offended military government, which has at times smashed equipment, arrested and threatened him; photo (M)

headline: World Bank Emphasizes Role of Free Media in Fighting Graft
abstract: World Bank, after surveying Asian financial crisis, has concluded that strong and independent news media could be important protection against economic mismanagement and government malfeasance in developing nations; bank president James D Wolfensohn stresses importance of 'the free flow of information' as one of 'essentials of good governance' on which sustainable economic progress depends, address to annual meeting of World Bank and International Monetary Fund (M)

headline: G.E. of Britain in Merger Talks With Several Global Concerns
abstract: General Electric Company of Britain PLC, which has held merger talks with British Aerospace PLC on an occasional basis since 1993, is in 'intense' merger talks with number of global companies (S)

headline: Toshiba Sells Most Time Warner Shares
abstract: Time Warner Inc says Toshiba Corp sold 9.5 million of its shares; Time Warner buys back 1.9 million shares of the stake, with remainder going to other investors (S)

headline: Finding The Profits (And Fun) In Mergers
abstract: Finding the profits (and fun) in mergers**Tyco International chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski comments on planned merger with AMP, maker of electronic connectors; photo (M)

headline: EASY MONEY: A special report.; For Russia and Its U.S. Bankers, Match Wasn't Made in Heaven
abstract: Special report, Easy Money, on role many United States investment banks played in rise and fall of Russian economy; Wall Street bankers, lured by prospect of big fees, helped Government, business elite and regional governments sell debt abroad not backed by reliable income streams; enabled Russia to build roaring bond market without developing banking system that provides conventional loans; governments and businesss have incurred massive short-term debt; adroit way in which Goldman, Sachs & Co escaped unscathed after helping Government sell $1.25 billion in bonds that are now nearly worthless cited; graphs; photos (L)

headline: TARNISHED LAUREATE: A special report.; Nobel Winner Finds Her Story Challenged
abstract: Book by American anthropologist David Stoll, Rigoberta Menchu and the Story of All Poor Guatemalans, casts doubt on accuracy of her 1992 autobiography--I, Rigoberta Menchu--for which she received Nobel Peace Prize and became overnight celebrity and much-sought-after crusader for human rights, special report, Tarnished Laureate; autobiography, first published in Spanish in 1983 at height of Guatemala's brutal civil war, tells wrenching tale of violence, destruction, misery and exploitation; Stoll, after decade of interviews with more than 120 people and archival research, concludes that key details of her story are untrue; says book is not eyewitness account since Menchu repeatedly describes experiences she never had herself; his assertions are corroborated by New York Times in interviews with members of Menchu's family, as well as with friends, neighbors and former classmates that indicate many of book's main episodes are either totally fabricated or seriously exaggerated; Menchu defends book as part of historical memory and patrimony of Guatemala, dismissing criticisms as part of racist political agenda to gain attention and publicity; photos; map (L)

headline: Emergency Preparedness
abstract: Q. How do I make an emergency boot floppy?    A. A boot floppy, or bootable floppy, is a disk that usually contains a minimal version of the computer's operating system and some utility programs to help diagnose hard-drive problems. A boot floppy is a handy thing to have when your computer is in such a sad state that it can't even start up properly to let you do basic system tests or repairs. Because most computers check the floppy drive first for a suitable bootable system before going to the hard drive, you can bypass the malfunctioning drive.

headline: Britain Joins France's Call for European Force
abstract: Britain accepts longstanding French proposal that European Union should be able to conduct military actions on its own in situations with US and other NATO allies do not want to become involved; US State Department welcomes agreement (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cut in U.S. Interest Rates Helps Markets Rally Abroad  Stock markets in Asia and Europe surged in response to Thursday's interest rate reduction by the Federal Reserve. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index jumped 9 percent, to 9,777.01, its highest level since early May.

headline: CLINTON ACCEPTS IRAQ'S PROMISE TO ALLOW WEAPONS INSPECTIONS
abstract: Pres Clinton says that Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq has unconditionally retreated and once again vowed complete cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors; says US and British forces that nearly struck Iraq on Nov 14 will remain poised to act; says Iraq must live up to its obligations; calls for overthrow of Hussein; says he is threat to peace of his region and security of world; Pentagon says it is suspending its military buildup in Persian Gulf region; senior US officials say Iraqis have clarified their position in two letters that eliminated all unacceptable conditions; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: State Farm Insurance Wins Savings Charter Approval  Federal savings regulators have permitted State Farm Insurance, the automobile and homeowners' insurer, to use its network of agents to sell banking products like car loans, mortgages and certificates of deposit.

headline: HAUSER TO BUY THREE UNITS OF ZUELLIG FOR $45.8 MILLION
abstract: Hauser Inc to buy three units of Zuellig Group NA for $45.8 million in stock (S)

headline: Influencing Doctor's Orders
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies are increasingly enhancing their advertising for prescription drugs in a style more commonly associated with products sold over-the-counter; Competitive Media Reporting, marketing research firm, reports spending on consumer advertising has exploded since Food and Drug Administration in 1997 loosened restraints on on television commercials for prescription drugs; says this type of advertising rose to $100 million this month, almost five times the total only three years ago; demand generated by consumer advertising has raised questions about how such ads are changing practice of medicine; some physicians contend ads artifically stoke demand for most expensive treatments and waste tiime for both patients and doctors; in addition, insurers complain that demand is inflating their pharmaceutical budgets; photo; chart on advertising budgets for certain drugs (Advertising column) (L)

headline: Jailed Israelis: A Spy Fiasco Or a Warning By Cyprus?
abstract: Two Isrealis, Udi Hargov and Yigal Damary, are arrested on suspicion of spying on military installation in Cyprus, raising questions in Israel about whether it is latest in series of bungles by Israeli intelligence agency, Mossad; arrest spotlights increased regional tensions about growing security cooperation between Israel and Turkey (M)

headline: On-Line Shoppers' Attitudes: A Case of Bahhumbug.com?
abstract: New survey by Jupiter Communications, market research firm, New York, projects that on-line shopping will hit $2.3 billion during this holiday season, up from $1.1 billion year ago; also finds that only 16 percent of purchases will be gifts and that majority will be for the shoppers themselves (S)

headline: THE DOCTOR IS IN
abstract: America's Doctor Online is a new service provided to members of America Online; site, found on AOL's Health channel, will provide AOL users with free access to certified primary-care doctors, either through E-mail correspondence or through real-time conversations in chat rooms (S)

headline: In a Straitened Brazil, Talk of Pay in Goods
abstract: Thousands of Brazilian businesses, struggling during sudden recession, are considering idea of paying workers their '13th month's salary' in products instead of cash; recession is making cash and credit short; 13th month's salary is not bonus, but a legally mandated payment due all workers; employers pay salaries on monthly basis, but because payments cover four weeks, the 13th payment at end of year compensates for extra days each month; some workers comment on nation's economic future (M)

headline: Microsoft and CBS Sell Ad Packages
abstract: John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co signs two-year, $7.5 million pact with Microsoft Corp to become 'premier life insurance sponsor' on MSN network of Internet services; Taylor Made Golf signs one-year pact with CBS Plus, new CBS unit formed to make so-called cross-media deals involving various CBS divisions (M)

headline: NABISCO MARGARINE BRANDS COST CONAGRA $400 MILLION
abstract: Conagra Inc. paid $400 million to buy several brands of margarine from the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, according to a regulatory filing. The price was not disclosed when the sale was announced in July. Conagra bought Fleischmann's, Parkay, Blue Bonnet, Touch of Butter, Chiffon and Move Over Butter margarines as well as Egg Beaters egg substitutes.  The purchase made Conagra, based in Omaha, one of the largest makers of table spreads in the United States.

headline: The Market Hesitates, Then Regains Hope
abstract: Assessment of stock market performance during week of November 9 to 13; graphs; charts (L)

headline: Concerns on Profit Outlook Help Deflate the Dow a Bit
abstract: Stocks prices decline on concern that euphoria that sent Dow Jones industrial average up 21 percent in six weeks is unjustified by outlook for corporate profits; average declines 73.12 points, to 9,301.15; Standard & Poor's 500 index falls 5.22 to 1,182.99; Nasdaq Composite index loses 11.54 to 1,965.88; graph (M)

headline: Stuffed Animals With Attitude May Spur Modest Rise in Toy Sales
abstract: Furby, animated stuffed animal with an attitude, is hot toy of this Christmas season, generating out-of-the door lines at any store that has any left in stock; Michael Glazer, chief executive of Kay-Bee Toys, retail chain, says his stores are selling out of Furbys within 15 minutes; other expected blockbusters include Mattel's talking Bounce Around Tigger, toys based on television shows Blue's Clues and Teletubbies, as well as those tied to Rugrats television show and movie; Tiger Electronics, unit of Hasbro that makes Furby, says it expects to sell more than million Furbys this year, double number it expected; for all the intererst in few hot products, toy companies are only expecting modest gains in sales this season; photos (M)

headline: Lo! Here Come the Technology Patents. Lo! Here Come the Lawsuits
abstract: Companies in fiercely competitive technology industries from communications and software to biotechnology and drugs are pursuing aggressive strategy of patenting new products and then filing lawsuits against competitors; chart of patent-related lawsuits since 1980; drawing (M)

headline: BOEING AND BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY TO BUILD FLIGHT CENTER
abstract: Boeing Co and Berkshire Hathaway Inc say they will build $100 million flight-training center in Miami to instruct pilots for Latin American routes; center will train 7,000 pilots and 3,000 flight technicians annually and will be largest flight-training center not owned by an airline (S)

headline: Aerospace Combination Plan Confirmed
abstract: Daimler-Benz Aerospace and British Aerospace PLC aim to combine early next year into military contractor that could include other European arms suppliers; combination would be initial step in creating multinational European defense and aerospace company that would eventually include Aerospatiale of France and others (S)

headline: LIBRARY/BOOKS ON THE TECHNOLOGICAL SOCIETY; Outsmarting Ourselves: How Computers Can Fail Children
abstract: Sandy Byers Harvin reviews book Failure to Connect: How Computers Affect Our Children's Minds--For Better and Worse, by Jane M Healy; photo (S)

headline: DeVito/Verdi Gets A Seagram Account
abstract: Seagram Americas expands its ad agency roster by naming DeVito/Verdi to handle its wine coolers account, which had been handled by Siebel Marketing Group; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: Stephen King Unleashed; He's back on the best-seller list. But now he wants more. Much more.
abstract: Stephen King, highly successful author of horror novels, has had his books regularly listed on The New York Times best-seller lists; lately, however, his novels have spent fewer weeks on the lists; King, at age 51, is aggressively dealing with highpoint of long career; his new novel, Bag of Bones, centers on popular author who develops severe case of writer's block following his wife's death; King is hoping romantic elements in Bag of Bones will result in book's selling better than anything he has done in years; year ago King left his publisher, Viking, which became part of Penguin Putnam Group; since then, King developed a unique profit-sharing partnership with Simon & Schuster; some critics believe King's book sales were too flat to justify the almost $18 million advance he initially demanded for Bag of Bones; chart on how King ranks against authors Michael Crichton, John Grisham and Tom Clancy in terms of estimated income, best-selling hardcover books and movie adaptations from books (L)

headline: Bringing 'New' Christianity to Africa: The Good News
abstract: Growth of Christianity in Africa and elsewhere is developing world is a focus of Eighth Assembly of World Council of Churches in Harare, Zimbabwe; presents challenge to ecumenical goals of the council; questions of doctrine and institutional structure that have preoccupied council since its founding 50 years ago seem less significant today than questions of national identity and of class, cultural and ethnic differences among churches of the world; photo (M)

headline: CLINTON APPEALS FOR JOINT ATTACK IN ECONOMIC CRISIS
abstract: Pres Clinton meets in closed session in Washington with finance ministers and central bankers from largest industrial economies and 15 nations with emerging markets that have been stricken by currency devaluations, plummeting stock markets and growing unemployment; urges them to develop unified attack on global economic crisis; session focuses on long-term ideas for making global economy less vulnerable to shocks, proposed by US and others, despite widespread criticism that too little attention is being paid to coordinated immediate action; Treas Sec Robert Rubin confronts Southeast Asian nations, notably Malaysia, that have been pressing for and enacting rules that would restrict right of investors to move funds freely across borders; delivers rare rebuke to International Monetary Fund and World Bank for failure to devise common solution to crisis; photo (M)

headline: Gates on Tape: Scant Memory Of Key Details
abstract: Taped deposition of Microsoft chairman William H Gates, played at antitrust trial in Washington, shows him professing ignorance of key meetings and strategies that lie at heart of Government's case--performance far removed from his reputation as brilliant business strategist who guided company's rise to dominance in computing; Government charges Microsoft with conspiring to bully competitors, such as Apple Computer Inc and Netscape Communications Corp, into abandoning Internet software markets that Microsoft sought to dominate; Microsoft says two hours of taped testimony from 20-hour deposition were often taken out of context by Government prosecutors merely to cause ambarrassment, and had little direct bearing on case; high points of Gates's testimony discussed; photo (M)

headline: ABC Radio Loses Contract Lawsuit
abstract: Walt Disney Co's ABC Radio Networks loses $20 million breach of contract verdict after jury decides that network misappropriated design of children's radio service from its onetime partner; jury rules in favor of Children's Broadcasting Corp, which sued two years ago, accusing ABC of abandoning strategic alliance and then using what it learned to start Radio Disney (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CAPITAL SENIOR LIVING CORP.,  Dallas, an operator of senior living communities, said it would buy four communities from NHP Retirement Housing Partners I Ltd. for $40.6 million in cash.    JOHNSON & JOHNSON,  New Brunswick, N.J., the health care company, agreed to acquire Femrx Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., a maker of products to treat gynecological disorders, for $2.35 a share, a total of $22 million.

headline: Deal Balances Concessions For Israelis and Palestinians
abstract: Under peace agreement signed in Washington Israel would withdraw from more territory on West Bank and Palestinian Authority would accept stronger plan for preventing terrorist attacks against Israel; summary of key gains for Israel; summary of concessions gained by Palestinians; map shows who controls what in West Bank (M)

headline: Ciba Specialty and Clariant End $7 Billion Merger Talks
abstract: Ciba Specialty Chemicals AG and Clariant AG end merger talks (M)

headline: Net Traffic in Asia:Where Every Line Is a Detour
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  It remains a peculiar fact about the Internet that an electronic mail message sent from Thailand to the Philippines will likely zip across the Pacific Ocean and back instead of crossing the South China Sea separating the two countries.

headline: A U.S. Message to Milosevic Turns Into Full-Dress Talks
abstract: American envoy Richard C Holbrooke, who came to Belgrade, Serbia, to warn Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to comply on Kosovo or face NATO attack, is in midst of full-dress talks; reportedly makes some progress; photo (M)p

headline: UNISOURCE SAYS IT PLANS TO SELL MEXICAN OPERATION
abstract: Unisource Worldwide Inc plans to sell its Mexican operation and take charge of as much as $70 million against fiscal fourth-quarter earnings as it tries to reduce costs and increase profits; Unisource cut 300 jobs in third quarter, and intends to cut about 1,200 more while closing 171 of its 424 facilities and eliminating 3 million square feet of warehouse space (S)

headline: U.S. Plans To Provide Food Relief To Russians
abstract: US is planning to provide millions of tons of food to help Russians stave off hunger and endure bitter winter; will provide at least 3.1 million metric tons under accord being negotiated in Moscow; much of food will be provided free and rest will be sold with generous long-term financing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ADAPTEC INC., Milpitas, Calif., a maker of computer connectors cards and storage devices, said it would buy back as much as $200 million of its common stock, or about 15 percent of its outstanding stock, to increase returns to shareholders.    COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP., El Segundo, Calif., a computer services company, acquired 51 percent of closely held KPMG Peat Marwick S.A., a Paris-based consulting and information technology unit of KPMG Peat Marwick. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Changes May Be Due For Miller Beers
abstract: Major changes may be in works for campaigns for Miller Lite and Miller Genuine Draft beer brands, sold by Miller Brewing Co; Susan Henderson, spokeswoman for Miller, confirms reports in trade publications that Miller executives recently briefed distributors on advertising and marketing plans for 1999; she declines to discuss details (S)

headline: Retail Sales Surprisingly Strong And Producer Prices Fall Again
abstract: Retail sales were stronger than expected in November, rising six-tenths of one percent, fourth consecutive monthly gain; producer prices fell two-tenths of one percent, biggest decline since August (S)

headline: 'New Labor' Strategist, a Blair Confidant, Quits Over a Loan
abstract: Peter Mandelson resigns as Britain's Trade and Industry Minister over his failure to disclose that he received a loan from Geoffrey Robinson, a millionaire colleague in the Government whose outside business interests have come under scrutiny of Mandelson's office; Mandelson is Prime Min Tony Blair's closest confidant and the architect of Labor Party's 1997 election victory; photo (M)

headline: STAPLES TO BUY OFFICE-PRODUCTS ASSETS OF IVAN ALLEN
abstract: Staples Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the office-products assets of the Ivan Allen Company for an undisclosed price. Staples, which is based in Westborough, Mass., and is the second-largest office-supply superstore chain in the United States, is expanding its operations in the Southeast and building its catalogue business. It said it would buy the closely held Ivan Allen's supplies assets in Atlanta and 14 divisional sales offices in the South. Ivan Allen will continue to operate its office-furniture business.

headline: Wishing on a Star, Computer in Hand
abstract: Excalibur Electronics offers computer device called the Night Navigator ($130) that is designed to make it easier to discern stars, constellations and planets in the night sky; device photo (S)

headline: Quarterly Profit Down at Gillette
abstract: Gillette Co says third-quarter profit fell 19 percent, to $353 million from $437 million a year earlier; sales fell 6.3 percent, to $2.53 billion from $2.70 billion (S)

headline: Bin Laden Plot Reported Against U.S. Sites in the Gulf
abstract: Osama bin Laden, Saudi dissident the United States has accused of bombing American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in August, orders terrorist attack on American targets in Persian Gulf within the next few days or weeks; American intelligence agents learn of preparations for a strike by eavesdropping on conversations between bin Laden and members of loosely knit terrorist orgn that he operates around Islamic world (M)

headline: Sounding the Alarm on Deadly Wells
abstract: Dipankar Chakraborti continues to raise alarms about the water used by more than 20 million villagers in Bangladesh and Indian state of West Bengal, which comes from aquifer that is naturally tainted with harmful levels of arsenic; Government of Bangladesh and charitable groups financed 4 million wells as part of a safe-water program, but no one tested the water for arsenic before they were sunk (M)

headline: RJR Nabisco Plans Cuts in Both Tobacco and Food Units
abstract: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp, hurt by economic weakness abroad and impact of smoking-litigation settlement, will close plants and cut 15.6 percent of its worldwide tobacco force, as well as restructure and reduce jobs in its food business; one thousand of 3,900 tobacco jobs to be eliminated and undetermined percentage of 1,500 food jobs to be cut are in US; moves will result in fourth-quarter after-tax charge of $348 million; says it is cutting back its tobacco operations, partly because of reduced cigarette sales (M)

headline: Seeking Bombs? No, a Wife, Arab Suspect Tells the F.B.I.
abstract: Mamdouh Mahmud Salim fights extradition from Germany to US, where he faces charges of conspiracy to carry out attacks against American military installations; insists he went to Germany in search of work and a wife; FBI says he intended to carry out an attack on American Consulate in Hamburg and is member of Osama bid Laden's terrorist group; Sidi Tayyib, a top financial aide to bin Laden and once a close associate of Salim, appears to have informed against them (M)

headline: Apple's Store on the Web Is Closed for Renovations
abstract: Apple closes its on-line store for renovations (News Watch column) (S)

headline: Hong Kong Leader Tries To Cope With the Crisis
abstract: Interview with Hong Kong's chief executive Tung Chee-hwa, who describes efforts to cope with effects of Asian financial crisis (M)

headline: Polygamy Keeps a New African Church From World Council
abstract: World Council of Churches, meeting at Eighth Assembly in Zimbabwe, refuses to accept Nigeria's Celestial Church of Christ as new member, citing church's policy of allowing clergy to practice polygamy (M)

headline: Israelis Are Reconsidering South Lebanon Occupation
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu cuts short a trip abroad to reconsider Israeli Army's long occupation of southern Lebanon after killing of seven Israeli soldiers there in last week and half; while there is a cyclical nature to debate in Israel on Lebanon policy, spate of recent casualties increases pressure on Israeli Govt to contemplate unilateral withdrawal of its troops from southern Lebanon after 20 years there; photo; map (M)

headline: REPRIEVE BY NATO ALLOWS MILOSEVIC ANOTHER 10 DAYS
abstract: NATO grants Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic a reprieve, extending by 10 days its deadline for him to withdraw military and police forces cracking down on ethnic Albanians in province of Kosovo; in face of abundant evidence that Milosevic has not yet kept his pledges to withdraw forces, NATO's reprs in Brussels give him until Oct 27 to comply or face threat of NATO military attacks; they say reprieve brings time for international observers to arrive on ground in Kosovo; they also say it will allow NATO to start surveillance flights; photo (M)

headline: New Earnings Criteria
abstract: Listing of corporate earnings in New York Times Business Day section covers companies that have at least $100 million in quarterly revenues; banking and insurance companies, which do not usually report revenues, will be covered in listing if their total assets exceed $2 billion

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises against mark after German central banker, Hans Jurgen Krupp, suggests that interest rates might be lowered; dollar rises 1.6484 marks, from 1.6384 on Sept 20 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Barnes & Noble in Deal That Could Hurt Amazon  Microsoft and Barnes & Noble announced an agreement to weave together their on-line products and services in a multimillion-dollar marketing arrangement that makes Barnes & Noble the exclusive book merchant on Microsoft's popular MSN network. The deal could prove damaging to the Internet's largest bookseller, Amazon.com.    Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed, but analysts said it could give Barnes & Noble significant reach in an area where it has lagged. Shares of Barnes & Noble surged 10 percent and Microsoft rose nearly 5 percent. Shares of Amazon rose 1.3 percent. [Page C6.]

headline: Play It Again, RAM
abstract: Yamaha Disklavier Grantouch digital grand piano has the shape of an acoustic grand even though it has no strings; keyboard action is the same as a concert grand's, and its database of digitized sounds is about 10 times that of earlier digital pianos; it can also record and play back performances; drawing (M)

headline: Intel Consolidates Consumer Accounts
abstract: Intel Corp consolidates consumer advertising, with American billings estimated at $100 million, at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, which began sharing account with longtime Intel agency, Euro RSCG DSW Partners in San Francisco, only eight months ago (S)

headline: Intel Chief Plans to Sell One-Third of Stake
abstract: Intel Corp chief executive Craig R Barrett discloses plans to sell about one-third of his stake in company, or 700,000 shares, as stock recovers from slump earlier in month; three other company insiders also have filed with Securities and Exchange Commission in last week to sell combined 110,000 shares (S)

headline: Music Made Easier; It's All In the Mix
abstract: Josh Gabriel, musician and computer programmer, helps form Mixman Technologies, San Francisco, which last year released software package, Mixman Studio, for PC's that creates self-contained recording studio and real-time mixer; software makes composing and recording music simple for average person (S)

headline: Foulard and Rep, Rest in Peace? Not So Fast!
abstract: Daniel Akst column on trend toward casual dress in workplace discusses demise of necktie as emblem of masculine propriety; drawing (M)/

headline: America Online Has New Portal
abstract: America Online unit ICQ (formerly Mirabilis) nears release of new World Wide Web software that contains all features of Web gateway, or portal; product translates information it finds into any language to accomodate its large international audience; AOL faces problem of promoting service while keeping its public distance to avoid offending ICQ's users, who opposed takeover by AOL (M)

headline: Europe Dominates Survey's Top 10 Least-Corrupt-Countries List
abstract: 1998 Corruption Perception Index issued by organization Transparency International lists Denmark, Finland, Sweden, New Zealand, Iceland, Canada, Singapore, Netherlands, Norway and Switzerland as least corrupt nations; most corrupt, from the bottom, are given as Cameron, Paraguay, Honduras, Tanzania, Nigeria, Indonesia, Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, Russia, Vietnam, Kenya; Cameroon objects; US is 17th from top (M)

headline: French Bottler of Water Buying a U.S. Rival
abstract: Groupe Danone is buying Aqua Penn Spring Water Co for $112 million, or $13 a share (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls to its weakest level against dollar since Oct 7 on speculation that Federal Reserve will not lower rates at its Nov 17 meeting; dollar costs 121.57 yen in New York, up from 119.10; graph; chart (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: OPEC Nearing Pact To Keep Prices From Falling  After a day of meetings, members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries appeared to be nearing an agreement on what action they would take to try to keep oil prices from falling further, but a spokesman for the group said there were more issues to discuss.    The spokesman, Rilwanu Lukman, the Secretary General of OPEC, said in Vienna, where the group is meeting, that the group would reconvene today. But analysts said the group had little choice but to extend the production cuts made earlier this year.   [C3.]

headline: Money Isn't Everything, Especially in Retirement
abstract: Daniel G Smith letter on Fred Brock's October 4 column on retirement describes his own comfortable retirement in Manhattan (S)

headline: Leveling the Playing Field For Left-Handed Gamers
abstract: Lefkey International hopes to revive idea of left-handed keyboard by appealing to game players; photo (S)

headline: A Computer Anti-Theft Alarm That Squeals Like a Stuck Pig
abstract: New car alarm system from Bluvenom is locked to desktop computer through flooppy disk drive or to laptop; if computer is moved after device is locked and set, Bluvenom will, according to company's co-founder, Gary Moser, 'squeal like stuck pig' at 120 decibels; photo of device (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction: Dec 20 Economic View column about possibility of future financial crises around world misstated amount of business debt in US at end of third quarter; it was $5.13 trillion

headline: French Insurer Buys U.S. Money Manager
abstract: AXA Investment Managers, fund management unit of AXA SA, takes control of Barr Rosenberg Investment Management; AXA Investment will have 60 percent of voting rights and receive about 50 percent of profit from venture, to be called AXA Rosenberg Group; AXA will pay Barr Rosenberg's management $125 million, plus additional amount in 2001 that will depend on company's performance (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Cantisano Foods Inc account to Greenstone Roberts Advertising, Melville, NY, for advertising for Franesco Rinaldi pasta sauces, which had been handled by Vito Catalano Inc, NY, which closed (S)

headline: U.N. Panel to Visit Cambodia to Study Khmer Rouge Atrocities
abstract: Three legal experts appointed by Sec Gen Kofi Annan will go to Cambodia to study documents on Khmer Rouge atrocities and recommend how and where tribunal should judge those crimes; legal panel consists of Sir Ninian Stephen, Steven Ratner and Rajsoomer Lallah (M)

headline: Ahold Profit Growth Slowed by Dutch Sales
abstract: Royal Ahold NV, Dutch supermarket operator and sixth largest supermarket operator worldwide, reports third-quarter 1998 profit rose 22 percent, to $133.2 million, or below 26 percent forecast by analysts (S)

headline: Cuddly, Sure, but Smart?
abstract: Wide variety of computer chip-enhanced dolls are on market, offering varying levels of interactivity and varying claims about educational value; child-development experts debate educational value of fuzzy toys from Microsoft and others; photos (M)

headline: Encouraging an Early Taste for Fame
abstract: Some hospitals are creating virtual nurseries, posting pictures of newborn babies on Internet for far-flung relatives and friends to see; photo (M)

headline: Ho! Ho! Ho! Boohoo-hoo!
abstract: The holiday season seems to bring out the best and the worst in bosses. We've all heard stories about workers who are fired on Christmas Eve, but then again, Scrooge himself ended up giving the long-suffering Bob Cratchit a raise. What holiday horror stories have emerged from your workplace? Or, to give the management world's guardian angels their due, how have the holidays melted the coldest corporate hearts? Send your anecdotes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: The O.E.D. Adds the Web to Its Lexicon
abstract: Oxford University Press, publisher of the Oxford English Dictionary, is beginning its most ambitious electonic project to date: next year the entire dictionary will be placed on the Internet as a searchable database; scope of project can be best understood when one realizes that dictionary's editors and technicians must take a 20-volume, 22,000-page reference work containing some three-quarters of a million entries and turn it into an electronic database that can be searched rapidly; John Simpson, chief editor of the dictionary, and Royalynn O'Connor, on-line project director, comment; photos (L)

headline: G.I.'s in the Desert Say 'Get It Over With'
abstract: Few Americans are closer to dispute with Iraq than US soldiers in Kuwait City; several thousand rotate in and out for training with Kuwaiti military; last several days have been tense ones for them as possibility of military confrontation neared, then apparently receded after Iraq said it would comply with inspections; map; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; WWUS in Key West Is a Voice in the Storm
abstract: Radio station WWUS-FM in Key West, Fla, left its lines open throughout day as Hurricane Georges battered Florida Keys with 100 mph winds and station itself was flooded; Sheriff Richard Roth says station was used as main source for supplying information to frightened residents; photo (S)

headline: Iran's Forces Said to Clash With Afghans Along Border
abstract: Iran says that its troops clashed with Taliban forces along Afghan border and inflicted heavy casualties there in skirmish between neighbors who have been in a tense standoff; reported fighting, which follows more than two months of bellicose statements from both sides, would be first between Iran and Taliban, whose rival interpretations of Islam have contributed to open hostility; map (M)

headline: A New Camera Comes With a Built-In Modem
abstract: Fone Cam, new digital camera made by Moonlight Products, has built-in modem; it can send images directly to PC when hooked into standard telephone line; photo (S)

headline: WB Network to Show Anti-Drug Spot Tonight
abstract: The WB television network in Burbank, Calif., part of the Warner Brothers unit of Time Warner Inc., is introducing its first public service announcement.    The commercial, to run tonight during the drama ''Dawson's Creek,'' is titled ''Think About It'' and was produced with the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy, which coordinates the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign. The WB is joining other networks in agreements with the drug control office to run pro bono anti-drug commercials when the office runs paid commercials on those networks.

headline: Companies view ethnic holidays like Kwanzaa and Three Kings Day as a way to reach a niche.
abstract: Many corporations are broadening advertising campaigns to include ethnic holidays and festivals, such as Kwanzaa, Lunar New Year and Three Kings Day, viewing it as way of building credibility and broadening appeal to ethnic consumers; advertising campaigns by McDonald's Corp, Wal-Mart Stores Inc and Flowers Communications Group illustrate trend (M)

headline: Textron to Build Complex
abstract: Textron Inc to build complex to design and develop automotive trim and other products for DaimlerChrysler AG, Auburn Hills, Mich (S)

headline: Without Joy, Netanyahu Wins Vote to Adopt Peace Agreement
abstract: Israeli Parliament approves American-brokered peace plan by significant majority, reflecting widespread, pragmatic acceptance of partioning the Land of Israel; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, whose Likud Party was created to defend Jewish homeland from territorial compromise, turns his back on his party's founding credo; in doing so, he wins far more substantial victory, with 75 yes votes, than Labor Party, with its slim margin of support, won for original Israeli-Palestinian peace accord signed in Oslo in 1993; but he does so with Labor opposition's support; only half of his coalition Govt votes for agreement; two of his Cabinet members vote against it; and five ministers, all Likud members, walk out of chambers, refusing to vote; photo of Arab legislator and member of National Religious Party arguing over West Bank map (M)

headline: Unleashing the Power of the Pen
abstract: Crosspad, developed by International Business Machines and A T Cross, pen maker, is making people take new look at word-recognition software; it uses pen with miniature radio transmitter; while user writes in ink, pen beams its movements to computer in clipboard, which assembles data into digital image of scribblings; Crosspad has enough memory to hold electronic record of more than 50 written pages; photos (M)

headline: Spain Says It's Neutral on Pinochet; Signs Are Otherwise
abstract: Spanish Government says it will let nation's courts decide whether it has right to ask Britain to extradite former Chilean dictator Gen Augusto Pinochet, arrested in London at request of Judge Baltasar Garzon, but it is reportedly working hard to have courts rule against extradition; Garzon says he has faced Government opposition since he began in 1996 to probe torture and killings by Argentine and Chilean military rulers in 70's and 80's; Chilean officials press Spain to drop case, holding Pinochet has diplomatic immunity; photo (M)

headline: Chrysler Sales in October Increased 20% Over a Year Ago
abstract: Chrysler Corp reports that its October car and truck sales rose 20 percent over a year ago; Chrysler sold 226,179 cars and trucks; Toyota Motor Sales says it recorded its best October ever for its Toyota and Lexus divisions; sales for two divisions totaled 121,216 cars and trucks, up 27 percent from year-earlier period; also reporting higher sales are American Honda, BMW, Volkswagen, Saab, Mitsubishi, Subaru, Mazda and Kia (M)

headline: U.S. Will Release Files on Crimes Under Pinochet
abstract: US will declassify some secret Government documents on killings and torture committed during dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet in Chile; decision to release documents is first sign that US will cooperate in case against Pinochet; Clinton Administration officials say benefits of openness in human rights cases outweigh risks to national security in this case; CIA worked closely with Chile's secret police in 1970's, when over 3,000 people were believed to have been killed; Pinochet was arrested in London on Spanish court's warrent in Oct; England's highest court has denied him diplomatic immunity; case has stirred uneasiness in US diplomatic and intelligence circles; Pinochet photo (M)

headline: Lion's Share of South Korean Credit Still Goes to a Favored Few
abstract: SEOUL—  Time was when the chieftains of leading conglomerates in South Korea could demand credit from their favorite banks and get what they wanted with little if any evidence of an ability to repay.

headline: Machine Vision: Narrowing the Gap Between Human and Robot
abstract: Machine vision allows assembly-line robots to locate and identify parts to inspect, count, measure and verify objects in variety of industrial processes; essential hardware components are video camera, personal computer, sensor and frame grabber; diagrams showing process (M)

headline: U.N. Votes, 157-2, in Referendum to End U.S. Embargo of Cuba
abstract: United Nations General Assembly, 157-2, calls for end to United States economic embargo of Cuba; Israel votes with United States against nonbinding resolution and 12 nations abstain; experts say vote reflects surprising unanimity by many of US allies and friends, holding support for sanctions eroded dramatically after Congress passed 1996 law extending sanctions to countries and foreign companies doing business with Cuba; US Amb A Peter Burleigh defends embargo (M)

headline: Town-Tycoon Politics Snarl $1 Billion Plan in Hong Kong
abstract: Li Ka-shing, billionaire businessman who controls Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd, one of Hong Kong's biggers developers, and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd, city's largest employer outside of Government, threaten to scrap unidentified planned project because of 'political environment' in city; issue reportedly involves suit aginst Albert Chan, legislator who criticized Cheung Kong's decision to sue people who had defaulted on apartments they had agreed to buy; Peter Churchouse, managing director of Morgan Stanley Asia Ltd, says there is 'sense in this town that tycoons have had it all their own way for some time'; says this is dangerous because property developers rely on Government for their business; photo of Li Ka-shing (M)

headline: Chairman Resigns At Telecom Italia
abstract: Gian Mario Rossignolo, chairman of Telecom Italia SpA, resigns; Berardino Libonati is named chairman (S)

headline: 2 Would-Be Presidents in Argentina Make Corruption an Issue
abstract: Gov Fernando de la Rua of Buenos Aires province and Congresswoman Graciela Fernandez Meijilde, two leading opposition candidates vying to succeed Pres Carlos Saul Menem, pledge to begin wide-ranging corruption investigations into current Govt if they win the presidency; Menem dropped out of race for third term under pressure from his party four months ago (M)

headline: Small Companies Proliferate : New Biotech Drugs Transform Market
abstract: PARIS—  For followers of last summer's Tour de France, the world's premier bicycle race was a sorry chapter. The competition was virtually ruined as officials discovered that some athletes were using EPO, a biologically engineered drug that stimulates the production of red blood cells, giving athletes a competitive edge.

headline: Library Grapples With Internet Freedom
abstract: First Amendment issues involving public's use of the Internet present a dilemma for Faulk Central Library and Austin Public Library branches, Austin, Texas, in allowing access to Web sites by their patrons, particularly minors, that contain objectionable material; concern by library's staff over content of some material being accessed led Branda Branch, Austin's library director, to install Cyber Patrol, a filtering program popular among parents but maligned by civil libertarians; use of software resulted in protest and threatened lawsuit from American Civil Liberties Union as well as criticism from Electronic Frontiers-Texas; protests have led to modification of blocking system; Branch comments on present situation; librarians across country are watching case with interest; photos, including Branch; chart on some filtering programs with analysis by librarians Karen G Schneider and David Burt (L)

headline: Dow Falls 77 Points, Taking a Breather After an 8-Day Run-Up
abstract: Stocks fall for first time in nine sessions; Dow Jones industrial average drops 77.50 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,897.96; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 10.81 points, or about 1 percent, to 1,130.20; Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks dips 1.89 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 398.43; Nasdaq composite index gains 4.49 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,861.05; graph; chart (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY     Industrial Production   Oct.    Capacity Utilization   Oct.

headline: DOCUMENT MANAGER RENEWS PACT WITH HOSPITAL ALLIANCE
abstract: Premier Inc, hospital purchasing alliance, renews five-year pact worth $700 million with Standard Register Co, provider of document-management products and services (S)

headline: ADELPHIA AGREES TO BUY VERTO FOR $127 MILLION
abstract: Adelphia Communications will buy Verto Communications Inc for $127 million in stock and $32 million of assumed debt (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: YELTSIN ATTACKS EXTREMISM -- President Boris N. Yeltsin ordered the Government to fight political and religious extremism in the wake of several recent anti-Semitic outbursts by Russian politicians. Mr. Yeltsin told Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov and other senior officials to draw up a program to oppose extremism, the President's spokesman said.   (AP)    SPAIN: CONCERN OVER BASQUES -- The conservative Government and opposition Socialist Party expressed concern that the new regional government formed by Basque nationalists could undercut the fledging peace effort in the Basque region. The crucial votes came from the leftist coalition Euskal Heritarrok, which is considered close to the Basque separatists who have observed a cease-fire since September.   (NYT)

headline: Beersheba Suspect Confesses to Other Terrorist Attacks, Israeli Army Aides Say
abstract: Israeli Army says Salem Rajab al-Sarsour, Hamas militant arrested in grenade attack on Beersheba bus terminal, has confessed to September grenade attack on army post in Hebron and fatal August stabbing of elderly rabbi in Hebron; says he used grenades intended for Jerusalem attack when he became frustrated at failure to get work in Beersheba; Hamas's armed wing claims credit for attack; Palestinian security aide say he acted as individual and attack should not reflect negatively on Palestinians' commitment to cracking down on terrorists (M)

headline: Financial Engineering 1.0
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column describes advantages to computer technology companies and potential disadvantages to outside investors when companies sell put warrants; such warrants give buyers right, for limited time, to sell shares back to company at below market 'strike' price; graph (M)

headline: Polygram Says Profits Rebounded in 3d Quarter
abstract: Polygram NV says third-quarter profits rose 95 percent; income rose to 166 million guilders ($90 million) from 85 million guilders a year earlier (S)

headline: German Unemployment Shows Unexpected Rise
abstract: Number of unemployed workers in Germany unexpectedly rose in November, first monthly increase in 1998, raising concern that Europe's largest economy will slow more than forecast; number of jobless people rose by 4,000, counter to analysts' expectations for decline of 30,000; seasonally adjusted unemployment rate is unchanged at 10.6 percent (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil futures leap as officials from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico raise hopes nations will cut output further; in New York, oil for January delivery rises 50 cents, to $11.29 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: A New PCMCIA Card For Cellular Net Connections
abstract: New generation of modems enables handheld Windows CE devices to make wireless connections to the Internet over cellular telephone networks; latest entrant, Aircard CE from Sierra Wireless, costs a hefty $450; photo (S)

headline: France Detects Iraqi Nerve Gas, Experts Assert
abstract: Weapons experts say French tests appear to have found traces of chemicals linked to nerve gas VX on Iraqi warheads, finding that would confirm earlier American test results; diplomats charge that France is delaying release of findings to avoid undermining Iraq's push at United Nations to lift economic sanctions; France denies withholding results; says they are expected to be 'consistent' with earlier tests that found no traces of VX (M)

headline: Internet Heroine Takes Aim at TV
abstract: Lynn Harris, freelance writer and stand-up comic, and Chris Kalb, develop Internet site called Breakup Girl (www.breakupgirl.com); speaking through on-line dating advice columns, essays and comic strip, Breakup Girl, a caped Internet heroine, has become star on the Net, drawing 45,000 visitors month; Robert Morton, television producer, says he wants to offer Breakup Girl to larger audience by making her star on television network, starting with ABC; says Web is now influencing television; photo (S)

headline: Just Blunt, or a Bully? Canada Divided on Leader
abstract: Article profiles Canada's Prime Min Jean Chretien, whose five years in office has been marked by directness uncommon among world leaders; at time of roundabout diplomacy and executive legalisms, he can be outspoken and blunt to degree that frightens and frustrates his handlers; photo (M)

headline: Faulty Condoms Thwart AIDS Fight in Africa
abstract: Another article in Dead Zones series describes how efforts to contain AIDS epidemic in Africa, especially South Africa, have been undermined by prevalence of substandard condoms; most condoms are made in India, Malaysia, Thailand and China, and while some operate very scientifically, others turn out a high percentage of defective condoms that makers try to unload wherever they can; South Africa became a dumping ground because it is rich enough to buy its own condoms and used ineffective test regimen; has now adopted testing standards used by British, American and other big aid agencies; photo; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee futures rise sharply amid concern about shipping delays from world's top producers, Brazil and Colombia; coffee for December delivery rises 3.15 cents, to $1.13 a pound in Neww York; graph; chart (S)

headline: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CUTTING 1,040 JOBS AT 3 OFFICES
abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp is cutting 1,040 jobs, or 25 percent of staff, at its various headquarters as part of plan to reduce costs by $200 million by 2000 (S)

headline: Israeli Diplomat Urges Vatican to Delay Beatification of Pius XII
abstract: Israeli Ambassador to Vatican, Aharon Lopez, urges it to wait 50 years before moving ahead with any plan to beatify Pope Pius XII, who has been criticized by Jewish groups and others for remaining silent during Holocaust (M)

headline: Black Belt in Market Share Becomes the Goal at Toyota
abstract: Interview with Toyota Motor Corp president Hiroshi Okuda, who has black belt in judo and has taken aggressive stance to revitalize company; photo (M)

headline: Fireworks At Wye As Dance Goes On
abstract: Tension, frustration and brinksmanship apparently have been building at Mideast peace talks at sylvan and secluded Wye Plantation, Maryland, erupting in Israeli threats to leave; feints, image and politics seem to be at least as important as substance as Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu comes under intensive pressure; he must either accept United States peace plan and face rebellion from his constituents, reject plan and be denounced by political opponents and much of world or play for more time, option both Pres Clinton and Palestinians seek to cut off; photos (M)

headline: The Comptroller for the Moment; Banking Lawyer May Have Trod on Some Senatorial Toes
abstract: Clinton Administration gives John D Hawke Jr temporary, or one-year, 'recess' appointment to post of Comptroller of the Currency; with recess appointment, Hawke still does not have entire five-year term until approved by Senate; Hawke's appointment became hung up in Senate for number of reasons; some Democratic senators objected to positions Hawke took on consumer banking issues that Democrats felt were made only to placate Republicans; other lawmakers are still smarting over Hawke's aggressive behind-the-scenes lobbying that helped scuttle legislation to overhaul nation's banking laws earlier this year; photo of Hawke with Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin (M)

headline: Learning Gemology on the Web
abstract: CARLSBAD, California—  As Gregory Harrison put it, he needed a school to fit a rather unusual lifestyle. Mr. Harrison spends half of each year in Antarctica as an air traffic controller.

headline: Boeing Results Beat Forecasts In 3d Quarter
abstract: Boeing Co reports third-quarter earnings that are higher than expected, but it warns that recession in Asia will cause it to lose more airplane orders than it previously estimated; company earned $347 million on $12.7 billion in revenue; chart (M)

headline: Shares Open With a Rally But Finish With a Slump
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 66.17 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 8,366.04; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 6.98, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,065.34; Nasdaq composite index dips 7.35, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,717.63; graph; chart (M)

headline: Wieden & Kennedy Revamping Structure
abstract: Wieden & Kennedy is overhauling its structure by creating top echelon of worldwide managers in its headquarters in Portland, Ore, and separate management teams for its regional offices; Dan Wieden, 53, chief executive and chief creative officer, will head worldwide management team along with Dave Luhr, 43, who is named to new position of chief operating officer (S)

headline: Clinton's Ratings Take Dip in West Bank
abstract: US-led air strikes on Iraq cause disillusionment among many Palestinians who hailed Pres Clinton on his recent visit to West Bank and Gaza Strip; opposition groups seize on attack as proof that American sponsor of Palestinian-Israeli agreements is an enemy of Arabs and Islam; photo of anti-US demonstration in Nablus (M)

headline: Bill to Punish Nations Limiting Religious Beliefs Passes Senate
abstract: Senate unanimously approves and sends to House compromise bill that would require United States to punish foreign goverments with measures ranging from private rebuke to tough economic sanctions for religious persecution; bill would let President decide how to respond, based on required annual State Department reports of each nation's religious freedom record; would create independent commission that would publish own religious liberties review; Pres Clinton, reversing earlier veto threat, plans to sign bill (M)

headline: Glenn William Poorman, 90, An Executive at Standard Oil
abstract: Glenn William Poorman, former Esso International president, dies at age 90; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall St. Unmoved by Possible Fedex Strike
abstract: Market Place column on possibility of strike by Federal Express pilots holds Wall Street analysts and investors appear to be unmoved at prospect; says pilots have begun toning down their language, trying to lure company back to negotiating table; photo (M)

headline: When Phone-Company Veterans Punch the Redial Button
abstract: Raymond W Smith, due to retire as Bell Atlantic chairman at end of year, plans to take head post at Rothschild Group's North American holding company; former AT&T president Alex J Mandl says his new wireless telecommunications company, Teligent, has opened in 10 cities (S)

headline: A New Little Pager That Also Handles E-Mail
abstract: Bell South is selling what it calls Interactive Paging Service; device sends and receives E-mail in addition to paging; photo (S)

headline: Patents; When Mom says, 'Eat your vegetables,' she may soon mean, 'Make sure you get your protein.'
abstract: Demegen Inc vice president, Jesse Jaynes, and Kenneth Derrick patent process that increases protein in potatoes, sweet potatoes and tobacco; company plans to expand genetic engineering technology to grains and other plants that are staples in developing nations; has licensed invention to Mycogen, Dow Chemical Co unit; Mitchell Hochman patents formula for cold cuts and hot dogs made from fresh vegetables and low-fat meat (M)

headline: Virtual Assistants, With Personality; Electronic Secretaries Can Be Charming, Funny and Frustrating
abstract: Computer-generated administrative assistants use speech recognition to manage telephone, E-mail and fax communications for busy people; growing number of people are using such virtual assistants, but there are tradeoffs; current limits of speech recognition technology make interaction with virtual assistants frustrating, and they speak and understand only preset phrases; they can be maddeningly literal and impenetrable; comparison of three systems that operate nationally: Portico, Wildfire and Webley; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Economic Scene; A combination of Exxon and Mobil would not be as fearsome for consumers as critics contend.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Exxon Corp's acquisition of Mobil Oil Corp says merger will not be as fearsome for consumers as critics contend; holds real control of oil market rests with OPEC (M)

headline: Images of a Bleak Era
abstract: Library of Congress makes available over Internet works of corps of photographers hired by Government during Depression; photographer Gordon Parks, who has 227 pictures on site, hails move; photo (M)

headline: Q & A
abstract: Q. What does it mean to partition a hard drive? Is it advisable to do so?

headline: He Made His Point, Whatever It Was
abstract: Peter Young, former manager of several Morgan Grenfell mutual funds, shows up in London court dressed as woman; he is slated for trial on fraud charges; photo (S)

headline: Buyback by Cooper
abstract: Cooper Industries will repurchase about 10.6 million of its common shares, or $500 million in stock (S)

headline: Iraq Has Network of Outside Help on Arms, Experts Say
abstract: Arms control experts say that network of outside help involving front companies and smugglers is being used by Iraq to supply centers around country with parts for illegal weapons systems; say Iraq has also made efforts to produce some components abroad; well-disguised centers inside Iraq are not considered likely to be accessible to United Nations arms inspectors who are now back in country; experts say that evidence may be fragmentary, but that it is apparent that Iraq has access to vital components--ready-made or built to specifications--for weapons systems; Khidhir Hamza, former director of Iraq's program to devise a nuclear weapon who defected in 1994, comments (M)

headline: Free Internet Access Is an Expensive Gamble
abstract: Providers of free, advertising-supported Internet acess are faltering; Bigger.net goes bankrupt and is acquired by Brigadoon.com; entrepreneurs are undeterred from introducing new variations of advertising-supporter Internet access (S)

headline: Early Retirement: So Close, So Far
abstract: James Schembari column describes what it takes to retire early, particularly saving and investing early and wisely; drawing (M)

headline: Elmer Wavering, 91, Pioneer Of Auto Electronics, Is Dead
abstract: Elmer H Wavering, inventor of first commercial car radio, dies at age 91; photo (M)

headline: As Trademarks Multiply, Infringement Does, Too
abstract: Profile of Frederick Mostert, who in addition to serving as intellectual property counsel for Compagnie Financiere Richement AG, London, is also the president of International Trademark Association; in his dual posts, Mostert keeps watch on other companies' products; brand names of major products are so valuable that even approximating their advertising slogans to sell similar products can mean millions of dollars in lost sales to manufacturers of the real thing; in the last decade, Mostert has helped pursue a number of trademark thieves; photo of brand name product and one that resembles the trademark (M)

headline: Konya Journal; Festival of Rumi, Poet of Life's Dance
abstract: Annual festival commemmorating Jalaluddin Rumi, Islamic mystic poet who conceived dervish dance as part of lifelong quest for religious rapture, is held in Konya, Turkey, which is world capital of Rumi cult; annual festival is city's main tourist attraction; map; photo (M)

headline: Medtronic Set To Buy Arterial For $3.7 Billion
abstract: Medtronic Inc, pacemaker manufacturer, to acquire Arterial Vascular Engineering Inc for $54 a share, or $3.7 billion in Medtronic stock (M)

headline: Slain St. Petersburg Lawmaker Mourned
abstract: Mourners bearing flowers and candles stage demonstration outside St Petersburg, Russia, home of Galina V Starovoitova, founder of country's democratic movement who was shot to death on November 20; photo (S)

headline: Misfortune of Hedge Funds Is Converted Into Bargains
abstract: Article on bargains that can be found in convertible bonds, which have fallen 21.5 percent since April 30; graph (S)

headline: If You Can't Get Enough Talk, Tune Into New Internet Shows
abstract: Exeter Technologies has developed an electronic device to help drivers park in garages without bumping into walls; photo (S)

headline: Treasury's Auction Offerings for This Week Will Be Limited to Three Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to bills, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills. The Treasury will also auction a 14-day cash-management bill today.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.41 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 4.43 percent.

headline: No Yielding To Inspectors By Baghdad
abstract: Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, meets with Secretary General Kofi Annan, reportedly urging him to undertake an investigation of United Nations Special Commission, which monitors biological, chemical and missile systems; fails to gain ground, and Iraq reportedly decides not to resume cooperation with Unscom; there have been hints for days of hints that a change of policy could be imminent (M)

headline: Stephens Settles Bribery Cases In Florida, Paying $5.4 Million
abstract: Stephens Inc agrees to pay $5.4 million to settle Federal 'pay to play' lawsuits contending that employees of brokerage firm paid bribes to win municipal bond business in Florida; Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission had filed civil complaints contending that the firm paid $35,200 to three Florida agencies (M)

headline: Rate Cut Expected at Bank of England
abstract: Bank of England is expected to cut benchmark interest rate a quarter-point from current rate of 7.25 percent (S)

headline: At AT&T, Cost-Cutting Lifts Earnings
abstract: AT&T Corp posts 68 percent increase in third-quarter eanrings, to $1.96 billion, up from $1.16 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue grew by fastest rate in almost two-years--4.3 percent--to $13.7 billion from $13.1 billion in year-earlier period; earnings growth linked to aggressive cost-cutting measure (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    IRAN: TALIBAN DISPUTE OVER, ENVOY SAYS -- A United Nations special envoy said that the threat of a confrontation between Iran and Afghanistan's ruling Taliban militia had passed. The envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, spoke in Teheran after more than a week of shuttle diplomacy during which he sought to defuse tensions that threatened to grow into a military clash. Iran sent more than 200,000 troops to its border with Afghanistan after Taliban forces killed eight Iranian diplomats and a journalist in August, and a limited clash between the two sides was reported early this month. In meetings with Taliban officials, Mr. Brahimi gained the release of 26 Iranian prisoners and a promise by the Taliban to hold direct talks with Iran.   Douglas Jehl (NYT)

headline: His Next Global Investment: Gas, Oil and Lots of Tires
abstract: Former hedge-fund manager Jim Rogers, 56, plans three-year drive around world in vehicle made from Mercedes SLK and Mercedes Galaendawagen sport utility vehicle as Millennium project; photo (S)

headline: Sweetening a Bitter Pill at Upjohn
abstract: Article on Fred Hassan, who was executive vice president of American Home Products when he jumped ship two years ago to become chief executive of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc; Pharmacia's current poor standing has not deterred Hassan from staying in post; photo (M)

headline: National Semiconductor Loss Below Expectations
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp reports smaller-than-expected loss for second quarter ended Nov 29; reports deficit of $94.4 million, compared with earnings of $28.9 million in year-earlier period; sales fell 29 percent, to $510.1 million from $719.9 million (M)

headline: Issue in Iran Democracy Debate: Clerics' Power
abstract: Iranians have begun to question ruling religious establishment in ways unthinkable only year ago, often spurring harsh backlash by and on behalf of Islamic clerics; few have openly dared to espouse full democracy, but open debate has begun about whether clerics alone should have power to chose supreme leader; some supporters of Pres Mohammad Khatami are arguing that panel of religious experts that names leader should also include women and laymen (M)

headline: Bankers Trust Deal Near, Deutsche Bank Confirms
abstract: FRANKFURT—  Deutsche Bank AG said Monday it was in the final stages of forming the world's biggest financial-services firm with the acquisition of Bankers Trust Corp.

headline: Burma's Shan Rebels Wrestle With the Trappings of Peace
abstract: OM MU, Burma—  To hear the leaders of the Shan State Army tell it, the nine-year truce in their fight against Burma's central government has done little to demoralize, disband or disarm their rebellion.

headline: ALZA PLANS TO ACQUIRE SEQUUS PHARMACEUTICALS
abstract: Alza Corp agrees to acquire Sequus Pharmaceuticals Inc in stock swap valued about $580 million (S)

headline: Bosses Beware When Bending the Truth
abstract: Article by Prof Jeffrey L Seglin on problems that can arise when culture of lying with impunity is perceived to have taken hold at top of an organization; notes once an executive blurs rules about what is acceptable, many in rank and file will conclude they are free, and perhaps ought to, emulate their bosses (M)

headline: WELSH, CARSON REDUCES OFFER FOR CENTENNIAL CELLULAR
abstract: Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe LP lowers price it will pay for Centennial Cellular Corp to $41.50 a share from $43.50; change reduces price by $60 million; price was about $1.5 billion in cash when it was announced in July (S)

headline: Coping With an Illness
abstract: Letter from Judy Saphir on Dec 10 article on Web site on ulcerative colitis (S)

headline: Antitrust Case Relies Heavily on Events at a 1995 Meeting
abstract: Justice Department's case against Microsoft Corp is narrative that revolves around Netscape Communications Corp and Government's leading witness, James L Barksdale, Netscape's 55-year-old president and chief executive; in Barksdale's 127 pages of written testimony, he supplies new details and first-hand perspective of disputed meeting between Microsoft and Netscape on June 21, 1995, at Netscape's offices in California; Government contends that at the meeting Microsoft executives proposed that two companies divvy up emerging market for software used to browse Internet's World Wide Web; Microsoft replies that prosecutors are misinterpreting routine business meeting; if court accepts Barksdale's version of meeting, it will represent big victory for Justice Department and 20 states suing Microsoft (M)

headline: In Mayoral Race in Taipei, Some Politics Is Global
abstract: Mayoral election in Taipei, in which the incumbent, Chen Shui-bian, faces challenge from Ma Ying-jeou, could upset Taiwan's precarious standoff with China and set stage for presidential election in March 2000; Ma is candidate of Nationalist Party, which seeks to run Taiwan like an independent country but swears homage to long-term goal of unifying with mainland; Chen, member of upstart Democratic Progressive Party, is committed to eventual goal of Taiwan's independence; victory by Chen would make him almost unbeatable if he runs for President; Nationalists are expected to retain control of legislature; photos (M)

headline: British Company Sells Canadian Property Unit
abstract: British property company Hammerson PLC to sell its Hammerson Canada Inc to Omers Realty Corp for net sum of 238 million pounds in cash, or $394.8 million (US) (S)
