headline: SHARES OF GROW BIZ RISE 32% ON NEWS OF BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Stock of Grow Biz International jumps 32 percent after company says it received $14-a-share cash buyout offer from two of its executives, chairman K Jeffrey Dahlberg and chief executive Ronald G Olson (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Treasury bonds rise for seventh session, longest streak since September 1993; benchmark 30-year bond yields five percent (S)

headline: Aetna Agrees to Buy Prudential Care Unit
abstract: Aetna agreed to buy Prudential Health Care from the Prudential Insurance Company for $1 billion, creating the nation's biggest managed care company.

headline: Borden Consolidates At Campbell Mithun
abstract: Borden Foods Corp expands relationship with Campbell Mithun Esty by consolidating creative duties for its American brands agency (S)

headline: Fuji Bank to Issue 503 Billion New Shares
abstract: Fuji Bank says it will raise 217 billion yen ($1.86 billion) through private placement of new shares with 60 companies, including Yasuda Life Insurance Co (S)

headline: Chinese President Setting Out for Visits to Both Russia and Japan
abstract: China's Pres Jiang Zemin leaves for visits to Russia and Japan; will meet with ailing Pres Boris Yeltsin; trip to Japan will be first by Chinese Communist head of state; visit to Russia is latest of several summits between giant neighbors, who seem determined to foster friendly ties despite history of feuding (M)

headline: COULTER AND SMITHKLINE IN CANCER DRUG PACT
abstract: Coulter Pharmaceutical Inc and SmithKline Beecham PLC to jointly market Coulter's Bexxar treatment for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma; deal could be worth up to $132 million plus shared profits and royalties to Coulter, which will get up-front payment of $41.5 million (S)1

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises against Japanese yen for third day amid doubts that officials in Tokyo have done enough to strengthen ailing banking system; dollar rises to 117.87 yen from 117 on Sept 21; graph; chart (S)

headline: Optimistic Consumers Drive Home Resales Up Sharply
abstract: National Assn of Realtors says home resales rose in November to second-strongest rate ever, energized by optimistic consumers, low mortgage rates and job gains; resales increase 2.7 percent to annual rate of 4.90 million units, compared with record 4.91 million units reached in July; sales are expected to set annual record in 1998 for third consecutive year (S)

headline: Columbia Sues Ex-Executive And Vendors
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp sues former vice president Samuel A Greco and several vendors, accusing them of engaging in conspiracy over seven years that defrauded company of millions of dollars; scheme described in racketeering lawsuit stems from Columbia's purchasing program, which was coordinated and overseen by Greco; lawsuit also names Norman R Dobiesz, contending that he controlled vendors like Florida Software Systems and Receivable Dynamics, which were among others named as defendants (M)

headline: Kia Motors' Suitor Must Now Face Reluctant Bankers
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co, which has won auction to take controlling interest in bankrupt Kia Motors Corp and its Asia Motors subsidiary, must wait to see if Kia's creditors will agree to bid; Korea Development Bank, Kia's largest creditor, says creditors will meet soon to discuss results of latest auction (M)

headline: Caserta Journal; The Italian Military Is Under Siege, in a Museum
abstract: Controversy is simmering in Italy over proper use of Reggia di Caserta, Royal Palace in Caserta; palace, one of most imposing in Europe, houses a museum, but most of it is occupied by air force training school for noncommissioned officers; Italian Culture Ministry wants military out; photo (M)

headline: Communists and Workers March to Denounce Yeltsin
abstract: Communists and trade unionists lead nationwide strike to protest Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin's rule; thousands of protesters march in Moscow; strikers briefly block road, Vladivostok; marches draw only small fraction of ten million demonstrators Communists expected; life basically goes on as usual, despite thousands of short, symbolic work stoppages; photos (M)

headline: At the U.N., a Pinch Hitter; Holbrooke's Benched for Now
abstract: Amb A Peter Burleigh has been filling in as United States representative to United Nations since Aug, while Pres Clinton's choice for post, Richard C Holbrooke, awaits Justice Department clearance, nomination and confirmation; Burleigh, career diplomat, has been leading American mission through season of multiple crises (M)

headline: Where Russians Are Hurting, Racism Takes Root
abstract: Racism takes root in Krasnodar, Russia, where refugees from former Soviet empire have settled in ruins of local economy; scapegoats are usually Jews, who are regarded as part of sinister worldwide conspiracy to bring Russia to its knees, and Turks; international human rights groups have put Krasnodar and neighboring Stavropol on its watch list; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices weaken on forecasts for mild weather, which would reduce demand for heating fuel; December contract declines 7.3 cents, to $2.275 for 1,000 cubic feet; graph; chart (S)

headline: ELTRAX AGREES TO BUY SULCUS FOR $66 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Eltrax Systems Inc to buy Sulcus Hospitality Technologies Inc for $66 million in stock (S)

headline: Ad Revenues Decline at Some Newspapers
abstract: Most newspaper companies have gained at least as much as they have lost despite gyrations of world's financial markets; Wall Street Journal's third-quarter advertising volume was down about 6.7 percent over year-earlier figure, but Miles Groves, chief economist for Newspaper Assn of America, claims Journal's revenue decline is anomaly because it is traditional vehicle for financial services advertising; Groves expects spending by companies and individuals advertising in newspapers to increase by more than 6 percent this year (M)

headline: Two Depart at Fox and Universal After TV and Film Setbacks; Shifting Priorities Lead To Biondi's Dismissal
abstract: Frank Biondi Jr is ousted as chairman of Universal Studios by Edgar Bronfman Jr, chief executive of Seagram Co, parent of Universal; Biondi will be replaced by Ron Meyer, president and chief operating officer at Universal, who will report directly to Bronfman; Meyer will oversee three of Universal's businesses: movies, television and theme parks; separately, Doug Morris, chairman of Universal's music business, will also report to Bronfman; Bronfman comments on how shifts will help company run more smoothly, interview; industry analyst says Biondi's expertise was in television and cable, not in the areas he was involved in at Universal (M)

headline: A Japan Collaboration on Car Technology
abstract: Hitachi Ltd, Japan's largest electronics maker, and Nissan Motor Co announce that they plan to collaborate on developing advanced technology for cars; Hitachi will most likely make equity investment in Unisia Jecs Corp, struggling auto parts maker affiliated with Nissan (M)

headline: Sinn Fein Leader Says He'll Urge I.R.A. Not to Retaliate for Killing
abstract: Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army, says he will urge organization not to retaliate for Oct 31 killing of Brian Service, Catholic man, appparently by Protestants in Belfast; death has heightened tension around stalled Northern Ireland peace effort, which are bogged down over issue of IRA disarmament and formation of new provisional Government to enact peace agreement approved in spring; Red Hand Defenders, small Protestant paramilitary group, has claimed responsibility (M)

headline: Survivor Aid by 2 Groups Called Slow
abstract: World Jewish Restitution Organization, umbrella group led by Edgar Bronfman Sr, and Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, Jewish groups that may play major role in distributing Swiss bank money, have had problems in past getting aid quickly to aging Holocaus survivors; survivors in United States are only now about to see money from $200 million Swiss bank fund restitution group agreed to help distribute 18 months ago and those in Israel will wait many months more (M)o

headline: A Great Day for Tire-Kicking, But Maybe Not for More
abstract: Ward's Dealer Business, automobile dealership trade magazine, reports that it is still difficult for people to buy cars on Sunday (S)

headline: Providian Stock Buyback
abstract: Providian Financial Corp will repurchase $500 million in common stock, or about 5.2 million shares (S)

headline: Electronics Stake Is Sold
abstract: C-MAC Industries agrees to acquire from AMP Inc 50 percent interest in Carolina Circuits Co that it does not already own; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Bank of America Settles Suits From California
abstract: Bank of America agrees to pay $187.5 million to settle charges by California state and local governments that it mishandled hundreds of millions of dollars of bond payments between 1978 and 1995 (M)

headline: Philippine Airlines' Unions Approve a Recovery Plan
abstract: Philippine Airlines' employees approve recovery plan one week after carrier suspended operations; airline says it will resume domestic flights on Oct 7; employees will give up collective-bargaining agreement for 10 years in return for 20 percent stake in airline and three seats on the board (M)

headline: Microsoft Disputes Netscape Meeting Account
abstract: John Warden, Microsoft Corp's lead counsel, portrays company's competitor in Internet software business, Netscape Communications Corp, as willing and eager participant in deal-making that culminated in June 1995 meeting at which Government and Netscape now say that Microsoft illegally offered to divide the market; Justice Department publicizes E-mail that seems to support elements of Government's account; memo, from Dan Rosen, senior Microsoft executive who attended meeting with Netscape's leaders, was written by Microsoft chairman William H Gates and others; it summarizes meeting and begins with list of goals that include 'establish Microsoft ownership' of market for World Wide Web browsers that run Windows computers; Netscape president-chief executive James L Barksdale expresses anger during third day of cross-examination by Warden; photo (M)

headline: 2 European Drug Giants Talk of Merger
abstract: Zeneca Group PLC, third-largest British drug maker, and Astra AB of Sweden are discussing merger of equals that would be worth at least $30 billion and create world's fourth-largest pharmaceutical company; deal would divide key management positions between the two companies; photo (M)

headline: In search of Mick? A new VH1 campaign offers brief visits with some of the rock 'n' roll pantheon.
abstract: Advertising column on VH-1 cable channel's new advertising campaign, which offers intimate inside glimpses into lives and careers of most popular and successful singers and songwriters; channel is seeking to capitalize on recent gains in viewership and advertising revenue (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Access Graphics advertising account is awarded to Barnhart/CMI Marketing, Advertising and Public Relations (S)

headline: Discounters Report Strong Holiday Sales
abstract: Specialty stores and discounters outdistance major department store chains in holiday sales during November; chart shows retail sales in November; table shows results for various stores (M)

headline: Third-Quarter Profit Fell 16% at DuPont
abstract: DuPont Co says third-quarter profit fell 16 percent, to $610 million from $725 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 4.3 percent, to $6.04 billion from $5.79 billion (S)

headline: Compressed Data; First Boston Moves To Polish Its Image
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston's technology banking team, lagging in business of advising on technology mergers and acquisitions, is opening its annual client conference to press in apparent effort to polish image (S)

headline: Corrected Tables
abstract: Closed-end fund table in Money & Business section on Oct 25 carried week-old data because of computer malfunction at Lipper Analytical Services; corrected table appears Oct 27 on page C25

headline: Israel Calmly Readies Itself, Just in Case
abstract: Israelis calmly pick up gas masks in case of Iraqi missile attack; people in Ramat Gan, which was hit hard by Iraqi missiles during Persian Gulf war, comment on latest crisis; Israeli officials are keeping low profile, avoiding threats of retaliation even as US prepares for possible military strike (S)

headline: Ogilvy Atlanta Wins William Carter Account
abstract: The William Carter Company, the children's apparel maker in Morrow, Ga., said yesterday that it had named Ogilvy & Mather Atlanta to handle its account, which had been handled since 1993 by Sietsma Engel in Minneapolis, now closed. Though billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $1.5 million to $2 million.

headline: The War as Art: NBC Borrows From a Game
abstract: Computer games on military subjects described; photo (Game Theory column) (S)

headline: Retailers Say October Sales Were Better Than Expected
abstract: Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd says retailers across the nation reported better-than-expected 4.8 percent sales rise in October, led by demand for clothes at specialty shops and name-brand goods at discount retailers; sales figures for specific retailers noted (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Jobless Rate Slips to 4.4%, Nearing 3-Decade Low  Despite fears that 1998 still could turn out to be the decade's worst year for layoffs, more Americans than ever are working, the Government said. United States employers added 267,000 workers to their payrolls in November as the jobless rate slipped to 4.4 percent, near a three-decade low.    It was the biggest gain in payrolls in three months and matched the pace of the year's first half, when many on Wall Street were more fearful of an overheated economy than of a recession. [Page A1.]    Mylan Said to Face F.T.C. Lawsuit  The Federal Government is preparing to accuse Mylan Laboratories, a big generic drug maker, of anti-competitive practices. The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has recommended filing a civil action against the company, which it said sharply raised the prices of its products after trying to corner the market on the drugs' raw materials. [A1.]    Unocal Quits Pipeline Project  Unocal has withdrawn from a consortium that planned an $8 billion energy pipeline system traversing war-torn Afghanistan, a company official said. The consortium, which brought together companies from Saudi Arabia, Japan, South Korea and Pakistan, had planned to build twin oil and gas pipelines from Turkmenistan to the Pakistan port of Gwadar. [C2.]    Republic Hires Sears Marketer  Republic Industries hired a top Sears, Roebuck marketing executive to be its president as part of its drive to raise the profile of its Autonation USA unit. John H. Costello, left, will be responsible for developing the marketing for the company, which owns the nation's largest chain of franchised new and used automobile dealerships. He will also oversee its retail and rental operations. [C2.]    Hollinger Selling 45 Newspapers  Hollinger International, the second-largest United States newspaper group, will sell 45 newspapers to Community Newspaper Holdings for $475 million. Hollinger said the papers to be sold are in 14 states. [C3.]    Buyers Bid Up Ubid Initial Offer  The stock of the on-line auction company Ubid ended the first day of trading with its shares closing at $48 -- more than three times the $15 offering price. Coming in the aftermath of several run-ups by Internet initial public offerings the last month, Ubid was able to offer the stock at a price beyond the original estimated range of $12 to $14. [C2.]    Scottish Power in Pacificorp Talks  Scottish Power was said to be discussing a deal to acquire Pacificorp, a big utility in the Northwest. The value of the potential deal was not known, but two British newspapers reported last month that Scottish Power wanted to buy Pacificorp for $6.6 billion. [C3.]    $1.5 Million Award in Air Bag Death  A Federal jury in Manhattan awarded $1.5 million to the estate of a 5-year-old boy killed after an air bag deployed in the front seat of a Dodge minivan where he had been riding without a fastened seat belt. DaimlerChrysler, the minivan maker, called the verdict unfair. [B2.]    Struggle Over Kenya Beer Market  The maker of Kenya's best-selling beer, which was named Tusker after one of the brewery's founders was killed by an elephant, is facing another behemoth. South African Breweries has taken on East African Breweries and its partner, Guinness, in what has quickly become a war over more than beer. [A4.]    Mexico Bank Bailout Held Up  After nine months of grueling debate, Mexican lawmakers have reached broad agreement on measures to refinance the Government's troubled $61 billion bank bailout. But a final accord has been stymied by a dispute over a top Government finance official. [A6.]    Rises Fuel Insurance Spiral  Many of the 16 million people under 65 who have to buy their own health insurance are facing increases of 40 percent or more this fall, creating a dynamic that appears likely to send prices even higher. [A7.]

headline: Council Seeks Punishment For the Kosovo Massacre
abstract: UN Security Council, prodded by Britain and United States, condemns recent atrocities against civilians in Kosovo and demands that those guilty be caught and punished; photo of Sir Jeremy Greenstock of Britain (M)

headline: Seoul's Luckless Feel Pain And Look to Orphanages
abstract: Children from very normal South Korean families are being left at orphanages in a indication of the psychological toll of country's economic tailspin, which has put hundreds of thousands of people out of work; other indications are a rise in insurance fraud, a rise in suicides and growing ranks of people living with relatives, in shelters or on the street; photos (M)

headline: Israeli Blocs: Humpty-Dumptys Right and Left
abstract: Israeli Parliament, united in bringing down Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, is expected to splinter into one of broadest playing fields in Israel's electoral history, where no outcome is predictable; Netanyahu, though seemingly isolated within political establishment, may still prove adept at wooing voters with pledge to protect Israel from Palestinians; Parliament, now made up of 11 parties, may include 19 by time elections are held; photos (M)

headline: Honduran Army's Abuses Were Known to C.I.A.
abstract: Newly declassified CIA report shows agency knew about hundreds of human rights abuses by Honduran army during 1980's, when US was supplying millions of dollars in military aid; shows although officers in Honduras knew military operated right-wing assassination squad, their poor reporting on human rights problems left senior agency officials unaware of their seriousness and scope; shows agency sometimes gave misleading information to Congress, downplaying Honduran involvement in abuses in part so as not to jeopardize country's crucial support for rebels fighting against Sandinista Government in Nicaragua (M)

headline: A Name So Smooth, the Product Glides In
abstract: VM Labs to offer microchip, called Nuon, that will be powering DVD players and settop boxes; idea behind Nuon is to piggyback video game platform on top of digital video system so people will find themselves playing video games; Lexicon, professional naming agency, came up with name Nuon; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises against dollar; graphs; table (S)

headline: LOCKHEED MARTIN SHARES FALL ON ACCOUNTING DISCLOSURE
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp, in Securities and Exchange Commission filing, says that a quarter of its third-quarter per-share earnings came from an accounting adjustment; disclosure is a factor in stock dropping $5.0625, to $101.9375 a share (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY    Xerox Corp

headline: Close Races and Wild Cards as U.S. Votes
abstract: WASHINGTON—  American voters headed into the midterm elections Tuesday with local issues generally uppermost in their minds but with the White House sex scandal making predictions dicey.

headline: Biederman Agency Revises Its Name
abstract: Biederman, Kelly & Shaffer changes its name to Biederman Kelly Krimstein & Partners; new partner is Ken Krimstein, chief creative officer (S)

headline: Real Estate Investment Trusts Expect a Slower 4th Quarter
abstract: National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts reports REIT's, unwilling to use their stock to finance acquisitions, bought $8.1 billion of property in third quarter, down 39 percent from second quarter and lowest amount since start of 1997; analysts say figures for fourth quarter will be even lower (M)

headline: Grenades Wound 67 in Israeli Bus Station
abstract: Grenade attack on bus terminal in Bersheeba, Israel, injures 67 people and casts shadow over fragile peace summit between Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat at Maryland retreat; third of victims in morning rush-hour explosions are soldiers and military students; attacker is identified as 29-year-old Palestinian construction worker, Salem Rajab al-Sarsour; photo; map (M)

headline: PATRIOT AMERICAN HOSPITALITY IS SELLING STAKE
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc agrees to sell about 30 percent stake for $1 billion to investor group led by financiers Leon Black and Thomas Lee (S)

headline: Morgan Sees Earnings Slide; Citigroup Unit May Be Sold
abstract: J P Morgan & Co says its fourth-quarter earnings will fall far short of analysts' expectations; Citigroup says it is considering sale of its Phibro Inc commodity trading unit; says Federal banking regulations require it to dispose of businesses that trade commodities for Citigroup's own account (M)

headline: U.S. Again Seeks Forensic Study On Killings in Kosovo Villages
abstract: US calls for forensic experts to investigate massacres of Kosovo villagers; NATO ambassadors meet in Brussels to plan strike against Serbian troops; United Nations Security Council sets emergency session for Oct 1 (M)

headline: From Palestinian or Israeli, The Attitude Is Skepticism
abstract: Palestinians and Israelis, be they religious or secular, are seen in complete accord on one item: Wye peace conference is not Oslo, in their eyes; they indicate that any legal agreement that would be signed at Wye Plantation in Maryland by two leaders who deeply mistrust each other would not be cause for either panic or celebration engendered by Oslo peace accord in 1993; hoto (M)cve

headline: INVESTING WITH: Tweedy, Browne & Co.
abstract: Carole Gould (Investing) column evaluates performance of Tweedy, Browne & Co, whose return on its managed accounts since 1975 has averaged 19.1 percent, versus 16.4 percent for S&P 500; photo; chart on performance of firm's funds (L)

headline: Uninstaller Programs Can Ease File Cleanup
abstract: Q. What do commercial uninstall programs do that I can't do by myself?    A. Although Windows 95 and 98 include an Add/Remove Programs utility, many users believe that this function doesn't quite clear out all the remains of uninstalled applications. Unneeded temporary files, outdated or unused fonts, D.L.L.'s (dynamic-link library files), old shortcuts and duplicate files can be left behind, taking up hard drive space and cluttering your system. The fear of deleting a file that seems to be a leftover but is actually needed by the system frightens many users into leaving it where it is.

headline: Earnings Climb At Tobacco Giant
abstract: British American Tobacco PLC says third-quarter profit rose 31 percent, to 207 million pounds ($346 million) from 158 million pounds last year (S)

headline: German Utility Expects Decline in Earnings
abstract: Viag AG, Germany's number 3 utility, indicates third-quarter pretax profit fell 7.2 percent; implied quarterly pretax profit fell to 634 million marks ($378 million) from 683 million marks a year earlier (S)

headline: Not (Yet) Gone the Way of All Asia
abstract: China enters politically dangerous era of slower growth and rising unemployment, even though economy has held ground in midst of Asian economic collapse; Govt leaders, eager to head off severe slump and social unrest, are using every Keynesian tool at their disposal to stimulate domestic investment and demand; they have, at same time, delayed badly needed overhaul of bloated state industries and overstretched banks; critics warn country is creating even bigger, more costly problems for banks and industries later on, but officials say they have no choice; chart (M)

headline: Eli Lilly to Pay Sepracor $90 Million to License Drug
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co will pay Sepracor Inc up to $90 million to license molecule that is purer form of Prozac, Lilly's market-leading antidepressant; Sepracor will also receive undisclosed royalty on sales of drug, R-fluoxetine, which is expected to have fewer side effects than Prozac; photo of Sepracor president, Timothy Barberich (M)

headline: Bell Atlantic Sets Fast Web Access
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp says it is offering high-speed Internet access in Washington and Pittsburgh, supported by marketing alliances with computer companies, to meet demand for faster connections to computer networks; Bell Atlantic also announces partnership with Cnet Inc's and NBC's Snap Internet search directory (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL CABLE CORP., Highland Heights, Ky., a maker of copper, aluminum and fiber optic wire and cable products, agreed to acquire Industria Venezolana de Cables Electricos C.A., a Venezuelan wire and cable maker. Terms were not disclosed.    SCHUFF STEEL CO., Phoenix, said it would acquire Bannister Steel Inc., based in National City, Calif., for $16.8 million, to strengthen its position in Southern California.

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.69   4.71   5.29        3-month T-bills   4.30   4.32   5.08        6-month T-bills   4.36   4.37   5.25        10-yr. headline: CD Radio Gets Backing for Car Network
abstract: CD Radio Inc says it will get an investment of as much as $200 million from affiliates of Apollo Management LP, headed by the investor Leon Black, as it seeks more financing for its satellite-to-car digital radio network; CD Radio is building $965 million space-based network that will broadcast music and other programming directly into subscribers' automobiles (S)

headline: Latin Markets Fall as Brazil Rejects Reform
abstract: Markets throughout Latin America plunge after Brazilian Congress votes down increase in pension contributions by public employees, delivering unexpected blow to Government's pledges of economic reform; while defeat represents loss of estimated $2.2 billion in revenue, vote's damage is more severe in political and psychological terms; legislative defeat also raises concerns about Brazil's ability to meet terms of its agreement for $41.5 billion in credit from IMF; photos (L)

headline: MEN'S WEARHOUSE ENDS OFFER FOR MOORES RETAIL
abstract: Men's Warehouse Inc, citing stock market conditions, terminates talks to acquire Moores Retail Group Inc (S)

headline: In the End, King Hussein Played Critical Role in Coaxing Peace
abstract: All parties to Mideast negotiations say that King Hussein of Jordan, longest serving leader in Middle East, played critical role in bringing two sides together;it is latest and perhaps one of final chapters in his long history of coaxing Arab world and Israel to accommodation if not peace, and it cast him as conscience to the region; King Hussein is present at peace talks in between rounds of chemotherapy for treatment of non-Hodgkins lymphoma; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.75   6.14   5.52        3-month T-bills   4.12   4.24   4.92        6-month T-bills   4.20   4.31   5.02        10-yr. T-infl.   3.51   3.56   3.58        10-yr. T-note   4.28   4.41   5.99        30-yr. T-bond   4.88   4.97   6.30        Telephone bd.   6.80   6.88   7.38        Municipal bds.   4.99   5.04   5.42          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge   Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Party Pointers
abstract: Consulting firm Executive Communications Group offers business people tips on how to 'see and be seen' at holiday parties (S)

headline: Big Board Firms Report Losses
abstract: Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange lost $117 million in the third quarter, down from a profit of $2.18 billion in the period a year earlier, according to report from the exchange (S)

headline: Can Teutonic qualities help Beck's double its beer sales in six years?
abstract: Brauerei Beck & Co, German brewer of Beck's beer, to use campaign developed by creative team from unit of Saatchi & Saatchi PLC to spur sales of Beck's beer in the United States; television commercials, which will be broadcast during sports events and late-night shows starting next week, poke fun at Germans; sales of Beck's beer rose 11 percent last year, to 7.4 million cases from 6.7 million, still lower than eight million cases sold in 1990, peak year for Beck's in the US; ad photo (Advertising)

headline: Four A's Addresses Review Problems
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York is undertaking three initiatives meant to address problems that occur in advertising agency review process (S)

headline: Soviet Mindset Blocks Capitalism on Farms
abstract: Agriculture remains least reformed sector of Russian economy, despite vaunted talk of building free market; nation's chronically inefficient collective farms have been relabeled rather than reorganized as Govt has refused to approve sale of farmland and has done little to help fiercely conservative farmers cope with brave new world of capitalism; distress has been compounded by virtual collapse of banking system and ruinous drought; harvests are at lowest point in 45 years and production of staples continues to plummet--leaving country heavily dependent on imports; conditions at state-owned collective near Novogorod described; photos; map (M)

headline: GLOBAL MOTORSPORT REJECTS GOLDEN CYCLE OFFER
abstract: Global Motorsport Group rejects offer by Golden Cycle LLC to buy substantially all of company's outstanding shares for $20 each, or about $103 million (S)

headline: S.E.C. Says Trader Cost AT&T Pension Fund a $150 Million Loss
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission contends in lawsuit that Boston trader Bing Sung cost pension fund for employees of AT&T Corp $150 million in 1996 as he made huge unauthorized bets on direction of technology stocks; holds Sung also lost $12 million belonging to pension fund for Massachusetts teachers and state employees; Sung managed hundreds of millions of dollars for two funds for at least three years while he was chief investment officer of Rhumbline Advisers, a firm that mostly manages funds meant to mirror performance of stock indexes; commission sues Sung, accusing him of securities fraud and seeking unspecified monetary damages; also announces that Rhumbline and its chief executive John D Nelson, agreed to fines and other penalties to settle SEC proceeding against them for failing to adequately supervise Sung (M)

headline: VW Profit Surged In the 3d Quarter
abstract: Wolkswagen AG says profit in third quarter rose better-than-expected 86 percent, to 676 million marks ($916 million) from 364 million marks last year (S)

headline: Brazilian Economic Plan Encounters Some Naysayers
abstract: Brazilian Government's $23.5 billion austerity package, which is crucial for securing International Monetary Fund credit and restoring Brazil's fiscal credibility, goes before Brazilian Congress, where reaction foreshadows bitter political wrangling to come; while most legislators embrace need for savings, they contest Government's formula, which relies on tax increases and pension payments from workers to meet more than half the promised amount; Finance Minister Pedro Malan and Gustavo Franco, president of central bank, field questions and criticims from senators, many belonging to Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso's party or to allied parties in government coalition; Brazil's benchmark stock index closes down 4.2 percent on day most other Latin American markets rise; chart highlights measures in austerity package; photo (M)

headline: EMPIRE TO BUY A RIVAL CANADIAN GROCERY CHAIN
abstract: Empire Co to acquire Oshawa Group for about $1.5 billion (Canadian), or $972 million (US) in cash and stock (S)

headline: 2 B-1's Join Iraq Combat And Gain Vindication
abstract: Controversial B-1 bomber is used in combat for first time in air raids over Iraq; struck military complex near Baghdad on second day of attack with 500-pound bombs (M)

headline: The Cisco Whiz Kid; Young Deal Maker Is Force Behind Company's Growth
abstract: Profile of Michelangelo Volpi, who at age 31 is vice president for business development at Cisco Systems Inc, San Jose, Calif; Volpi's reputation as one of most influential deal makers in technology is aided by the market valuation of Cisco's stock, which is nearly 500 percent above where it was at beginning of 1996; he has been instrumental in talks for 27 of 29 companies acquired since 1993 by Cisco, which is one of most active companies in pursuing acquisitions; Volpi career sketch; his photo; chart on Cisco's acquisitions from 1996-1998 (L)

headline: KINROSS GOLD TAKING CHARGE TO WRITE DOWN MINES' VALUE
abstract: Kinross Gold Corp to take fourth-quarter charge of $216.1 million, that includes cost of its acquisition of Amax Gold Inc (S)

headline: Federal Judge Deals Microsoft A Setback on Antitrust Lawsuit
abstract: US District Court Judge Richard Stearns, Boston, deals Microsoft Corp a setback in its pretrial antitrust suit preparations by denying the company access to interview tapes and transcripts for book Competing on Internet Time; as yet unpublished book by Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School Prof Michael A Cusumano and Harvard Business School Prof David B Yoffie is based largely on interviews with Netscape Communications Corp executives (M)

headline: Top U.N. Arms Inspector Tries to Quiet Ex-Iraq Team Member
abstract: Richard Butler, head of United Nations' Iraqi disarmament commission, says that he has ordered Scott Ritter, American inspector who quit in anger in August, to stop revealing information he gathered on the job (M)

headline: VULCAN VENTURES TO INVEST IN ZIFF-DAVIS'S ZDTV CHANNEL
abstract: Vulcan Ventures Inc, controlled by billionaire investor Paul G Allen, to invest $54 million in Ziff-Davis Inc's ZDTV, a 24-hour cable TV channel that deals with computing and the Internet; Ziff-Davis, unit of Softbank Corp, Japan, also says it plans to exercise its option to buy the TV channel from Softbank's MAC Inc unit; MAC owns 43 percent of Softbank (S)

headline: FERTILIZER COMPANY SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 530 JOBS
abstract: IMC Global Inc will cut 530 jobs, or about 5.9 percent of its work force, as part of drive to reduce costs, increase profit and accelerate growth (S)

headline: PRIVATE SECTOR; The Speaker Gets A New Platform
abstract: Newt Gingrich, outgoing House Speaker, will join advisory board of Forstmann Little & Co, privateinvestment firm; photo (S)

headline: A Financial Limbo
abstract: A measure that supporters say would modernize the nation's financial system and make it more globally competitive is stuck in Congress, caught in the crosscurrents of several political fights, including the D'Amato-Schumer Senate race.    Article, page A14.

headline: Clinton Putting Off Visits to India and Pakistan
abstract: White House says Pres Clinton has postponed visit to India and Pakistan, whose tests of nuclear devices in May set off alarm around world; says Clinton will not make separate visit to Bangladesh, but will go ahead with plans to attend meeting of Asia Pacific Economic Conference in Malaysia in mid-Nov (M)

headline: Not Going Gentle Into Off-Line Night
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (User's Guide) column on being disconnected from network by America Online when browser determined she was not using service and another time when she used a non-AOL browser; says her solution was to download software package Stay On Pro 2.6, distributed by RC Computer Labs of Colorado Springs, which employs an 'idle timmer' from disconnecting you; says at $19.95 program sounded so good she contacted AOL to learn the company prohibits programs such as Stay On Pro, but also found out AOL has no way of enforcing the ban (M)

headline: Bandwidth: More Is Better
abstract: Circuits Q&A column, explains term bandwidth in relation to computers

headline: NATIONAL-OILWELL ACQUIRING A BUSINESS FROM WESTBURNE
abstract: National-Oilwell Inc to buy Westburne Inc's oil and natural-gas field-supply business for about $58.6 million in stock and debt securities to expand its services in Canada and to cut operating costs (S)

headline: U.S. Says Palestinians, Too, Fail to Observe Peace Accord Fully
abstract: Senior American and Israeli officials say Israel has frozen its compliance with recent accords, but Palestinian Authority is not fully complying with its commitments either; among problems they cite are incendiary Palestinian statements about prisoner releases and lagging efforts to confiscate illegal firearms and to cut security forces; Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader, has denied Israel's charges that Palestinians are violating accords reached in Wye, Md, in October; American officials are trying to get Palestinians to meet their obligations, which would make it easier for Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu to keep selling accord to Israeli Cabinet; Americans are also pressing Palestinian officials to stop any statements that would qualify as incitement to violence as Pres Clinton prepares to fly to Middle East on Dec 12 (M)

headline: Facing Severe Shortage of Food, Russia Seeks Foreign Relief Aid
abstract: Russia, rocked by worst harvest in 45 years and plummeting ruble, seeks relief aid from European Union, United States and Canada; Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov seeks aid, meeting with European Union Pres Jacques Santer; graph; photo (M)

headline: Lilly Pays Big Fee Up Front To Share in Rival of Viagra
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co and Icos Corp will form joint venture to develop and sell anti-impotency drug that some evidence suggests could be superior to Pfizer's Viagra; Lilly agrees to pay Icos, biotechnology start-up company that owns rights to drug, an up-front fee of $75 million; in another unusual arrangement, the two companies will share marketing and sales of drug in North America and in Europe and split profits 50-50 (M)

headline: Airtouch Names Mediacom as Buyer
abstract: Airtouch Cellular subsidiary of Airtouch Communications names Mediacom in New York to handle its national media buying account (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY     Elcor    Lubrizol    Stewart Info Svcs    Summit Pptys    Total Sys Svcs

headline: Trail of Dealings With China Rocket Gear
abstract: Chronology of help that Loral Space and Communications and Hughes Space and Communciations gave China on rocket launching that Pentagon says violated defense policy (M)

headline: Doing a Number on the Boss
abstract: Wife of retired American Airlines head Robert L Crandall explains that, in order for him to distinguish more than dozen nearly identical gray suits, she sewed matching numbers into pants and jackets; photo (S)

headline: PCS Antenna Can Avoid Thick Skulls
abstract: Range Star International introduces a cell phone antenna that it says is more effective because it redirects signals away from the user's head; photo (S)

headline: John Chadwick Is Dead at 78; Solved Puzzle of Greek Tablet
abstract: John Chadwick, British linguist who played critical role in deciphering ancient Greek writings known as Linear B, died on Nov 24 at age of 78; photos (M)

headline: In the West Bank, Almost Zero Jubilation
abstract: Palestinians in West Bank town of Ramallah show little reaction to Wye River agreement that promises them 40 percent of West Bank; to Palestinians, agreement is mostly reiteration of actions already promised, in accords signed in Oslo in 1993 and 1995, and never undertaken; difference this time is that latest agreement sets precise timetable for Israeli troop withdrawal in exchange for specific Palestinian steps to eradicate terrorism; also, this agreement is trilateral one, with Americans playing guarantor, policeman and financier; wary Palestinians say these distinctions could make huge difference, or they could crumble; photo (M)

headline: Tommy Flowers, 92, Dies; Broke Nazi Codes
abstract: Tommy Flowers, British civil servant who was instrumental in breaking Nazi Codes during World War II, dies at age 92; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; At Brill's, More Light, Less 'Homework'
abstract: Steven Brill, chairman and editor in chief of media-watchdog monthly Brill's Content, says magazine is going to incorporate 'lighter style of content'; photo (S)

headline: Separatist Premier Keeps Control In Quebec's Provincial Election
abstract: Premier Lucien Bouchard and separatist Parti Quebecois retain control of Quebec in provincial elections, setting stage for bitter confrontation with rest of Canada, and possibly another referendum on independence; had greater-than-expected difficulty defeating provincial Liberal Parety leader, Jean Charest, on whom many in rest of Canada had pinned hopes to end French-speaking province's 30 years of threats to separate; fell short of votes needed to launch winnable third referendum over next few years to take Quebec out of Canada and form independent nation; Bouchard reiterates pledge to create winning conditions under which referendum can be won, while acknowledging that lower-than-expected level of support for party reflected dissatisfaction among voters that cannot be ignored; map; photos (M)

headline: IT GROUP ACQUIRING FLUOR DANIEL GTI FOR $69 MILLION
abstract: IT Group agrees to buy Fluor Daniel GTI Inc for $69 million in cash; Fluor Daniel GTI wins $147 million contract to design and build paperboard mill in Lawton, Okla, for Republic Paperboard Co (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: PINOCHET PLAN REJECTED -- British officials rejected a proposal for a Spanish judge to interview Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, in London to spare him extradition to Madrid to face genocide charges. Home Secretary Jack Straw must decide by Dec. 11 whether to proceed with the judge's extradition request. Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Arab Town Celebrates As It Sheds Occupation
abstract: Israeli military occupation ends in Qabatiya on West Bank and Palestinians rejoice; town was once hotbed of anti-Israeli resistance; Israelis complete first part of three-phase withdrawal from West Bank without incident, month after land-for-security peace plan was signed in Washington; no Israeli Army bases are moved in first redeployment, and no roads leading to and from Jewish settlements fall into Palestinian hands; Israel also releases 250 Palestinian prisoners, more than half of them common criminals; they also sign document authorizing long-delayed opening of Palestinian airport in Gaza; photos; map (M)

headline: Daiwa Bank to Cut Employee Pay 10%
abstract: Daiwa Bank Ltd will cut employees' salaries by 10 percent and focus on business in its home city of Osaka, two days after announcing closing of its overseas branches; Daiwa slashes half-year profit forecast by 36 percent, to 7 billion yen ($58 million) and triples bad-loan write-offs to 53 billion yen (S)

headline: Young & Rubicam's President to Retire
abstract: John McGarry will retire as Young & Rubicam Inc president; duties will be divided among other top executives (S)

headline: Firstplus Chief Sells Shares
abstract: Firstplus Financial Group chairman and chief executive Daniel T Phillips sold 1.23 million shares of company last month, about quarter of his holdings, according to SEC filing (S)

headline: Ho! Ho! Ho! Boohoo-hoo!
abstract: The holiday season seems to bring out the best and the worst in bosses. We've all heard stories about workers who are fired on Christmas Eve, but then again, Scrooge himself ended up giving the long-suffering Bob Cratchit a raise. What holiday horror stories have emerged from your workplace? Or, to give the management world's guardian angels their due, how have the holidays melted the coldest corporate hearts? Send your anecdotes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Hitachi and Toshiba Post 6-Month Losses
abstract: Toshiba Corp and Hitachi Ltd report losses for six months ended Sept 30; Toshiba lost 6.4 billion yen, or about $54 million at current exchange rates, compared with profit of 22.4 billion yen in year-earlier period; sales dropped more than 12 percent, to 1.59 trillion yen, or $13.3 billion; Hitachi lost 124.7 billion yen, or about $1 billion, compared with net income of 24.3 billion yen last year; sales dropped more than 12 percent, to 1.8 trillion yen, or about $15.1 billion (M)

headline: Emap to Acquire Petersen for $1.5 Billion
abstract: Petersen Companies Inc is being purchased by British magazine publisher Emap PLC in deal valued at $1.5 billion; deal involves group of magazines aimed at young male readers (M)

headline: Turks' Anger With Italy Deepens Over Extradition of Rebel Kurd
abstract: Italy's refusal to extradite Abdullah Ocalan, Kurdish rebel wanted by Turkey, has soured relations between normally close allies; US calls for Ocalan's extradition (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Set to Be Offered This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's auction of three-  and six-month bills.     By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.61 percent and the rate on a six-month bill was 3.87 percent.

headline: Two Foreign Affairs Agencies Are Eliminated
abstract: Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and United States Information Agency are abolished under catchall spending bill signed by Pres Clinton; their responsibilties will pass to State Dept (S)

headline: An Exiled Chinese Activist Speaks Out
abstract: Liu Nianchun, Chinese activist who arrived in US on December 20, accuses Government of trampling on human rights and says he was beaten while in prison; served more than two years in labor camp; photo (S)

headline: Wyse Is Selected By Sherwin-Williams
abstract: Sherwin-Williams Paint Stores Group names Wyse Advertising to handle creative portion of its account, which had been handled since 1995 by J Walter Thompson Detroit; billings estimated at $32 million (S)

headline: To Surf, Perchance To Dream
abstract: Accounts of anxiety-filled dreams about computers are showing up in public spaces of Internet and in off-line conversations; people are posting their dreams in dozens of on-line dream journals, Web rings and newsgroups, and computers play starring roles in some of them; most therapists say computers have not been in common use long enough to become part of dreamers' repertory, but Barbara J Lee, clinical social worker, claims computer is becoming its own archetype--symbol of how modern life has accelerated; sampling of technology-related dreams reported on various Internet sites; photos (M)

headline: TEMPLE-INLAND TO ACQUIRE HF BANCORP FOR $120 MILLION
abstract: Temple-Inland Inc to buy HF Bancorp, savings-and-loan holding company, Hemet, Calif, for $18.50 a share in cash and stock, or a total of $120 million (S)

headline: Mott's and Thompson End Relationship
abstract: Mott's Inc and J Walter Thompson New York advertising agency agree to end six-year relationship, citing client conflicts; Mott's consolidates account at Griffin Bacal (S)

headline: Media Talk; Freedom Forum Changes Focus of Fellowships
abstract: Freedom Forum changes focus of its writing fellowships and will now disperse new fellows around the country and preselect most of their research topics; decision is greeted with dismay as it moves around book-party-circuit populated by former fellows; new Forum criteria discussed (M)

headline: Foote, Cone Realigns Leading Managers
abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide, part of True North Communications, has reorganized top management at its San Francisco and New York offices; Geoff Thompson, worldwide creative director, is named to additional new positions of chairman and chief executive officer of San Francisco office (S)

headline: Asian Economic Crisis Hits Home, and Silicon Valley Is Targe
abstract: Silicon Valley's home county, Santa Clara, and state have been impacted by Asia's economic woes; Asian crisis, which began in July 1997, has slowed exports, causing cascade of layoffs; and stock market volatility has battered technology company shares, making it harder for young companies to raise money and crimping the spending of workers whose sense of wealth is tied to stock options that are considered birthright in Silicon Valley; scene at Mattson Technology Inc, which has seen sales and share price drop drastically in last year, discussed; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: Pinochet Vows to Fight 'With All My Spirit'
abstract: Gen Augusto Pinochet, former Chilean dictator, says he is 'hurt and bewildered' by his arrest in London, and he vows to fight attempts to extradite him to Spain to stand trial; photo (M)

headline: U.S. SET TO GIVE UP ARMS INSPECTIONS FOR CURBING IRAQ
abstract: Clinton Administration said to conclude that sanctions or use of force will be necessary to restrain Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq, because United Nations inspections regime is no longer effective; Washington no longer believes that Hussein will cooperate with UN weapons inspectors, who have spent seven years trying to eliminate Iraq's nuclear, missile, biological and chemical weapons programs; Hussein has cut off all cooperation with inspectors, and 15 of them have left Baghdad; Western officials have concluded that Hussein cares more about keeping his ability to produce weapons of terror than he does about eliminating sanctions (M)

headline: U.S. REJECTS PLAN
abstract: Iraq's Pres Saddam Hussein appears to back down in face of imminent US military attack and says Iraq will resume cooperation with UN arms inspectors; letter to UN Security Council sets conditions on agreement, restating demands that have already been rejected by US, Britain and other Council members; is again rejected as inadequate by US, and American forces remain poised to strike; most Council members say they are prepared to take Hussein at his word; urge quick resumption of arms inspections; Great Britain remains strong in support of US, even though delegates suggest London might be willing to give Iraq chance to re-admit inspectors; Prime Min Tony Blair says until Iraq's compliance is unconditional, British forces will remain on alert; photo (M)

headline: Citigroup Is Facing First Law of Megamerger: The Inertia of Mass
abstract: Citigroup Inc, merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group, is getting off to rocky start, and it may be some time before any of the hype surrounding creation of company becomes reality; how co-chief executives Sanford I Weill and John S Reed will get their troubled corporate businesses, those involving investment banking activities like stocks and bond trading and underwriting that Travelers specializes in, to mesh with such staid businesses as corporate lending that were Citicorp's forte is remaining basic question (M)

headline: Big German Union Will Seek 6.5% Raises
abstract: IG Metall, Germany's largest union, said today that it would seek the biggest pay increase in years, as it enters job-creation negotiations with the new Social Democratic-led Government.    The union, representing 2.7 million workers in the metal and electronics industries, said it would recommend a 6.5 percent pay increase, the highest since the early 1990's and more than double last year's raise.

headline: For Actors and Agents, On-Line Links to Casting Directors
abstract: Hollywood casting directors are now using electronic search services to find actors to fir certain specifications; talent agents Bonnie Black and Taylor Jacobs comment; photo (S)

headline: Tropicana Raising Prices
abstract: Pepsico Inc's Tropicana juice division will raise wholesale prices of its orange juices by average of 10 percent in November because of reduced Florida crop (S)

headline: Amid Bombs, a Tired Capital Keeps Its Cool
abstract: Iraqi antiaircrat gunners fire hundreds of rounds against incoming US and British missiles; only single missile appears to have hit Baghdad; small caravans of cars drive around, honking horns in sign of defiance, and cortege is staged as demonstration; photo; map (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar drops further against Japanese yen for weekly decline of 13.8 percent, biggest fall since major currencies went off gold standard in 1971; dollar falls to 116.95 yen, from 119.05 on Oct 8; graph; chart (S)

headline: A New Chief Pushes to Restore a Soft-Drink Maverick's Lost Luster
abstract: Profile of Cott Corp under leadership of Frank E Weise 3d, who became chief executive last June; Wiese is pushing to move Cott into third place behind Coke and Pepsi in soft drink industry; beverage analyst says that besides competition from Coke and Pepsi, regional private-label players are trying to take over Cott's customers, capitalizing on Cott's problems in recent years with customer service; photos; financial graphs (M)

headline: Bloodcurdling Capitalism; Theme Parks Raise the Dead to Lift the Bottom Line
abstract: Amusement parks, including Universal Studios Florida and Walt Disney World Resort, both in Orlando, Fla, are using Halloween, traditionally not a big tourist holiday, to boost business in October; some main events noted; graph; photo (M)

headline: Deutsche Gets Bankers Trust for $10 Billion
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG formally announces its plan for $10.1 billion takeover of Bankers Trust Corp and says acquisition will result in elimination of 5,500 jobs, mostly in New York and London; Deutsche Bank chairman Rolf-Ernst Breuer says cuts will not all be at Bankers Trust; company commits some $400 million in bonus payments to retain top Bankers Trust managers, including Frank N Newman, chairman and chief executive of Bankers Trust, who will be only executive receiving seat on Deutsche Bank's management board; graph; photo (M)

headline: With New Disk Drive, Inventor Of Floppy Competes With Itself
abstract: Sony Corp, inventor of the 3.5-inch floppy disk, is joining the already crowded effort to dislodge that floppy as the removable computer storage device of choice; Sony and Fujifilm officially unveil HiFD, floppy disk that holds about 140 times as much information as conventional disk, and the HiFD disk drive, which costs $199 (S)

headline: Italy Ending House Arrest Of Rebel Chief Of the Kurds
abstract: Appeals court in Rome, Italy, frees Kurdish rebel leader Abdulllah Ocalan from house arrest, further inflaming bitter diplomatic dispute between Italy and Turkey; rules Italy has no grounds for detaining Ocalan, leader of Kurdistan Workers Party, which has been fighting for self-determination in southeast Turkey; Italy's Prime Min Massimo D'Alema quickly asserts that Ocalan will be kept under police surveillance; Turkish officials express outrage and renew threats of economic retaliation against Italy (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph plots movement of Japanese yen against dollar during trading on December 29; dollar closed lower in New York, at 115.53

headline: ABRAXAS AGREES TO SELL NATURAL-GAS FIELDS TO G.E. UNIT
abstract: Abraxas Petroleum Corp sells its natural-gas fields in southwestern Wyoming to GE Capital Corp for $60.2 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Powerbar Inc to Wieden & Kennedy to handle advertising, which had been handled by Citron Haligman Bedecarre; spending for 1999 is estimated at $10 million to $12 million (S)

headline: British Textile Maker To Close 8 Factories
abstract: Courtaulds Textiles to cut 1,220 jobs and close eight factories of its recently acquired Claremont Garments unit (S)

headline: China, a Land of Heavy Smokers, Looks Into Abyss of Fatal Illness
abstract: Scientists calculate toll of cigarette smoking in China and declare country to be on verge of calamitous epidemic of smoking-related disease that could ultimately result in deaths of one in three Chinese men; say that in country where 70 percent of men smoke, there are now 2,000 smoking-related deaths a day, which will increase to 8,000 a day by middle of next century unless public health measures are taken; photo (M)

headline: Merger Wave Spurs a New Scrutiny
abstract: Federal Trade Commission and Justice Department file a record number of challenges to mergers and other anticompetitive practices in 1998 and collect a record amount in civil fines and other penalties; have stretched some old antitrust theories and applied a few new ones, such as routinely investigating how every proposed merger may affect product innovation and development; renewed antitrust vigor reflects deregulation of certain industries and unparalleled wave of business mergers and acquisitions; graph (M)

headline: 2 Mexican Parties Near Accord on Bank Bailout
abstract: Agreement on measures to refinance Mexican Government's troubled $61 billion bank bailout is reach by members of Congress from Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) and National Action Party, but the latter demands that Guillermo Ortiz resign as head of Bank of Mexico as part of agreement; PRI, following cues from Pres Ernesto Zedillo, opposes Ortiz's resignation on ground that central bank enjoys independence (M)

headline: Some Good News, Some Bad From Soft Energy Prices
abstract: Latest corporate earnings reports reflect effects of cheap oil on US economy; nearly all big airlines post robust earnings as US trade deficit continues to widen (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH; Internet Service For Orthodox Jews
abstract: Koshernet, an Internet service based in Borough Park section of Brooklyn, filters out sites that might be objectionable to Orthodox Jews and provides links for Jews who want to use Internet for religious purposes; cartoon (M)

headline: NATIONWIDE FINANCIAL ENDS BID FOR PILGRIM BAXTER
abstract: Nationwide Financial Services Inc ends talks to acquire Pilgrim Baxter & Associates Ltd; United Asset Management Co is said to be seeking as much as $600 million for unit (S)

headline: Media Talk; Embattled Writer to Meet With Anti-Drug Group
abstract: Stephen Glass moves to settle a $10 million libel suit arising from magazine article he wrote about DARE, a drug prevention group, agreeing to tell group what he knows about editing and fact-checking processes at Rolling Stone and New Republic, which published articles; DARE weighs suit against magazines; seeks to refute his charges that it intimidated critics into silence; photo (M)

headline: CENTRAL RESERVE AGREES TO BUY CONTINENTAL GENERAL
abstract: Central Reserve Life Corp to acquire Continental General Corp from Western and Southern Life Insurance Co for $84 million (S)

headline: Bottler's Debt Refinanced
abstract: Pan-American Beverages Inc restructures $360 million in debt due in Dec and Jan; gets new $200 million, three-year loan from Coca-Cola Financial Corp to replace some short-term bank credit (S)

headline: News Corp. Sets Italian TV Deal
abstract: Telecom Italia SpA agrees to sell up to 80 percent of its Stream pay-TV unit to News Corp for as much as $118.8 million (S)

headline: For the Bereft in Chile, a Cause for Tears: Pinochet Could Slip Spain's Grasp
abstract: Chileans whose family members and loved ones disappeared during dictatorship of Gen Augusto Pinochet revert to despair on hearing that English High Court ruled that Pinochet had diplomatic immunity and that he could be released to return to Chile unpunished; photos (M)

headline: On-Line Samurai Transform an Ancient Game
abstract: Ancient Asian game of Go, game of samurai, expands around world on Internet, drawing in players far removed from Japanese culture; photos (M)

headline: Got a Dime? Citibank and Chase End Test of Electronic Cash
abstract: Citibank and Chase Manhattan Bank to discontinue their test of electronic cash; banks issued so-called smart cards to nearly 100,000 people who live on Upper West Side of Manhattan; most people who tried system never loaded their cards a second time; and with few people using cards, two-thirds of merchants dropped out; less than $2 million was spent using all of the cards in program's first year (M)

headline: O Canada, Land of Few Banks; The Industry Seeks Mergers, but Consumers Are Wary
abstract: John E. Cleg horn showed what a formidable competitor he can be when he played center on the McGill University football team that won the intercollegiate championship in 1960. Now that he is chairman of the Royal Bank of Canada, the country's largest, and campaigning vigorously for Government approval to make it a lot larger by merging with the Bank of Montreal, he is acting as though he still thinks no one can get past him.    From the look of things, however, he will need all the grit he can muster. Strongly backed by public opinion, the Government remains uncertain about allowing the Royal-Montreal deal or mergers by any other of the country's top five banks, which, with 93 percent of the industry's assets, dominate the banking sector to an extent unmatched anywhere else in the world.

headline: APPLIED MATERIALS PLANS $285 MILLION EARNINGS CHARGE
abstract: Applied Materials Inc will take charges of $285 million as part of previously disclosed plan to reorganize operations (S)

headline: Grace Is Planning Charges of $50 Million
abstract: W R Grace & Co plans to take about $50 million in pretax fourth-quarter charges for environmental cleanup at a company site and other costs (S)

headline: Jewish Group Occupies House in Arab Area
abstract: Group of ultra-nationalist Jews occupy vacant house in Palestinian neighborhood in Jerusalem; plant Israeli flag on roof and bring in ark and Torah, saying house was old Sephardic synagogue; scuffles break out as Palestinians gather to shout their anger (S)

headline: Only Chile Can Judge Me, Pinochet Tells British Court
abstract: Gen Augusto Pinochet, former Chilean dictator, appears at hearing in London, Eng, on Spanish order seeking his extradition to Madrid to stand trial on charges of crimes against humanity; it is his first appearance in public since his arrest two months ago; Pinochet defiantly tells London court that he does not acknowledge right of any court outside his own country to consider charges against him; outside court, hundreds of supporters and protesters chant slogans and beat drums; next hearing is scheduled for Jan 18; photo (M)

headline: Guerrillas in Kosovo Rebound, Provoking Concern
abstract: United States is surprised and concerned by major reorganization and rearming of separatist Kosovo guerrillas now under way; guerrillas have killed at least six Serbian policemen in two weeks since some Serbian forces withdrew from province under US pressure; Western officials are concerned about Serbian threats to retaliate unless Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe responds; guerrilla leader Naim Maloku comments, interview; NATO officials say guerrillas, while unable to win in straightforward battle against Yugslav Army and Serbian police, can keep up low intensity conflict; map; photo (M)

headline: Apparel Retailer Drops 2000 Bug Claim
abstract: J Baker, apparel retailer, drops claim that Andersen Consulting, designer of computer system it installed in 1991, is liable for system's Year 2000 defects after mediator backs Andersen (S)

headline: Potential of the Internet
abstract: Edwin H Grageri letter says that even though Internet is the most powerful educational tool the world has ever seen, uses on which most people have focused are its massive storage capability and its role as a research tool

headline: New PC: How to Kick The Tires
abstract: Peter H Lewis article offers advice on shopping for computer; cites minimum specifications; drawing (M)

headline: SKY FINANCIAL AGREES TO ITS 2D ACQUISITION THIS WEEK
abstract: Sky Financial Group acquires Wood Bancorp for $59 million (S)

headline: BUILDING ONE SERVICES PLANS SHARE REPURCHASE
abstract: Building One Services Corp teams up with financier Leon Black to buy back about 78 percent of its shares for $900 million; deal will give Black about 40 percent stake (S)

headline: Red Ink No More; With Deficits Gone, Benefits of Surplus Are Debated
abstract: Benefits of Federal budget surplus are being debated as Pres Clinton announces that for first time since 1969 the budget will show surplus; Clinton says surplus should be about $70 billion when all calculations are completed in few weeks; some economists and analysts think benefits from fiscal prudence have been overstated, and some wonder whether projected surpluses will materialize if economy should slip into recession; there is still debate about how much strong economy reflects nation's improved fiscal condition and how much improved fiscal condition is result of strong economy; there is also some lingering doubt, especially among liberal Democrats, about whether fiscal belt-tightening will prove good deal for low- and moderate-income people in long run, or whether it primarily benefits Wall Street and wealthy; there is no consensus yet about what to do with coming surpluses, which Congressional Budget Office estimates will total $1.55 trillion over next decade; graph show fluctuations in Federal budget since 1968; photos (M)

headline: Coltec Shares Rise as Crane Presses Its Bid
abstract: Shares of Coltec Industries rise 12 percent as Crane Corp pursues its attempt to block planned $1.3 billion merger between Coltec and B F Goodrich; Goodrich says it has no plans to drop its offer to buy Coltec (M)

headline: Media Talk; Newsweek May Find New Editor on Its Staff
abstract: Death of Newsweek editor, Maynard Parker, prompts speculation on his successor; photo (S)

headline: Calcutta Journal; Living Up to Mother Teresa's Legacy
abstract: Sister Nirmala, who succeeded Mother Teresa as head of Missionaries of Charity in Calcutta, India, says she cannot replace Mother Teresa, only try to carry on her work; she is administering Missionaries' ascetic empire while also gathering evidence of miracles that will be needed to win sainthood for Mother Teresa from Vatican; photos (M)

headline: France Confronts Holocaust Claims
abstract: French authorities, after 50 years of suppressing memories of what collaboratist Vichy Govt did to Jews under Nazi occupation, have been trying since 1995 to do justice to their survivors; commissions are pouring over long-closed files and reopening Nazi records in attempt to meet moral obligations; for French Jews, question of how hard to push for restitution or compensation remains difficult since France made major effort to restore seized assets after war in which probably 70 percent of bank assets were restored (M)

headline: Board of E.spire Ousts Its Chief Executive
abstract: Jack E Reich, chief executive and president of E.spire Communications Inc, resigns; E.spire's board demanded Reich's resignation; chairman Anthony J Pompliano will take over as chief executive (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises to two-month high against German mark as Germany's top central banker bolsters optimism about possibility of interest rate cut; dollar settles at 1.7031 marks, up from 1.6927; graph; chart (S)

headline: U.S. Witness Says Browser Split Is Feasible
abstract: Computer science expert Dr Edward W Felton, in written testimony in Microsoft antitrust suit, says he has done what Microsoft insists is impossible: extricate company's Internet Explorer Web browsing software from its Windows operating system (M)/

headline: American Topics : Hats for Cowboys With Deep Saddlebags
abstract: The cowboy hat, now an internationally recognized symbol of America's Old West, started out as a joke.

headline: ONEOK TO SELL SOME RESERVES AND PLANTS TO DUKE ENERGY
abstract: Oneok Inc to sell oil and gas reserves and number of processing plants and gathering systems in Louisiana, Oklahoma and Kansas to Duke Energy Corp; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Media Talk; Former Journalist Is Cited With Contempt
abstract: John Rezendes-Herrick, former reporter for Inland Valley Daily Bulletin, is cited with contempt and sentenced to jail for refusing to tell grand jury source for his 1996 series of articles on how Cadiz Land Co got financing to acquire much larger company; would be first journalist jailed for protecting source in over 20 years in California; sentence has been postponed pending appeal; case may depend on outcome of another case challenging state's strong shield laws protecting news source confidentiality; photo (M)

headline: DUKE ENERGY IN NATURAL GAS PIPELINE DEAL WITH TEPPCO
abstract: Duke Energy Corp is folding its oil and natural gas liquids pipeline unit into its Teppco Partners LP affiliate in transaction valued at $100 million, and plans to use Teppco to acquire other pipeline businesses; Duke will own about 20 percent of Teppco after transaction (S)i

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: WASHINGTON MUTUAL INC., Seattle, the savings and loan company, said it would close 161 branches in California next year to combine outlets too close to each other after its purchase of Home Savings of America.    WEYERHAEUSER CO., Federal Way, Wash., the paper and lumber company, agreed to buy a corrugated-packaging plant near Philadelphia from the closely held Connelly Containers Inc. for an undisclosed price.

headline: Economic Scene; In the health care business, size can ultimately benefit patients.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Aetna Inc's proposed purchase of health care business of Prudential Insurance Co of America; says merger has touched off concern among doctors and consumers, but Aetna's large size could ultimately benefit patients (M)

headline: Making It Politically Possible for the Two Leaders to Agree
abstract: Success at Wye Mills peace conference depends on insuring that Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat could return home claiming that they had reaped real benefits and not sold out (M)

headline: Republicans Criticize Clinton On Kosovo
abstract: Several influential Republicans, including Sens Richard G Lugar, Don Nickles and Pete V Domenici, criticize Clinton Administration's approach toward ending crisis in Kosovo, which calls for air strikes in Kosovo and elsewhere in Serbia if Pres Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia does not agree to remove his special police forces from province, permit aid to refugees and begin serious negotiations toward a political settlement (M)

headline: Prices Turn Upward, With the Dow Climbing by 30.64
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 30.64 points, to close at 7,968.78; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 10.73 points, to 1,005.53; Nasdaq composite index rises 31.52 points, to 1,540.97; graph; chart (M)

headline: Campbell Soup Revamps Roster
abstract: Campbell Soup Co announces sweeping realignment of its advertising agency roster; shops eliminated are Foote, Cone & Belding and Saatchi & Saatchi; BBDO Worldwide and Young & Rubicam will each handle nearly half of Campbell's more than $500 million in worldwide ad spending (S)

headline: Former Driver's Sodomy Testimony at Issue : Witness in Anwar Case Seems to Change Story
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  A key witness in the trial of Anwar Ibrahim appeared to reverse himself on Monday by stating under cross-examination that he had not been sodomized by the former deputy prime minister.

headline: Murdoch Puts 2 Satellites In New Orbit
abstract: News Corp agrees to sell two satellites and their orbital license over US to Echostar Communications Corp for about $840 million in stock; News Corp wants to abandon direct-broadcast satellite business in US; MCI Worldcom Inc, which as MCI Communications was in partnership with News Corp to buy license in 1996, will receive about $209 million in Echostar stock; if deal is approved by regulators, MCI Worldcom and News Corp will own about 37 percent of Echostar (M)

headline: CENTURA BANKS TO BUY FIRST COASTAL FOR $117 MILLION
abstract: Centura Banks Inc will buy First Coastal Bankshares Inc for $117 million in stock (S)

headline: Mexico Rebels Turn Down Peace Proposal
abstract: Zapatista rebels reject peace proposals by Mexican Government at end of three days of meetings in Chiapas (S)

headline: Drug Inquiry Into a Governor Tests Mexico's New Politics
abstract: Special report, Yucatan Strongman, on Mario Villanueva Madrid, Quintana Roo governor and member of hard-line faction of Mexican Pres Ernest Zedillo's governing party, who is suspect in sweeping federal probe of drug operations in his state; federal government has neither charged him nor been able to contain his political counterattack; case is test of Zedillo's ability to deal with challenges of crime and politics that are multiplying in party as once-absolute authority of President erodes; map; photos (M)

headline: HOUSTON EXPLORATION BUYING PROPERTIES FROM CHEVRON
abstract: Houston Exploration Co acquires offshore producing properties for $85.3 million from Chevron USA unit of Chevron Corp (S)

headline: Allstate Buys Insurer Units
abstract: Allstate will buy Leucadia National Corp's two insurance units (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: BLAIR AIDE FORCED TO QUIT -- The Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair has suffered its first forced resignation since taking office 18 months ago. Ron Davies is out as Secretary for Wales after he was robbed Monday night by strangers he invited into his car in an area known as a meeting place for homosexuals and drug dealers. Mr. Blair has often attacked the previous Conservative Government for the number of its members who left office in disgrace.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: NEW VOTE PROCEDURES PROPOSED -- A commission headed by the former Finance Minister, Lord Jenkins, proposed new proportional voting procedures in elections for the House of Commons that would give small parties greater representation and make Continental-style coalition governments more likely. Prime Minister Tony Blair has promised a referendum on the current ''first-past-the-post'' electoral system, in which the winner takes all, sometimes even without a majority of votes.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Oil Pipeline Agreed On for Caspian Area
abstract: Russia, Kazakhstan and major oil companies, known as Caspian Pipeline Consortium, agree to build multibillion-dollar pipeline to link oil-rich Caspian Sea region with Black Sea; project, scheduled for completion in 2001, will be first major new pipeline in region and will connect Tengiz oilfield to Russian port; is important step not only in tapping oil resources of Caspian but in struggle by Russian Govt to regain credibility with foreign businessmen; is signal that Russian Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov's left-leaning team is capable of doing business with increasingly skeptical West; will bring billions of dollars in tax revenue to Russia's cash-starved Govt; oil companies are led by Chevron Corp; (M)

headline: Pushing the Limits Of an Irreplaceable Resource
abstract: William K Stevens article surveys man's effects on the earth's water cycle and progress toward mitigating some of the harm he has done; photos; map; graph (M)

headline: Swatting Y2K Bug
abstract: Q. How can people find out if their home computers have a Year 2000, or Y2K, problem?    A. Even if you don't have an aging mainframe machine sitting in your living room, Y2K compliance is still important. One way to check out your system and software before the big day is to list all your computer equipment and programs according to the company that made each item. The Vendor 2000 site has a lengthy list of Y2K compliance information submitted by computer and software companies (www.vendor2000.com).

headline: F.C.C. Likely to Halt BellSouth Long Distance Bid
abstract: Federal Communications Commission will reject BellSouth Corp's latest application to offer long-distance service in Louisiana; Telecommunications Act of 1996 prohibits a Bell company from selling long-distance phone services until it can convince FCC that it has opened its local network to potential competitors (M)

headline: A Top Morgan Stanley Officer Is Retiring
abstract: James Allwin to retire as president of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co's institutional investment management arm, Morgan Stanley Asset Management, and as member of its management committee; will be advisory director; Richard Worley will succeed him (S)

headline: U.S. Report Says Salinas's Banker Ignored Safeguards
abstract: United States Congressional report says that Citibank executives, eager to do business with Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of former Pres of Mexico, ignored some of bank's own safeguards against laundering of illicit funds; report finds that as bankers took in millions of dollars from Salinas, they never asked for standard information on his financial background and made virtually no effort to verify source of his money (M)

headline: Board Member Resigns At No. 2 German Bank
abstract: Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank AG, Germany's second-largest bank, says Franz Huber resigned as management board member responsible for real estate; no successor has been named (S)

headline: G.E. Division May Buy Unit Of Japan Bank
abstract: GE Capital Services Corp, financial services unit of General Electric Co, may acquire leasing arm of troubled Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd in move that would give it needed edge in Japan's corporate leasing market (S)

headline: Emerson Raises Dividend
abstract: Emerson Electric Co will increase its dividend 10.1 percent, to 32.5 cents a quarter from 29.5 cents (S)

headline: U.S. Fighters in Saudi Arabia Grounded
abstract: More than half of the 100 American strike aircraft at ground bases in Persian Gulf region are kept out of the attack on Iraq because of objections from Saudi Arabia; only fighters and bombers in Kuwait and Oman join in the campaign; Saudis have been so clear in their opposition to permitting Saudi-based planes to attack Iraq that Americans stopped asking permission months ago; episode underscores limitations on US military operations in the region, where anger over attack on Iraq is vented in many newspapers; photo (M)

headline: How Do We Measure The Virtue of Charity?
abstract: Mary Murphy letter responds to September 27 article on whether to support charities or purchase goods (S)
