headline: Divided and Distracted, APEC Prepares to Meet
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  As the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum prepares to admit three new members on Saturday, before heading into its annual summit meeting next week, the group appears more divided and distracted than at any time since it was formed in 1989.

headline: History Buffs' Hangout
abstract: History Channel reopens its Web site for history buffs, which includes archive of articles, audio and video clips and exhibits; photo (S)

headline: Drug Aid for Colombia
abstract: A recent Congressional initiative, spurred by appeals to conservative Republicans, has more than doubled anti-drug money to Colombia. The increase brings the assistance to $289 million for 1999 and is mostly in the form of weapons and aircraft.    Article, page A14.

headline: SERBS IN KOSOVO ARE WITHDRAWING FROM MANY POSTS
abstract: Yugoslavia begins what appears to be serious troop withdrawals from many positions in Kosovo Province, day before NATO deadline to launch air strikes; soldiers and policemen leave many positions fortified over past three months; hundreds pour out of bunkers along major road westward from Kosovo capital of Pristina, essentially ceding strategic areas to ethnic Albanian rebels, who quickly move into place; Albanians watch exodus with strong skepticism, which is also voiced by NATO officials who must verify that withdrawal is sufficient to avert air strikes; photos (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Weighs Big Issues Prior to Bankers Trust Purchase
abstract: Employees and investors seek information on layoffs and other issues as Deutsche Bank AG prepares to announce its acquisition of Bankers Trust Corp (S)

headline: Tech Help, on Paper
abstract: Letter from Eugene V Weinstock on Nov 12 article on providing technical support for computer users (S)

headline: U.N. Fails to Reach Consensus on Iraq Policy
abstract: United Nations Security Council seeks to produce statement broadly outlining a policy toward Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq, but defers discussion after several hours (M)

headline: Tentative Accord Is Reached With Federal Express Pilots
abstract: FDX Corp reaches tentative five-year labor accord with its pilots' union, Fedex Pilots Association; FDX shares rise on news; pact calls for 17 percent pay rise over five years (M)

headline: Trading This [up arrow] Even Up for That [down arrow]; An Exchange for the General Good Was Better for Some Than Others
abstract: Questionable tactics of land deal involving Deer Creek near Las Vegas, Nev, culminated in September with release of Federal Government audit that has caused re-examination of land exchange program, one of West's most popular methods for preserving environment amid rapid growth; Federal Government traded Deer Creek land to American Land Conservancy, which then sold it to developers as part of land exchange; Federal audit determined that Government has given up land worth $5.9 million more than value of what it got back; discrepancies were also found in other Nevada exchanges; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Diet Coke Shifts Duties To Wieden & Kennedy
abstract: Coca-Cola Co will shift lead creative duties on Diet Coke advertising campaign between roster agencies, moving assignment to Wieden & Kennedy, from Lowe & Partners/SMS (S)

headline: Mannequins vs. Top Models?No Contest : The Changing Face Of Shop Dummies
abstract: PARIS—  Who can compete with top models? Not the dummies in the windows, those material girls and boys who never make the catwalks because they are made of wax, wood, plaster, cloth or fiberglass.

headline: More About the Oil Merger
abstract: THE ODD COUPLE -- The chief executives of Exxon and Mobil, Lee R. Raymond and Lucio A. Noto, have markedly different styles, making their proposed alliance seem an unusual match. Page C1.

headline: Deal for Northwest Chief
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp says John H Dasburg, its president and chief executive, has signed long-term employment agreement; also names Richard A Anderson executive vice president and chief operating officer (S)

headline: Late Comeback Gives Dow 13.91-Point Gain for Day
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 13.91 points, to close at 8,533.14; Nasdaq composite index gains 27.87 points, or 1.67 percent, to 1,702.64; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 8.56 points, to 1,078.48; graph; chart (M)

headline: Sangstat Drug Is Cleared By the F.D.A.
abstract: Sangstat Medical Corp says Food and Drug Administration has approved its immune-suppressant drug, Sangcya, for preventing organ rejection in transplant patients, and for treatment of rhematoid arthritis and psoriasis; Sangstate says it will bring out drug within a month (M)

headline: BOOLE & BABBAGE SOARS ON PLANNED PURCHASE BY BMC
abstract: Shares of Boole & Babbage Inc rise 13 percent after BMC Software Inc announces it will buy company for about $877 million in stock (S)

headline: Meet Jeopardy the CD-ROM
abstract: J D Biersdorfer reviews Hasbro Interactive's computer trivia quiz game Jeopardy; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; Preceding Prime Time With Infomercials
abstract: Controversy over CBS selling time for infomercials, those half-hour plugs for everything from exercise machines to car wax, to appear on half hour preceding prime time (S)

headline: Alfred Van Sinderen, 74, Phone Executive
abstract: Alfred W Van Sinderen, who served as top executive of Southern New England Telecommunications Corp for 17 years, died on Oct 12 at age 74 (S)

headline: Uh, Dad, Can I Borrow The Key to the Modem?
abstract: Dallas entrepreneur Douglas Horn devises low-tech solution for parents to restrict their children's surfing Internet: his Netprotector is lock designed to shut off access to modem with turn of key; when key is turned, rest of computer works, but modem goes mute; photo (S)

headline: This Space Available on AOL Starting for a Mere $25,000
abstract: New Neiman Marcus Christmas catalogue offers exclusive spot on menu of America Online for $25,000 (S)

headline: DEXTER PLANS TENDER OFFER FOR LIFE TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Dexter Corp will make tender offer of $420 million for 48 percent of Life Technologies Inc it does not already own (S)

headline: Popular Tax-Free Health Plans Spark Holiday Rush to Doctors
abstract: More than four million Americans who have Flexible Spending Accounts--tax-free savings set aside by employers for health care expenses not covered by insurance--must use up their totals each year or forfeit them; use-it-or-lose-it rule can lead to unusual spending binges at year's end, often on goods and services people do not need; providers of nonemergency care love program, but some health care advocates say program may not be good for efforts to make health care more accessible to all Americans; flexible spending accounts, created by Congress in 1984, were designed to give workers relief from ever-shrinking health care coverage; health care experts say growth of program has been hampered by employees' fear of losing money at end of year (M)

headline: Blair Backs Clinton's Call for Iraqi Opposition Groups to Topple Hussein
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair says that Britain has evidence of growing opposition to Pres Saddam Hussein inside Iraq that would seem to give Clinton Adm's new call for his overthrow a better chance of success than in in past, interview, 10 Downing Street; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Deal For Banc One
abstract: Microsoft Corp signs five-year, $90 million agreement with First USA unit of Banc One Corp that is being described as largest such deal involving Internet advertising; agreement makes First USA exclusive credit card advertiser on most of on-line programs and services on Microsoft's MSN network (S)

headline: A Worthwhile Investment
abstract: Suesan W Taylor letter reports that Web TV has greatly enriched the life of her 90-year-old mother-in-law

headline: Interpublic Group Announces 3 Deals
abstract: Interpublic Group of Cos acquires Austin Kelley Advertising; Interpublic's Carmichael Lynch unit acquires Minneapolis office of Valentine-McCormick-Ligibel, which will be merged into Carmichael Lynch; Carmichael Lynch Spong, public relations division of Carmichael Lynch, acquires McGrath Buckley Consulting Group; will form McGrath Buckley Group division, headed by Douglas K Spong as managing partner (M)

headline: Soweto Journal; That Little White Ball Is Suddenly Colorblind
abstract: Refurbishment of golf course at Soweto Country Club has become symbol of renewal in South Africa's most famous black township; club, which many say was built to create buffer zone between black and mixed-race areas during era of apartheid, is trying to attract new members; its efforts described; photos (M)

headline: Israel Is Advertising for Clues to a Sub Lost in 60's
abstract: Israel, seeking to solve mysterious maritime tragedy, has appealed to public in Turkey and elsewhere to help it find wreck of submarine that disappeared 30 years ago; sixty-nine crew members were lost in the sub; they constitute largest group of Israeli military personnel listed as missing; large advertisement signed by Israeli military and Defense Ministry appeared in leading Turkish newspaper in September, offering reward of $5,000 to $300,000 (M)

headline: G.M.'S DELPHI AUTOMOTIVE TO OFFER 17.7% STAKE TO PUBLIC
abstract: General Motors Corp's Delphi Automotive Systems Corp unit plans to sell 17.7 percent of its stock in initial public offering to raise about $1.53 billion (S)

headline: Duke Energy to Buy U.S. Gas Business Of Union Pacific
abstract: Duke Energy Corp to buy Union Pacific Resources Group's United States natural gas gathering, processing and marketing business for $1.35 billion (S)

headline: 10 Years After Lockerbie, Still No Trial
abstract: US tells Libya on 10th anniversary of bombing of Pan American jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, that it will face more sanctions if two Libyan suspects are not turned over for trial by Scottish judge in Netherlands by February 1999; Libyan leader Col Muammar el-Qaddafi apparently rejects compromise plan for trial in Netherlands, saying he wants international tribunal to hear case; photo (M)

headline: Mayflower Descendant Digs Deep Into the Lore
abstract: Caleb Johnson, recent college graduate, creates Web site to fill need for authoritative on-line source for information about Mayflower Pilgrims; drawing (M)

headline: Lincoln Artifacts Are Popular on Line
abstract: Artifacts connected to Abraham Lincoln are popular on variety of on-line auction sites; photos (M)

headline: Longtime Editor To Leave Forbes Post
abstract: James W Michaels, editor of Forbes magazine since 1961, will leave post on Jan 1, 1999, to become a vice president of Forbes Inc; he will be succeeded by managing editor William Baldwin (S)

headline: INPUT/OUTPUT TO BUY A LAITRAM EQUIPMENT SUBSIDIARY
abstract: Input/Output Inc agrees to buy Digicourse, subsidiary of Laitram Corp, for about $46 million in stock (S)

headline: Favorable Trials of 2 Drugs Push Centocor Shares Up 9%
abstract: Shares of Centocor Inc rise 9.26 percent after researchers at separate medical conferences report positive results from clinical trials of company's two major drugs, Remicade to treat rheumatoid arthritis and Reopro to reduce risk of death in patients whose coronary arteries are held open with metal coils called stents after being opened in angioplasty procedures (M)

headline: Chase Will Sell Title Insurance
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp forms new venture, Madison Park Title Agency LLC, to sell commercial title insurance; hopes to take advantage of its strong position in commercial real estate lending market; takes majority position in new venture but does not identify its partners or disclose amount of its investment (S)

headline: Microsoft and Barnes & Noble Join Forces
abstract: Amazon.com, Microsoft Corp and Barnes & Noble Inc agree to merge their online products and services; marketing arrangement makes Barnes & Noble exclusive bookseller on Microsoft's popular MSN network (M)

headline: 3 Balloonists Press Flight, Then China Lifts Its Ban
abstract: China belatedly grants balloonist Richard Branson, Steve Fossett and Per Lindstrand overflight permission, allowing them to continue round-the-world journey; permission comes after intense diplomatic efforts--including appeal by Prime Min Tony Blair; map (M)

headline: Legacy of the 90's Boom: More Jobs for Black Men
abstract: Economic View column says byproduct of current economic boom is that more young black men are working or going to school; question now is whether recentimprovement has chance of sticking through next recession; labor markets were tight in late 80's, and more young black men found work then, too--only to see their gains disappear in 1990's; there are some reasons for cautious optimism (M)

headline: Art Studio Offers Lots Of Layers
abstract: Dulcie Leimbach assesses Make a Masterpiece, children's art software from IBM and Crayola; drawing (M)

headline: Down and Out at the Hedge Fund? Maybe, but Don't Bet on It
abstract: John W Meriwether's career may be resurrected despite near-collapse of his Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund; consortium of 14 financial firms that pumped $3.6 billion into Long-Term Capital agreed to keep Meriwether, his partners and his management team intact as condition of the deal; he and his partners still control 3.3 percent of equity in the fund, valued at about $120 million (M)

headline: Joseph F. Unanue, 41, Executive Vice President at Goya Foods
abstract: Joseph F Unanue, senior executive in Goya food business, dies at 41 (M)

headline: Luck, Be a Microchip Tonight
abstract: Casino makers say computers have quietly revolutionized multibillion-dollar slot machine industry; behind brightly-colored cabinets with spinning reels and pictures of cherries, bars and bells is highly sophisticated computer technology; slot machines are built around chips and then networked, making hefty payoffs possible; woman recently won record $27 million in slot machine in Las Vegas; photos; diagrams (M)

headline: U.S. Weighs Extradition Of Pinochet
abstract: US Justice Dept officials discuss whether to seek extradition of Gen Augusto Pinochet, former dictator of Chile, in connection with four killings that took place under his regime more than 20 years ago; they say move could take place if Pinochet is set free by House of Lords in London, which is reviewing a request for his extradition on genocide charges filed by Spain; two of killings under discussion took place in Washington in 1976; they took lives of former Chilean Foreign Minister, Orlando Letelier, who had escaped Pinochet regime and worked at a liberal research institute, and his American colleague, Ronni Moffitt; two other killings, which took place in Chile, took lives of two Americans who disappeared in 1973 coup that swept Pinochet to power; they were Charles Horman and Frank Teruggi (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Whet prices jump 3.8 percent on speculation that US may donate food to Russia; commodities chart (S)

headline: Congress to Debate Greater Oversight of Hedge Funds
abstract: Congress will debate whether hedge funds that cater to very rich should be subject of greater scrutiny; House Banking Committee will take up issue at hearing where Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, New York Federal Reserve Bank president William McDonough, securities officials and top financial regulators will testify; graph; chart (M)

headline: MILOSEVIC ACCEPTS KOSOVO MONITORS, AVERTING ATTACK
abstract: The American special envoy Richard C. Holbrooke announced an agreement here today that averted the immediate threat of NATO air strikes against Serbia and could lead  to a form of autonomy in Kosovo Province.    The crux of the accord with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia calls for 2,000 international observers and NATO reconnaissance flights to monitor promised withdrawals of troops and police from Kosovo, where Serbian forces have mounted a crackdown against the mainly ethnic Albanian population.

headline: Coke Warns of Poor Foreign Results as It Tells of Global Deal
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says its fourth-quarter earnings will be 20 percent lower than previously estimated because of weakening market abroad; also announces agreement to purchase overseas rights to Cadbury Schweppes PLC soft drinks for $1.85 billion (M)

headline: U.N. Chief Says U.S. Goes Too Far in Calling for Iraqi's Ouster
abstract: Interview with UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan, who distances himself from Clinton Administration's policy on Iraq; says American calls for overthrow of Pres Saddam Hussein goes beyond Security Council resolution on what is demanded of Iraq and runs contrary to opinion of other UN members; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas futures prices fall on forecasts for mild winter weather; graphs; table of other commodity futures prices (S)

headline: Consumer Spending Rose Again in October
abstract: Commerce Department reports consumer spending rose half-percent in October, after having increased seven-tenths of 1 percent in September; says personal incomes rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October after climbing two-tenths of 1 percent in September; National Association of Realtors says home resales climbed 2.1 percent in October to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.79 million; savings rate in October was minus 0.2 percent compared with revised minus 0.1 percent in September; Labor Department reports number of first-time claims filed for state unemployment benefits fell by 39,000 last week, to seasonally adjusted 300,000; University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment rose to 102.7 in early November compared with 97.4 in October; graph on personal income (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.69   4.66   5.43        3-month T-bills   4.30   4.30   5.04        6-month T-bills   4.34   4.36   5.19        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.85   3.58        10-yr. T-note   4.56   4.59   5.87        30-yr. T-bond   4.98   4.99   6.07        Telephone bd.   6.76   6.76   7.31        Municipal bds.   5.10   5.11   5.32          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: South Africa Sharply Curbs Smoking and Tobacco Advertising
abstract: South African Pres Nelson Mandela is expected to sign bill that would ban smoking in public, outlaw all tobacco advertising and regulate nicotine levels in cigarettes (M)

headline: Relief Efforts Reaching Rural Areas In Nicaragua
abstract: Relief workers and international aid groups, with flood waters generated by Hurricane Mitch finally receding, step up their efforts to reach survivors in isolated rural areas across Central America and to rush food, medicine and other vital supplies to them; combined death toll from huge storm, which officials describe as worst natural disaster to strike subcontinent in this century, is estimated at more than 11,000, mostly in Honduras and Nicarauga; photo (M)

headline: William R. Johnson
abstract: Contents of briefcase of H J Heinz chief executive William R Johnson described; photos (M)

headline: 2 Ulster Peacemakers Win the Nobel Prize
abstract: 1998 Nobel Peace Prize is awarded to John Hume and David Trimble, leaders of largest Roman Catholic and Protestant political parties in Northern Ireland, for their efforts to bring peace to long-polarized British province; Hume, 61, Catholic head of Social Democratic and Labor Party, is cited by Nobel Committee in Oslo for having been 'the clearest and most consistent' of Northern Ireland's political leaders in his work for a peaceful solution; Trimble, 54, Protestand leader of Ulster Unionists, is honored for having demonstrated 'great political courage when, at a critical stage in the process, he advocated solutions which led to the peace agreement'; photos (L)

headline: REPUBLIC BANCSHARES CUTS 340 JOBS
abstract: Republic Bancshares Inc says that it dismissed 340 employees in its mortgage banking units, or 54 percent of its loan production staff (S)

headline: Headache, Thy Name Is 'Hedge Fund'
abstract: BankAmerica agrees to absorb $372 million of $1.3 billion unsecured loan to D E Shaw & Co, hedge-fund manager, and take over and liquidate its bond portfolio in effort to recoup rest (S)

headline: BankAmerica Hedge Fund Loss Expected
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest bank, is expected to announce a big hedge fund loss today in the latest example of the dangers posed to financial companies from the risky, sometimes high-flying investment pools.    Some analysts estimate that the loss may be about $100 million, but others say that BankAmerica's overall exposure to the hedge fund, D. E. Shaw & Company, could be as large as $1 billion, taking the form of either loans or credit lines. It is not clear whether BankAmerica owned an interest in Shaw, and the legality of commercial banks holding such stakes is murky.

headline: Local Elections in Israel: A Virtual Free-for-All
abstract: Local election campaigns have been particularly down and dastardly in Israel this season, with far more violence than in past; ethnicity, religious-secular divides, clan rivalries and municipal scandals inflame passions; dirty tricks are commonplace; map; photo (M)

headline: Loewen Group's Founder Sells His Stake
abstract: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce has acquired almost 14 percent of Loewen Group's common stock for about $91 million (US) from Raymond Loewen, founder of company; Loewen resigned as chief executive last month (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen gains in trading on currency markets on November 19, strengthened after governing party said it would consider deeper cuts in taxes to help stimulate economy; graph (S)

headline: Nippon Steel Posts Drop in Portfolio Value
abstract: Nippon Steel Corp expects to post loss of 50 billion yen ($365 million) in market value of its investment portfolio for half year ended Sept 30 (S)

headline: THOMAS H. LEE INVESTS $300 MILLION IN DIRECT MARKETER
abstract: Metris Companies says it received $300 million investment from the Thomas H Lee Co, private equity investment firm, Boston (S)

headline: BAGHDAD DISRUPTS ARMS INSPECTIONS
abstract: Iraq balks at handing over documents on chemical and biological weapons and missile systems, throwing up new roadblock to work of United Nations arms inspectors less than week after agreeing to cooperate; American and British officials warn that air strikes remain immediate option if Government of Pres Saddam Hussein does not honor its pledge to renew cooperation with inspectors; Iraq appears to believe it can balk on major issues pending comprehensive review of its relations with UN, but Security Council decided that review cannot take place until there is full cooperation with inspectors; confrontation has come sooner than expected; it raises questions about Hussein's understanding of seriousness of threat he faces and limited diplomatic help he can expect, if any, from former supporters like Russia, China and France (M)

headline: Patents; Combing the Web for data on consumers that will let companies aim aids most effectively.
abstract: Be Free Inc, small start-up in Marlborough, Mass, says it expects to be awarded patent for method of passively collecting behavioral profiles and psychographic data (information on attitudes and life styles) for individual computer users, storing this information in huge data base and then using it to decide what consumers should see which advertisers; David M Solak gets patent for smoke alarm disguised as Christmas tree ornament; Intellectual Property Owners, trade association, is accepting applications until Dec 18 from inventors who would like to exhibit at 1999 National Inventors Expo and Conference, Orlando, Fla (Patents column) (M)

headline: STATE OF MISERY: A special report.; Afghans Ruled by Taliban: Poor, Isolated, but Secure
abstract: Special report: State of Misery; focuses on Afghanistan's plight since withdrawal of international aid groups in dispute with ruling Taliban; it is hard to tell if Kabul is on edge of catastrophe or merely in throes of severe hardship; Taliban concentrates its resources on war, leaving no one to replace water, bread and medicines aid groups supplied city; map; photos (M)

headline: 2 U.S. Options For Iraq Strike: Swift or Larger
abstract: Pentagon drafts separate plans for sharp, swift strike against Iraq that could begin at any time and larger, more punishing assault that would require sending more forces to region; Pres Clinton meets with senior national security aides to discuss strategies for responding to Iraq's new defiance of United Nations weapons inspections; Administration officials say Clinton has not yet decided to use force in latest confrontation with Pres Saddam Hussein and that plans could change (M)

headline: Iraq Rebuffs France on Plan for Compromise on U.N. Weapons Inspections
abstract: Iraq rejects suggestions by France to change decision against allowing return of UN arms inspectors if composition or leadership of inspection teams are changed; Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz brushes aside proposal from Pres Jacques Chirac under which UN sanctions would be lifted while new team of inspectors monitors sites where Iraq is suspected of producing weapons of mass destruction; condemns proposal for concentrating on Iraq selectively (M)

headline: The TV Screen as Mirror
abstract: Jim Samuel letter responds to November 1 article on relationship between TV sitcom characters and US economy (S)

headline: SUNGLASS HUT SAYS IT HAS SHUT 149 UNPROFITABLE STORES
abstract: Sunglass Hut International, world's largest retailer of sunglasses, closes 149 stores and will close as many as 76 more by end of January 1999 (S)

headline: S.E.C. Chairman Is Cautious About Social Security Plans
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Arthur Levitt Jr says that plans to help shore up Social Security by seeking higher returns in financial markets risk leaving inexperienced investors vulnerable to fraud; stresses that he is not endorsing any of proposals for revising Social Security in advance of boomer generation's retirement; notes that nearly all of plans involve allowing individuals to invest part of their payroll taxes in stocks and bonds or permitting Federal Government itself more latitude to invest retirement system's trust funds, which are now held in special Treasury bonds (M)

headline: NATO Nears Final Order To Approve Kosovo Strike
abstract: Western officials say NATO is ready to approve 'activation order' on Oct 12, opening way for its military commanders to order air strikes against Serbian targets in Kosovo and perhaps in Serbian heartland (M)

headline: Surfing Around The House
abstract: Cyrix Corp demonstrates prototype product called Webpad at Comdex computer trade show in Las Vegas, Nev; Webpad is battery-powered, wireless computer about size of thick magazine; it uses radio waves to browse World Wide Web, send and receive E-mail and perform other Internet tasks, all channeled wirelessly through receiver attached to regular personal computer; it will be available sometime next summer; drawing (M)

headline: Cable and Wireless Names Chief in U.S.
abstract: Cable and Wireless PLC names Dennis D Matteucci chief executive of its American unit, replacing Rich Yalen, who resigned (S)9

headline: Nissan, Losing Money, Seeks Public Loan
abstract: Japanese Government is expected to come to the aid of Nissan Motor Co, nation's ailing No. 2 auto maker, by making loans from the Japan Development Bank available to it; Nissan says it is negotiating with Government-backed bank but that amount and timing have not yet been determined; auto maker has debt of 4.3 billion yen ($35 billion); car sales in Japan fell 14 percent last year and an additional 8 percent in first half of this year (M)

headline: Air of Crisis in Zimbabwe Grows After Threat to Seize 841 Farms
abstract: Threat by Zimbabwe's Government to seize 841 farms, owned mostly by whites, has thrown commercial farmers into confusion and added to country's sense of crisis; whites, fewer than 2 percent of population, own 70 percent of land, while millions of rural blacks are crowded onto 'communal areas' of stony depleted soil (M)

headline: Fuji Settles Orange County Suit
abstract: Orange County, California, says Fuji Securities has agreed to settle lawsuit for at least $7.9 million, in connection with county's 1994 bankruptcy (S)

headline: More Aviation News
abstract: Fuji Photo Film USA president George Tanaka takes trip aboard company blimp from Westchester Airport to his home in Elmsford, NY (S)

headline: Germany and U.S. Nurture Bond At a Mansion With a Few Ghosts
abstract: New American Academy opens in Berlin mansion that was once wartime home of Hitler's chief economic adviser, Walther Funk; much of founding grant for academy was provided by descendants of Hans Arnhold, Jewish banker who fled mansion; former Sec of State Henry A Kissinger attends opening (M)

headline: GPU TO BUY ARGENTINE COMPANY FOR $435 MILLION
abstract: Morristown, NJ-based GPU Inc acquires Emdersa, Argentine electricity distribution holding company, for $435 million (S)

headline: S.E.C. and Firm Settle Municipal Bond Case
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission announces settlement in civil case against O'Brien Partners Inc, which it accused of breaching its fiduciary duty to four municipal bond clients by not informing them of commissions it received from brokers who invested revenues from municipal issues; O'Brien, without admitting or denying findings, agrees to cease and desist order and will pay $250,000 civil penalty (S)

headline: Irish Leader Urges Restarting Ulster Peace Drive
abstract: Prime Min Bertie Ahern of Irish Republic confers with Catholic and Protestant leaders of new Northern Ireland Assembly in an attempt to restart stalled Ulster peace effort, two days after killing of Brian Service, Roman Catholic man, in Belfast; is seeking to allay fears that murder, apparently by Protestant splinter guerrilla group, will lead to renewed violence (M)

headline: Mixed Reviews, With Doctors Giving Thumbs Down
abstract: Doctors and other health care providers are concerned about Aetna Inc's decision to acquire Prudential Health Care from Prudential Insurance Co of America; Aetna is largely viewed as one of most stringent managed-care companies, pushing hard for cost cuts, disputing claims, questioning out-of-network services and insisting on mountains of documentation; Aetna says doctors and patients have little to fear (M)

headline: Pauline Julien, 70, Chanteuse Who Inspired the Quebecois
abstract: Pauline Julien, singer who was strongly identified with songs she sang in cause of separate and independent Quebec, dies at age 70; photo (M)

headline: Attention Internet Shoppers: No New Taxes
abstract: Senate votes, 96 to 2, to make cyberspace a tax-free zone for most transactions for next three years, following House in trying to help incubate a new engine of commerce (M)

headline: Ski Association Picks Leagas Delaney
abstract: National Ski Areas Association names Leagas Delaney as first advertising agency to handle campaign to increase participation in skiing and snowboarding; billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: Two in Ireland Share Nobel Prize for Peace
abstract: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to John Hume and David Trimble, leaders of the largest Catholic and Protestant political parties in Northern Ireland, for their efforts to bring peace to the British province.    The Nobel Committee in Oslo cited Mr. Hume, 61, the Catholic head of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, for having been ''the clearest and most consistent of Northern Ireland's political leaders in his work for a peaceful solution.''

headline: Data Offer No Hint Yet Of a Slowing Economy
abstract: American gross domestic product posts 3.9 percent gain in third quarter, confounding warnings that Asian and Russian economic crises would slow US economy (S)

headline: A Blizzard in Florida
abstract: Employees can come up with the darnedest excuses for returning to work a day or two late from vacations and long weekends: A car breakdown. An ill great-aunt. Believable? Maybe. But what about that mysterious allergy to the pineapple at Waikiki? What particularly imaginative tales have you heard -- or told? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Greeting Cards At Your Fingertips
abstract: Felicia Lindau runs what she says is the world's largest greeting card store, an on-line business with a selection of 5,000 cards from hundreds of publishers; photo (M)

headline: Columbia/HCA Profits Are Flat
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp says profits from continuing operations in third quarter rose to $131 million from $129 million a year earlier; revenue fell to $4.58 billion from $4.61 billion a year earlier (S)

headline: Stocks Mixed On Uncertainty About the Fed
abstract: Stock market turns mixed as investors await meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers to see if there will be another cut in short-term interest rates; Dow Jones industrial average gains 89.85, to 8,919.59; S&P climbs 8.03, to 1,125.72 while Nasdaq declines 3.07, to 1,847.99; Russell 2000 declines 2.84, to 389.36; in the bond market, 30-year Treasury gains 2/32, to 100 4/32, with yield falling to 5.24 percent, from 5.25 percent on Thursday; chart on Dow Jones average; list of some stocks showing significant gains and losses (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.69   4.80   5.46        3-month T-bills   4.37   4.34   5.21        6-month T-bills   4.37   4.35   5.23        10-yr. T-infl.   3.78   3.78   3.64        10-yr. T-note   4.56   4.57   5.72        30-yr. T-bond   5.00   5.01   5.92        Telephone bd.   6.70   6.70   7.18        Municipal bds.   5.13   5.13   5.23          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: The Making Of an 'It' Girl; WB Network Hyped 'Felicity' But Still Seeks the Right Viewers
abstract: Felicity, new television show which attracted most attention this season, has apparently not built on pre-premiere excitement; ratings have fallen in second week and show trails other new series appealing to teen-agers; WB Network's skillful effort to promote show and star Keri Russell discussed; photos (M)

headline: Economic Scene; The timid Japanese banking bailout just might do the job.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Japan's new banking law says that despite its flaws, measure might pry open clogged credit lines and channel money to companies in need of fresh start; Adam Posen of Institute for International Economics and Daniel K Tarullo, formerly Pres Clinton's top adviser on international economic policy, comment; drawing (M)

headline: Again, The Glass Looks Half-Empty
abstract: Market Watch column notes that since October, investors have been buying stocks, regardless of earnings outlook; they focus instead on positive effects of three interest rate cuts; now, with no rate cuts in sight, investors are resuming their interest in earnings; fears about lower corporate profits knocked down shares of some blue-chip stocks last week, causing Dow Jones industrial average to fall 2.1 percent on week; graph (M)

headline: Finding Jobs at Ski Resorts
abstract: Letter from John Andrew says there are Web sites that bring together job seekers and employers in snow-sports industry (S)

headline: IRVINE APARTMENT RETAINS ADVISER TO EVALUATE OFFER
abstract: Irvine Apartment Communities Inc hires Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co to evaluate $540 million offer from chairman Donald L Bren to take company private through his Irvine Co (S)

headline: U.S. Welcomes Arab Statement on Iraq
abstract: Clinton Administration welcomed statement today from eight Arab nations saying Iraq bears responsibility for consequences of confrontation with UN arms inspectors (S)

headline: F.C.C. Approves Hearst TV Deal
abstract: Hearst-Argyle Television Inc wins Federal Communications Commission clearance to buy Pulitzer Publishing Co's broadcast group for $1.85 billion in stock and debt (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: KEYSPAN ENERGY CO.,  Brooklyn, a natural gas and electric company, said it planned to repurchase as much as 10 percent, or about $500 million, of its shares.    WESTERN GAS RESOURCES INC.,  Denver, said it sold natural gas fields in three East Texas counties to Vintage Petroleum Inc. for $49.7 million and a gas gathering operation to Dynegy Inc. for $6.1 million.

headline: Seeing Opportunity As Others Are Fleeing
abstract: Question-and-Answer column with J Mark Mobius, manager of eight Franklin/Templeton emerging-markets funds, who sees investment opportunity in declining emerging markets funds; photo (M)

headline: Kroger to Buy Fred Meyer, Creating Country's Biggest Grocer
abstract: Kroger Co will acquire Fred Meyer Inc in deal that will create supermarket giant with $43 billion in annual revenue and 2,200 stores in 31 states; Kroger will pay about $8 billion in stock and assume $4.8 billion of company's debt; acquisition gives Kroger status of the leading chain; map; chart (M)

headline: Silver Cups Don't Run Over
abstract: Victor Niederhoffer, money manager who lost his savings last year, says he is surprised that his silver trophy collection raised only $2.6 million at Sotheby's auction; needs money to pay debts and for his children's college tuition; some of his silver collection described (S)

headline: Entergy Is Selling Australian Unit
abstract: American Electric Power Co to buy Entergy Corp's electric distribution unit in Australia for $1.1 billion (S)

headline: After All the Talk, a Hesitant Peace
abstract: News analysis of Wye Memorandum, new peace agreement reached between Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and Israel's Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu; both leaders may have crossed painful and fateful political threshold, despite technical and tentative nature of actual arrangements and despite certainty that they will be violated (M)

headline: Three Proposed Telecommunications Mergers Draw Challenges at an F.C.C. Hearing
abstract: Three of largest proposed telecommunications mergers in history are challenged by consumer groups and rival companies at hearing held by Federal Communications Commission that raises fundamental questions about whether broad deregulation in industry, intending to promote competition, is starting to have opposite effect; agency is reviewing whether to approve, block or impose conditions on proposed $56 billion acquisition of Ameritech by SBC Communications; Bell Atlantic's $52 billion purchase of GTE, and AT&T Corp's $32 billion deal to buy Tele-Communications Inc (M)

headline: PRI Reverses Fortunes and Wins Crucial Mexican Governorships
abstract: Mexican Pres Ernesto Zedillo's governing party wins gubernatorial races in Sinaloa and Puebla and may have regained municipal control over three state capitals that had fallen to opposition, closing out election year in which it has repeatedly humbled bickering opposition rivals; results fuel party's hopes of extending its 70-year domination of Mexican politics; leftist coalition wins governorship of Tlaxcala (M)

headline: Fed Opens the Door For Buying Opportunities
abstract: Standard & Poor's latest newsletter, comparing six comparable third-quarters with greatest 500-index declines, notes five of them were followed by fourth-quarter gains; sees hope for 1998 fourth quarter as Federal Reserve shaves interest rates; graph (S)

headline: ABN Amro Completes Deal for Asia Unit
abstract: ABN Amro Holding NV acquires remaining 30 percent of Hong Kong-based ABN Amro Asia (Holdings) Ltd it did not already own for about $220 million from Guoco Group Ltd (S)

headline: HALLIBURTON TAKES ACTION TO SAVE ABOUT $250 MILLION
abstract: Halliburton Co will eliminate about 5,250 jobs and close about 400 offices worldiwde as part of its plan to save about $250 million a year (S)

headline: Spanish Judge Is Hoping To See Secret Files in U.S.
abstract: Spanish judge who wants former Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet, to stand trial, plans to go to Washington to try to see secret Government files; Judge Baltasar Garzon is particularly interested in United States Government files about events of 1970's, when Central Intelligence Agency and other American Embassy personnel were close to Pinochet Government and knew of activities of its powerful secret police; that police force is widely considered responsible for worst excesses of Pinochet Government, including kidnapping, torture and secret execution of leftist opponents (M)

headline: FOUNDER AND HIS FAMILY OFFER TO BUY OUT ST. JOHN KNITS
abstract: St John Knits Inc says its founder and chairman Bob Gray and his family have offered to buy company for about $490 million (S)

headline: Led by I.B.M., the Market Chalks Up Gains
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.55 percent las week, extending its advance to six consecutive days, as portfolio managers engaged in what people on Wall Street call window dressing - adjusting holdings to make their year-end reports look good.

headline: Is the Box Half-Full or Half-Empty?; Top Cereal Maker Fights To Retain Eroding Share
abstract: Kellogg Co's breakfast business is in trouble, the result of time-constrained consumers who once started the day with cereal now moving to other choices, such as the breakfast bar; in addition, prices for brand-name cereals have risen so high that consumers are trading down to generic brands or avoiding the cereal shopping lane altogether; slowdown in growth has led to speculation of management shake-up at Kellogg, with Carlos M Gutierrez, thought to be likely successor to chief executive Arnold G Langbo, perhaps taking over sooner than expected; Kellogg is also expected to try to meet consumer preferences by selling more non-cereal foods and promoting its cereal as nutritional part of a healthy diet; graphs on share of domestic cereal market and Kellogg's operating revenue; photo (M)

headline: Kosovo's Rival Forces Are Moving Closer to a New War
abstract: Yugoslav forces and ethnic Albanian rebels are goading each other into new round of fighting, with people of Kosovo province and Western countries unable to do little more than watch; military and police units have been on move in last few days, and rebels who have moved into many areas vacated by Serbs in October are stepping up recruitment and training of fighters and are reportedly obtaining large amounts of military gear; map (M)

headline: Clinton Presses Yugoslavs As NATO's Role Is Hailed
abstract: In an effort to keep up pressure on President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, President Clinton today demanded he make serious progress in complying with an agreement to end the crackdown in Kosovo.    Senior American officials insisted that they had used NATO successfully to avert a human disaster and to  do justice to the Kosovar Albanians.

headline: Controlling Stake Is Sold In Top Noodle Maker
abstract: Indonesia's Salim Group agrees to sell control of world's biggest noodle maker, PT Indofood Sukses Makmur, for $570 million in cash and stock; First Pacific Co, Salim's Hong Kong affiliate, will set up equal joint venture with Nissin Food Products Ltd of Japan, to buy 60 percent stake in company; graph (S)

headline: Most Chileans React Moderately to Arrest
abstract: Most Chileans react with moderation to arrest of former strongman Gen Augusto Pinochet by Scotland Yard, in response to warrant by Spanish magistrate investigating human rights violations during era of military rule in 1960's and 1970; photo (M)

headline: A Search For Identity At Impasse In Canada
abstract: Police in Canada and US are unable to identify a young found naked and dazed in Montreal parking lot on Oct 12; he has no idea who he is or how he got there; is given hypnosis and injection of 'truth serum,' after which he says he might be James Edward Brighton from Morristown, NJ; photo (M)

headline: A Gentle Hero Dies, and Mongolia's Innocence, Too
abstract: Mongolians see political motives in stabbing murder of Sanjaasuren Zorig, man known as father of their democracy; Zorig, who served as Minister of Infrastructure, was due to be nominated for Prime Minister by his party; Zorig was one of 13 men who began agitating for Mongolia's freedom in 1989, and he emerged as most articulate and respected leader; photo; map (M)

headline: Depth of Rift Over Software Is Disclosed
abstract: Antitrust suit against Microsoft Corp has opened window into extraordinary rift between Microsoft and Intel Corp, partners in most lucrative business relationship in modern capitalism, and how it was patched up; few in computer industry were aware of depth of split over multimedia software developed by Intel, its significance or personal animosities involved; partnership was repaired personally by chief excutives William H Gates of Microsoft and Andrew S Grove of Intel over lengthy dinners and frequent E-mail dialogues, with Intel backing down from technology initiative (M)

headline: Office-Block Brussels / Bureaucracy Is Their Business : Eurocapital in Search of a Human Dimension
abstract: BRUSSELS—  The European Union and other international organizations have brought wealth but not much style to the capital of Europe. The EU institutions, which occupy about 13 percent of the office space in Brussels, have grown haphazardly in response to the changing nature and the successive enlargements of the 15-nation community. It was only in 1992 that heads of government decided once and for all that Brussels would be the EU's permanent home and it is only since comparatively recently that serious thought has been given to the impact this decision will have on the city, at least from an architectural point of view.

headline: Washington and Baghdad Agree on One Point: Sanctions Hurt
abstract: Pres Clinton and Pres Saddam Hussein agree on one point: economic sanctions imposed on Iraq over eight years ago, which Baghdad has cited as cause of latest crisis, have devastated its economy and its people; sanctions are among toughest imposed in modern age and are estimated to have cost Iraq over $120 billion in oil revenues (M)

headline: Makers of Surgical Devices in Stock Deal Valued at $3.6 Billion
abstract: Medtronic Inc, biggest maker of heartbeat regulators, agrees to buy Sofamore Danek Group for $3.6 billion in Medtronic stock (M)

headline: Leftist Leader to Try to Assemble a New Government in Italy
abstract: Massimo D'Alema, former Communist and leader of largest leftist party in Italy, is selected to try to form a new Govt; D'Alema, is chosen after Acting Prime Min Romano Prodi, who resigned after losing confidence vote last week, failed to gather enough support in Parliament to form a new Govt (M)

headline: On Its Own Turf, It's Microsoft, Right or Wrong
abstract: Microsoft Corp and its chairman Bill Gates receive staunch support from vendors attending Comdex computer trade show, Las Vegas; most of 252 companies represented at show see themselves as living proof that Windows business model is making money for more than just Microsoft; photo of Comdex show (M)

headline: An Upstart Talent Agency Blossoms Quickly
abstract: Profile of Endeavor Agency, three-year-old Beverly Hills talent agency that has emerged as significant player in cutthroat and potentially vastly lucrative world of talent agencies; says Endeavor, whose success lies heavily on its clients in television, has endured some setbacks and is still struggling to forge significant movie division, but agency has, in relatively short time, turned into formidable and high-profile one; photo (M)

headline: The Trials of Tech Support
abstract: Jo-Ann Christian letter, commenting on Nov 12 article, says most of her telephone calls to computer company's tech support staff have been nightmares

headline: Seeking Mature Judgment, U.N. Sets Minimum Age for Its Troops
abstract: UN, seeking greater maturity and experience among peacekeepers, says countries contributing to its forces should not send any civilian police officers or military observers under age 25; says soldiers should preferably be over 21, but never younger than 18(S)

headline: Patents; The Commissioner quits, after focusing attention on intellectual property and making enemies.
abstract: Profile of Bruce A Lehman, who has announced that he will step down as Commissioner of US Patent and Trademark Office; photo (M)

headline: Save Social Security? From What?
abstract: Fred Brock column offers reasons to oppose proposed Social Security system reforms soon to be considered by Congress; drawing (M)

headline: WITH DEMAND FOR TRACTORS DOWN, DEERE PLANS LAYOFFS
abstract: Deere & Company, world's largest farm-equipment maker, will lay off about 2,400 workers for several weeks because of weakening demand in North America (S)

headline: Corporate Delete Keys Busy As E-Mail Turns Up in Court
abstract: Growing number of companies are imposing curbs on E-mail use, learning from antitrust case against Microsoft Corp that E-mail can be mine field of legal liability and source of public embarrassment; privacy of workplace correspondence and accountability for what is written are growing concerns for many employers (M)

headline: Rancorous Asia Pacific Talks End With a Pledge and a Sigh
abstract: Leaders of 21 Pacific Rim countries wrap up contentious summit meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, by pledging to revive region that has been set back decades by Asian economic crisis; US and Malaysia engaged in war of words during forum over speech by Vice Pres Al Gore; he accused Malaysia of suppressing freedom and threw his support behind protesters who are demanding ouster of Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad (M)

headline: In Inaugural Speech, Schroder Stresses Jobs and Environment
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder makes inaugural speech to Parliament, laying out program of sweeping ambitions but scant detail; stresses environment and job creation; seems to stand on both sides of debate over welfare state, attacking high cost but reversing very limited cutbacks begun under Chancellor Helmut Kohl (M)

headline: No Compromise on Glacier
abstract: India and Pakistan fail to make progress toward peace in place where their armies are now killing each other: a wretched, freezing, thin-aired border spot 24,000 feet above sea level known as Siachen Glacier; for 15 years, India and Pakistan, both claiming this 48-mile-long ice floe, have been heaving artillery and mortar fire at each other through piercing winds (S)

headline: Circling the (Station) Wagons
abstract: Several Web sites are devoted to the classic, wood-paneled American stationwagon, and at least one to Volkswagen Bus; photo (M)

headline: Pope Beatifies Croat Prelate, Fanning Ire Among Serbs
abstract: Pope John Paul II, visiting Croatia, beatifies Alojzije Stepinac, World War II archbishop of Zagreb, as martyr to Communist atrocities; cardinal was imprisoned by Tito regime as Nazi collaborator, and is national hero to Catholic Croatians and Franjo Tudjman; Orthodox Serbs view Stepinac as sympathizer with regime that killed many thousands of Serbs, Jews and Gypsies; Vatican and many historians credit Stepinac with saving many Jews and Serbs, but critics say by not speaking out he lent support to Ustashe regime; Croatian Jewish leader says record is 'mixed' (M)

headline: Earthweb Share Price Triples On the First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of Earthweb Inc, an on-line provider of technical information for World Wide Web site designers, more than triple on their first day of trading. Earthweb rises $34.6875, to $48.6875, on trading of 11.5 million shares (M)

headline: Media Talk; Michael Eisner Waits For the Right Price
abstract: Walt Disney Co chairman Michael D Eisner is expected to do everything he can to lift price of company's stock because Eisner is sitting on eight million options that he cannot start to exercise before September 2003; so-called stock price of options--price he will pay for shares when he is able to claim them--is $21.18 a share; but discounted price looked lot sweeter on May 4, when Disney stock hit 52-week high of $42.79, than on Oct 23, when shares closed at $27.75; Disney ex-president Michael Ovitz received stock options that, since 3-for-1 split, are equal to nine million shares with strike price of $19 each--exercisable at any time; photo of Ovitz (S)

headline: War Crimes Panel Seeks a Way For Massacre Survivor to Testify
abstract: Investigators are trying to get lone survivor of mass shooting in Kosovo out of Serbia to testify about killings at war crimes tribunal; Western diplomats say unidentified witness was among 14 ethnic Albanians who were systematically shot by Serbs; two investigators from International War Crimes Tribunal are in Kosovo to look into matter, one of two executions of ethnic Albanians that witnesses say Serbian forces carried out in central Kosovo on Sept 26; 13 men were killed in village of Golubovac, while 18 members of extended family were killed near Gornji Obrinje; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia Parliament Meets, and Demonstrators Protest
abstract: Indonesian Parliament meets for first time since Pres Suharto's ouster to chart course toward more democratic government in special session called by Pres B J Habibie; opposing groups of demonstrators stone each other; leading opposition figures meet and demand quick elections and phasing out of military role in Government; student demonstrators call for Habibie's immediate resignation; photo (M)

headline: He's on His Way Up; No, He Resigned; Uh-Oh
abstract: Carol J Loomis, reporter and member of board of editors of Time Warner's Fortune magazine wrote article as magazine's deadline approached that James E Dimon, president of Citigroup, would ascend to position of director of Citigroup's Global Capital division; Dimon, however, resigned next day, Monday; Wall Street Journal also published an article on Monday that Dimon was being groomed for post of chairman; Loomis comments; Dimon photo (M)

headline: Monsanto Gains Support of F.D.A. Panel
abstract: Food and Drug Administration advisory panel recommends approval of Monsanto Co's pain-relieving drug Celebex for patients suffering from osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis; drug is first of new class of painkillers, called Cox-2 inhibitors (S)

headline: Rival Warns That Microsoft Could Control Web Trade
abstract: William Harris, pres of Intuit Inc, states that Microsoft Corp could use its market power to gain control over 'major areas' of Internet commerce and asks courts to give Microsoft's rivals equal access to its Windows operating system and desktop screen; 47-page written testimony by Harris brings two new issues into Microsoft antitrust trial--Microsoft's potential impact on fast-growing field of Internet commerce and possible steps to curb Microsoft's power (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Fall 5 Percent on Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers says open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market fell 5 percent in month ended Oct 15; uncovered short positions totaled 2.05 billion shares, compared with 2.16 billion shares in previous month; chart (M)

headline: Shares Bounce Back, With Nasdaq Advancing 54 points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 16.99 points, to 9,133.54; Nasdaq composite index rises 54.21 points, to 2,003.75; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 11.65 points, to 1,175.28; graph; tables (M)

headline: Response to Baghdad: Military Muscle May Not Suffice
abstract: Tim Weiner analysis contends that as Pres Clinton ponders military strategy against Iraq, and Pentagon once more picks its targets and programs its cruise missiles for attack, debate at White House is whether to simply punish Pres Saddam Hussein or try to change his political course by force; maintains that nothing short of sustained assault involving perhaps thousands of bombs and missiles can break Iraqi leader's will and stop Baghdad's defiance of United Nations and rebuilding of its arsenals (M)

headline: U.N. Gives Rights Awards to People Working at the Grass Roots
abstract: United Nations gives its highest award for human rights work to grass-roots workers who struggle for rights of ordinary people; Sec Gen Kofi Annan presents awards in ceremonies at UN on 50th anniversary of Universal Declaration of Human Rights (M)

headline: Can't Program That VCR? Just Click for Help
abstract: IDT Corp is marketing new service called Click 2 Talk that uses the Web to dial into various companies' telephone banks for technical support or customer service on variety of subjects; to place a call, the user merely clicks on a Click 2 Talk icon; thus far 70 companies have signed up with service (S)

headline: SWISHER'S PLAN TO GO PRIVATE SENDS ITS SHARES SOARING
abstract: Shares of Swisher International Group jump 30 percent, after company says it will buy back all of its shares for $9.50 each and go private (S)

headline: He's Seen The Enemy. It Looks Like Him.
abstract: Interview with George Soros, currency speculator, philanthropist and author of new book on global economic woes who seeks to advise world leaders on cures for variety of economic ills; he discusses efforts to straddle many fences in worlds of finance, economic and politics, which have raised questions about possible conflicts of interest; chronology of his involvement in Russian economic crisis; photos (L)

headline: Purges Hint at Beginning of the End for Milosevic
abstract: Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, in what may be sign of weakness, has purged his innermost circle, dismissing heads of army, air force and intelligence service and trusted political commissar; purge culminated with dismissal of Army Staff Chief Gen Momcilo Perisic; Milosevic is seen by former associates as increasingly insecure, even paranoid, as Kosovo drifts from his control, economy weakens and he bows to demands of his politically powerful wife, Mirjana Markovic, replacing his apparatchiks with hers; photo (M)

headline: Gore Rejected C.I.A. Evidence of Russian Corruption
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore reportedly rejected conclusive report by Central Intelligence Agency in 1995 about personal corruption by Prime Min Viktor Chernomyrdin of Russia; incident fostered perception in agency's ranks that Clinton Administration is dismissive of 'inconvenient' intelligence about corruption among Russian leaders with whom White House and State Department officials have developed close personal relationship; Gore, who held regular talks with Chernomyrdin that became important channel for relations with Russia, declines comment (M)

headline: DEATH BY ARSENIC: A special report.; New Bangladesh Disaster: Wells That Pump Poison
abstract: Tens of thousands of Bangladeshi villagers are slowly dying from biggest mass poisoning ever, victims of naturally occuring arsenic in ground water; crisis is unintended result of 25-year-old safe-water program, in which Unicef and other aid groups weaned villagers from disease-carrying pond water and helped them build vast system of tube wells; map; photos (M)

headline: Finishing Unfinished Business
abstract: Congress finishes work on a number of measures affecting information technology industry; table (S)

headline: A Day for Mergers, With $40 Billion in Play
abstract: Mergers-and-acquisitions wave that crashed in August has returned in full force, with nine combinations worth $40.4 billion either announced or under negotiations; deals are crossing many industry lines--departure from combinations earlier this year; executives are more eager than ever to find partners abroad; graph (M)

headline: Supersizing the Supermarkets in a Shift of Power; Discounters and Mergers Alter Balance of Power
abstract: Traditional supermarket chains are consolidating to compete with upstarts such as large warehouse stores and discounters that offer food under same roof as general merchandise; manufacturers, wholesalers, distributors and independent grocers risk being trampled if they cannot learn new rules and adjust to new order quickly enough; major change in industry has big retailers calling shots instead of food suppliers; graph; photo (M)

headline: C.I.A.'s Role in Mideast Peace Prompts Outcry and a Call for Senate Hearings
abstract: Sen Richard C Shelby plans to have his Select Committee on Intelligence hold hearings on Central Intelligence Agency's role in new Israeli-Palestinian peace accord; expresses concern about CIA's open new role in verifying accord as departure from traditional role of intelligence gathering; State Sec Madeleine K Albright says CIA is already engaged in similar work, especially in Middle East; says CIA Dir George J Tenet will explain issues to Congress (M)
